HEADLINE: Shaky Asia, New Shivers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
For nearly a quarter-century, Washington has usually assumed that its main allies in Asia, who are also some of America's leading economic rivals, would grow ever stronger.
That supposition has influenced scores of policy debates, from contingency planning for a collapse of North Korea to assessing counterweights to China's growing might, to measuring when to threaten sanctions in trade disputes. 
 Now the economic crisis that has swept through the region -- first in Southeast Asia, now in South Korea, where a team from the International Monetary Fund arrived today to make arrangements for a painful economic bailout -- raises the question of whether America's Asian partners may be weakened for several years.
As President Clinton begins a series of meetings in Vancouver with leaders from Asia and North and South America, his aides acknowledge that there is a risk that the economic turmoil could translate into political fragility.
There is talk for the first time of a new "domino theory" in Asia -- not one in which country after country falls to Communism, but one in which a cycle of currency devaluations, bankruptcies and austerity measures saps political strength.
"This is a region where the political power has grown directly out of economic success," one of Mr. Clinton's senior foreign policy advisers said as the President left for Vancouver to attend the annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. "If Korea is going to be under the strictures of the I.M.F. for the next few years and Japan is consumed with cleaning up its own act, we have a lot of thinking to do."
One longtime veteran of the older dominoes, Donald Gregg, put it differently this weekend. Mr. Gregg, a former Ambassador to South Korea and for years one of the top Central Intelligence Agency operatives in Asia, said in an interview: "The equation has definitely been changed. Clearly it's time for President Clinton to readjust. But it is very hard to say right now how long this will last, how far it will resonate around the world or which way it could go."
Today President Clinton described Asia's problems as "a few little glitches in the road" rather than a full-blown crisis, apparently heeding the counsel of his economic aides that any deeper public ruminations about bailouts and bankruptcies could further unnerve investors around the world.
Even in private, the President's advisers are determined to sound upbeat, talking about the opportunities the economic reckoning creates for the United States to help itself by helping its major trading partners.
"There's an understanding that economic growth is not a static process," Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said today after meeting with Asian trade and foreign ministers. "The fundamentals are there to return to very high levels of growth."
Of course, economic fortunes and political influence rarely rise and fall in neatly synchronized patterns. Japan's emergence as an economic superpower in the 1980's, when it was buying Hollywood studios, the Seattle Mariners and New York skyscrapers, prompted endless debate of its impending political dominance.
But Japan never made the leap from building car plants around the world to exercising diplomatic clout. Conversely, Britain and France retain a political heft in world affairs these days that far outweighs their economic impact in the world.
But over time, economic strength counts. And the Korean Peninsula may be the first test of how money and political influence intersect.
For most of this decade, Pentagon and State Department planners drawing up scenarios for responding to a potential collapse of North Korea assumed that South Korea and Japan would be standing by with billions of dollars to invest in the North, much as West Germany invested in the East.
Without question, North Korea will need roads and manufacturing equipment, billions of dollars in new ports, a telephone system that works and a safety net for a population that periodically veers toward starvation. Whenever the North Koreans cracked open the door to foreign visits, South Korean and Japanese business executives would board the country's 1930's-era trains and, after bouncing over a bone-jarring track bed, take copious notes about where they could put their first investments.
But it is increasingly clear that far less cash will be available if the collapse happens while South Korea and Japan are working through extraordinary economic strains.
And the North has clearly sensed that, for once, South Korea is hardly in a position to use its economic power as a weapon. That may explain why the North agreed last week to head into long-delayed talks about negotiating a peace treaty that would formally end the Korean War.
"The effects are subtle, but what is happening to the South Korean economy definitely hurts," said Han Sung Joo, who was South Korea's Foreign Minister during the 1994 nuclear inspection standoff with North Korea, when the United States and South Korea came perilously close to renewed military confrontation with North Korea.
"Any linkage of their concessions to our willingness to provide economic assistance will clearly ring hollow to the North Koreans," he added.
But Mr. Han insists that any weakness on South Korea's part will be temporary.
"This was a preventable crisis, one that arose from a real absence of leadership," he said. "There are a lot of people, though, who are secretly hopeful that having an outside force begin to regulate things will result in reforms happening a lot faster than they would have."
Korea will not be the only test case of how economic and political power converge.
As the Southeast Asian countries have grown richer in recent years, they have also begun a significant military buildup -- politely called a "modernization," so as not to cause alarm among neighbors -- that was clearly aimed at dissuading China from extending its influence.
"We are going to see a significant slowdown in arms procurement, and that will almost certainly lead to a rise in fears about China," Masashi Nishihara, one of Japan's leading defense experts, said in a telephone interview.
In Japan, Professor Nishihara said, pressure will grow to pare back the billions of dollars that the Japanese Government spends each year to maintain America's huge military presence in Okinawa and the Japanese mainland.
"You can see the disagreements with the United States starting on this," he said. "And the political pressure to cut back in Japan could easily intersect with a lot of frustration in Washington as the trade deficit grows."
Just today, Japanese officials said, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley once again warned his Japanese counterparts against exporting their way out of their economic troubles.
That course, always a tempting one for Japanese companies encountering a stagnant economy at home, would cause cause Washington's politically sensitive trade deficit with Japan to surge, ending what has been two years of relative trade peace.
Should Japan's economic troubles worsen before they get better -- and most economists believe that they will, with more huge financial failures like the closing today of Yamaichi Securities, the country's oldest brokerage -- the effects may be seen around the world.
Japan emerged in the 1980's as the world's largest supplier of foreign aid. That budget has been slashed once in the last year, and it seems certain to be slashed again.
Of course, all of this creates opportunities for the United States as well. For years American companies have complained that it is too expensive to invest in Japan; now they can pick up companies on the cheap. By the same token, American companies that have long complained that Japan is cornering key growth markets, like Vietnam, now have a chance to move while the Japanese are distracted.
American officials say that it is still too early to assess which way the economic ripples will radiate.
"You can see a little piece here and a little piece there," Ms. Barshefsky said today, "and clearly in all the Asian countries, the immediate resources will be reduced.
"But you have to remember that all the attributes that made these countries the engines of Asia are still there, and they'll be back."

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
State Losing People To Land of Blue Skies

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC CITY

 BODY:
New Jersey is losing population and millions of tax dollars -- to states with more attractive weather and financial climates, Federal figures show.
About 144,000 more taxpaying families moved out of the state than moved in from 1992 to 1995, for a net earnings loss of $4.4 billion, according to Internal Revenue Service data. 
 Why the loss? Figures show that the states where most of the New Jerseyans have gone have warmer weather, lower taxes, cheaper housing and less congestion, The Press of Atlantic City reported yesterday.
Some experts say the state needs to pay careful attention to the effect of the loss on state finances. Donald Linky, of the Public Affairs Research Institute of New Jersey, said the loss was "a negative sign about confidence in New Jersey's future."
Others, however, say it is of little significance to the state's economy. James Hughes, an economist at Rutgers University, and the State Commerce Commissioner, Gil Medina, said the loss was less than 1 percent of New Jersey's $2.9 trillion income base.
The decline indicated in the most recent figures is no cause for alarm, Mr. Hughes said. Except for a period in the 1950's and 60's when the population shifted rapidly to the suburbs, in recent decades New Jersey has more typically lost population rather than gained, regardless of the state economy or taxes, he said.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said she had done just about all she could to make the state an attractive place to live, including cutting income taxes and creating jobs.
Still, she said, "The Northeast is very expensive. There's no two ways about it."

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Victorian Skinflint Who's Liberal at Heart

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
In some parts of this county and abroad, Ebenezer Scrooge, as played by Roddy McDowall in this year's version of "A Christmas Carol" at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, could get himself elected to high office.
After all, the man is firmly opposed to the welfare state handouts that are troubling so many economies. He favors prisons and workhouses over crime and begging. He believes in hard work and thrift. He worries about uncontained population growth and therefore looks upon death (when it comes to others, of course) as a blessing. 
 Sure, he's a bit blunt in expressing his ideas, but that flaw is nothing that a good spinmeister couldn't fix in a jiffy.
So it's something of a tribute to Mr. McDowall, who is alternating with Hal Linden in the role of Scrooge this year, that he makes such a forceful case for the old skinflint before an assault by apparitions turns him into a sentimental old liberal for the grand finale.
Mr. McDowall's performance restores some much-needed balance to a show that all but subsumes Charles Dickens's classic Christmas tale beneath soulless spectacle. And that is welcome news for those who make their way into a theater whose antechambers intersect Victoriana of the 1880's with the bottom line of the 1990's. Buskers, bobbies and carolers line the passageways where peddlers are hawking everything from costumed teddy bears to that least Victorian of refreshments, the egg cream.
Scrooge of Scrooge & Marley would be amused.
Anyway, Mr. McDowall may not be a Pavarotti when it comes to carrying a tune or a Schwarzenegger when it comes to hoisting Tiny Tim on his shoulder, but as they say in school, he works and plays well with others and makes the most of the rare comic line.
The Tony Walton sets are still impressive, the Alan Menken music and Lynn Ahrens lyrics are serviceable if unmemorable; the cast, with its ghosts, ghouls, Cratchits and old Londoners from beadles to butchers and bankers, goes about its tasks with good will, and the show, playing through Jan. 4 and directed by Mike Ockrent, moves along at a brisk pace.
This "Christmas Carol" may not be all Dickens, but it's all right.
 
A CHRISTMAS CAROL
 
Based on the story by Charles Dickens; music by Alan Menken; lyrics by Lynn Ahrens; book by Mike Ockrent and Ms. Ahrens; directed by Mr. Ockrent; choreography by Susan Stroman; sets by Tony Walton; costumes by William Ivey Long; lighting by Jules Fisher and Peggy Eisenhauer; sound by Tony Meola; projections, Wendall K. Harrington; flying by Foy. A Madison Square Garden production presented by American Express. At the Theater at Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 31st Street, Manhattan.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains Against the Yen After the Failure of Yamaichi

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar finished slightly higher against the Japanese yen yesterday and edged lower against the German mark in subdued trading after the failure of a major Japanese brokerage firm.
The Japanese financial markets were closed yesterday for a national holiday. That and the coming Thanksgiving break kept dealings quiet after Yamaichi Securities became the biggest Japanese company to collapse since World War II and the third Japanese financial company to fail in less than a month. 
 The dollar's gains were also limited because the currency has already risen sharply against the yen in the last month while Japan's economic troubles worsened amid a slump in Asia's financial markets.
"I think people are getting a bit numb to Japanese companies closing up shop," said John Hazelton, chief currency trader at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company.
The dollar peaked at 127.23 yen when European trading began, but retreated later to settle at 126.80 yen in New York, up from 126.40 late Friday. The dollar cost 1.7375 marks, down from 1.7384. The British pound was quoted at $1.6906, down from $1.6932. The dollar ended mixed in other dealings.
Mr. Hazelton said many traders hesitated to make major moves before seeing how Japan's stock market reacted to Yamaichi's failure.
The dollar's climb against the yen was partly contained by concern about the Bank of Japan's possible intervention to buy yen for dollars if the United States currency's advance was deemed excessive. Many traders regard the intervention threshold as 127.45 yen, the nearly five-year high reached by the dollar last May.
The Yamaichi collapse pushed the yen lower against the mark as well, which indirectly helped the German currency strengthen a bit against the dollar despite a sign that Germany's economy was not growing fast enough to merit a rise in interest rates. The German Government reported yesterday that producer prices fell by a tenth of a percent in October, confounding expectations of a rise and suggesting that Germany's central bank would not have to raise rates to repress inflation. Higher interest rates tend to raise demand for a country's currency.

HEADLINE: What the Fed Can't Do

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Bob Herbert (column, Nov. 20) says "it is national policy to keep the unemployment rate artificially high" and that "Alan Greenspan's purpose in life is to protect the assets of the very wealthy." Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, does not simply wake up in the morning and choose the unemployment rate. All the Federal Reserve can do is print money and lend it. 
 It is widely accepted that, in the short term, if the Fed prints too much it can bring down unemployment and accelerate inflation. But does Mr. Herbert really imagine that the Fed can permanently lower unemployment? While it is true that unexpected inflation hurts lenders and helps borrowers, inflation itself is hardly regarded as a plus by most Americans.
 
THOMAS GUNDERSON
Cambridge, Mass., Nov. 23, 1997

HEADLINE: A Small Start To U.S. Deficit

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The 1998 fiscal year has barely begun and already the Government's budget deficit is running below 1997, which had the smallest deficit in 23 years.
The deficit in October -- the first month of the 1998 budget year -- totaled $35.6 billion, down 11 percent from $39.8 billion the previous October, the Government reported today. Federal revenue for the month totaled $114.9 billion and spending was $150.5 billion. 
 Even with the good start, few analysts predict that the current year will beat the $22.3 billion deficit for all of the 1997 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30. That was the smallest budget gap since 1974.
The Clinton Administration is predicting a $58.3 billion deficit in 1998.
Legislation promising a balanced budget by 2002 has been enacted. But the deficit is forecast to be higher for several years because tax cuts are taking effect before most of the spending cuts.
In addition, most economists expect the economy to slow in 1998. Thus the rapid growth of tax revenue, which helped reduce the 1997 shortfall, should slow as well.

HEADLINE: Nabisco Offers to Buy $1.23 Billion in Notes

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PARSIPPANY, N.J., Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Nabisco Holdings Corporation offered today to purchase $1.23 billion of Nabisco Inc. notes due in 1999 and 2000, as it seeks to secure lower interest rates on its debt.
The company, based in Parsip pany, said it planned to finance the transaction with short-term debt, saving $1 million to $1.5 million in interest payments in 1998 for each $100 million in bonds tendered. 
 The company said the move, which would leave it with about 45 percent of its total debt in floating-rate notes, was aimed at taking advantage of lower interest rates. The company may refinance the debt with longer-term borrowings at a later time.
Fred Taylor, a Salomon Brothers analyst, said the bonds were "going to come due relatively soon anyway. The company will consider long-term debt at the appropriate time."
Mr. Taylor said that might occur after Nabisco was spun off from the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation, which owns 80.5 percent of Nabisco's shares and which has said it will seek a spinoff before the end of 1998.
Also, Nabisco, which last week named James Kilts, a former Kraft executive, as its chief executive effective Jan. 1, might sell off some assets to focus on making Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers, giving it advantageous borrowing rates later.

HEADLINE: Thunder Over Asia

 BODY:
As President Clinton meets with leaders of the Asia-Pacific rim in Vancouver this week, financial turmoil threatens the Asian economic "miracle" on which their partnership is based. The paradox of the summit meeting, however, is that the bailouts in Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea, not to mention the failure of some big banks and securities firms in Japan, are driving home lessons of fiscal discipline better than the Clinton Administration ever could. The turbulence might tempt some countries to back away from harsh measures, but they should realize that the markets are demanding long-postponed moves to open financial systems to scrutiny and competition, lower trade barriers and reduce government economic regulation.
The economic problems in Asia could also send a signal to the world's other "big emerging markets," as Administration officials call them. While the Asian successes were all built partly on healthy habits of education, saving and shrewd investment, too much corruption and cronyism was involved. The South Korean economy, for example, has long been anchored by large, secretive family-run business groups known as chaebols, which government regulators allowed to incur excessive debt without disclosure to regulators or investors. 
 Exacting discipline in Asian countries will be painful, especially if it leads to widespread job losses or wage reductions. But the United States needs to reiterate the importance of full transparency by companies and financial institutions. In South Korea, for example, leading businesses want to repeal one of the most important reforms of President Kim Young Sam, the rule requiring bank depositors to maintain accounts in their own names. The rule, instituted to reduce corruption, must be kept if Korean companies are to regain credibility in the international markets. Similar vigilance against corruption must be pressed in Indonesia, where relatives of President Suharto are trying to prevent the closing of banks they control.
In recent decades, the Asian "tigers" have looked to Japan for leadership, and in the current crisis Japan can show the way with its own reforms. The postwar boom in Japan was built on an elaborate system of government support, much of it undisclosed, including favorable loans and lax regulation. Collusive practices were not only tolerated, they were encouraged. Over the weekend, in an action that would have been unthinkable until recently, Japan allowed the shutdown of its fourth-largest brokerage firm, Yamaichi Securities, which has now revealed $2 billion in previously undisclosed off-the-book debts.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has long talked about the need for Japan to open its financial system to more scrutiny. The first step for any country toward regaining financial credibility in the world markets is to acknowledge the extent of its problems candidly, to itself and its own people.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: F.C.C. to Open Phone Market To Foreigners

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Federal regulators plan to take a major step today to open America's $200 billion telecommunications market to foreign competition, hoping to lower international calling rates for consumers and bolster opportunities for American communications companies elsewhere in the world.
The five-member Federal Communications Commission will vote today to approve rules carrying out February's World Trade Organization agreement to liberalize international telecommunications, commission officials said yesterday. The ruling will make it much easier for foreign carriers to offer service in the United States, increasing competition and potentially driving down prices. 
 The commission also plans to increase to 49 percent from 25 percent the limit on how much of an American communications carrier can be owned by foreign entities without passing a difficult Federal review.
"I'm very confident that we'll be able to approve this unanimously," William E. Kennard, the commission's new chairman, said yesterday. "It is a significant step toward bringing competition to worldwide telecommunications markets and it will be particularly good for American companies, who are well poised to take advantage of these market-opening opportunities."
For years, the F.C.C. has forced foreign carriers that want to offer service between the United States and their home markets to demonstrate that their native territory is open to American companies. So far only Britain, Sweden and New Zealand have passed that test.
Under the new rules, the commission will normally allow companies from all 132 W.T.O. nations to market to American customers and deliver services to America's shores, Mr. Kennard said.
But the commission has apparently decided not to extend tough international pricing rules it adopted in August to foreign carriers that resell services from other telephone companies. The rules affect settlement rates, the payments phone companies make to each other to complete calls. MCI Communications and AT&T had lobbied the commission to extend the rules, which would place a greater burden on their foreign competitors.
Mr. Kennard declined to comment on whether the commission would vote today on extending the August pricing rules.
In February, 69 countries representing more than 90 percent of the global $600 billion telecommunications market signed an agreement in Geneva to open their communications arenas to foreign companies. The agreement, which does not require Congressional approval, is scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1.
Today's rulings by the F.C.C. are expected to be the last official actions required to bring the United States into line with the Geneva accord.
"It's an enormous step forward," said Scott Blake Harris, a former chief of the F.C.C.'s international bureau who is now a partner at the law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher.
"You'll see far more foreign capital available for investment in our infrastructure," he said. "You'll also see foreign carriers seeking to compete in the international services market and you will start to see a drop in international calling rates. And through the next few years you will see the same thing rolling across the globe."
Big American long-distance companies like AT&T and the MCI could see their share of the nation's $12 billion international calling market fall as foreign communications giants like Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom start offering service directly to American businesses and consumers.
But Mr. Kennard and some analysts expect American companies to more than recoup that loss as they take advantage of newly opened markets in other parts of the world. Because the United States is by far the world's largest telecommunications market, today's action is expected to spur other countries to fulfill their responsibilities under the W.T.O accord to open their markets.
"The rest of the world will be watching to see how completely we implement the W.T.O., and we are implementing it completely," Mr. Harris said. "That will persuade many others to do the right thing in their countries."
Mr. Kennard said, "American companies are going to be the prime beneficiaries because as competition spreads internationally they are in the best position to take advantage of these opportunities."
In August the commission issued an unprecedented ruling that would have the effect of forcing foreign carriers to lower the prices they charge American carriers for terminating international calls.
The pricing "benchmarks," as the F.C.C. calls them, normally would not take effect until 1999. But foreign carriers that apply to offer service in the United States under the W.T.O. agreement using their own equipment would have to comply immediately.
AT&T and MCI lobbied the commission extensively, seeking to have the commission extend the immediate-compliance rule to foreign companies that buy calling time in bulk from other carriers and resell it at a profit, instead of using their own equipment.
Resale is usually an easier option for entering new markets than building new telecommunications systems. It is usually more popular as well.
"We want the F.C.C. to use all means at its disposal to bring accounting rates closer to costs," Sheila Blackwell, an MCI spokeswoman, said yesterday. "The W.T.O. agreement rests on the principle that foreign dominant carriers will not be permitted to distort competition in the U.S. market."
AT&T declined to comment yesterday.
Foreign carriers, including Cable and Wireless P.L.C. and Kokusai Denshin Denwa, the dominant Japanese international telephone company, had pushed for the August rules not to be extended. The two Virginia Senators, John W. Warner, a Republican, and Charles S. Robb, a Democrat, also sent letters to the commission urging it not to expand the pricing rules, according to people close to the commission.
The offices of the two Senators said they could not confirm that yesterday.
As put by Scott Cleland, an analyst in Washington for the Legg Mason Precursor Group: "This is a microcosm of the traditional free trade versus protectionist debate. AT&T and MCI are worried that if they play fair and their foreign counterparts don't that the imbalance will skew to their disadvantage."
But according to people close to the commission, the F.C.C. intends to deny the requests from the American carriers under the theory that extending the pricing rules would hamper competition in the American market.

HEADLINE: For White Goods, A World Beckons;
But New Markets Are Tough Going

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
In 1994, the Harvard Business Review featured a long interview with David R. Whitwam, the chief executive of the Whirlpool Corporation, entitled "The Right Way to Go Global."
In case anyone doubted the value of Mr. Whitwam's wisdom, a chart accompanied the article, showing how Whirlpool's returns to shareholders in the 1990's were far outdistancing those of the stock market in general. 
 Shortly thereafter, though, Mr. Whitwam went from hero to goat on Wall Street. Whirlpool, the maker of major home appliances, or "white goods," that is based in Benton Harbor, Mich., stumbled in Europe, sending its stock tumbling from a peak of $74 a share to less than $50 in a matter of months. And two months ago, with continuing European problems compounded by heavy losses from more recent investments in China, Whirlpool told shareholders it needed to set aside $350 million -- more than its projected earnings for all of 1997 -- to retrench.
It's not easy going global. Companies typically dream that breaking into foreign markets will provide hordes of new customers. But for all the benefits, the reality all too often is also overexposure to volatile currencies and troubled relationships with foreign partners. In developing countries like China, vague and shifting laws governing taxation and commerce add to the riskiness of big investments. And in developed markets like the United States and Europe, the rules may be clearer but there are often so many entrenched players that newcomers pay heavily for the slightest tactical slip-up.
It is hard enough for the leaders of high-technology industries like Intel in semiconductors or Boeing in aerospace to conquer new territory. Nor have icons of American culture like Coca-Cola, Disney or McDonald's been able to simply waltz into foreign markets after laying down barrages of advertising.
But the business Whirlpool is in may well be among the toughest for corporations with global ambitions. The marketer's home run -- a truly global brand name like Coke or Marlboro that is capable of capturing both mass markets and premium prices -- may be beyond anyone's reach in the $80 billion white goods industry. Not only are there countless variations in what consumers in different countries want from cooking, washing and refrigeration products based on how they live, but in most countries there are already well-established local competitors that cater to those preferences.
"The home is the most culture-bound part of one's life," said John A. Quelch, a Harvard Business School professor who studies globalization issues. "Consumers in Paris don't care what kind of refrigerator they are using in New York."
That condemns multinational appliance companies to nation-by-nation trench warfare. "This is the most competitive of all G.E.'s businesses," said David Cote, head of the General Electric Company's appliance operations, which are based in Louisville, Ky., and had revenues last year of $6.5 billion.
Virtually every company Whirlpool competes with also has globalization bruises. Its latest bad news came just months after Electrolux, based in Sweden, announced a $320 million write-off to pay for shedding 12,000 workers and closing 25 plants in several countries. It is just two years since the Maytag Corporation sold its Hoover subsidiaries overseas, giving up on a six-year effort to penetrate Europe that cost it several hundred million dollars. And G.E. fled Brazil in the 1980's after incurring heavy losses there.
Overcapacity is particularly endemic in Europe, the biggest foreign market. Unlike the United States, where the top four manufacturers account for 90 percent of sales and Whirlpool, G.E. and Maytag all have enjoy double-digit operating margins, the top four in Europe have just 55 percent of sales and face off against more than 300 local manufacturers. Many of these smaller rivals are willing to initiate price wars and other scorched-earth tactics to increase or at least preserve their market share.
"They know that Europe is going to end up consolidating like the United States and that the companies that might buy them are not looking for last year's profits but space on the retail shelf," said Susan Anthony, an analyst at Schroder Securities in London, said of the small companies.
Market saturation is also a problem in China, where the number of local and foreign manufacturers plunging into the appliance business has outstripped the spending power of the Chinese consumer.
So why not stay home? Though globalization has become a bit of a corporate cliche -- with endless talk of the global economy, global markets, global competitiveness, global forces, global imperatives and even global citizens in a global village -- even skeptics see attractions for those who stayed focused.
Developing countries are the only places in the world where major appliance sales are growing at double-digit percentage rates. Even as it suffered in Europe, Whirlpool had sales growing at a 25 percent to 30 percent rate in Brazil in recent years.
There's also the potential cost savings in global procurement and manufacturing; the opportunity to profit from being the first to transfer new technology between continents, and the benefits in recruiting management talent from a bigger, more diverse pool.
For all the difficulties, most of the big appliance makers have concluded they must remain engaged in the globalization fray. The issues are how to dodge setbacks where possible and try, try again where necessary. Thus, G.E. last year reversed direction and bought a Brazilian stove maker in an effort to return to Latin America's biggest market. Whirlpool contends its European business is growing and will be back in the black by 1998, and Mr. Whitwam calls its decision to sell two of its four ventures in China a "temporary retreat." Maytag, although still sour on Europe, has a $35 million year-old joint venture producing washing machines in China and plans to invest a similar amount to expand into refrigerators.
At the moment, Mr. Cote of G.E. would be more likely to get a call than Mr. Whitwam if the Harvard Business Review wanted to revisit its 1994 subject. His cautious tactics have emphasized preserving G.E.'s industry-leading operating margins. While all its major rivals have invested in manufacturing capacity in China, for example, G.E. bought 80 percent of a Chinese distribution company and has used that venture to find Chinese companies to make G.E.-designed products under contract. Total sales this year will not amount to much more than $20 million but, with very little money invested, they will generate a positive return on assets.
Similarly, though G.E. has a strong base in Britain through Hotpoint, which it operates as a joint venture with Britain's General Electric Company (the two namesakes are unrelated), it has chosen to nibble at the luxury end of rest of the European market. It courts noted kitchen designers and wealthy customers familiar with its name by importing products rather than pay a premium price to acquire a European manufacturer big enough to allow it to fight an all-out war with leaders like Electrolux, Bosch-Siemens and Whirlpool. And it licenses some European manufacturers to sell their products under the G.E. name.
"Our goal is to be the most profitable appliance company," Mr. Cote said. "We don't necessarily have to manufacture."
But other international giants are going all out to make G.E.'s current strategy look short-sighted.
Electrolux, the world's largest appliance maker, may face the biggest struggle. It has made itself the European leader through acquisitions, but has produced disappointing earnings as it struggled to integrate them better. In the United States, it acquired big-name brands -- notably Frigidaire in 1986 -- but underestimated how much investment was needed to rebuild them.
The challenge of sorting Electrolux out fell early this year to Michael Treschow, a 53-year-old executive who had been running Atlas Copco, a Swedish mining and metals multinational that like Electrolux is part of the constellation of public companies controlled by the Wallenberg family. Within a month of switching jobs, Mr. Treschow delighted analysts by announcing Electrolux's huge streamlining program.
"We are trying to get margins, which are now under 4 percent, back up above 6.5 percent in the next two years," Mr. Treschow said. One aim is to develop more products like the new Euro-oven, which attempts to address the varied product preferences of Europe's fragmented markets with 46 minor variations on a single platform. The goal is to simplify everything from procurement and manufacturing to customer service.
Also on the move is Bosch-Siemens, a joint venture of two of Germany's biggest companies, Robert A. Bosch G.m.b.H. and Siemens A.G. Three years ago, Bosch-Siemens acquired Brazil's largest maker of cooking appliances, and has since built factories to make refrigerators and washing and drying machines in that country, and started construction of a refrigerator factory in Peru. Its newer ventures have begun taking share from both Whirlpool, the market leader through its majority control of Brasmotor S.A., and Electrolux, according to Roger Wright, an industry analyst at Garantia, a Brazilian investment bank.
Whirlpool stepped up its investment in Latin America recently but is also committed to recovering from its international missteps. It has the most on the line in Europe, where it became a big player overnight in 1989 by acquiring the appliance arm of Philips N.V., the Dutch conglomerate. Part of the $2 billion deal, which was completed in stages, required Whirlpool to replace the famous Philips brand with its own within five years, thus imposing a huge marketing burden that helped drive the business into the red after a promising start.
But such challenges have neither dampened Mr. Whitwam's optimism nor caused him to recant much of what he said in 1994 when Whirlpool was riding high. "Everything we based our strategic plans on has happened and we are further along than I envisioned," he said in a recent interview at Whirlpool's headquarters in Benton Harbor.
"We have probably realized no more than a third of the benefits of creating an integrated global company so far," he said. "We never expected this industry to get there in the 90's."

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Pleased With U.S. Economy

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The United States economy looks well balanced in its seventh year of growth, with surprisingly low inflation despite tight labor markets, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said in a report today.
"The United States has enjoyed a year of exceptionally good economic performance," the Paris-based group of 29 industrial countries said in its annual review. "This is all the more remarkable in this, the seventh year of economic expansion." 
 The O.E.C.D. forecast that gross domestic product in the United States in 1997 would grow by 3.8 percent, the fastest rate among the group's seven largest members and the highest since 1988.
The annual review, whose content was approved on Oct. 8, predicted that above-trend growth would continue through spring and said the inflation rate could increase to around 3 percent from its current level of just above 2 percent.
The O.E.C.D. said that keeping prices in check would probably require the Federal Reserve to raise short-term borrowing costs by as much as three-quarters of a percentage point "to curb some interest-sensitive demand."
The Fed last changed monetary policy on March 25, when it lifted the Federal funds overnight lending rate by a quarter-percentage point, to 5.5 percent. Despite the tightening, long-term interest rates and other market rates are lower since the spring. "As a result, all of the restrictive effect of the March tightening has since been undone in the interim," the O.E.C.D. said. The group saw the biggest inflation risk coming from the labor market.

HEADLINE: White House Memo;
President Using Fund-Raising Speeches to Test Campaign Themes for '98

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
He gives the speeches late at night, after the sorbet has puddled and most reporters are past their deadlines. Working from sketchy notes after long days, President Clinton often rambles, and he sometimes wanders off on tangents, as when he recently called the Internet "the fastest growing human organism in all of history."
But as he delivers speech after speech at fund-raisers, President Clinton can be heard these days puzzling through the proposals and starting to develop a message that his aides say he hopes will, in final form, carry Democrats to a majority in Congress next year. 
 No two speeches are identical, but almost all fit a rough template: Mr. Clinton presents a starkly partisan review of his record in office, crediting himself and the Democrats with deeds like cutting the budget deficit and and humanely changing the welfare system but skipping right past the Democrats' deep internal rift over trade. He mixes that political message with a sweeping analysis of American history and a philosophical, searching look at how the country should grapple with technological and economic change.
"He's noodling," one of Mr. Clinton's senior aides said. "He's in noodle mode. He's asking questions that are on his mind."
The President's recent defeat on legislation that would have increased his authority in trade negotiations has persuaded Mr. Clinton that he needs to do a better job of articulating his economic goals, aides said. As Mr. Clinton himself put it at a recent fund-raiser here, "We have to have a new definition of security in a more dynamic world."
Sometimes, that notion prompts the President to fire questions at the silent guests, as he did on Saturday at a dinner near Seattle. How can the United States benefit from "this huge technological and information revolution" while preserving "some sort of coherent life for ourselves, our families, our communities, and our nation?" he asked. "How do we preserve the common good as we break down the old bureaucracies, the old established ways of doing things and all of that?"
Such questioning can lead Mr. Clinton down vague, theoretical byways, as it did that night. "There are a lot of very brilliant people who believe that the nation-state is fast becoming a relic of the past," he said.
But it can also prompt an enumeration of policies that he says were meant to address people's anxieties. Many times, he cites his tax credits for education and his efforts to protect pensions. And he sketches other policies he hopes to enact.
"The next big challenge is child care," Mr. Clinton said at a recent fund-raiser here, noting the tensions between work and home life. "And I think we are really going to have to work hard to find the way -- and the Government can't afford all this -- we've got to find a way to have a quality child care network in America that's safe and affordable."
As that statement indicates, Mr. Clinton is still formulating his ideas, and, aides said, pushing his staff to develop specific policies. But as he races between fund-raisers, he leaves no doubt which party he thinks will do the better job of salving economic fears.
"I believe history will record that at this moment in time our views were right and that we prepared the world -- prepared America -- for a totally new world," Mr. Clinton said on Saturday at a lunch in Denver.
In contrast to his cheery bipartisanship at most events in Washington, the President's comments at fund-raisers can be brutally partisan. He repeatedly conjures images of Republican hit men by attacking the "Contract on America."
Mr. Clinton often argues that Republicans won votes in 1994 by scaring people about his economic package and stance on gun control. Now, he says, enough time has passed to show the rightness of his positions.
"Sooner or later," he said at a reception in Las Vegas, Nev., "people should be held accountable."
Repeatedly saying that the United States is better off than it was when he came into office, Mr. Clinton credits Democrats with caring about the environment and with reducing crime. "If you talk to the police officers of the country, they believe it's because of the ideas advanced by the Democratic Party," Mr. Clinton assured donors at one event.
Just in the last 11 days, Mr. Clinton has spoken at 13 fund-raisers for his party, for individual candidates and for a nonprofit group. The Democrats are more than $14 million in debt, largely because of legal bills incurred because of investigations into how the Clinton team raised money for the 1996 Presidential campaign. These dinners regularly raise $300,000 or more.
One senior White House aide that Mr. Clinton was just beginning to formulate next year's political message.
"We're in an interlude now," this aide said, adding that Mr. Clinton would practice with these speeches, "shadow-boxing, and then we'll get the first real crack in the State of the Union."
Mr. Clinton is said to prefer small events, with 75 or so people, to what one aide called "2,000-people cattle calls." He stands up with notes on a long, narrow card to guide him. He thanks his hosts, compliments their inevitably vast home, tells a reminiscence or a joke about the city or someone at one of the circular tables.
Often, Mr. Clinton lays out a grand theme. "Now that I have been President for five years," he said at a dinner two weeks ago in Las Vegas, "I tend to have a little bit of detachment and see a lot of the specific struggles and contests and efforts we're making as part of the broad sweep of American history."
In general, Mr. Clinton devotes the first section of his speeches to reviewing his efforts to reposition his party ideologically, to achieve what he called at one event "a new politics for a new era."
At times, he can sound defensive.
"I get so tired of hearing our friends in the Republican Party and some of our friends in the press say, 'Oh, the President caved in and signed the Republicans' welfare bill,' " Mr. Clinton said at an event on Tuesday evening. "It's a load of bull." After reviewing his record, Mr. Clinton looks ahead to the rest of his term, usually in less detail.
Mr. Clinton never fails to thank his donors, routinely, if a bit incongruously, pairing his thanks with a call for tighter campaign finance laws. He assures them of the "direct connection" between their contributions and the success of his policies.
"I think our country is better because of what you have done," Mr. Clinton said at a dinner here recently. "This is an act of high citizenship, what you're doing."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: A Withering Little Town Sees Its Salvation in an Old Asylum

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WESTON, W.Va.

 BODY:
Like the center of many other towns in West Virginia, downtown Weston is a sad-looking place, made almost obsolete by the strip malls closer to the Interstate. Only a handful of shops remain open for business on Main Avenue, the central thoroughfare, and pedestrians are rare.
But these are hardly mournful souls, the 4,994 who live here in Lewis County's largest community: many believe rejuvenation may be only a handshake away. Just across the West Fork River, which ambles through town, stands the silver bullet that local leaders hope will profoundly change the character of Weston, the county, maybe all of central West Virginia. 
 "I don't even think it has sunk in yet -- we'll be a whole different town," said Patricia Minehardt, president of the county's Economic Development Authority.
In 1994, the Weston State Hospital, a massive sandstone complex that served as West Virginia's largest mental institution, closed after 130 years. The hospital, sitting at the front of 300 acres, was built during the Civil War as the Lunatic Asylum West of the Alleghenys and continued operating, under various names, until a new psychiatric hospital opened at the western edge of Weston three years ago. Along the way, the old hospital gained designation as a national historic landmark.
Now Tennessee developers intrigued by Weston's central location -- the town is easily accessible by Interstate highway, and a new state park is opening nearby -- want to transform the old hospital and its grounds into Weston Grande Resort, with a luxury hotel, a golf course, restaurants, an office complex, a convention center, condominiums and 165 single-family houses that would sell for as much as $200,000 each, nearly five times the current median value of a Lewis County home.
"There will be nothing second class about this proposal," said Charles W. Wilson, a lawyer working closely with local officials who sought proposals on what use to make of the old place and then chose the idea submitted by the Archidesign Group of Pigeon Forge, Tenn., a company that helped design Dollywood, the Pigeon Forge theme park named for Dolly Parton. (Other bidders for the Weston project had proposed a prison, a health care center or a museum.)
The developers, required to submit their formal plans to the state by early December, could wait months for approval. But Alan E. Dillow, Archidesign's president, says that he envisions no problems and that the $90 million complex could open as early as mid-2000, drawing tourists from the Middle Atlantic region.
Robin S. Poling, executive director of the Economic Development Authority, says that the old hospital's past is "part of the aura that attracts the developers" and that construction of a national museum on mental health is being contemplated as part of the project.
As its original admissions logs show, the old asylum treated all manner of problems, among them "religious excitement," "parents were cousins," "fever and loss of lawsuit" and "desertion by husband." Originally designed to accommodate 250 patients, through expansion it served almost 2,400 by the 1950's, and not just the mentally ill: tuberculosis patients were ultimately housed in one building, the criminally insane in another.
As for the planned resort, many here can hardly contain their enthusiasm, confident that a deal will create several hundred permanent jobs and spur the kind of economic development not seen in these parts since mid-century, when three manufacturing plants made Weston a major center of glass-blown products. Only one plant remains, and Weston's unemployment, hovering around 7.8 percent, is well above the national rate of 4.7.
"I hope to heaven this happens," Ruth Bragg, a 77-year-old lifelong Weston resident, said as she waited to have her hair done at the New Image beauty shop, one of the few thriving businesses in town. "I don't care if they put in girlie joints. It'll be good for the town."
The shop's owner, Sheila Sayre, agreed. "It'll bring a lot more business here," Ms. Sayre said. "I have three grown kids, and they all went out of town to find jobs."
Given the potential for job creation and economic rebirth, and the prestige a lavish resort would bring, it is almost impossible to find anyone in town who opposes the project outright, although some are leery.
Beyond the southwest corner of the hospital grounds is a working-class neighborhood of old single-family homes on narrow streets, where residents confess that they know little of the town's revitalization plans and that what they do know is based on rumor.
Robert Blake, 62, a disabled heavy-equipment operator who has lived in Weston for 50 years, says he has heard that the developers intend to buy all the houses in the area and move people out. William F. Buckhannon, a retired state employee, says he understands that the resort will have gambling, which he opposes.
Actually the purchase of existing private homes is not part of the deal, and the developers have no plans to offer gambling. But other residents express concern that so massive an undertaking will overwhelm the neighborhood, shattering its quiet. Carol Cowger, a mother of four children who like to play outside, says she worries about traffic.
And Laura Ashford, a 17-year-old high school senior, says she has heard that the plans call for "golf courses, indoor pools and horse stables," leading her to wonder how that kind of luxury can exist beside homes that are decidedly frayed.
"I wouldn't want to go to a five-star hotel and look at my backyard," Ms. Ashford said.
Local leaders insist that they have studied all aspects of the project and cannot identify a single negative consequence. Their only fear, they say, is some unforeseen glitch that could stall or even cancel the project, forcing them to reconsider other ideas.
"I feel in my heart that this community will not throw up its hands and quit," Ms. Poling said. "We will persevere. We will be pro-active. This is too important not to be."

HEADLINE: Study Casts Doubt On Wisdon Of Mandatory Terms for Drugs

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Among drug offenders sentenced to long, mandatory terms in Massachusetts state prisons, nearly half have no record of violent crime, according to a study of the state's prison population released today.
"Mandatory sentencing laws are wasting prison resources on nonviolent, low-level offenders and reducing resources available to lock up violent offenders," said William N. Brownsberger, the study's principal investigator and an assistant attorney general, who conducted the study at Harvard Medical School while he was on leave.
Drug policy experts say the study will add valuable facts to the growing debate around the country over the efficacy of tough minimum sentences for drug crimes.
"We have to respond to drug dealing forcibly and incarceration is often an appropriate response," Mr. Brownsberger said, "but today we are going too far."
The study of 1,175 inmates in the Massachusetts prison system also found that 82.9 percent of the drug offenders were black or Hispanic, though they make up just over 9 percent of the state's population.
And when researchers looked closely at the criminal records of a sample of 151 inmates, Mr. Brownsberger said, they found that nearly half had never been charged with a violent crime in Massachusetts, only one-third had ever been convicted of a violent crime and only 1 in 12 had been convicted of a serious violent crime like assault with intent to kill.
That data can be expected to be used by one particular corner of the drug-policy debate where some who back tough mandatory sentences contend that even if drug use and dealing is arguably a victimless crime, the sentences serve to put away mainly dangerous criminals who belong in jail.
However, Mr. Brownsberger's findings appear to indicate that a significant percentage of inmates in state prison for drug convictions would not be there otherwise.
The study "is quite important because it's state-specific, and it's quantitative, and in particular, it's grounded in data," said Jonathan Caulkins, a drug policy researcher at Carnegie-Mellon University.
Mr. Caulkins was the principal researcher on a Rand Corporation study released in May that also harshly criticized mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses. The study argued that incarceration is so expensive, $20,000 to $30,000 a year for each inmate, that it would be more efficient to shift the emphasis to old-fashioned law enforcement and traditional prison sentences, or to spend more money on drug abuse treatment and prevention.
Mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenders became popular during the crack-related crime scares of the 1980's. Supporters said the laws took criminals out of circulation and sent a tough message to the streets.
The rules differ significantly from state to state. In Massachusetts, they concern mainly cocaine and heroin, and include provisions that anyone convicted of dealing within 1,000 feet of a school must serve at least two years and anyone convicted a second time of dealing cocaine serve at least five years. They are also based on the quantity of drugs involved: anyone convicted of selling 100 grams of cocaine, for example, must serve at least 10 years in prison, even if it is their first offense.
Researchers say mandatory drug sentences are also seen as a major cause of prison overcrowding, budget overruns and, in some cases, simple injustice -- as when a nonviolent drug offender ends up serving more time than someone convicted of manslaughter or armed robbery.
The Massachusetts Sentencing Commission, a panel of judges, prosecutors and other criminal justice experts appointed in 1994, has recommended that judges be allowed to depart from tough mandatory sentences when a defendant does not have a serious criminal record. The state Legislature is expected to take up its plan next year and it is expected to be hotly debated.

HEADLINE: Stew Leonard's Plans Big Store in Yonkers, Singing Cows Included

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
Stew Leonard's, the carnival-style dairy store in Connecticut, isn't letting a tussle with the law interfere with its success.
With megastores in Norwalk and Danbury, Conn., the company is expected to announce plans today for the opening of a new Stew Leonard's in Yonkers, marking its first foray into New York State. 
 The announcement comes only five months after Stew Leonard Sr., the store's founder, was released from a Federal prison in Pennsylvania where he served almost four years for tax evasion, and one month before his son Thomas is to be sentenced on similar charges.
"In the long run, everything that happens makes you stronger," Stew Leonard Jr., the company president and the founder's other son, said yesterday. "You just have to keep your chin up and keep moving forward and you get through it."
Taxes are playing a part in the deal to be announced today, but this time the tax savings will be legal. The Yonkers store is to occupy part of a state economic development zone on Austin Avenue, off exit 6A of the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. In September, the state agreed to expand the zone to include the 12-acre Stew Leonard's site, allowing the store to qualify for as much as $3 million in tax credits.
The $25 million store will sprawl across 110,000 square feet and employ 700 people when it opens in the spring of 1999, Stew Leonard Jr. said.
Like the Connecticut stores, which he said draw a total of 13 million shoppers a year, the Stew Leonard's in Yonkers will also try to raise the dull chore of grocery shopping to the level of family entertainment, with mechanized singing cows and free food samples inside and a petting zoo outside. At the entrance will be company Rule No. 1, literally etched in stone: The customer is always right. (Rule No. 2 says that if the customer is wrong, reread Rule No. 1.)
That deference to customers, along with the folksy atmosphere and emphasis on fresh foods at low prices, made Stew Leonard's a national icon in American retailing during the 1980's. The store was praised in the 1982 book "In Search of Excellence" by Thomas J. Peters and Robert H. Waterman Jr., the management experts, and the Reagan Administration gave the elder Mr. Leonard the Presidential Award for Entrepreneurial Achievement.
But the good times came to an abrupt end in 1993 when Mr. Leonard, who is now 68, and three company executives pleaded guilty to skimming more than $17 million from sales at the Norwalk store. (Two of the executives were Mr. Leonard's brothers-in-law.) The scheme involved customized computer programs, destruction of records and bags of money smuggled to the Caribbean. It was the largest criminal tax case in state history.
Stew Leonard Jr., 43, had also participated in the scheme, but had received immunity from prosecution as part of the plea agreement, according to Government documents.
At the same time, Connecticut's Consumer Protection Commissioner accused Stew Leonard's of having its thumb on the scale, short-weighing packaged food. Those charges were settled last year when the company paid a civil penalty without admitting wrongdoing.
Just last month, Thomas Leonard, who was president of the Danbury store, pleaded guilty to two counts of aiding and assisting the preparation of false tax returns. The Federal charges stemmed from wrongdoing that occurred after the elder Mr. Leonard went to prison. Asked yesterday about his brother's activities, Stew Leonard Jr. simply said, "I have a colorful family."
While the criminal charges did have an impact on business at first, things have since bounced back, with sales at the Danbury and Norwalk stores this year expected to reach $160 million, Stew Leonard Jr. said. "Now we're ahead of where we were in 1993," he said.
The company suffered a setback in April, however, when zoning officials in Orange, Conn., rejected plans to build a dairy store on a 50-acre parcel the company already owns there.

HEADLINE: Children of Working Poor Are Day Care's Forgotten

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.

 BODY:
At 5 the other morning, Marlene Garrett had her 11-month-old baby in her arms and was guiding her other two sleep-dazed children, ages 3 and 4, through the darkness to the baby sitter's.
"Mama has to go to work so she can buy you shoes," Mrs. Garrett told them. She had just that day moved up the economic ladder, from a job selling sneakers for $5.25 an hour to a job behind the counter at a bagel cafe for $6 an hour. Her shift started at 6, and she did not want to be late. 
 Seven blocks on foot, and then she was hugging her children and handing them over to Vivienne, a Bahamian woman who works nights at the self-service laundry where Mrs. Garrett does her wash.
Vivienne's small apartment was clean but sparsely furnished. There were no toys or books in sight, just a television that the children spent most of the next 10 hours watching. For this, Mrs. Garrett scrapes together $50 a week -- a little less than half the cost for just one child in most licensed day care centers here.
Mrs. Garrett hurried down the stairs and set off for work, three miles away. The family car died a month ago.
"It breaks my heart, leaving them there," said Mrs. Garrett, who arrived in Florida from Jamaica in 1989. "I want them in a learning environment. This is the best I can do right now. It's an emergency situation."
The experts agree: for Mrs. Garrett and tens of thousands of other low-income working parents nationwide, child care is a perpetual emergency.
Low-income working families are, in many ways, the forgotten class in the national debate over child care. They make too little to afford the choices of professional women -- whether to use a nanny or an au pair, to work part time or full time. And many make too much to qualify for government programs. Others make little enough to qualify, but are low on long waiting lists while priority is given to women leaving the welfare rolls for jobs.
Florida offers a good illustration of this squeeze on the working class. More Federal money is available for child care here because of the new welfare law: Florida added over $100 million to its child care budget this year. And the state has a program to provide assistance to nonwelfare families whose income is below 150 percent of the poverty level ($17,775 for a family of three).
But like other states under pressure to meet the work requirements of the new law or risk severe penalities, Florida has budgeted the bulk of its child care money to welfare recipients moving to jobs.
There are 25,000 children of low-income families receiving no welfare benefits who are on the waiting list for assistance in Florida, and an additional 39,000 who are eligible, according to Susan Muenchow, executive director of the Florida Children's Forum, a statewide nonprofit child care resource and referral agency. Marlene Garrett's children are among those waiting.
"From a child-care standpoint," Ms. Muenchow said, "you're better off on welfare."
 
When Staying Home Is Not an Option
The lives of women like Mrs. Garrett are ruled by hard economic facts. "If my finances permitted, I'd love to stay home," said Mrs. Garrett, whose husband, Rod, works in a factory making hospital curtains. "Who's a better caretaker than Mom?"
But staying home is not an option. Her husband takes home about $250 a week. Her own $200 a week helps put food on the table and pay the $400 monthly rent. Mrs. Garrett, who keeps a folder with her expenses neatly itemized, says she owes nearly $5,000 in medical bills. The family does not have health insurance.
Welfare is not an option. "I don't want to plant that seed in my children," she said. "I want to work."
When it comes to child care, Mrs. Garrett, who is 36, has almost no choices. She would like to put her children, Hasia, 11 months; Angelique, 4; and Scherrod, 3, in her church day care center and preschool, Holy Temple Christian Academy, but at $180 a week -- about $90 less than what most licensed day care centers in Fort Lauderdale charge for three children -- it is beyond her reach.
The church day care center had seemed possible back in September, when Mrs. Garrett was earning $8 an hour as a home health aide for the elderly. (It helped that she was often able to bring her children to work.) She took her children for their shots and put money down on school uniforms, at $32 apiece. But then her car gave out, and with her hours long and unpredictable, and bus service irregular, she had to give up the work she says she was born to do. There was no money for another car. Overnight, her family was downwardly mobile.
"I took back the uniforms," she said. "They credited me for them."
Mrs. Garrett has to make do with the child care she can afford, and Vivienne is what she can afford.
Mothers like her improvise fragile arrangements that inevitably break down. The friend, neighbor or relative who was looking after their children gets sick, or goes to work, or moves away, or simply becomes unavailable, and they have to find someone else to take their children.
"How can you get a job if you don't have day care?" said Christina Burdhimo, 26, a waitress who is raising two children, ages 2 and 4, alone. But without a subsidy -- she is also on a waiting list for one -- she cannot afford day care. A lot of places want $94 per week per child," said Ms. Burdhimo, who is divorced.
Her father and her mother-in-law have been alternating baby-sitting duties. "My mother-in-law will do it a couple more months," she said.
Regulated child care in Florida costs $4,000 a year or more, and many families are doing without other essentials in order to pay for it. Kelly McKnight, who earns $8 an hour monitoring burglar alarms, moved her two daughters, ages 3 and 4, into her father's mobile home, in Hollywood, after her husband left her. It was the only way she could afford the $135 a week for a licensed day care center, she said.
Her father, a retired correctional officer, helps with the child care, but the situation is far from ideal: the mobile home is in an adults-only community. Ms. McKnight's children can be there only temporarily.
After two years on the waiting list, Ms. McKnight began receiving her subsidy six months ago.
In rural areas, where people are spread out, and with public transportation often nonexistent, makeshift arrangements with friends and family can become even more difficult.
Wendi Slay has a 3-month-old baby and works for $7.20 an hour as a collections clerk for a credit union in Pensacola, in northern Florida. Ms. Slay, who is not married, drives 100 miles a day to take her baby, Chandler, to either her aunt's house or her father's, and then to work -- and back again to pick up Chandler, and head home. "I sing to him all the way home," she said.
Ms. Slay's aunt takes Chandler on Mondays, Tuesdays and Wednesdays. Her father takes him on Thursdays and Fridays, his days off from his job as a landfill supervisor.
"I don't know how much longer my aunt is going to be able to do it," Ms. Slay said in a telephone interview. What will she do for child care when her aunt stops helping? "Wing it, I suppose," she said.
 
Quality Bows To Availability
In all this scrambling, many experts say, low-income women do not have the luxury to worry about quality. "They're desperate," said Helen Blank, director of the child-care division of the Children's Defense Fund. "They miss a day of work, and they lose their job."
Recent research on rapid brain development shows that an enriching, nurturing environment is important for infants and toddlers. Studies show that children in low-quality care can have delayed cognitive and language development, behave more aggressively toward others and react poorly to stress.
Mrs. Garrett, who keeps on a shelf in her children's bedroom a set of 1961 World Book Encyclopedias that was a gift from the family of an elderly man she was caring for, does not need experts to tell her that her children need stimulation. That is what her church offers.
"The children play games," she said. "They go on field trips. They teach them, they train them. My children are bright. You would be amazed at what they would acquire in a year."
But for her, and for many other low-income parents, it is all they can do simply to find a safe place for their children.
Two years ago, state social service inspectors in Pensacola found a woman running an illegal day care center in her trailer for 20 children under age 4. According to their report, the children were hungry, and watching soap operas and game shows. Two of the children had chicken pox. "There appeared to be a total lack of stimulation for the children indicated by the abnormal inactivity of all the children," the report stated.
The parents, who had no other day care they could afford, were angry that the operation was shut down, according to Becky Kirsch, the executive director of the Children's Service Center, Pensacola's child resource and referral agency.
 
Waiting for Help, Not Likely to Get It
The Florida Legislature has recently passed two budget amendments, transferring some surplus child-care money for welfare recipients to low-income working families. But there is still a freeze on helping low-income families on the waiting list, and advocates fear that as increasing numbers of welfare recipients go to work, they will need more money for child care -- leaving even less for low-income working families who have not been on welfare.
"We're pitting one group of poor people against another," Ms. Muenchow said. "Many of these parents have no choice but to leave their children in substandard arrangements that are rotting their brains, and jeopardizing their futures."
She and other advocates say that states should base eligibility for child-care subsidies on income, not welfare status. Only a few states, including Illinois, Washington and Rhode Island, have taken that step.
"The country is focused on moving mothers from welfare to work," said Ms. Blank, of the Children's Defense Fund. "It's not nearly as focused on mothers who are already working to give them the support they need to stay independent, and to keep their children safe."
There are other sources of assistance: Florida has established a nationally recognized child-care partnership program that encourages businesses to help low-wage employees with child care. About 4,000 nonwelfare children are getting help.
Tammy McLamore, who works for $6.25 an hour as a reservations clerk for a transportation company in Fort Lauderdale, has watched the youngest of her five children, shy, 3-year-old Katie, blossom this fall. The reason: She began attending the highly regarded Jack and Jill Nursery School on a scholarship provided by the school. Last year, her mother says, Katie spent her days stuck in a baby sitter's crowded, dirty apartment, in front of a television with five or six other children.
At 7 one morning, Katie was eagerly boarding the school bus. "They sing and dance," Ms. McLamore said. "They do activities. Katie talks about all the teachers. She comes home from school and says, 'Want me to teach you a song?' "
One recent Sunday, Mrs. Garrett, who credits God and her Pentecostal religion with her relentlessly positive attitude, was near tears. "Vivienne told me she cannot keep my children so early," she said. "She has to take her little girl to school. Her husband's work schedule at the Laundromat is about to be changed. I have to try to find somebody else."
A day later, Mrs. Garrett said she had offered Vivienne an additional $25 a week. "She said she will keep my children," said Mrs. Garrett, who is still hoping to send her children to Holy Temple Christian Academy.
To that end, she had a promising interview the other day for a second job working room service nights at the local Marriott hotel. She says she will pay Vivienne another $15 to care for her children the extra hours. She hates it that she will have even less time with them, she said.
"It is temporary," she said. "I am doing what I have to do."

HEADLINE: Dow Falls 113.15 Amid Concerns Over Asian Turmoil

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The tug-of-war continued in the stock market yesterday, with those worried about the economic fallout from Asia's financial turmoil winning this round.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 113.15 points, or 1.4 percent, to 7,767.92, while the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 16.42 points, or 1.7 percent, to 946.67. While a sizable decline, the Dow is still up 8.5 percent since its record 554-point decline on Oct. 27, leaving the Asian optimists still in the lead. 
 But analysts expect the stock market to stay volatile as investors reassess the outlook almost daily because of new developments from Asia.
The stocks of companies exposed to Asia remained on their roller coaster as the sentiment about the outlook for Asia and its impact on growth, earnings and inflation here changed once again.
Down sharply yesterday were Citicorp, J. P. Morgan and Chase Manhattan. They all have exposure in Asia and rallied sharply last week as investors seemed to discount the Asian impact. The same was true for Applied Materials, the leading maker of semiconductor machinery, and Microsoft.
The apparent trigger for yesterday's selloff was the formal announcement of the closing of the Yamaichi Securities Company, the fourth-largest brokerage house in Japan. When the rumor of the closing was reported on Friday, the Dow managed a 54-point gain, although the technology-heavy Nasdaq index fell, as it did again yesterday, dropping 33.76, or 2.1 percent, to 1,586.99.
In Europe, the Yamaichi closing seemed to have a much more negative impact, with the Financial Times index in London down 1.8 percent, the CAC 40 index in Paris off 2.1 percent and the DAX index in Frankfurt declining 2.8 percent.
"Every now and then we get a reminder that there is this financial crisis going on in the Pacific Rim and it is extremely serious," said Hugh Johnson, the chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
Mr. Johnson is in the group of stock strategists expecting the fallout from Asia to have a significant drag on the American economy and corporate earnings. The Yamaichi announcement, he said, "is telling us that the crisis carries with it significant impact on U.S. companies going foreward."
He also said that the recent decline in long-term interest rates coupled with a rise in short-term interest rates is a signal that "the outlook for the U.S. economy is getting darker." This narrowing of the spread between short-term and long-term interest rates has occurred before previous slowdowns of the United States economy.
But Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company, is optimistic, making him and Mr. Johnson an example of how hard it is for individual investors to assess the outlook today.
Mr. Battipaglia said that the Yamaichi closing was raising concerns -- which he dismisses -- about the Japanese selling their holdings of American bonds, a move that could drive interest rates higher here. He also said he was not worried that the unwinding of Yamaichi's holdings in derivatives would lead to problems for American banks or investment banks.
Derivatives are securities that are based on the performance of an underlying asset, like a stock, bond or currency, and allow investors to make very large bets at relatively low costs. But because the positions taken can be large and involve many other firms, the chance that Yamaichi might not honor a deal is worrying to some.
"I don't think that we will have an unraveling of derivatives and I don't think the Japanese will be repatriating" by selling United States Treasury bonds, Mr. Battipaglia said. And he added that the impact from Asia would be mostly positive. The resulting drag on the United States economy from the slowdown of buying from Asia, he said, will help keep the American economy from overheating and inflationary pressures from growing. He is in the camp that thinks that the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates will not be up but down.
He said yesterday's concerns were temporary and that the market "would swing back into the mode it has been in -- bullish for the long term."
On the day, declining issues led advancers by almost 3 to 1 and volume on the New York stock exchange was just under 520 million shares, which is below the daily average.
