HEADLINE: Russia and U.S. Square Off Over U.N. Sanctions on Iraq

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Russia stepped up pressure today to hasten the process of declaring Iraq free of banned weapons, prompting the United States to stiffen its resistance and raising questions about how far Moscow will go -- alone if necessary -- in what is now seen here as a determined campaign to help Baghdad escape from sanctions.
In the last few days, backstage diplomacy has turned to more open confrontation between Moscow and Washington, culminating tonight in a Russian attempt to block any Security Council action on the subject of Iraqi compliance unless Baghdad's progress in meeting disarmament requirements was emphasized. 
 At the same time, the United States is hardening its position against Iraq's persistent refusal to allow access for weapons inspectors to dozens of sites that Baghdad considers sensitive, including numerous presidential palaces and areas controlled by intelligence services or President Saddam Hussein's elite Special Republican Guard.
President Clinton said today in Vancouver, British Columbia, where he is attending an economic conference of Asian and Pacific nations, that Iraq cannot dictate what areas are open or closed to United Nations inspectors. Some of the disputed sites, he said, "actually encompass more land than Washington, D.C."
Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Hussein's palaces were not what the average American would imagine a palace to be but rather huge installations with enough space for weapons production or storage.
"There are 78 such palaces in Iraq," he said. "Many of them are huge compounds." Putting them off limits would undermine the entire disarmament effort, he said. United States officials over the weekend said that Mr. Hussein had 47 presidential palaces that he was seeking to exempt from inspections. A Government official said today that 47 was the number built since the Persian Gulf war, and 78 the total.
In Iraq today, United Nations inspection teams worked without hindrance for a third day after a three-week standoff, which began on Oct. 29 when Iraq ordered Americans barred from United Nations teams. Today's inspections apparently did not challenge Iraqi restrictions.
An American U-2 surveillance plane also flew unhindered in support of the commission. Iraqis had threatened to shoot at the planes, which Baghdad charges are spying for Washington.
At the United Nations, American and Russian attitudes have been hardening since Friday, when Russia failed to persuade an emergency session of the board of the commission charged with disarming Iraq that Baghdad had made enough progress to end intrusive inspections of nuclear and missile programs.
The board concluded instead that Iraq was not in full compliance in any area of the United Nations restrictions on its arms development, and that the fastest way to end sanctions was for Iraq to cooperate. The United Nations commission must be able to certify that Iraq has no prohibited nuclear, chemical or biological programs and no long-range missiles for sanctions to be lifted.
Today the Security Council planned to thank the commission board for its report and the recommendations it contained and urge that they be carried out. Some of these recommendations for hastening the inspectors' work and making it more efficient had been sought by Moscow. They included broadening the composition of inspection teams with more experts from countries other than the United States and adding surveillance flights from other countries.
But after a full day of talks today, Russia blocked the letter, demanding a longer statement enumerating Iraqi accomplishments and emphasizing board requests to the commission's chairman, Richard Butler, whose authority the Russians -- and to some extent the French -- would like to see curtailed.
The Russians want Mr. Butler to go to Iraq for talks immediately, as the board urged. The United States and Britain said today that he should make the decision when to go, depending on progress on the ground. The Americans would like to see an assessment of what damage might have been done to monitoring equipment in the absence of inspectors. Commission officials say this will take several weeks.
After hours of fruitless wrangling today, Britain's representative, Sir John Weston, emerged from the Council chamber visibly angry.
"I find it bizarre that anyone should have difficulty taking note with approval of the Special Commission's report and the recommendations contained therein, or with the expectations that those recommendations would be followed up promptly by those concerned," he said. "Why anybody should find that difficult to accept I cannot imagine."
Bill Richardson, the United States' representative, charged the Iraqis with violations of Security Council resolutions.
"How can you say that there are over 60 sites that can't be inspected?" he asked, speaking to reporters. "How can you say that there are 43 presidential palaces. What are they hiding? We think there should be full access to these sites."
Iraqi efforts to keep inspectors out of sites where prohibited arms may be stored or manufactured began almost as soon as the United Nations disarmament process began in 1991. By 1993, Rolf Ekeus, the Swedish diplomat who was Mr. Butler's predecessor as executive chairman of the Special Commission, was in Baghdad urging more cooperation.
In 1996 Mr. Ekeus and Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister and spokesman on the issue of inspections, signed an agreement with Mr. Ekeus. In the accord, Iraq promised "immediate, unconditional and unrestricted access" to all sites, and Mr. Ekeus pledged to be sensitive to the "sovereignty, territorial integrity and independence" of Iraq.
The Russians and French have argued that there is no need to reopen the access question now, since there is already an agreement in principle and on practices governing inspections.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tokyo Squirms Over Questions About Hidden Losses at Yamaichi

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 25

 BODY:
The collapse of the Yamaichi Securities Company was not a particular shock in Japan, where predictions had been building for months that the nation's oldest brokerage firm, saddled by debts and mismanagement, would go out of business.
The nasty surprise, however, came in the disclosure during the firm's final days that Yamaichi had hidden $2.06 billion in losses, much of it amassed under a practice outlawed six years ago. Moreover, the Government on Monday expressed a remarkable passivity over whether more such losses were lurking in a financial system already under enormous strain. 
 As Yamaichi began to unwind its business following a decision over the weekend to close, Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka acknowledged on Monday that he did not know how many other firms might be hiding similar losses. He also struggled to answer questions over how the Government intended to find out.
"Unless a document is offered . . ." he told a news conference, his voice trailing off. "It is a limitation of the investigation. I hope you understand."
Such an explanation might have been accepted years ago, when the secret losses would have been regarded as just another example of financial impropriety in the world's second-largest economy.
But coming against a backdrop of alarm over Asia's growing financial crisis and the Government's own effort to make Japan Inc. more transparent, Mr. Mitsuzuka's statement reflected how entrenched the present system remains.
Worries that more such losses would emerge were underscored Monday in the global stock market reaction to the downfall of Yamaichi, Japan's fourth-largest brokerage firm and the third big Japanese financial institution to fail in less than a month. Japanese markets were closed for a holiday on Monday, but stocks fell sharply in Europe and in the United States, where the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 113.15 points, or 1.4 percent. In early trading today, Japan's main stock index fell 4.7 percent.
The disclosure of the hidden losses also underscored what critics of Japan have long maintained: not only do companies regularly deceive the Finance Ministry and their own shareholders, but their past assertions that they had cleaned up these practices have proved fraudulent.
It was not lost on financial markets that Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who was reassuring President Clinton at an Asian Pacific summit meeting Monday that the Yamaichi problem would be addressed, was also the Finance Minister when similar hidden losses in 1991 caused a scandal that forced him to resign and cast doubt over his political future.
Japan's securities industry has historically not faced the kind of aggressive regulatory scrutiny found in the United States. The Finance Ministry does not have an equivalent of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal agency that has far-reaching powers to police Wall Street. Indeed, some Japanese market experts find it incongruous that Japan cannot monitor its securities firms when it is so adept at keeping close tabs on other major industries, down to such minute dealings as the inflow and outflow of tourists.
"The Government, in fact, has a long relationship with the brokerage houses," said Jeffrey Arpan, a Japan specialist and professor of international business at the University of South Carolina in Columbia. "It's easier for the Government to pass blame onto somebody else than to admit they made a mistake by not keeping a closer watch."
Yamaichi accrued its newly disclosed losses in the process of covering the trading losses of favored customers -- a practice supposedly rooted out in the 1991 scandal.
Such deals, called tobashi -- in which a firm temporarily shifts losses on investments from one client's account to another's to help clients avoid reporting losses -- were common then, when the Japanese stock market was falling as the air came out of the bubble economy.
Corporate clients had accumulated huge stock positions, using the money they had raised in the bubble economy's heady market to play the market in hopes of scoring quick profits. When the market came tumbling down, their brokers helped them hide their losses by arranging to have other willing customers buy shares at an inflated value.
The assumption among all participants in this game was that eventually the shares would regain their value and there would then be no need to hide any losses. Of course, the Nikkei stock index has dropped by more than half since then, and a lot of brokerage firms ended up absorbing the tobashi losses themselves.
In July 1991, when Japanese brokerage firms acknowledged extensive tobashi dealings, Yamaichi said it had paid some $330 million to reimburse customers. But, somehow, the firm managed to overlook at least $1.6 billion in tobashi losses that were recently uncovered, according to Mitsue Aizawa, Yamaichi's lawyer. The rest of the $2.06 billion in losses Yamaichi reported to the ministry on Nov. 17 resulted from foreign currency trading, Ms. Aizawa said
Mr. Mitsuzuka said Monday, "I want to believe there is no other situation," like Yamaichi's, voicing a widespread if probably vain hope shared by much of the Japanese business community.
There is growing concern here that at a time when Japan is desperately seeking to retain its stature as an economic superpower, foreign investors are coming to regard it as a hotbed of scandal and cozy deals that favor Japanese clients.
"You're seeing a pattern here of the chief executives at securities firms saying they will cover their clients' losses because of some trouble and then resigning," said Lawrence Harris, a finance professor at the Marshall School of Business at the University of Southern California. "Since this keeps happening, there are some fundamental control problems that haven't been solved."
This year's version of what is becoming an annual disclosure of questionable activities centered on the Japanese practice of paying off racketeers, known as sokaiya, to keep them from disclosing the peccadilloes of senior executives at annual meetings and threatening harm to other employees and their families Yamaichi was one of the first companies forced to purge its senior ranks because of sokaiya payments, but a string of blue-chip names including Toshiba, Mitsubishi Motors, Mitsubishi Electric and Hitachi are also under investigation.
As for the latest disclosures, Mr. Mitsuzuka said on Monday, "For the time being, I have not received any other report that there is loss-transferring taking place at other companies." He said the first time he heard of such losses at Yamaichi was on Nov. 17, when the firm reported them to the ministry. Asked whether the ministry had any responsibility for the firm's collapse, he said, "I don't recognize that."
Indeed, Yamaichi's off-the-books transactions were not what precipitated its end. The firm and its troubles have been discussed endlessly in the press in the last few months, and its stock price collapsed at one point last week to 58 yen, or about 46 cents. The bad news had made it increasingly difficult for the firm to borrow money, and when it became clear that its longtime ally, Fuji Bank, would not help, the funds dried up.
Yamaichi is closing with $24 billion in liabilities, but officials of the Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan have said they believe that the firm has nearly that amount in assets and that no customers will lose money. The central bank said Monday that it would reimburse customers for any losses.

Pleas in Payoff Case
 TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 25 (Reuters) -- The Nomura Securities Company, its former president and two other former senior executives pleaded guilty today to charges of giving 369 million yen, or about $2.9 million, to a corporate racketeer.
A senior Nomura executive representing the firm told a Tokyo court that the company itself had paid money to the racketeer in 1995. Hideo Sakamaki, a former Nomura president; Nobutaka Fujikura, a former managing director, and Shinpei Matsuki, another former senior executive, also pleaded guilty to charges of making payoffs.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fallout from Yamaichi Weighs on Markets
The formal announcement of the failure of Yamaichi Securities heightened the concerns about Asia's financial turmoil that have weighed on global stock markets for nearly a month. Following drops on European markets, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 113.15 points, or 1.4 percent, to 7,767.92, while the broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks dropped 16.42 points, or 1.7 percent, to 946.67. 
 The stocks of some companies that have exposure to Asia fell, including Citicorp, J. P. Morgan, Chase Manhattan, Applied Materials and Microsoft. Those stocks rallied sharply last week as investors seemed to discount the Asian impact. Page D10.
 
Treasury prices fell on concerns over how Japanese investors will react to the failure of Yamaichi. Some investors were concerned yesterday that Japanese banks and brokerage firms would need to sell United States securities to bolster their finances. D20.
 
Asia's economic troubles were at the center
of discussions at the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting in Vancouver, British Columbia. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan, left, and President Kim Young Sam of South Korea enjoyed a light moment before the start of yesterday's session. President Clinton told the two leaders that while the United States and international organizations could help, they would have to take painful steps on their own to recover. A1.

Accounting Seeks to Draw a Line
The changes now sweeping the accounting industry make questions over potential conflicts even more pressing. The concern is that investors may lose faith in the integrity of the public audit. Market Place. D10.
 
Telemundo Purchase Set
Sony Pictures will take control of programming for Telemundo Group, the Spanish-language network, after a group that includes Sony, Liberty Media and two investment firms complete the acquisition for $539 million. It will be the first move by Sony of Japan into television broadcasting in the United States. D8.
 
Dell Earnings Jump 71%
Third-quarter earnings at Dell Computer rose 71 percent, to 69 cents a share, topping analysts' expectations by 4 cents. The direct marketer of computers continued to grow at more than three times the industry rate during the quarter and jumped to the No. 2 market position in the United States, behind Compaq Computer. Worldwide, it ranks third behind Compaq and I.B.M. D2.
 
F.D.A. Approves Diet Drug
The Food and Drug Administration approved the first new obesity drug since a ban on Redux and fen-phen. The drug, Meridia, made by the Knoll Pharmaceutical Company, is "moderately effective" at helping patients shed pounds, the F.D.A. said. A19.
 
Ad Agencies Vie for Levi's
Levi Strauss has selected five agencies to compete for its $90 million domestic jeans account, including the incumbent shop of 67 years, the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, but strains have appeared in that relationship because of personnel changes. Stuart Elliott: Advertising D8
 
U.S. Economy Sound
A report from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development says the United States economy looks well balanced in its seventh year of growth, with surprisingly low inflation despite tight labor markets. D4]
 
Gas Prices Increase 2%
Gasoline futures prices jumped almost 2 percent amid forecasts for record highway travel during the Thanksgiving holiday week as retail gas prices hover close to their lowest levels this year. D17.
 
Monitor Set for Teamsters
The Justice Department and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have reached an agreement in which a Federal monitor will oversee the union's spending and keep an eye out for any improper expenditures. A1.

HEADLINE: Hanging Out With the Mall;
Stamford Youths Get Jobs, Advice and Respect

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 24

 BODY:
It is a law of nature that things end up, if at all possible, in places where they are not wanted. Ants invade picnics, popcorn slips between the teeth and teen-agers converge on shopping malls.
And so it is that mall managers deal each day with squadrons of giggling, shouting and sometimes menacing adolescents on the prowl. 
 But here at the Stamford Town Center, things are oddly peaceful, in large part because of the gentle intercessions of two social workers hired by the mall. They approach loitering or misbehaving teen-agers and help them find something to do -- something other than hanging around the mall.
The pair, who patrol the mall after school and on weekends, offer teen-agers an opportunity to enroll in a course on how to get a job at the mall, if that appeals to them. Or the teen-agers may be offered lists of sports and other activities available to them around Stamford, as well as help in enrolling.
On a recent afternoon, an exuberant curse burst from a 15-year-old boy, provoking a whispered but firm reprimand from Ronald A. Miller, one of the workers and by now a familiar presence to local teen-agers. "Oh. Sorry, man," the boy said, and he seemed to mean it.
Three years after the mall began its unusual effort to deal with constant, unruly mobs of teen-agers, the profanity was the toughest problem of the day.
"If you treat young people as if they have brains and they're honorable, they will react accordingly," said Al Messer, the mall's manager. "They see through baloney and they see through smoke and mirrors. I think they really see us as being on their side."
That was clearly not the case three years ago, he said, when both the city and the mall were searching for ways to reduce the high rate of crimes by teen-agers.
"If you acted up in the center, we just kicked you out," he said. "It was us against you and, 'In your face!' "
When Mr. Miller made his first foray into the society of mall adolescents, his mission was simple: find out what they wanted. But the teen-agers quickly sized him up and told him how things were going to be, he recalled.
"The kids thought it was their mall," Mr. Miller said. "They controlled it."
The presence of a vast number of aimless teen-agers was both incongruous and intimidating to the high-end shoppers the mall hoped to attract with stores like Saks, Brooks Brothers and Burberrys.
"You didn't have the luxury of sitting in peace because the kids were always yelling, and older people felt unsafe," Mr. Miller said as he looked down on the amphitheater at the center of the vertical mall, where a handful of shoppers rested peacefully on the steps.
"The first day, I got hammered," he said.
Mr. Miller, 37, who in addition to his part-time job at the mall works as an inspector for the city's Health Department, persisted. He had grown up in Stamford with children just like that. "I listened to what they wanted," he said. "They wanted a place to go and they wanted jobs."
But they did not trust adults and they did not believe that he would help them, Mr. Miller said. The turning point came after several long months during which he and his former partner, Marcia McNeil-Major, were generally rebuffed.
The key was winning over one tough-talking teen-ager who "gave us hell from Day One," Mr. Miller said. If Mr. Miller approached, he recalled, the boy would stalk off, muttering, "I don't want to hear that."
But after learning that the boy liked to lift weights, Mr. Miller and his partner arranged to take a group of teen-agers to the local Gold's Gym once a week for free. The boy signed on.
"We went every Thursday, rain or shine," Mr. Miller said. A year later, the boy was working in the mall and had two jobs, Mr. Miller said.
It is difficult to measure the program's results precisely, but logs kept by the two social workers indicate that they are having some success. In 1995, they recorded 409 disturbances caused by teen-agers, but only 134 in 1996, a 67 percent drop. Statistics for 1997 have not yet been compiled.
The workers broke up only 113 large groups of teen-agers in 1996, down from 421 in 1995. Each time, the teen-agers are reminded of the mall's first rule: "Shop, eat, look for a job or leave the mall."
The harshness of the edict is softened, however, by the list of options offered outside the mall. Information and frequently transportation are provided regarding city programs, jobs, careers, teen-age parties, social services and even an Explorer Scout program.
But while the numbers indicate fewer problems with teen-agers, those who do come are not necessarily happy about their plight.
"Just because we're young and in a group, they treat us like we're not customers," said Diana Gonzalez, 16. "They're always kicking us out of everywhere."
Perhaps because the mall works with the Urban League, it has avoided accusations of racism that have been leveled against other malls' attempts to deal with teen-agers.
Two years ago, a black teen-ager from Buffalo was killed crossing a highway to get to a mall in a nearby suburb that barred inner-city buses from entering its property. Buses from suburban towns and from Canada were allowed in. Officials of the mall, the Walden Galleria, said they had been trying to prevent inner-city crime from reaching the mall.
The furor caused by the death of the teen-ager, Cynthia Wiggins, 17, forced the Walden Galleria and two other suburban malls to allow access for city buses.
And in Trumbull, Conn., which borders economically troubled Bridgeport, officials of the Trumbull Shopping Park fought a three-year battle with the Greater Bridgeport Transit District to stop buses from discharging passengers near the mall on Friday and Saturday nights. An arbitrator ruled in 1995 that the mall had the right to limit bus service. Mall managers had argued that they were trying to deal with the security problems created by hordes of teen-agers congregating on weekend nights.
At the Stamford Town Center, it was Mr. Messer, the mall's manager, along with Andrew D. McBride, the director of Stamford's Heath Department, who came up the idea of hiring social workers to help teen-agers who hang out at the mall. It was part of a grant proposal the city made to the state in 1994 to cut down on teen-age violence and delinquency.
The city did not get the grant, but Mr. Messer liked the mall's part of the project so much that he hired two "youth outreach workers" anyway. It costs the mall about $40,000 a year. The mall job-training program, run in conjunction with the Urban League, costs $45,000 more. About 200 teen-agers have been steered into the job program, and many have gone to work at the mall.
And over the years, all the mall's security guards have been instructed to deal with teen-agers respectfully. "We don't want them to precipitate something themselves, just by their attitude," said Roy Schiffer, the director of security. "We don't want people just hassled out of here. It's officer friendly, but officer resolute."
Mr. Miller's current partner on teen patrol is Lorie Miller (no relation), a 37-year-old social worker and artist with a friendly, quiet manner. "Our approach is always respectful," she said as she moved toward a group of girls hanging out just beyond the glass doors that lead to the parking deck, a popular spot to try to sneak a cigarette.
"Are you smoking? That's so bad for you," she said with half a smile and then asked the girls why they were there. The complaint reflected teen-age frustration: "There's nowhere else to go in this town!"
Ms Miller was sympathetic, and she told the girls that if anyone treated them unfairly, they could go to her and she would intercede. But for now, they had to break up into smaller groups and move on. "I know that right behind me is security," she confided to them. "If you don't leave, they're going to kick you out."
Later, Diana Gonzalez pronounced herself satisfied. "I think that was nice," she said. "She understands."
Ms. Miller said she knew she would run into the girls again and would remember them. And she hopes they will remember her.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Lorie Miller, a social worker hired by Stamford Town Center, tells young people that they cannot congregate but that she will step in if anyone is unfair to them. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)(pg. B1); Ronald A. Miller, a social worker at the Stamford Town Center, talks with three youths after quieting them on the escalator. Incidents involving teen-agers have dropped sharply. "I listened to what they wanted," he said. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PRESSES ASIANS AT SUMMIT ON FISCAL TURMOIL

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia Nov. 24

 BODY:
A day after describing the spreading economic turmoil in Asia as a mere glitch, President Clinton met today with leaders of the region's largest countries to deliver a tougher message, telling them that while the United States and international organizations could help, they would have to take painful steps on their own to recover.
Mr. Clinton held back-to-back meetings with the leaders of Indonesia, China, Japan and South Korea, four nations that represent the full range of economic, geopolitical and human rights issues driving American policy in Asia. 
 Against a backdrop of escalating trouble in Japan's financial system, continuing jitters in stock and currency markets worldwide and the likelihood that Asia's woes will slow global economic growth, Mr. Clinton emphasized to his counterparts that the solution to the region's economic problems had to start with more prudent policies at home, White House officials said.
In particular, Mr. Clinton told Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto that Japan needed to deregulate its economy, strengthen its ailing banking system and pursue an economic recovery built on domestic demand and not cheaper exports. Mr. Clinton emphasized that strengthening Japan economically was crucial to restoring stability across Asia.
"We just want to be in a position to be supportive when we can," Mr. Clinton said. "But I think Japan can lead Asia out of this difficulty with the strength of its economy."
He said all the leaders should work with the United States in pressing developing countries to take part in plans to curb emissions of pollutants and reduce the dangers to the environment from global warming.
To President Jiang Zemin of China and to President Suharto of Indonesia, Mr. Clinton again raised longstanding American concerns about human rights. He welcomed the release last week by Beijing of Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent dissident, and pressed for further releases. And he raised with Mr. Suharto American unhappiness about the treatment of ethnic minorities in East Timor and about the repressive nature of the Indonesian Government.
Mr. Clinton spoke about "the need for countries like Indonesia to deal with how to accommodate order and liberty and to create the correct balance as they develop," said Samuel R. Berger, his national security adviser. "In the new information world, provisions need to be made for people who move to the beat of a different drummer."
Asked how Mr. Suharto responded, Mr. Berger said he "did not respond to that directly."
The sessions dominated the first of two days of meetings among the leaders of the 18 members of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. While Mr. Clinton and his counterparts from other nations continued to stress the region's resiliency and underlying strengths, their conversations here were tinged by deep concern that the financial turmoil had not yet been brought under control and could still permanently tarnish its standing as a driving force in the global economy.
Administration officials dismissed concerns that Japan could follow South Korea as the next country to need an international financial bailout. But they said the situation warranted acute international attention to prevent a further spread of instability. They said finance ministers from many of the affected nations would meet in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, next week and again in Japan in January.
"My view is that we should approach this with determination, but with confidence," Mr. Clinton said.
Administration officials said the Asian leaders Mr. Clinton met with all endorsed the American-backed strategy for dealing with the crisis.
The strategy calls for the International Monetary Fund to take the lead role in dealing with any countries that need international financial assistance. It also allows countries in a region to put together backup pools of financial help if I.M.F. assistance proves insufficient. And it calls on nations to enact more prudent economic policies in return for receiving international assistance.
Hanging heavy over today's proceedings was the failure of Japan's fourth-largest securities firm, Yamaichi Securities Company. It was the second failure of a major financial institution in Japan in recent weeks, and it heightened concerns that Asia's spreading woes could lead to further failures among Japan's beleaguered banks and set back Japan's already faltering efforts to spur its economy.
American officials said Mr. Hashimoto did not provide Mr. Clinton with any details of his plans to deal with the banking crisis beyond emphasizing protection of depositors rather than financial institutions. But Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said the United States was satisfied with the Japanese Government's statement that it would take the "necessary steps to contain the effects" of the Yamaichi collapse.
American officials also reported progress on another of the economic issues facing them in the region, negotiating the terms under which China would join the World Trade Organization, the body that sets the rules for international commerce.
Administration officials said China had made a "significant" new offer to the United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, in the last several days, and that Presidents Clinton and Jiang had directed their trade ministries to follow up with further talks. The officials did not provide any details of the new offer.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Clinton Tells Asians They Must Fix Economies
President Clinton told the leaders of East Asia's largest nations that they would have to take painful steps of their own to recover from recent economic turmoil. A1 

Troubling Figures From Korea
The head of South Korea's central bank contended that "the worst of the situation" was almost over for his country's troubled economy, but statistics he released suggested that the $20 billion bailout South Korea sought last week from the International Monetary Fund would not be enough. He blamed South Korea's own financial institutions for excessive lending to conglomerates. A10
 
Chinese Dissident Disunity
A prominent dissident in Beijing criticized Wei Jingsheng, who was released from a Chinese jail a week ago after being held political prisoner for most of the past 18 years. The critic said Mr. Wei had demonstrated a lack of understanding of democracy by acting like a tyrant in his first few days of freedom. In an open letter, Xu Wenli accused Mr. Wei of being headstrong, arrogant and too soft on Deng Xiaoping. A12
 
Russia Presses on Iraq
Russia stepped up pressure to hasten the process of declaring Iraq free of prohibited weapons, seeking to block any Security Council action on the subject of Iraqi compliance with the United Nations unless emphasis was placed on progress. But the move has prompted the United States to stiffen its resistance. A6
 
 
United States military and intelligence officials said Iraq had spied on United Nations weapons inspectors, learning in advance of the team's targets and moving swiftly to hide suspected weapons caches. A1
 
Afghan Moves Against Heroin
Leaders of the Taliban, the Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan, have agreed to uproot poppy crops in part of the country and to destroy heroin laboratories. The Taliban also proposed eradicating all poppy cultivation within one year, but this schedule was rejected as too radical by the head of the United Nations drug control agency. A3
 
Tense South Africa Testimony
Witnesses testified about atrocities allegedly carried out by Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, the former wife of President Nelson Mandela, as part of a weeklong hearing before South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is investigating apartheid-era crimes. Testimony addressed accusations that Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela had a role in as many as a dozen murders. A9
 
Trial of Zimbabwe Politician
An opposition leader, Ndabaningi Sithole, went on trial in Zimbabwe, charged with trying to assassinate President Robert Mugabe and to overthrow his Government. While Mr. Sithole pleaded not guilty, two other men arrested in the case pleaded guilty and are expected to be the chief witnesses against him. Mr. Sithole pulled out of presidential elections last March, accusing Mr. Mugabe's Government of infiltrating his party in an effort to destroy him. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A14-23
 
U.S. and Teamsters Agree To Monitor Union Spending
The Justice Department and the teamsters' union reached an unusual agreement in which a Federal financial monitor would oversee the union's spending and keep an eye out for any improper expenditures. The agreement is an embarrassing setback for the union's efforts to show that the teamsters have rid themselves of corruption. A1
 
Astronauts Grab Satellite
An satellite that went out of control when it was released last week by the crew of the shuttle Columbia was pulled back aboard after two astronauts grabbed the slowly tumbling spacecraft with their hands. A16
 
1996 Elections Were Costliest
The 1996 elections were the most expensive in history, with $2.2 billion having been spent by the two major political parties, political action committees and political groups. A18
 
New Diet Drug Approved
The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first new obesity drug since a ban on two popular diet aids left many overweight Americans clamoring for help, but the new medicine also poses a risk. The drug, Meridia, is "moderately effective" at helping patients shed pounds, the agency said. But Meridia can cause increases in blood pressure and pulse rate that may endanger certain patients, the F.D.A. warned. A19
 
A Session-Ending Tradition
Representative Christopher Smith, a New Jersey Republican, has made a small tradition of injecting debate about the contentious issue of abortion just as Congress prepares to end its sessions. This year he tried to cut off all Federal money for abortions abroad in a move clearly meant to mollify conservatives. A23
 
Mandatory Jail Terms Studied
A study in Massachusetts has shown that when long, mandatory jail terms are imposed on drug offenders, most of them tend to be black and Hispanic and nearly half have no record of violent crime. A14

Manhattan Gets Closer To a 2d Area Code
The state's Public Service Commission is expected to approve a plan today adding a second area code, 646, for any new phone connections in Manhattan, beginning in 1998. SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 579 words

HEADLINE: Footlights

BYLINE: By RON WERTHEIMER 

 BODY:

NEWS
Encore!
 
Since 1977, the pianist Emanuel Ax has been a frequent soloist with the New York Philharmonic. The 48-year-old Mr. Ax, who played Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 20 in his Philharmonic debut, will celebrate its 20th anniversary by performing another of the composer's concertos, No. 22, in five concerts with the orchestra: tomorrow, Friday, Saturday and Monday evenings and Dec. 2. Zdenek Macal will conduct the program, which is to include works by Smetana and Schumann. 

Selecting a Gender Bender
 
Israel will be represented in next year's Eurovision song contest by a transsexual pop star named Dana International. An 11-member committee of the Israel Broadcasting Authority chose Ms. International to compete with 15 other singers in Birmingham, England, in May. The annual competition offers prizes and wide television exposure. The choice of the singer drew quick condemnation from the Orthodox religious establishment in Israel. The selection "proves that our battle against debauchery is justified," said Moshe Mimni, secretary general of the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. The party has demanded that the Government rescind the selection. Dana International, 29, who is known for her revealing outfits as well as her singing, underwent sex-change surgery five years ago. Since she started singing in 1994, her popularity has spilled beyond Israel's borders, becoming, well, international. Six million of her albums have been sold clandestinely in Egypt, despite a formal ban by the authorities.
 
Literary Late Bloomers
 
The novels of James A. Michener would overflow a good-size shelf, but he began his writing career relatively late in life. He was about 40 when his first book, "Tales of the South Pacific," was published in 1947, winning a Pulitzer Prize, inspiring a Broadway musical and leading to some 40 more works, many of them best sellers -- like "Hawaii," "Texas" and "Space" -- that blended history and histrionics. Mr. Michener died last month, and his longtime publisher, Random House, has established a fellowship to honor his memory while encouraging other midlife beginners. Each winner of the James A. Michener Memorial Prize, who must have published a first book at age 40 or later, will receive $10,000 a year for five years. The prize is to be administered by the Texas Center for Writers, which Mr. Michener and his wife, Mari, endowed at the University of Texas at Austin. Random House and the center will establish a group of nominators, who will submit names of deserving writers to a panel chosen by the Center for Writers, with the prizes announced annually on Mr. Michener's birthday, Feb. 3, beginning in 1999.
 
Budget Spying
 
Even James Bond may not be crafty enough to outfox the British economy. Sequences filmed in London for the latest 007 movie -- "Tomorrow Never Dies," due for release next month -- were too expensive, said the film's producer, Michael Wilson. He cited the strong pound and the country's "unfavorable" taxes, adding that MGM might urge that the next Bond thriller be shot elsewhere. "If there are other countries which are cheaper, it will be hard to remain here," Mr. Wilson told The Sunday Times of London. Shooting for the next and 19th Bond picture is to begin in December 1999. RON WERTHEIMER

A new biography of Jane Austen reveals a tough, humorous and highly resourceful woman. Books of the Times, page 8.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Time for Repairs

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
President Clinton and the people he chose to help him steer American foreign policy have steered it straight into a collision that left it a near-wreck.
The collision was not as much between the U.S. and Iraq as between Mr. Clinton's policies and America's own best interests. 
 The question now is whether the Administration has the fortitude to see where it steered off the road and make repairs in time for Saddam Hussein's next challenge. He is preparing it now.
It was, and is, in American interests to keep Saddam in the "box," as Clintonians call the squeeze of sanctions, containment and world opinion against him. The box was hurting Saddam's regime so badly that he risked American military attack to try to get out of it.
He did, by showing the world that Mr. Clinton would exact no price, exercise no power against him during or after the three weeks he had ousted the U.N. inspection system and threatened its existence.
It was in the best interests of America to keep control of the struggle against Saddam in peace as it did in war. Instead, the Administration permitted Russia to make a deal with Saddam to weaken and then dismantle the inspections and the sanctions that kept him in the box.
It was in the best interests of America to keep Russia from again becoming a major player in the Middle East. Instead it handed Russia that role, free of price or protest.
It was in the best interests of the U.S. not to desert Israel, its one reliable Mideast ally over the past half-century, as it tries to reach a peace with the Palestinians that might protect Israel from attack by terrorists or hostile armies.
Instead, the Administration harasses, insults and pressures Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, to force him to abandon insistence on a peace based on Israeli-Palestinian reciprocity of carrying out commitments.
The U.S. endorsed the concept of reciprocity in a letter to Mr. Netanyahu when Israel gave up control of Hebron. Now Martin Indyk, Assistant Secretary of State for Middle East affairs, denounces Israel for insisting on it.
And from the sides of their mouths, Clinton people try to make Israel a world scapegoat. They imply that Israel -- not Iraq, not Russia or China or France, not the Arab states -- broke up the wartime coalition.
Nobody sane thinks Saddam will take the Iraqi people out of their troubles by suddenly doing what he promised his conquerors to do almost seven years ago -- turn over all plans, plants and stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction.
But if inspections and sanctions are removed, within two years he could re-create the nuclear weapons capacity that U.N. inspectors needed seven years to discover and damage. And he would expand the stockpiles of biological and chemical weaponry he is utterly determined to keep.
Already, with inspection resumed only a few days, Bill Richardson, U.S. representative to the U.N., charges that Iraq is still preventing inspectors from getting into the 63 suspected weapon sites that Iraq calls presidential property.
At a moment he selects, Saddam will again try to destroy the whole inspection system. Russia is doing his advance work -- trying to close the nuclear and missile investigations and rush the germ and chemical warfare investigations to an end.
To keep Saddam boxed means the U.S. would have to tell him that rather than permit him to kill the inspection system it would go to war against him. It would have to tell Russia, France and China to choose now between bolstering Saddam or supporting the U.S; no double scoops.
Richard Butler, the Australian head of the investigation commission, calls Iraq the test case for arms control agreements, and the hope they will bring a world free of the danger of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons.
But the Iraqi case also shows how hard it is for inspectors to uncover and destroy those weapons, when they are hidden and protected by a killer regime, even after its defeat in war.
The American interest is to remember both realities. That means a new policy -- to carry on fiercely with international inspection and fight militarily for its survival the next time he jumps out of the box, to warn off Saddam's new allies, and stand ready to help Iraqis end Saddam and his regime. Repairs never come cheap.

HEADLINE: The Age of Indulgence;
Self-Denial Takes a Holiday

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
GET ready for the big one.
By tradition, Americans throw their diets right out the window on Thanksgiving Day, the starting line in a marathon of overeating that extends through New Year. By the time festive diners have worked their way through holiday dinners, office parties, celebratory lunches, spontaneous after-work cocktail fests and the obligatory year-end blowout, the citizens of the land of the free and the home of the brave have put on enough weight to tilt the earth. This year, the binge could set records. 
 After more than a decade defined by health consciousness, nutritional enlightenment and self-denial, the United States seems to be entering a new phase in its often tortured relationship with food. Many more Americans are just saying yes to brontosaurus-size steaks and high-fat ice cream, the big-finned Cadillacs of American cuisine. They jump into the deep end of crystal-clear martinis and, emerging refreshed, put their collective feet up and ignite large cigars. Perhaps most shocking of all, they are not suffering the pangs of guilt.
Peek in any evening at the goings-on in Churrascaria Plataforma, a Brazilian meat palace in the theater district. Waiters wheel slabs of beef from table to table, slicing as they go. They race between diners brandishing skewers stacked with sausages and roast-turkey chunks. One rolling cart, gaudy as a circus wagon, dispenses high-octane drinks called caipirinhas, while another digs grooves in the floor under the weight of a dozen desserts.
At table after table, large parties of men wear the determined expressions of athletes waiting for the starting gun to go off. Many of them, young and fit-looking, resolved to make a good showing, shed their jackets and throw their ties over their shoulders.
Across town at Maloney & Porcelli, where the offerings make Trimalchio's feast in "Satyricon" look like cuisine minceur, diners are doing their best to hoist five-pound lobsters, family-size pork shanks and giant ribs from an Amazonian fish that looks as if it came straight out of a horror film.
"I think the Dionysian element is taking hold in my life," said Robert Sawyer, a freelance creative director in the advertising business. Mr. Sawyer, 43, a former athlete, used to ride his Italian racing bike in Central Park three or four times a week. The bike has not been out in a long while.
"I'm no longer interested in having fun," he said. "I'm interested in pleasure."
The treadmill is losing its allure. The burn still beckons, but fewer people seem to be going for it. Self-denial does not feel as good as it used to. "The 'no pain, no gain' approach of the 80's and early 90's is now being seriously reviewed by people," said Barbara Caplan, a partner at Yankelovich Partners, a research and consulting company in Norwalk, Conn. Its most recent survey research suggests that Americans still care about nutrition and health. They believe in exercise. But they may be growing tired of the blood, sweat and tears approach to personal fulfillment.
"They're saying, 'I need pleasure, I want pleasure, and I deserve it, without apologies to myself or anybody else,' " Ms. Caplan said.
AN important cultural moment seems to have passed. Its spirit was expressed succinctly in the late 1980's when Michael Douglas snarled, "Lunch is for wimps," at Charlie Sheen in "Wall Street." Winners and beautiful people did not eat. A spartan ethic of self-denial, reflected in films, health magazines and fashion advertising, promoted the idea that food was little more than fuel for the perfectly tuned body, and in a world dripping with toxins, the fuel had to be closely monitored, filtered and purified. An unending flow of detailed information on health and nutrition explained how to do this.
Throughout the era of conspicuous consumption, the elite set a standard of conspicuous culinary denial, ostentatiously subsisting on a small rectangle of poached fish, steamed vegetables and Evian water. Is it any wonder that eating disorders emerged as the American disease par excellence?
After a while, the food not eaten began to look awfully enticing.
For the last 17 years, NPD, a food-research company in Rosemont, Ill., has asked members of 2,000 households whether they agree with the following statement: "The most important thing about food is that it look good, taste good and smell good." From 1985 to 1995, the number of "agree" answers remained stable, at 30 percent. In 1996, without warning, the figure jumped to 36 percent. This year, it went up to 40 percent.
"People are finally admitting something that has always been true," said Harry Balzer, a vice president of NPD. "No matter how nutritious something is, if it doesn't taste good, people are not going to eat it."
In its annual survey of 2,500 consumers nationwide, Yankelovich found a declining interest in nutrition and an increasing tendency to indulge. When subjects were asked whether they paid as much attention to nutrition when they ate out as when they ate at home, 40 percent answered yes in 1994. The figure has declined each year since, dipping to 36 percent a few months ago. The number of respondents who say that weight concerns them has dropped from 37 percent to 29 percent in the last two years. When subjects were asked to rank the things they most wanted to do in the coming year, "Have more fun" topped the list.
"People have decided that stress reduction is more important than an extra inch on your waist or a flabby bicep," said Michael DeLuca, the editor of Restaurant Hospitality, a trade magazine. "Also, a lot of people realized these low-fat products didn't taste very good."
At a recent food-industry conference in Manhattan, Barry Krantz, the president of Krantz Consulting, was asked a simple question: What sells at restaurants? "I'll tell you what sells," he shot back. "Fat, sugar and salt. That's it."
Robert Levithan, a Manhattan psychotherapist in his mid-40's, used to walk a straight and narrow dietary line. Very narrow. "I was the annoying person at a restaurant who would ask if there was sugar in the salad dressing," he said. Now, he shops at Balducci's and feels fine about it. "My diet was an area of discipline rather than indulgence in my life," he said.
The word "indulgence" puts nutritionists on guard. Cathy Nonas, the administrative director of the Van Itallie Center for Nutrition and Weight Management at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan, has watched with some concern as Americans sit down to monster portions and high-fat feasts. "People say, 'I'm going out for a steak dinner,' but that seems to include a martini, and a cheesecake, and fried onion rings and a 16-ounce steak," she said. "It's not necessary, and it's not good for you."
Ms. Caplan, of Yankelovich, says that the shift in attitudes does not suggest a collapse of values, merely a relaxation. "There are times when a spartan approach to eating is something you want," she said. "We're not going to go back to a Roman orgy. But people are saying, 'I want to bring back the pleasure of food into my life.' "
Adding velocity to the pleasure backlash is confusion about the welter of health information. Who can truly claim to understand the intricacies of trans fatty acids? Cholesterol seems to be bad, except when it is good -- or is it the other way around?
"Nutrition has been so fluid," said L. Timothy Ryan, the senior vice president of the Culinary Institute of America. "To take just one example, about 10 years ago, salt was thought to be about as bad as saturated fat, but recent studies suggest that perhaps salt isn't so bad. A lot of people throw up their hands."
IT'S hard to listen, however, when an entire culinary culture looks as though it is being dismantled stone by stone. Like Roman Catholics watching the stained glass, the statues and the paintings being removed from their churches during the Reformation, Americans have seen a precious part of their heritage whittled away. "Some of the basic building blocks of American cooking -- eggs and milk and cheese and beef -- have been under attack for 20 years," said Clark Wolf, a New York restaurant consultant. "It's crazy. There actually are people who think that cheese is bad for you."
It doesn't help that the experts often seem to be scolds. When the public is told that there shall be no more cakes and ale, is it any wonder that they head straight for the bakery or the bar?
"When information is presented in a moralistic or authoritarian way, people resist," said Edward Deci, a psychologist at the University of Rochester. "A lot of the information that comes in is very controlling information."
Mr. Deci, who has studied human motivation for decades, finds that the word "should" usually produces bad results. In a well-known experiment, he had his subjects spend time performing tasks that they enjoyed. Then he began paying them for it. Gradually, they lost interest. A sense of obligation killed their feelings of pleasure.
If "should" can kill pleasure, it isn't going to give an unpleasant task much allure. No wonder the diet industry shows a rate of recidivism that makes the American prison system look like a model of efficiency.
Richard Klein, the author of "Cigarettes Are Sublime" and "Eat Fat," has some radical thoughts on American eating behavior. One of his pet theories is that dieting causes obesity, in part by stoking the fires of obsession. Mere desire grows into a craving and a torment. When willpower breaks down, as it must, the crazed dieter often goes berserk, binging shamelessly.
Janet Polivy and C. Peter Herman, psychologists at the University of Toronto, have studied this "blown-diet syndrome" and found that when nondieters overeat, they simply cut back their intake to normal levels. Dieters, by contrast, feel that an entire regulatory system has collapsed and, behaving like damned souls, eat excessively, in part because dieting has taught them to ignore the body's normal cues signaling hunger and satiety.
At any rate, Mr. Klein says, if people simply ate what they wanted, could things be worse? "If you stop obsessing compulsively about everything you put in your mouth, and eat for pleasure, as the French do, the chances are you will lose weight," he said. Just do it.
Tomorrow, Americans gathered around the dinner table will have a few extra reasons to give thanks. Unemployment is down. The stock market seems to be surviving the jitters. And from now until New Year's Day, the gourmand superhighway seems wide open, with no speed limit or police in sight.
"I'm ready to eat," said Mr. Sawyer, the creative director. "The parties start Thursday."

HEADLINE: A 2-Pound Truffle Takes Flight As a Chef Seizes the Moment

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
ABOUT two weeks ago, Alfredo Landucci, the head of Boscovivo Tartufi in Arezzo, Italy, was awakened at 3 A.M. by a telephone call. It was a truffle hunter who had just pried what seemed to be the mother of all white truffles loose from the damp soil around an oak tree in the hills of Alba, in the truffle-rich Piedmont region.
Was Mr. Landucci interested in buying it? 
 "Give me 20 minutes," Mr. Landucci recalled saying, hesitating just a bit. He called Massimo Vidoni, who heads the company's New York office, at 13 East 37th Street, to see if there might be a buyer in New York. It was 9 P.M. on the East Coast, but this being white truffle season, Mr. Vidoni was still at his desk. The first chef he reached was Rick Moonen at Oceana on East 54th Street.
Mr. Moonen did not hesitate. The truffle was his.
Why had Mr. Vidoni paused? This has been the most frenzied season anyone can remember, perhaps because the booming economy has led to freer spending. Of course there would be a buyer.
"I had to be sure," Mr. Vidoni said. Had it remained in Italy, Mr. Landucci would probably have put it into an auction, and it might have sold for even more than the $3,600 that Oceana paid. (Boscovivo is donating its profit, $300, to a fund for victims of the recent earthquakes in Italy.)
The truffle, once cleaned, looked more like a geologic specimen than a fungus. Intensely fragrant and somewhat gnarled, it weighed in at exactly one kilogram, 2.2 pounds.
A heavyweight champ? Though no truffles, white or black, are listed in the Guinness Book of World Records or industry archives, most experts say that one this large is a true rarity. Mr. Landucci had not seen a truffle approaching this size in more than four years, and it is believed to be almost as large as a white truffle can get.
And when it comes to truffles, bigger is not only more impressive, but probably better, yielding broad, attractive swaths that no normal truffle can match.
White truffles, which are eaten uncooked, have a shelf life of no more than about three weeks. Larger ones often hold up a little longer than smaller ones, especially when they are as hard and dense as this one.
"I find bigger truffles to be more pungent," Mr. Moonen said. This one had an especially rich aroma.
Mr. Landucci, who personally escorted the truffle to New York (imagine the aroma from across the aisle on the eight-hour flight), formally presented it to Mr. Moonen last week at the James Beard House. He said the truffle probably took two to three months to reach full growth.
And though this season started with a sparse initial crop because the weather was dry, some truffle hunters have been finding big ones. About three weeks ago, Boscovivo sold a 1.4-pound truffle to Circo, on West 55th Street, for $1,700.
The season for white truffles ends with the frost, usually by December, which kills any still in the ground.
For four days, Mr. Moonen glorified raw Nantucket bay scallops and risotto with mottled light brown shards that filled the mouth with a taste and perfume both garlicky and nutty. By Saturday, at $20 a portion for an appetizer or $40 for a main course, the truffle was no more.
Mr. Landucci would not reveal the name of the lucky truffle hunter, whose take for an evening's work was 5.5 million lire, about $3,300, any more than the truffle hunter would pinpoint the location of the beneficent oak tree.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reaches a 5-Year High Vs. Yen on Japan's Problems

BYLINE: By Bridge News 

 BODY:
The dollar climbed to a five-year high against the yen yesterday after Japanese traders, returning from a national holiday on Monday, reacted to the closing of the Yamaichi Securities Company, the oldest securities firm in Japan. The dollar rose against the mark after a Bundesbank official suggested German rates would remain steady.
The failure of Yamaichi, although not totally unexpected in Japan, drove home the point that the major financial institutions could no longer expect to be automatically bailed out by the Bank of Japan. 
 In New York trading, a steady flow of rumors that other major Japanese banks were in a dire financial state kept the dollar on a strong footing against the Japanese currency.
"It is a confusing time to trade the Japanese yen," said Jeff Yu, senior dealer at Sanwa Bank in New York. "On one hand, the weakness of the Japanese financial systems warrants a weaker yen; on the other hand, a weaker yen would hurt the U.S. trade deficit even further.
"Since the U.S. stock market is still one of the only stable markets right now, and the U.S. market is still growing under low inflation conditions, I believe that the dollar will gain further against the Japanese yen."
The dollar peaked at 127.96 yen -- its highest level since August 1992. In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 127.07 yen, up from 126.80 late Monday, still finishing at a seven-month high despite its retreat. The dollar was also changing hands at 1.7485 marks, up from 1.7375.
The German mark weakened against the dollar and the Swiss franc after Franz-Christoph Zeitler, a German central bank official, said German monetary policy could remain on hold. The Swiss franc, which is the traditional safe-haven currency, climbed to a fresh 15-month high against the German mark.
The British pound weakened to $1.6772 from $1.6898. The currency accelerated its recent decline after Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, tied the growth of the economy to the success of wage restraint and the welfare-to-work programs.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Prices Hit 12 1/2-Year Low On British Official's Remarks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Gold fell to a 12 1/2-year low yesterday after Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, said that a new European central bank would not need much gold in its reserves.
In other markets, orange juice plunged as Florida weather warmed and grains tumbled. 
 Unlike cash or securities, gold does not pay interest or dividends, the main reason Mr. George, speaking in Brussels Monday, said he would be "surprised" if the European central bank would hold much gold as Europe prepares for economic and monetary union in 1999.
"The comments from George were enough to knock prices down a few dollars," said Bridget Fraser, vice president of commodity-based derivatives at the Bankers Trust Company in New York.
Gold for December delivery fell $3.40 an ounce, or 1.1 percent, to $300.50, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest since March 1985.
Central banks of the 15-member European Union hold more than 10,000 tons of gold, 10 percent of government reserves worldwide.
Mr. George's comments were another blow for gold prices, which have fallen 19 percent this year as some central banks unloaded part of their reserves.
Mr. George would not be involved in setting the new European central bank's gold policy because Britain is not initially joining the economic and currency union.
Orange juice plunged 3.6 percent as temperatures warmed in Florida, reducing concern that the state's groves could be damaged by frost.
A cold air mass that settled last week on central Florida, the state's major orange-growing region, has moved out and temperatures are expected to be mild for the next two weeks, said Mike Palmerino, a meteorologist at the Weather Services Corporation in Lexington, Mass.
The mild weather raises the likelihood that farmers will pick a crop forecast by the Department of Agriculture at 254 million 90-pound boxes, which would be a record and up 12 percent from last season.
Orange juice for January delivery fell 2.95 cents, to 79.8 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Corn dropped and wheat reached a four-month low as slow demand prompted traders to sell contracts.
Corn for December delivery fell 3 cents a bushel, or 1.1 percent, to $2.7025 on the Chicago Board of Trade. December wheat slid 5.25 cents a bushel, or 1.5 percent, to $3.35 a bushel, the lowest since July 21.

HEADLINE: Gain Reported In Confidence Of Consumers

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Consumer confidence increased in November, while home resales rose in October, suggesting that the economy could end the year on an unexpected high note.
The last two months have seen sharp movements in stock prices in the United States, Asia and elsewhere, and turmoil in Asian economies. But "confidence has barely been dented by the drop in stock prices and the events in Asia," said Ian Shepherdson, chief economist at HSBC Securities in New York. "The housing market is responding in textbook fashion to lower mortgage rates." 
 The Conference Board, a business research group in New York, said today that its index of consumer confidence rose to 128.3 in November, the third-highest reading this year. October's index was revised upward to 123.4 from 123.3. A separate index of consumer confidence, calculated by the University of Michigan, also increased this month, rising to 107.2 from 105.6 in October.
A second economic report showed that home resales climbed in October for the third consecutive month, rising 2.1 percent, to a record annual rate of 4.4 million units.
With unemployment at its lowest level in a quarter century, "consumers are feeling pretty flush as the holiday season approaches," said Bill Cheney, an economist at John Hancock in Boston. "The Fed must be feeling increasing pressure to stay ahead of the curve, but they also don't want to play the Grinch before Christmas."
If the Federal Reserve's policy makers fear that the economy is growing fast enough to cause an acceleration in inflation, they might consider raising interest rates.
In its report, the Conference Board also said an index gauging consumer expectations for the next six months rose to 107.9 in November from 107.3 in October. An index tracking consumers' assessment of present conditions increased to 158.9 from 147.5, the highest reading since 1969.
Lynn Franco, a Conference Board researcher, said: "Recent turmoil on Wall Street and world financial markets, along with continuing layoff announcements, have not dampened consumer confidence. Consumers continue to express confidence about the health of the U.S. economy and expect these favorable conditions to continue well into 1998."
That could bode well for retailers. Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said sales during the holiday shopping season would probably rise a healthy 4.5 percent nationwide from last year. "I can't see anything on the economic horizon that would keep this shopping season from being a strong one," he said.
Consumer confidence could falter, of course, if another bout of turmoil sweeps Wall Street or if fallout from Asia's economic crisis spills into this country's economy. "Common sense almost dictates a decline in confidence," said Nick Perna, chief economist at the Fleet Financial Group in Hartford.
In the report on home resales during October, the National Association of Realtors said that resales rose 6.6 percent in the Midwest and 6.5 percent in the West. They were unchanged in the South and fell 4.5 percent in the Northeast. The figures represent actual closings, which lag behind contract signings by a few months.
"We have been surprised at the strength of the housing market all year, and with record levels over the last two months, sales were expected to ease slightly," said the association's president, Layne Morrill. "Clearly, the high level of consumer confidence in a strong economy with low interest rates is bringing more people into the market than many expected."

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Subway Crime, on the Rise

 BODY:
Crime may be falling in New York City, but it is rising in the city's subways. It is still nearly 70 percent below the 1990 level, and crimes that occur on subways and buses constitute a mere 2.5 percent of all crime committed in the populous five boroughs. But whatever level of comfort one derives from those realities, this is a problem that needs to be squelched before it undermines the public's rebounding confidence in mass transit.
Police Commissioner Howard Safir's decision to boost transit patrol strength from 2,200 to 2,500 last month was a prudent response. That effort ought to be sustained, particularly since the police cannot yet say definitively that these recent upticks are just transient blips. 
 What catches the eye in comparisons of January-through-October figures for 1996 and 1997 is not homicide. There were three in that period last year and four this year. No reasonable person would consider that 33 percent increase statistically meaningful. But the spikes in robbery (up 4.3 percent), pickpocketing and related acts of larceny (up 23 percent) are worrisome. These increases, which hit this summer and have lasted about four months, come at a time when the city's overall crime rate has continued to decline and when riders are turning in great numbers to rapid transit.
The Giuliani administration has not been bashful about claiming credit for bringing the crime rate down. That gives it an obligation to also be forthcoming in explaining the latest rises in crime. Beyond that, the administration should provide more useful data about transit crime, not just aggregate numbers but data about crime on specific lines and stations at particular times of day. Such information, distributed frequently, ought to be as easy to scan as stock tables and box scores.
With more than three million rides a day, rapid transit is more than a service that moves people to and from work, school and play. The subway system is perhaps the most underrated democratic space in the city, where people, regardless of culture and economic circumstance, mingle. Protecting the 468 stations and 722 miles of passenger track not only increases ridership but also safeguards the social experiment called New York.

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE U.S. INVESTORS;
Government Bond Funds Receiving Influx of Cash

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Mutual fund investors turned their backs on overseas stock funds in October and instead sought the shelter of United States Government bond funds, which received new cash for the first time in four years.
Fund shareholders continue, of course, to favor funds that invest in American stocks. So far this month, money has poured into those funds at Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, the two largest fund companies, as well as at Charles Schwab & Company, which sells mutual funds from hundreds of smaller companies. 
 The money entering funds has slowed somewhat from last month, but "that's not surprising," said Brian Mattes, a Vanguard vice president, given the recent volatility in the domestic and foreign stock markets. In addition, he said, "investors usually hesitate to buy until after most funds have paid out distributions" of capital gains and dividends, which for most fund companies occurs in early to mid-December.
Until last month, investors had remained similarly steadfast in their love for international and global stock funds, despite their having been battered for months by Asian currency devaluations and unstable equity markets that stretched from the Pacific Rim through Latin America to Eastern Europe.
Tutored by fund companies and investment advisers to diversify by sending money to the far corners of the globe, Americans this year added an average of $4 billion a month to international stock funds, which invest only outside the United States, and global funds, which can also buy American stocks.
In October, however, only $1.3 million trickled into international and global funds, according to figures released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group. Not since December 1990, when $55.9 million flowed out of the group, have overseas stock funds suffered a worse month.
Meanwhile, Government bond funds, once the largest category of fixed-income mutual funds, received $187 million in net new cash in October, the trade group reported. That ended a string of months in which money flowed out of the Government funds that stretched back to October 1993, shortly before the Federal Reserve moved to raise interest rates.
As money dribbled out of Government bond funds over the last four years, and as the returns from fixed-income investments have lagged behind those of equities, other categories of bond funds have become more popular with investors, particularly those specializing in high-yield or junk bonds and municipal bonds.
Funds investing in fixed-income securities with high current yields accounted for the biggest portion of the cash flows to fixed-income funds all year, including in October, when all bond funds received $3.7 billion, about even with the previous month.
Those latest developments overseas and at home apparently did little to dampen investors' enthusiasm for American stock funds, which received a revised $18.2 billion in new investments last month, the fourth-highest total so far in 1997.
Previously, the trade group had estimated that stock funds of all types had added $21 billion last month, which would have been the third-highest inflow of the year. While the revised figure is down from September's intake of $25.7 billion, it remained above the October 1996 figure of $13.5 billion.
As expected, the October cash flows left the total collected by stock funds so far in 1997 ahead of last year's record pace. In the first 10 months of 1997, investors added $195.6 billion to their stock fund investments, bringing the total assets of the funds to $2.3 trillion. In the period last year, stock funds took in $192.5 billion, on their way to a record 12-month total of $221.4 billion.
The two largest fund companies reported that the cash has continued to flow this month, although at slower rates than before the stock market's late-October slump.
Fidelity and Vanguard each expect their stock funds to receive $1.5 billion in new investments in November, officials at those companies said yesterday. At Vanguard, that is about half the level recorded in October, said Mr. Mattes.
But T. Rowe Price reported that domestic stock funds are attracting more new money this month than last, while international funds continue to lose money.
At Schwab, whose Mutual Fund Marketplace serves as a primary distributor for the funds of hundreds of companies, net flows into all stock funds measured about $330 million so far in November, about half the level of last month, with the largest flows into the most conservative stock funds like growth and income funds, which invest in blue-chip stocks that typically pay dividends.
Bond funds, however, have added to their take, gaining $291 million in net new cash so far in November, up from $170 million for all of October.

HEADLINE: Baghdad Risks New Sanctions Or Even an Attack, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Secretary of Defense William Cohen said today that Iraq "continues to evade and to deceive" United Nations weapons inspectors and that its defiance could lead to still-tighter sanctions or a military attack.
He called the confrontation over Iraq's suspected caches of biological and chemical weaponry "a long-term problem," one that will last "as long as Saddam Hussein adopts the attitude that he's going to try to inhibit or restrict" the inspectors. 
 Until that resistance ends, Mr. Cohen said, the Iraqi leader "cannot expect any light at the end of the tunnel" in his quest to end the political and economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations against Iraq after its 1990 invasion of Kuwait in 1990. The United States wants those sanctions kept in force until the weapons inspectors certify that Iraq has been effectively disarmed.
Iraq must let the weapons inspectors into 63 sites it has defined as Presidential palaces and declared off-limits, Mr. Cohen warned. If it does not, he said, Iraq may face punishment.
This might include even stricter sanctions, he said. The United Nations might tell President Hussein: "There'll be no relief at any time in the future,"' he said, or, as a last resort, Iraq might face a military attack. "I think you can be reasonably assured it will not be a pinprick," the Secretary said.
"At this point, there's no need to put Iraq under any sort of a deadline," he said. "I think it'll become clear in the coming weeks as to whether or not Saddam Hussein is going to continue to deny access to the palaces. The proof we will find either in the palaces or in the pudding or in the poisons."
Mr. Cohen, releasing an annual report on the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons, said Iraq's hidden arsenal exemplify a "clear and present danger today, one that's only going to grow with time." He said more than 25 countries possess or are working on such weapons.
The report detailed the capabilities of 12 nations: Russia, China, Iran, Iraq, North Korea, India, Pakistan, Libya, Syria and three former Soviet states -- Ukraine, Kazakhstan and Belarus. It did not list the capabilities of old allies like Britain or Israel.
The United States and Russia still possess the world's largest nuclear arsenals. Russia has "the world's largest stockpile of chemical agents: 40,000 metric tons" or more, the report said, and parts of the former Soviet Union's biological weapons program remain intact, though the Russian Government has said it will be eliminated.
The United States formally abandoned its biological weapons program in 1969 and is slowly destroying its formidable chemical-weapons stockpile. Mr. Cohen has added $1 billion to the defense budget requested from Congress for defenses against biological and chemical weapons. He said Pentagon planners assume that biological and chemical attacks are likely in wars to come.
The report released today said the post-cold war world posed "a paradox" for those planners: "American military superiority actually increases the threat of nuclear, biological and chemical attack against us."
Nor is Iraq the sole threat.
For example, if war came to the Korean peninsula, the report said, North Korea, outgunned by South Korean and United States forces, would be likely to use chemical weapons. Such weapons "may have become an integral part of North Korea's war-fighting strategy," the report said.
China, a nuclear power, poses a potential threat to United States interests in its role as "an important supplier of equipment, materials, and technology for Iran's chemical warfare and ballistic missile programs," the report said.
Iran renewed its efforts to build nuclear weapons when it learned that its rival, Iraq, had a well-advanced program under way before the gulf war, the report said. Iran also has biological and chemical weapons programs.
Libya has a mismanaged and perhaps moribund nuclear weapons program but is also building a huge underground chemical weapons factory. Syria is vigorously developing chemical weapons and ballistic missiles, which it believes will serve "as deterrents against Israeli attacks."
And India and Pakistan, both nuclear powers, also have the potential to use chemical and biological weapons if their 50-year rivalry flares for a fourth time into war, the report said.
Assessing the threat posed by outlaw groups, the report said: "Most terrorist organizations have shown little proclivity to develop and use nuclear, chemical and biological weapons." And while plutonium and enriched uranium suitable for weapons may have been diverted from Russian nuclear facilities, the amount is "insufficient to make a single nuclear weapon," the report said.
