HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Those headed for the Middle East and South Asia are warned to be extra cautious these days.

BYLINE: By Paul Burnham Finney 

 BODY:
THE Middle East and South Asia are hot spots for business travelers these days because of Muslim terrorist attacks in Egypt and Pakistan, along with the still- simmering confrontations between the United States and Iraq.
"It's a time to go into a country, do your business and get out," said E. C. Ackerman, managing director of the Ackerman Group, an executive-security firm based in Miami with a large ex-C.I.A. staff and many multinational company clients. 
 The Middle East is an especially proceed-with-caution place, Mr. Ackerman said. "Anti-American sentiment is currently running high throughout the Muslim world," the Ackerman Group wrote in a memo to its clients earlier this month. "If Mir Aimal Kansi, recently convicted of the 1993 murders of two C.I.A. employees, is sentenced to death, personnel have every reason to remain cautious." A Virginia jury recommended the death penalty on Nov. 14; formal sentencing is scheduled for Jan. 23.
The most dangerous countries in the Middle East and South Asia, according to the Ackerman Group, are Egypt, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. In the second tier -- with less risk -- are Bahrain, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen.
Mr. Ackerman's advice: "Don't go to the first-tier countries if you can avoid it. Stay away from mosques and tourist sites. It's not a time to visit St. Sophia in Istanbul or the pyramids in Egypt. Limit your circulation on Friday during midday prayers. I probably wouldn't go into souks. That's where fundamentalists feel comfortable. I think if I absolutely had to go shopping, I'd stick to hotels or malls associated with hotels."
Mr. Ackerman added: "Vary your route to work. Keep away from the watering holes of the expatriate community -- they're a potential target. Have meals in your hotel restaurant -- or to be really safe, order from room service."
Scanning the globe, the security company notes that two Muslim countries, Malaysia and Indonesia, are an exception to the threat of violence. "The problem may be different in Southeast Asia," Mr. Ackerman said. "It's traditionally a fairly safe area for travelers on the beaten track. But with their economies in turmoil, we'll probably see an uptick in street and other types of crime."
Beyond maintaining a low profile and keeping alert, can a corporate traveler do more to be safe? "Security devices are improving a lot," Mr. Ackerman said. "For instance, good locks for train compartments have been around for a while, but the alarms are getting better."
When it comes to kidnapping executives for ransom -- a continuing threat in Brazil, Colombia, Guatemala and Mexico -- criminals are using the latest technology.
"One of the things they now have are laptops," Mr. Ackerman said, citing a recent incident outside Bogota, Colombia. "The guerrillas run your name through a computer to see what you're worth. And they have pretty good financial data."
 
Keeping Track of Rates
In January, in a no-nonsense campaign to capture the lower air, car-rental and hotel rates they have negotiated for employees, the Siemens Corporation will equip some 2,000 of its North American travelers with smart cards provided by U.S. Bancorp. Siemens, a Germany company, says it is losing several million dollars on the $71 million it spends annually on travel booked in the United States. In a six-month pilot test, the smart cards will be checked by electronic readers in four cities where Siemens employees travel and will automatically compare rates to insure that Siemens is getting the deals it arranged.
 
A Roof for Returns
To keep drivers dry when dropping off cars in rainy or snowy weather, Hertz is putting steel roofs over its return centers. It will begin the $50 million project in January with canopies at airports in Atlanta; Charlotte, N.C.; Cincinnati; Dallas; Denver; Detroit; Miami, and San Antonio.
 
Smoke-Free Spa
After winning approval in a survey of its regular guests, Le Mirador Resort and Spa, a popular corporate retreat perched high above Vevey (where Nestle is based) on Switzerland's Lake Geneva, has decided to become what it says is the first smoke-free five-star hotel in Europe. But not entirely: there is a lounge, pub, meeting room -- all separately ventilated -- and a few guest rooms in an annex for smokers.
 
Travel Secrets
An evening out on a business trip to New York? There are funny sketches of the bittersweet life of frequent travelers in "Secrets Every Smart Traveler Should Know," a musical comedy revue at the Off Broadway Triad Theater. The show is based on a Fodor guide by Wendy Perrin, a writer for Conde Nast Traveler magazine.

HEADLINE: New U.N. Estimate Doubles Rate of Spread of AIDS Virus

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Medical experts working for the United Nations say they grossly underestimated the spread of the AIDS virus worldwide, and they now believe that new infections are occurring almost twice as fast as they thought a year ago. Instead of 8,200 new infections a day, they now believe there are 16,000.
The new data, which began circulating today among American officials here and will be issued on Wednesday in Paris, suggest that 30.6 million people around the world are now living with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The last estimate, for 1996, was that 22.6 million people had the virus. 
 Some of the increase results from actual spread of the virus, and some from new methods of collecting data and making estimates, which United Nations officials believe give a more accurate picture. The United Nations did not say how much of the increase was attributable to each factor.
The United Nations estimates that 2.3 million people around the world will die of AIDS this year, an increase of more than 50 percent from an estimate that 1.5 million people died of the disease in 1996.
United Nations experts said the new data suggested that the AIDS epidemic could have ruinous economic effects in some regions, of the world, because it strikes many people of working age. Businesses should join governments in more aggressive efforts to fight AIDS, they said.
Two-thirds of the people infected with H.I.V. live in sub-Saharan Africa, and the United Nations experts said the epidemic in that region had been badly underestimated even though it was known to be severe.
Asked about the new estimates, Sandra L. Thurman, director of the White House Office of National AIDS Policy, said: "These numbers are so overwhelming that they numb the mind. We knew the numbers would increase. But I was surprised to learn how far off the mark we were in our estimates of how the epidemic is progressing globally."
Gareth Jones, a spokesman for the United Nations Program on H.I.V./ AIDS, said: "New infections are occurring at an alarming rate. In addition, it does appear that previous calculations grossly underestimated the rate of transmission of H.I.V., particularly in sub-Saharan Africa, where the bulk of infections are concentrated."
In a telephone interview today from Geneva, Mr. Jones said: "The older estimates were based on data that came from a small number of countries. It was assumed that one could extrapolate similar rates of transmission for all countries in a particular region, assuming that regional factors would be pretty much the same. It turns out that that assumption was wrong."
For the new estimates, Mr. Jones said, "we replaced regional models with separate models constructed for each country."
The United Nations estimates that 1,600 children under 15 are infected with H.I.V. each day, up from last year's estimate of 1,000 children a day. Moreover, it says, 1,200 children die of AIDS each day, up from the prior estimate of 1,000.
Many developing countries have crude systems of tracking disease, keep inadequate statistics and have denied the seriousness of the AIDS epidemic, public health experts said.
In many of these countries, Ms. Thurman said, "cultural norms prevent people from looking realistically at the AIDS epidemic and taking preventive measures, which would require more open discussion of sexuality, homosexuality and drug use."
Mr. Jones said the new data accentuated the contrast between countries at different stages of economic development. "More than 90 percent of new infections occur in developing countries," he said. "The industrialized world is experiencing decreases in new infections and AIDS cases generally. Prevention has worked among certain target groups like homosexuals, and new drugs are coming on stream. But the picture for the rest of the world is very different."
New tables prepared by the World Health Organization show that of the 5.8 million people newly infected with the AIDS virus this year, 4 million are in sub-Saharan Africa, 1.3 million are in South Asia and Southeast Asia, and 30,000 are in Western Europe.
The estimated number of new infections in Caribbean countries (47,000 this year) slightly exceeds the number in North America (44,000).
About 10 percent of all the new infections are in children under 15, and more than half of the remainder are in people 15 to 24, the health organization said.
Worldwide, the United Nations estimates that 11.7 million people of all ages have died from AIDS since the beginning of the epidemic in the late 1970's and early 80's. This year's deaths account for one-fifth of all deaths ascribed to AIDS since the start of the epidemic.
The United Nations estimated that 9.7 million people in sub-Saharan Africa had died of AIDS since the beginning of the epidemic, with a total of 740,000 deaths in South Asia and Southeast Asia, 420,000 in North America, 110,000 in Caribbean countries, 470,000 in Latin America and 190,000 in Western Europe.
Dr. Peter Piot of Belgium, executive director of the United Nations Program on H.I.V./AIDS, said, "AIDS is increasingly a threat to the global market economy." The disease, he said, has already slowed Kenya's economic growth, and it is likely to affect other countries' output too.
The United Nations said China, India and Thailand, for instance, were "likely to replicate the experience of sub-Saharan Africa in a few years' time." New outbreaks of H.I.V. infection have erupted in Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union, India, Vietnam, Cambodia, China and elsewhere.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Bolstered by 5-Year Note Sale

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices edged up yesterday, bolstered by strong demand at an auction of new five-year notes.
Optimism that Treasury securities will remain popular as a haven from turbulent world financial markets, particularly in Asia, also helped prices. 
 "There is an appetite right now for U.S. securities," said Patricia Larkin, who oversees the management of $35 billion of fixed-income securities at the Dreyfus Corporation. "People will fly into Treasuries" if Asian economic troubles flare again, she said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 4/32, to 100 31/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, slipped to 6.05 percent, from 6.06 percent on Tuesday. Traders paid little attention to private reports showing robust consumer confidence and rising home sales -- signs that the economy is still growing at a healthy clip.
The Conference Board said its November index of consumer confidence jumped to 128.3, the third-highest reading this year. The National Association of Realtors said existing home sales rose 2.1 percent, to a record annual rate of 4.4 million in October.
"The numbers don't offer a lot of useful information," because they offer little insight into how Asia's woes will affect the United States economy, said Ben Mayer, who manages $1.3 billion in fixed-income securities at AMR Investments in Fort Worth.
At its auction yesterday, the Treasury sold $11 billion in five-year notes at a yield of 5.769 percent, the lowest in almost two years. Demand was stronger than the average at the previous 10 five-year note sales, based on the dollar amount of bids received divided by securities sold. The bid-to-cover ratio was 2.98, compared with an average of 2.61 at the 10 previous sales.
"Obviously it was well-bid for," said Rick Schwarz, head government bond trader at Zions First National Bank Capital Markets in Salt Lake City. "It might be some anticipation of more flight to quality."
To be sure, the firms that bought the notes from the Treasury are working to resell a total of $26 billion of notes sold this week. That could weigh on prices in the next few days, said Bill Edwards, a five-year note trader at the Nikko Securities Company International, "We have to work ourselves out" from under the new debt, he said. The Treasury also sold $35 billion in 15-day cash management bills yesterday at an average yield of 5.56 percent. On Monday, the Government sold $15 billion in two-year notes. In addition, some concern persists that Japan may sell Treasury securities to bolster ailing banks and brokerage firms.
Following are the results of the Treasury's auctions of new five-year notes and 15-day cash-management bills:

HEADLINE: On Campus;
Idaho Helps Vietnam In Business Training

BYLINE: By STEPHEN STUEBNER 

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho

 BODY:
As Vietnam strives to expand its new market-oriented economy, a Hanoi university has linked with the state college here to develop educational opportunities for Vietnamese teachers and business leaders.
Boise State University received a $3.2 million contract from the Swedish International Development Authority this fall to help the National Economics University in Hanoi create its own school of business by 2000. 
 Boise's M.B.A. program is the only United States-accredited M.B.A. program in Vietnam, though institutions like Harvard, the Tuck School at Dartmouth and Georgetown are beginning to offer short courses and seminars to Vietnamese business leaders.
Nancy Napier, a Boise State professor of business management, is behind the endeavor. Professor Napier and her colleague in Hanoi, Suzanne Hosley, the project manager of SL Development Consultants, a private consulting firm working on the project, will try to give officials from the Hanoi institution the tools to develop a business school and will then fade into the background.
The relationship between the two institutions has been built over the last three years. With $4 million in assistance from Sweden, Boise State has granted master's degrees in business administration to 55 Vietnamese business and education leaders.
Vu Dinh Hien, 28, a graduate of the M.B.A. program in 1995, is teaching two undergraduate accounting classes at Boise State this semester. He said cultural differences abound. Written contracts may be essential in the West, but are meaningless in Vietnam, he said, adding, "If there's no trust, there's no business."
Professor Napier said her work in Vietnam had been refreshing. She recalled sitting in the canteen at the Hanoi institution when a student approached her to practice his English. He was studying American accounting on his own in hopes of becoming a university instructor, she said, to "do something good for his country."
"I sat there, chopsticks in hand, trying to remember when my students in the United States had ever talked about doing something good for their country," Professor Napier said.
"This is why I went into education," she said. "These people are fighting for their future. I'm teaching people who want to learn."
 STEPHEN STUEBNER

HEADLINE: No Storm In Pacific

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 25

 BODY:
To Clinton Administration officials, the meeting of leaders from the Pacific Rim that ended here today was a clear success, putting on display American political and economic influence over a vital and unsettled region.
The summit meeting brought no quick solutions to the financial turmoil that has left Asia's economies in disarray. And it brought some muted but passionate warnings from Asians that the United States should not overplay its hand at this delicate time, lest Washington find itself the object of a backlash from a region crucial to its security and economic interests. 
 Still, under prodding from the United States, the nations of Asia were willing to pledge themselves to adopting the kinds of prudent, market-pleasing policies that define the American brand of capitalism -- enduring whatever domestic political and economic pain it takes to stabilize their plummeting currencies, control inflation, strengthen their tottering banking systems, stem corruption and open their markets to world trade.
It remains an open question whether the developing countries of Asia will actually fulfill those goals.
Nothing done here irrevocably commits any nation to any specific policies, with the exception of trade deals. Other arrangements will be made between individual countries, like South Korea, and the International Monetary Fund, which dispenses financial aid only in return for reforms. Instead, officials here emphasized that in an atmosphere in which even a pillar like Japan seemed threatened by instability, the symbolic importance of the Asian countries stepping up with a promise to do what it takes should send a powerful message about lessons learned.
"This year, we proved that our community is for good times and for challenging ones as well," President Clinton said before leaving for Washington tonight. "Asia's financial difficulties would have made it tempting for some of our partners to turn inward, maybe even to stay home."
The gathering of the 18-member Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum also underscored President Clinton's success in nurturing the once-obscure organization into an increasingly important pan-Asian diplomatic structure -- and one that gives the United States a seat at the head of the table while excluding the European Union, the primary rival to the United States for economic influence in the Asia Pacific region.
"Everyone wants to hear what the United States says," one senior Administration official here declared. "It's palpable."
Administration officials did not seem worried about possible resentment by the Asian countries that see themselves as rising economic powers.
But to varying degrees, Asian leaders expressed disquiet about the impact of American insistence on painful steps towards economic reform in Asia. There is little enthusiasm in many Asian nations for the philosophy that pleasing the forces of the global market must come first.
And for all the recognition throughout the region of the economic power of the United States, of the country's indispensable role in arranging bailouts for Thailand, Indonesia, South Korea and any other countries that might fall to the wave of financial turbulence, there is also a strain of anti-Americanism, or at least of anti-imperialism, that is being stoked by the current crisis.
Prime Minister Mahatir Mohamad of Malaysia, long the most outspoken critic of the market-based solutions championed by the United States, was the leader most explicit in opposing a strategy that from his perspective amounts to granting currency traders control over his country.
Mr. Mahatir said an ideology based on the notion that "the market can do no wrong, is sacrosanct, is your benefactor, savior and the ticket to prosperity, is now as extreme as was the Communism and socialism of yesteryear."
While they put it more delicately, other Asian leaders also seemed to wonder whether the United States fully appreciated how it was viewed in countries facing new pressures for austerity. And they sometimes seemed to be questioning whether the United States appreciated the strains placed on their domestic political systems by the requirement that some nations surrender a portion of their sovereignty to institutions like the International Monetary Fund, which is often seen as an instrument of American policy.
In an interview in his hotel room here, President Fidel V. Ramos of the Philippines, which could see its hopes of "graduating" soon from its 30-year-long monetary fund program fade with the financial turmoil, said, "If you are here on this side of the Pacific, especially if you are inside the United States, as long as your numbers and your three meals a day are there, maybe you won't care too much." He added, "You might consider your position to have been enhanced."
But Mr. Ramos alluded to the dangers of developing countries in Asia feeling that they could be forced back into the colonial status they have worked so hard to shed.
From an Asian perspective, he said, the divide between the developed and developing worlds should not be allowed to widen, yet the poorer countries of the region have little choice but to swallow the medicine the United States is prescribing.
"Certainly if you are looking at it from the other side, you would not want to see an increase in the gap between the haves and the have-nots," Mr. Ramos said.
"I'm calling upon the sense of community spirit that we are so proud of in Apec to now operate," he said. "That's all we in the developing countries can ask for. We cannot impose anything, mandate anything."
It was left to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright to address such concerns.
"Will we squander our energies on finger-pointing and blame-pinning, or will we focus on how to get back on track?" she said. "Will we put our faith in alleged panaceas that are quick, easy and wrong, or will we renew our commitment to the basic principles that underlay past accomplishments and are essential to our future hopes?"
Ms. Albright hammered home one of the Clinton Administration's main themes, that it was up to each country to adopt market-oriented policies to restore international confidence in its economy.
"This is true no matter how difficult or painful the choices may be," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: President Clinton, far right, and the 17 other Pacific Rim leaders posed for photographers in Vancouver yesterday. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 545 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Leaders Agree on Ways To Contain Asian Crisis
President Clinton and other leaders at the Asia-Pacific economic summit declared that stringent domestic policies and closer international monitoring are the only ways to contain the financial emergencies that have crippled South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand recently and have endangered Japan. 
 The broad message of the gathering in Vancouver was that the fast-growing Asian "tigers" must accept a time of slower growth and narrower dreams. Page A1.
 
As the contagion in Asian markets has spread from Thailand to Indonesia to South Korea, the question of whether Japan might be next has lurked ominously in the background. But there are compelling reasons to believe Japan will not catch this flu and that it will not leap across the Pacific to the United States. A1.
 
Mutual fund investors avoided overseas funds last month because of the Asian crisis and sought the shelter of Government bond funds, which received new cash in October for the first time in four years. D6.
 
Japan's financial system showed further fractures as a small regional bank collapsed and speculation intensified that Yasuda Trust and Banking Company, a much larger institution, might seek a bailout. D6.
 
Evans Joins Zuckerman Empire
Harold M. Evans, the president and publisher of Random House's trade group, will leave the publishing house to become editorial director and vice chairman of Mortimer B. Zuckerman's publishing group. A1.
 
Signs of Economic Vibrance
Consumer confidence increased in November, while home resales rose in October, suggesting that the United States economy could end the year on a high note despite the turmoil in Asian financial markets. D4.
 
Canadians Feel Strike Impact
After a week without mail, Canadians are feeling pain from a postal strike. And anger is increasing, seen here as a postal worker blows a whistle in a guard's face at the office of the Minister in charge of the postal system, who has threatened to order strikers back to work. A6. Blood Platelet Drug Approved
A subsidiary of American Home Products received F.D.A. approval to market a drug that stimulates the production of blood platelets. D4.

19 Accused of Infiltrating Street
The Government has charged 19 men with artificially inflating the price of a health care stock in a fraudulent scheme. A1.
 
Newsweek Magazine Criticized
Newsweek magazine is feeling the heat from a computer-enhanced cover picture of the mother of the septuplets born last week. A24.
 
Gold at a 12 1/2-Year Low
Gold fell to a 12 1/2-year low yesterday after a governor of the Bank of England said that a new European central bank would not need much gold in its reserves. D8.
 
Geraldo Rivera Stays at NBC
NBC has retained Geraldo Rivera, keeping his interview program on its CNBC cable network while expanding his duties. D2.

The dollar climbed to a five-year high against the yen in reaction to the closing of Yamaichi Securities. The dollar settled at 127.07 yen. It had hit 127.96 yen during the day, its highest level since August 1992. The U.S. currency also strengthened against the mark, rising to 1.7485 marks. D8.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
In Brooklyn, New Allure For Old Office Buildings

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
In the aftermath of the real estate recession of the early 90's, new owners have emerged in downtown Brooklyn to instill vigor into older office buildings near Court Street.
Some of the buildings had been financed with mortgages that proved too generous for rent and occupancy levels in the 90's to sustain. Others lost big tenants and were no longer attractive investments for their owners. Whatever the cause, properties changed hands and new owners have been putting money into them to strengthen their competitive position in the improved market of the last two years. 
 One owner, the Treelines Companies, has purchased three buildings -- 188 and 189 Montague Street and 175 Remsen Street. Like other new owners, it is capturing tenants from neighboring buildings, strengthening the competitive position of Brooklyn's prewar downtown properties even as a new generation of buildings only blocks away is tempting larger tenants.
The principal in Treelines is Glenn Schor, who had a general law practice on Court Street for 20 years, but began investing in real estate with a client, the late Louis Markus, a fuel oil dealer and real estate owner. With the three acquisitions, Mr. Schor owns 10 buildings with 700,000 square feet of space, including a Manhattan property at 12 East 41st Street.
The Brooklyn properties were what real estate brokers would call Class C buildings. The term suggests a pre-World War II building of lesser market appeal, usually lacking recent upgrades of elevator service, security systems and lobby decor.
Treelines often captures tenants from nearby Class C properties by improving the buildings and offering favorable lease terms. "We rent to lawyers, doctors, court-related tenants," Mr. Schor said.
The typical tenant takes about 3,000 square feet, he said, and pays about $19 or $20 a square foot per year on a five-year lease, plus $2.75 a square foot for electricity. "Tenants from other buildings in the neighborhood come in looking for space," Mr. Schor said.
The newer Class A space is in Metrotech, with its 4.5 million square feet of offices, and Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza, a 32-story mixed-use building still in construction between Adams and Jay Streets diagonally across from Borough Hall.
Renaissance Plaza will give Brooklyn 820,000 square feet of new office space, plus a new luxury hotel, the New York Marriott Brooklyn, and an 1,100-car garage. The hotel, opening in May, will have 384 guest rooms and 27,000 square feet of meeting space in 19 rooms, including an 18,000-square-foot ballroom that can accommodate 2,900 people. There will also be a 15,000-square-foot health club with a 75-foot lap pool.
The Kings County District Attorney's office became the prime tenant with a 20-year lease of 400,000 square feet in Renaissance Plaza, giving up 130,000 square feet in the Municipal Building on Joralemon Street and also 43,700 square feet in two privately owned buildings, 16 Court Street and 200 Montague Street.
In another 20-year Renaissance Plaza lease, 280,000 square feet was taken by the Leucadia National Corporation, a Manhattan-based holding company, for itself and its Empire Insurance Company subsidiary. Most of the rest of the space, 140,000 square feet, is on the market.
Another departure from an older building occurred when the Legal Aid Society leased 61,500 square feet of space on three floors at 111 Livingston Street, the former Nynex building, for its juvenile rights and criminal defense divisions. The society gave up eight floors in 175 Remsen Street, which Treelines acquired in September.
At the northwest corner of Montague and Court Street, the 84,000-square-foot 205 Montague Street, built in the 1960's, is being renovated under the new ownership of Blumberg & Freilich Equities, based in Fort Lee, N.J., in partnership with ING Holdings, a Dutch financial company. It was bought mostly empty from Republic National Bank last year. Originally, Brooklyn Savings Bank had its headquarters there, as did its successor bank, Crossland Savings, which was taken over by Republic.
The new owner has already leased the ground floor to a bank -- EAB -- and the upgraded upper floors will probably go to Brooklyn-based insurance, financial and legal firms, and nonprofit organizations, said Robert F. Hebron of Ingram & Hebron Realty, the leasing agent. A $2 million renovation of public areas is under way, Mr. Freilich said.
And at 26 Court Street, a 30-story 1920's building on the corner of Remsen Street, 26 Court Associates, in which Jonah Zupnick is the principal, upgraded the elevators for $750,000 after taking over last year from an owner who had defaulted on a mortgage. The building has 160 tenants, mainly lawyers. "The elevators were the key to renewing leases," said Joseph Schachter, the manager.
"Once the owners make the decision to put money into the infrastructure, these properties will rent," said Glenn Markman, an executive managing director of Grubb & Ellis New York. The firm was the broker in the Legal Aid Society lease at 111 Livingston Street.

GRAPHIC: Map of Brooklyn: New ownership has rejuvenated buildings in downtown Brooklyn. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New York City Now Expects an Additional $319 Million in Revenues

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration expects New York City to end the fiscal year with $319 million more in revenues than it had forecast, largely because of continued robust profits on Wall Street, and it is proposing that the city salt away much of that money for the future.
Administration officials said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani wanted to put $240 million of the extra revenue into the city's so-called rainy day fund, which would bring the total in the fund to $740 million. The rest of the money would be allocated for a variety of programs, including the antidrug initiative the Mayor presented in October. 
 The officials said that if the city did not need to spend the money in the rainy day fund on emergencies in the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, then they would save it to help reduce a projected gap in next year's budget. The administration plans to hold a briefing today to discuss the proposals, most of which require City Council approval.
"While we are fortunate to have some additional revenue, the Mayor is going to do what he has done in the past, which is use the lion's share of that additional revenue for gap reduction," said Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations.
Though the administration defended its plan as prudent, the news of the potential windfall is nonetheless likely to touch off a debate over whether the city should spend more of it, particularly on agencies whose budgets were cut in the first three years of Mr. Giuliani's first term. To some extent, the city government is facing the situation confronting the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has more than $100 million in unexpected revenue and is under pressure to use the money to restore service cuts and roll back increases in transit fares.
The Giuliani administration, like senior officials at the transportation authority, is counseling caution, pointing out that just as revenues jumped unexpectedly, so too could they drop without warning, particularly if there is a downturn on Wall Street. If that happened, then the city might have trouble paying for the programs that it promised to finance when times were flush. The M.T.A. has made similar assertions.
Despite the tax windfall, New York still must contend with large projected budget gaps in the next few years, including one of $1.2 billion in the 1999 fiscal year, which begins on July 1. The gaps in the two years after that are more than $2 billion annually. The city's budget is nearly $34 billion.
The Mayor is calling for $185 million in new spending, including $46 million for the antidrug initiative and the rest to be allocated in small amounts across an array of city agencies. He is getting some of that money from what is left over after he puts $240 million of the $319 million in extra revenue into the rainy day fund.
In addition to the extra tax revenues the city now expects, Mr. Giuliani is also gaining, and hopes to spend much of, $150 million that he had expected to lose to a proposed tax cut on inexpensive clothing. State officials have approved the cut, but not until the next fiscal year. The administration had anticipated that the cut would come sooner, so it has extra money in the current budget.
When the Mayor and the City Council agreed on the budget in June, they predicted that the stock market would have a mediocre year, an estimate that independent budget analysts called appropriate. But Wall Street is still producing strong earnings, so revenues from taxes on incomes and businesses, and from other taxes, are greater than projected, officials said.
The administration might have to raise its estimate of an extra $319 million in revenues even higher during the coming months if Wall Street profits remain high.
In fact, the leadership of the Democratic-controlled City Council, which has often called the administration's revenue estimates too conservative, said it believed that the additional revenue would be higher than $319 million, though it declined to give an exact projection.
The Council leadership noted that Speaker Peter F. Vallone had championed the rainy day fund, but was also interested in increasing money for social programs.
The administration's budget proposals are "consistent with Speaker Vallone's desire to increase the rainy day fund and to support the Mayor's drug initiative," said Thomas L. McMahon, the Council's finance director. "As we get the details, the Council will negotiate a number of items, like increased funding for food programs and expanding portions of the drug initiative."
This is the second year in a row that the city is benefiting from a surge in unexpected revenues, in sharp contrast to the beginning of Mr. Giuliani's term, when the economy soured and he had to grapple with large budget gaps. The city finished the 1997 fiscal year, which ended last June 30, with $1.4 billion in extra revenue.

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE JAPANESE INVESTORS;
In Tokyo, Taking a Collapse in Stride

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Tamio Shiraishi arrived at the Yamaichi Securities Company's branch in Otemachi, Tokyo's banking center, at 7 A.M. today with his newspaper and plans to withdraw his assets.
No, Mr. Shiraishi, a 76-year-old former liquor wholesaler, was not overly concerned that the failure of Yamaichi, one of Japan's "Big Four" brokerage firms, would hurt clients like him. 
 "I'm not too worried because the ministry said I shouldn't worry," Mr. Shiraishi said, referring to the Ministry of Finance, which has promised that Yamaichi's clients would walk away unscathed from the country's biggest financial debacle since World War II. "I just came early because I thought it would be better to get ahead of the crowds."
Indeed, since the announcement, Tokyo has gone even further to reassure the public. A senior Bank of Japan official said this evening that Japan's ruling party would move quickly to devise a plan, which could be announced on Dec. 10 in conjunction with a package of tax reforms, to use public funds to steady the country's deteriorating financial system. Page 6.
 On Wednesday, Tokuyo City Bank, a small regional bank burdened by bad loans and rising losses, became the fourth Japanese financial institution to fail this month.
For the 50 people lined up quietly outside the Yamaichi branch, panic seemed far from their minds. Like Mr. Shiraishi, most appeared reassured by the Government's statements.
Rather, several waiting to enter the Yamaichi branch seemed embarrassed. Some wore sunglasses, a fashion accessory far less common in Japan than in the United States. One woman took the extra measure of draping a large scarf over her head. Many buried their faces in books and newspapers, and others turned toward the wall when they saw reporters and photographers.
Their sheepishness may have partly reflected how the stock market is widely viewed in Japan: a sort of disreputable casino. Making money through shrewd investment, rather than hard work and industry, runs counter to Japanese ethics, a perception that shows up in statistics.
Of the universe of Japanese personal financial assets, only 6.1 percent are invested in securities, according to J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd., compared with 22.4 percent in the United States. The vast majority, 56.9 percent, are held as currency or deposits.
Indeed, the biggest beneficiary of Yamaichi's collapse will likely be the postal savings system, the $2 trillion pool of savings administered by the Post Office.
Hosoya Shinobu, a 49-year-old housewife waiting on the Yamaichi line, said that when her husband had dispatched her this morning to claim their assets he said "gambate," or persevere -- a Japanese way of saying "good luck."
"I'm very worried about the other assets," she said. "I feel I should withdraw all our assets from other institutions as well and put them in postal savings because it's a national institution and that makes me feel safe."
Mrs. Shinobu was not the only one worrying about the overall safety of the Japanese financial system after the collapse of Yamaichi.
Stocks plunged in the wake of the announcement. The Nikkei index of 225 issues dropped 5.11 percent on Tuesday -- the first day of trading this week -- pulled down by heavy selling of bank shares.
Japanese newspapers and television spent the weekend assessing the comparative strengths of various banks and brokerage firms. Most reports concluded that the biggest banks would not be allowed to fail, but that a range of weaker second-tier financial institutions would eventually go bust.
On Friday, Moody's Investors Service rated the financial strength of one Japanese insurer, the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company, as "very poor" and four others as "poor."
Two banks, the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company and the Chuo Trust and Banking Company, have the ratings agency's lowest rating, and a third, the Long-Term Credit Bank, has its second-lowest rating.
The public's growing awareness of the depth of the problems that have festered in the financial system since the bubble economy burst here in the early 1990's also seems to have raised acceptance for the idea of using public funds to protect depositors. Many, though, seem wary of using the same money to prop up banks.
The Government is trying to find a way to use public funds without raising the angry outcry that accompanied a similar bailout of some housing lenders last year.
"I want them to protect my assets, that's all I want," said Masahiko Tada, a 26-year-old salaryman, or midlevel manager, who was waiting to retrieve stocks worth between 700,000 yen and 800,000 yen -- or between roughly $5,555 and $6,350 -- his entire savings. "I'm not worried about the system itself."
While Mr. Tada and others were not too concerned about the fate of their own assets, they worried that a financial meltdown would threaten Japan's stature internationally.
Shigeru Morii's 84-year-old mother not only had an account at Yamaichi, but also one at Hokkaido Takushoku, Japan's 20th-largest bank, which failed last week. Mr. Morii, a cab driver, said he was relieved the Government had in both cases protected her assets.
"But, you know," he said, "we are suddenly in a terrible world. I could not imagine this kind of thing happening even a year ago."

GRAPHIC: Photo: It was a somber day in Japan yesterday, the first trading session after the collapse of Yamaichi Securities. In Tokyo, a stock quotation board flashed the result: an 854-point tumble in the Nikkei index. (Reuters)(pg. D6)

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE RESPONSE;
Could Japan Be Next?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Could Japan be next?
For months, as the contagion in the Asian markets spread from Thailand to Indonesia to South Korea, that question has lurked in the background at the White House, next door at the Treasury, behind the sealed doors of the Federal Reserve and on Wall Street. Few officials in the Clinton Administration will discuss the subject publicly, except to recite the reasons why Japan is different and will not succumb. The reasons are compelling: the Japanese have prodigious national savings, a war chest of $230 billion in United States Treasury bonds and industrial strength that is rivaled only by the United States. 
 So far, though, none of that has compensated for a series of huge miscalculations that has mired Tokyo in economic trouble since 1991. A sudden collapse of the kind that afflicted the smaller Asian economies seems highly unlikely. Nonetheless, with every bit of economic evidence suggesting that things in Japan could worsen before they improve, Washington and the markets are awash in gloomy visions in which a panic in Japan -- or even Japanese efforts to quell one -- could leap the Pacific.
It seems even less probable that the United States will catch Asia's flu -- indeed today Wall Street shrugged off a 5.1 percent drop in the Japanese stock market.
To a large extent, Asian markets are responding to the collapse of a huge speculative bubble that began in Japan and spread through Southeast Asia, fueled by cronyism and, it turns out, a good deal of old-fashioned fraud. But markets feed off one another in unpredictable ways, as Americans were reminded last month after a run in Hong Kong resounded here. As one senior Administration official put it the other day, "It's hard to imagine the world's second-largest economy going into a convulsion without affecting us."
That may explain why a series of letters from Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin to his Japanese counterpart, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, have taken on a more urgent tone in recent months, as American officials insisted the Japanese were deceiving themselves into thinking the worst was over. It also explains President Clinton's apparently toughly worded caution to Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on Monday in Vancouver, British Columbia, that the time had come to "move decisively" before Japan's financial problems become the world's. Mr. Hashimoto reportedly conceded that Japan had "miscalculated" when it dismissed the warnings earlier this year.
Details of that conversation were conveyed to reporters not by Mr. Clinton's aides but by Mr. Hashimoto's in a clear attempt to create the impression at home that the Prime Minister was under excruciating pressure to take unpopular actions -- starting with the use of public money to bail out the same Japanese institutions that a decade ago seemed ready to bury their American rivals.
"What's happened now is that every scenario for the next few months in Japan is filled with bad news," said Edward Lincoln, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who served as chief economic adviser to Walter F. Mondale, the American Ambassador in Tokyo until the end of 1996. "But that said, the theories about what will happen next -- and what their effect could be here -- are diametrically opposed."
The future that Japanese Government officials are peddling is that a new age has dawned -- one in which they will not let problems linger by propping up failing companies.
Finally, Japanese companies will sink or swim, this line of reasoning goes. The weakest -- even giant, venerable institutions like Yamaichi Securities, the century-old trading house that announced on Monday that it was liquidating -- will go out of business. Depositors will be protected, the Japanese say, but banned forever is the instinct to interfere with market forces whenever they threaten the established order.
It is an appealing pitch, a signal to the world that Japan is finally going to let market forces rule its economy, rather than insist that the country's bureaucrats bend the market forces. But it also seems to contradict the Government's gradual move toward injecting huge sums into the financial system to stabilize it.
Letting a large number of companies die would also lead to a time of extraordinary pain, one in which workers who thought they had jobs for life could be out on the street, investors in loss-plagued businesses could lose their money and the economy's growth could dwindle to zero.
"This is a reality that has been discussed more realistically in the United States than in Japan," a leading Japanese lawmaker said on a visit to the United States last week. "I think Japan is only now waking up to what this means."
Believe it or not, that's the optimistic outlook. It involves a lot of short-term agony, but, in the minds of American officials, it sets the Japanese economy on the path to growth.
No doubt American companies with heavy exports to Japan will suffer. Japan may also sell some of its huge holdings of Treasury securities to smooth over a rough patch, and depending on the magnitude of the sale, that could roil the American bond market, weaken the value of the dollar and in the worst case, lead to higher interest rates in this country. There is always the possibility, however, that Japan's Finance Ministry is telling something short of the full truth when it insists Japan is changing so quickly.
There is plenty of reason to be skeptical. Mr. Hashimoto has promised before that Japan's financial sector was cleaning up its act -- in 1991, when he served as Finance Minister. It was on his watch that the country faced the first of a series of financial scandals, in which the four biggest securities houses admitted they had compensated big customers for losses when the Japanese market began to turn down. They apologized and said it would never happen again. Mr. Hashimoto resigned. And the practices went on, leading to Yamaichi's admission on Monday that it hid more than $2 billion in off-the-books losses for years.
The fear in Washington is that Mr. Hashimoto will bend to pressure to funnel aid to companies that deserve to fail -- perhaps acting overtly or perhaps in the more cloaked, traditional manner of Japan.
"This would be the worst outcome because the banks and the securities houses would only weaken and the pain would go on much longer," Mr. Lincoln said. Japanese industry, despairing of selling more at home, would seek to let the yen weaken so that Japan's cars and computer chips remain competitive with goods made by South Korea, Taiwan and the Southeast Asian nations. That would be good for American consumers -- who would pay less for Japanese goods -- but the trade deficit with Japan would surge.
Eventually, a growing deficit could threaten American jobs, particularly in industries that compete directly with Japanese products. The stock prices of companies facing more intense price competition would undoubtedly drop. Mr. Clinton told Mr. Hashimoto quite explicitly on Monday that any effort by Japan to export its way out of trouble would lead the two countries into "political problems," Japanese officials say.
But Japan has been through plenty of political problems in Washington before, and may decide it is worth the risk -- and better than wallowing in whatever disease has swept through some of the world's most promising economies.

TYPE: News Analysis

HEADLINE: Liberties;
One Life To Give

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
I have met egomaniacal rich guys like Donald Trump, who thinks every woman wants him and every politician fears him.
I have met plain old maniacal rich guys like Ted Turner, who can promise to give away a billion bucks as spontaneously as he can brag about his love life with Jane Fonda. 
 But I had never met a billionaire who is shy and retiring, who doesn't own a house, a car or a Rolex, who likes to take the subway and fly economy, who goes to the supermarket with his wife and worries about the price of carrots, who gives away a lot of his money because, as he puts it, "you can only wear one pair of shoes at a time."
So I trotted over to the 21 Club, where Irish America Magazine was honoring Charles Feeney, a 66-year-old businessman who has given away $610 million in anonymous donations to universities, medical centers and others in need. Chuck Feeney's desire for anonymity is startling in an age when people stamp their names on every available surface.
Here was the real-life John Beresford Tipton on the old television show "The Millionaire," whose face was never seen as he instructed his personal secretary to give some unsuspecting person a check for $1 million, on the condition that the Samaritan never be revealed.
The American Benefactor magazine says Mr. Feeney may soon become the greatest American giver of all time. He is ahead of Ted Turner, says Randy Jones, The Benefactor's chairman, because Mr. Feeney has given "hard, cold cash, the check has cleared, the work is being done." By the standards of Charles Feeney, Bill Gates isn't even on the charts.
Michael Sovern, president emeritus of Columbia University, who is on the board of one of Mr. Feeney's charitable foundations based in Bermuda, compares him to St. Francis. "When we go to Bermuda, he makes the board fly coach," Mr. Sovern says. "And he won't go to a restaurant there anymore that tried to make him wear a tie."
Mr. Feeney does not act out of an aristocratic sense of noblesse oblige. He acts on the idea that our great pursuit of more stuff is silly, that quantity is the American vice, that people need only what they need.
Donald Keough, the chairman of Allen & Company, called it "mind-boggling" that this self-made billionaire from a working-class New Jersey family "will surpass the Mellons, the Rockefellers, the Du Ponts in his charitable giving."
Like Ted Turner, Mr. Feeney was angry that the richest Americans give such a small percentage of their incomes. He was thrilled to be dropped from Forbes's list of the richest Americans this year because he had given so much money away.
But unlike the Mouth from the South, this "raggedy-trousered philanthropist," as one friend calls him, would never scream that Bill Gates and Warren Buffett were "ol' skinflints." He was reluctantly dragged into the spotlight last January, after the sale of the duty-free shops he helped found was about to make the information public. He was so little known that one network put up a photo of the wrong Feeney.
You would never pick him out in a room. He is a small man with a nondescript blue suit, a clipped Jersey accent and amused blue eyes.
I ask him if he's nervous at his first public appearance.
"Well, they promised me $20 to make the speech," he kids.
When someone tells me a bill is sticking out of my purse, I don't want Mr. Feeney to think I'm addled, so I assure him that it's only a dollar.
"It's still money," he chides me gently. "Money is money."
I want to ask him if relatives were angry that he'd scattered so many millions that could have been theirs. But I can see that he is surrounded by his proud family.
His speech is awkward and endearing, the halting effort of someone not used to the limelight.
He urges the Irish-American business community to give away more money, and talks about his role encouraging the cease-fires in Northern Ireland. He also finances Sinn Fein's Washington office.
He tells about how, as a student at Cornell, he got a pop quiz in a course on money and banking. "I got my paper back with a note from the professor: 'You have a flair for writing, but no knowledge of the subject matter. Consider journalism.' "
Afterward, the other corporate chieftains leave 21 and climb into waiting black limos. Mr. Feeney, in an old gray raincoat and Irish tweed cap, tramps off on foot.

HEADLINE: Fish Are Victorious Over Dam As U.S. Agency Orders Shutdown

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Handing a landmark victory to fish defenders and river enthusiasts, a Federal agency refused today for the first time to relicense a hydroelectric dam and, going even further, ordered the aging structure on Maine's Kennebec River demolished at the owner's expense.
The agency, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, ruled that the hindrance the Edwards Dam posed to migratory fish outweighed the benefit it provided in electric generation. 
 The 160-year-old dam, which produces one-tenth of 1 percent of Maine's electricity, largely blocks the passage of sturgeon, salmon and other fish that struggle upstream to spawn, the commission said.
"Today's order requiring the removal of the Edwards Dam reflects a balanced view of environmental as well as social and economic considerations," said James J. Hoecker, chairman of the commission, which oversees the nation's power industry.
Since a 1986 change in Federal law, the commission has been required to balance conservation, recreation and other environmental values with energy generation in deciding whether to renew licenses. But the Edwards Dam is the first case in which it has exercised the power to deny a license.
Mr. Hoecker emphasized that the decision to remove the dam, which is in Augusta, need not be viewed with trepidation by the hydroelectric industry, which provides 14 percent of the nation's electricity, because Edwards is a special case involving a tiny amount of generation and a great deal of environmental damage.
Nonetheless, the decision had been anxiously awaited, particularly in Western states with many large dams. About 550 dams will come up for relicensing in the next 15 years, and many hinder the spawning routes of salmon and other fish.
Though the 3.5-megawatt Edwards Dam may be a special case, its pending demise was hailed by environmentalists today as a major triumph. "This is the first time the commission has said no," said Pete Didisheim of the Natural Resources Council of Maine, which helped lead opposition to the dam.
The decision also brought warnings of peril from the Edison Electric Institute, representing investor-owned public utilities, which noted that hydropower provided more than 95 percent of America's renewable energy. "This is a dangerous precedent," said James Evans, the institute's manager of hydropower issues. "Declining to issue a new license for a dam, or going even further to order the owner to remove the dam, are precedent-setting steps that Congress has not authorized in the Federal Power Act."
For all of today's drama, however, the demise of the Edwards Dam does not look especially imminent. The Edwards Manufacturing Company, which owns the dam and holds its license together with the City of Augusta, plans to appeal the commission's decision, first before the panel itself and then, if need be, in court, said Mark Isaacson, the company's vice president.
Mr. Isaacson said that under the 1920 Federal law that governs dam licensing, if the Government wants to deny renewal to a licensee, it must compensate the company for its net investment in the project. That would amount to $6 million to $10 million for Edwards Manufacturing, he estimated. But the energy commission ruled that it was within its rights not only to deny that compensation but also to order the company to pay for the demolition, which is expected to cost more than $2 million, and to pay for any environmental damage the demolition causes.
"Why do they think they can get away with it?" Mr. Isaacson asked. "Because they're so much bigger than we are. We're a small private company with four employees."
Indeed, the forces in the fight over the dam have not been very evenly matched. A broad coalition of environmental groups, state agencies right up to Maine's Governor, and Federal agencies right up to the Secretary of the Interior all advocated the removal of the dam.
Since the change in law, the Federal commission has ordered the removal of seven other dams, but this was the first case involving a dam owner that wanted to continue its operations. It was also a case skewed heavily in favor of the fish.
Before the dam was built in 1837, the Kennebec River was extraordinarily rich in aquatic life, providing a migratory route and spawning grounds to virtually every species in the Northeast that struggles upstream to breed, from sturgeon to salmon. The dam devastated many of them, and fish ladders installed later did little to restore the stocks.
In more recent years, though, Maine worked to improve its water quality and help migrating fish return with fish lifts. In its application for relicensing, Edwards Manufacturing offered to install new and improved ways to help fish get upstream to spawn, and the Federal commission's staff at first offered tentative approval to the plans.
But environmentalists responded with 7,000 pages of rebuttal, arguing that some species, like the endangered shortnose sturgeon and the Atlantic sturgeon, could not effectively use "fish passages." Also, they said, returning the river to its natural state would restore 15 miles of river habitat that were favored spawning grounds of several species.
Recreation enthusiasts also argued that fishing and boating on the river would be vastly improved if the dam was eliminated, giving them an uninterrupted 60-mile stretch of river.
In its decision today, the commission noted that the dam did produce energy that would otherwise probably be produced by nonrenewable fossil fuels. And that is Mr. Isaacson's main argument as well: that hydroelectric power is clean and renewable, and provides additional side benefits like irrigation reserves.
But the commission decided that the benefits of the dam were definitively outweighed by its costs, saying, "We believe that the public interest in this proceeding lies in our denying the license application."
In a telephone interview today, Mr. Isaacson asserted that The New York Times Company co-owns two dams upstream on the Kennebec in connection with its paper interests in Maine; He would be happy to remove the Edwards dam at his own cost, he said in a challenge only partly in jest, if The Times would do the same with its dams.
(In fact, The New York Times Company has only a 40 percent equity interest -- and therefore not a controlling one -- in Madison Paper Industries, which owns and operates the two dams, said Nancy Nielsen, spokeswoman for The Times.)
The appeals process could go on for months or years, Mr. Isaacson said. In the meantime, he said, the dam's licensees must apply yearly for short-term licenses, as they have been doing since their long-term license ran out in 1993.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edwards Dam, rear, has been denied relicensing in a move to protect fish in the Kennebec River in Maine. (David McLain for The New York Times)
 
Map of Augusta showing location of Edwards Dam: A Federal agency has ordered the Edwards Dam to be dismantled.

United Nations medical experts said they grossly underestimated the spread of the AIDS virus worldwide, and now believe there are almost twice as many new infections daily as they thought a year ago. The new data suggest that 30.6 million people around the world are now living with H.I.V., as opposed to last year's estimate of 22.6 million. A6
 
Postal Strike Grips Canada
A week-long postal strike is hurting some businesses and helping others across Canada. Pre-Christmas catalog orders have not been shipped, and direct marketing companies are losing millions of dollars a day and laying off employees. Meanwhile, Federal Express and other private delivery services are enjoying a surge in business, and United States post offices along the border have been flooded by Canadians trying to send mail. HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Unemployment Dips And Jobs Rise in City

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
New York City's economy, fueled by business services, retailing and tourism, added 53,000 new jobs in the first 10 months of the year -- the best job-creation performance by the city for any comparable 10-month period since 1984, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.
There was also encouraging news for New York City residents who have been trying to get those new jobs. 
 The New York State Department of Labor said the city's unemployment rate, while still among the highest in the nation, continued its four-month downward trend in October, falling to 9.1 percent, from 9.3 percent in September, after adjustments for seasonal variation.
There are now about 43,000 more city residents with jobs than was the case in June, when the city's unemployment rate peaked at 10 percent, said James Brown, an analyst for the State Labor Department.
Mr. Brown said there was continued strength in construction employment and a variety of service jobs, like accountant, hotel cleaner and store clerk.
Figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics suggested, in fact, that the local economy is continuing to gather steam. About 8,000 new jobs were added in October in the city's five boroughs, more than the 5,000-per-month average through the first nine months.
"With the unemployment rate inching down a bit, and strong job growth in October, the city is entering the fourth quarter with some momentum," said John L. Wieting, the New York regional commissioner for the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Statewide, New York's unemployment rate was unchanged in October, at 6.4 percent, where it has remained for four months, the state said. The national unemployment rate was 4.7 percent in October, down from 4.9 percent in the previous month. KIRK JOHNSON

HEADLINE: THE ASIAN CRISIS: Watchful Waiting on Japan;
For U.S. and European Markets, a Steady Course So Far

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Japanese stocks were higher today after a 5.1 percent tumble Tuesday, leaving investors debating whether the Asian turmoil will undermine United States and European stock markets or whether a rebound in both those markets will help bring some stability to Asia.
At the close of trading, the benchmark Tokyo index was up 178.02 points, or 1.12 percent, at 16,045.55. Hong Kong stocks surged, ending the morning session up 2.66 percent. But the South Korean market was trading mostly lower, down two-tenths of a percent late in the day, and Thai stocks were also down two-tenths of a percent. 
 After the American stock market rallied yesterday, ignoring Tuesday's decline in Tokyo stocks, some analysts were more confident that United States and European markets could distance themselves from the problems in Asia, as long as there were some signs that the problems there were being dealt with. But they also said they were not sure that stability here would be all that helpful to Asia and the world's other major emerging markets in Latin America, Russia and Eastern Europe.
"We can't export our stability because they're facing real local problems," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company.
Desmond Lachman, head of emerging markets economic research at Salomon Brothers in New York, agreed. "There are things that are going on with Asia and Russia and Japan that have nothing to do with the United States," he said.
But both analysts agreed that a rout in the United States could cause foreign markets to suffer.
"The last thing that Asia needs is the U.S. to be weakening," Mr. Lachman cautioned.
On Wall Street yesterday, stocks finished mostly higher, with American companies buoyed by a round of so-called safe-haven buying and assumptions that Japanese officials will deal quickly with the country's unfolding banking crisis.
Telephone companies like BellSouth, Bell Atlantic and AT&T benefited from investors seeking safety, predictable earnings and relatively high dividend yields. In addition, positive news helped the Boeing Company's stock to rise, while stronger-than-expected earnings from Dell Computer pulled up technology shares, with companies like I.B.M. and Microsoft posting gains.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 41.03 points, or five-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,808.95. Standard & Poor's 500-company stock index gained a modest 4.15 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 950.82.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 2.05 points, to 1,589.04, as smaller companies lagged, with the Russell index of 2,000 stocks dipping 92-hundredths of a point, to 426.91.
"Every once in a while, we take a sigh of relief that things are not as bad as they could have been," said Arthur Hogan, a senior trader at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover.
But Tom Galvin, chief equity strategist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, warned that United States markets would continue to be volatile because the worse it became for Asia the more investors would worry about the impact on the United States economy and, more importantly, corporate earnings.
He also said that while bailout plans are being worked on for the most troubled countries, "it's a long road from identifying a problem to implementing a plan."
On Monday, the Dow fell 113.15 points, or 1.4 percent. The S.& P. 500 fell 16.42 points, or 1.7 percent. The drops followed the formal announcement that the Yamaichi Securities Company, the fourth-largest brokerage firm in Japan, had collapsed. Yamaichi's failure also caused fears that more Japanese financial institutions could follow suit.
Yesterday, investors seemed to gain confidence from news that Yamaichi would be allowed to close and that there were funds available to pay off depositors. In addition, Japanese and officials from the United States and the International Monetary Fund gave indications that quick action would be taken to make sure that additional closings would be orderly and "it was not going to be a free fall" in the Japanese markets, Mr. Pradilla of Cowen & Company said.
But the focus is still on what is occurring in emerging markets, Mr. Hogan said, adding that the stock market "really did not" focus at all on a report showing a sharp uptick in consumer confidence in November. While the report should have been positive for stocks, he said it was largely ignored because of the current focus on international issues.
Also, the fallout from Japan could affect emerging markets, like those in Latin America, as well as highlight structural and economic problems in other parts of the world, like Russia and India, analysts said.
"Japan is just so big that what's going on there is going to dictate the mood and sentiment of the other emerging markets," said Julie Wang, a vice president and portfolio manager at Bankers Trust Funds Management.
"Japan supplies a lot of liquidity to other markets," Ms. Wang added, with Japanese banks lending money to companies in Latin America.

HEADLINE: ASIA PACIFIC TALKS VOW TOUGH ACTION ON ECONOMIC CRISIS

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Nov. 25

 BODY:
Leaders gathered for the annual Asia Pacific economic summit meeting declared today that stringent domestic economic policies and closer international monitoring are the only way to contain the financial emergencies that have crippled South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand in recent months and have endangered Japan's already weakened financial system.
While previous Asia Pacific summit talks have made traditional declarations about the importance of sound economic policies, the Asian financial crisis that hung over this meeting like a sullen cloud will put pressure on member nations to turn these platitudes into policy. Three of the 18 members of the Asian-Pacific Economic Community, South Korea, Indonesia, and Thailand, have asked the International Monetary Fund for emergency loans, and they must follow I.M.F. conditions for austerity in order to get that money. 
 The conference, which ended tonight, was dominated by talk of the Asian crisis. In their session this morning, the leaders cast aside their agenda to focus on the financial situation and kept a wary eye on currency and stock markets throughout the region for new signs that the financial virus had spread. On Tuesday, Japanese stocks fell more than 5 percent while the yen plunged to a five-yearlow. The stocks recovered some lost ground on Wednesday, rising 1.1 percent.
The plan endorsed by the leaders was based on a document drafted last week in Manila by a group of finance officials from the United States and several countries in the region. Individual nations did not pledge financial help, but the United States and others did commit to make individual contributions if the I.M.F. package proved inadequate.
Instead, the arrangement calls on countries experiencing financial difficulties to take responsibility for solving them by adopting belt-tightening domestic economic policies, propping up their currencies, rooting out corruption and strengthening oversight of banks.
The broad message of the gathering was that the fast-growing Asian "tigers" would have to accept a time of slower growth and narrower dreams to insure a more stable and predictable future. The International Monetary Fund would hover nearby as a watchful nanny, ready to intervene at the first sign of trouble, backed up if necessary by further aid from countries in the region.
The summit meeting produced a public consensus that these remedies are the right way to rescue Asian economies, and that, officials argued, was the important accomplishment of what could easily have been a ritual gathering.
Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai of Thailand, whose country sparked the current crisis in July when it devalued its currency and sought emergency relief from the I.M.F., summarized the climate at this year's conference. "Confidence and optimism are out, and uncertainty and gloom are in," he declared as the two-day meeting opened.
But President Clinton emphasized the positive, repeatedly stating that prospects for strong growth in Asia remain good, that the gathering had agreed to continue dropping trade barriers in nine large industries and that it had endorsed a framework for addressing problems that arise.
"We also supported an action plan to meet the financial challenges that we all face in Asia," Mr. Clinton said. "We believe that the affected countries are doing the right thing in committing to take the right steps to remain strong, with the I.M.F. taking the lead for the international community, and with other advanced countries backing them up when it's appropriate."
Leaders of all the conference nations labored to convey a sense of determination even as they acknowledged the seriousness of the region's financial problems. In the communique released at the end of the meeting, the group said, "We believe it is critically important that we move quickly to enhance the capacity of the international system to prevent or, if necessary, to respond to financial crises of this kind."
The I.M.F. has already pledged $57 billion to underpin the shaky financial systems of Indonesia and Thailand. The Fund is certain to be called on for at least $20 billion more to assist South Korea, which appealed for aid last week as the depth of the crisis in its large conglomerates and financial system became clear.
The Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum includes not only major regional powers -- the United States, Japan, China -- but developing countries including Mexico, Singapore and Chile as well. The leaders voted to admit three new members -- Russia, Vietnam and Peru -- next year. They then declared a 10-year moratorium on new memberships.
The thrust of the Manila declaration last week and the discussions here is that miracles do not last forever and that a thriving middle class is the foundation of growth and democracy.
"During the past quarter-century, Asia Pacific economies have achieved miracles of expansion, job creation, poverty reduction and rising living standards," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said on Monday. "Today, they are undergoing a severe test. And so are we all."
She then delivered the international prescription for renewed expansion. "We must act with patience, persistence and principle to stabilize economies, promote good governance, bring down barriers to trade and engender a broad public conviction that open markets will open the door to prosperity not just for the lucky few, but for the hard-working many," Ms. Albright said.
The main session of the two-day meeting this morning, held at the Museum of Anthropology on the campus of the University of British Columbia, was consumed by a discussion of the economic malaise. President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico captured attention with an account of how his country confronted its currency crisis in 1994-95 and emerged with its economy strengthened.
He said the most important thing was to seek international help early and reassure investors that the country is moving aggressively to restore the economy and banking system to a sound footing.
Daniel Tarullo, a senior White House economic adviser, summarized Mr. Zedillo's words, saying, that "as a political matter, obviously this entails a good deal of problems in the short run." Mr. Tarullo added, "But he pointed out that the experience of Mexico demonstrates that the political situation can also turn back quickly in favor of the Government's programs and policies."
With the regional crisis threatening even the economic powerhouse of Japan, only the United States emerged from the meeting with its stature enhanced.
And American officials, fighting smugness, lectured Asia Pacific leaders on the need to take action now to prevent deeper problems.
"This is not a painless process," Mr. Tarullo said today. "Obviously some policies are going to change."

HEADLINE: To U.S. Workers, Trade Deficits Are a Threat

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Laura D'Andrea Tyson (Op-Ed, Nov. 24) offers several arguments to convince us that trade deficits need not concern us -- from the difficulties in defining them, to the impossibility of their elimination, to their relative unimportance to high-wage industries, to the current economic expansion.
These arguments, even if true, only obscure a more powerful truth: prices are set at the margin based on supply and demand. 
 Unions and American workers understand that competition from offshore labor paid minuscule wages reduces domestic demand for unskilled, semiskilled and blue-collar workers and depresses their share of national income. It is of no consequence to these workers that highly educated, high-tech workers have enough to do.
The recent debacle on President Clinton's fast-track negotiating authority ought to serve notice that this is an issue that is not going away. Until Ms. Tyson's party is willing to address it in a meaningful way, her arguments will ring hollow to the many left behind by the economic expansion.
 
DAVID GRUBER
East Hampton, N.Y., Nov. 24, 1997

HEADLINE: To U.S. Workers, Trade Deficits Are a Threat

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Laura D'Andrea Tyson (Op-Ed, Nov. 24) cites several supposedly benign reasons for our soaring trade deficits and one worrisome issue for the future -- the lack of "fast track" negotiating authority for the President.
Missing in her analysis was an important and damaging factor in our trade deficits -- the growing use of unilateral trade sanctions by the Federal Government, states and even cities. 
 An estimated 185 such sanctions have been in force or proposed since 1993. These sanctions are usually designed to punish our trading partners or to deter them from behavior we don't like.
A study by the Institute for International Economics showed that only one in five sanctions studied was effective, while at least 200,000 export jobs were lost.
In a survey I conducted this year, the chief executives of companies representing more than 10 percent of United States exports, when asked what Government action hurts their exports the most, overwhelmingly named trade sanctions.
 
RICHARD J. MAHONEY
St. Louis, Nov. 24, 1997
 
The writer is an executive in residence, Center for the Study of American Business, Washington U.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Drop as Rise In OPEC Output Is Expected

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, reflecting expectations that OPEC will raise its production output at a time of ample world supplies. Heating oil and gasoline futures also fell sharply.
On other markets, gold prices fell below $300 an ounce for the first time in 12 1/2 years amid continued fears that European nations might sell their gold reserves. 
 Crude prices fell on expectations that Saudi Arabia's proposal to increase oil output in coming months would be accepted by other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at a meeting in Jakarta, Indonesia. Total output could rise to 27.5 million barrels a day from the group's current ceiling of 25.033 million barrels a day.
The United Nations in the next few weeks is also expected to consider increasing the amount of crude Iraq is allowed to export as part of its oil-for-food program. Iraq has been barred from exporting oil freely since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait.
The current export round in which Iraq can sell $2.1 billion in oil over six months ends on Dec. 5, and United Nations officials say that figure could rise to $3 billion.
The oil output rise would come at a time of ample stockpiles in the United States. The American Petroleum Institute reported late Tuesday that crude inventories jumped unexpectedly last week by 3.6 million barrels, to 317.576 million.
Crude oil for January delivery fell 58 cents, to $19.15 a barrel. December unleaded gasoline fell 1.77 cents, to 57.31 cents a gallon, and December heating oil fell 2.39 cents, to 53.10 cents a gallon.
Gold futures fell sharply on the New York Mercantile for the second consecutive session after the governor of the Bank of England, Eddie George, said the new European Union central bank was unlikely to hold large inventories of gold in its reserves. The central bank will be formed next year as Europe prepares for an economic and monetary union in 1999.
On the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, December gold fell $3.60, to $296.90 an ounce, the lowest for the contract closest to delivery since March 1985. The more-active February contract fell $3.70, to $298.60 an ounce.
