HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls vs. Yen as Tokyo Vows Aid to Banking System

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the yen yesterday as officials in Tokyo pledged to restore calm to a battered banking system. It rose against the mark, as traders saw no near-term rise in German interest rates.
Japanese stocks rebounded from Tuesday's sharp drop to end more than 1 percent higher after the Bank of Japan and the Ministry of Finance promised to provide liquidity to stem any run on funds. 
 "We strongly urge the public not to pay heed to irresponsible rumors and act calmly," the two institutions said in a rare joint statement, adding they would provide funds "smoothly and without hesitation so that repayment of financial terms' deposits and other payments will not be hindered."
The comments, after the collapse in recent weeks of two banks and Japan's fourth-largest brokerage firm, helped buoy the yen. That, in turn prompted investors to stop buying marks, which had been seen a safer investment than the dollar.
In trading in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.7613 marks from 1.7485 marks on Tuesday -- highest level against the mark since Oct. 24, the last trading day before Asian markets plunged. The dollar slipped to 126.97 yen from 127.07 yen. The British pound fell to $1.6736 from $1.6770. But trading in New York was subdued ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday. Nearly all foreign markets will be open today.
Persistent talk that more Japanese banks could fail minimized the dollar's losses, traders said. "We are seeing the who-is-next syndrome," said Steve Flanagan, chief dealer at Erste Bank, describing market fears that official pledges of aid would not be sufficient to save more banks from collapsing.
The dollar also gained ground against the mark as investors remained convinced that Germany's central bank would not raise interest rates in the near term.
On Tuesday, a Bundesbank council member, Franz-Christoph Zeitler, said the central bank would likely be able to hold to its so-called steady-hand policy for some time.
In other trading, the Canadian dollar fell to 70.2 United States cents from 70.3 United States cents even though the Bank of Canada bought Canadian dollars to defend the Canadian currency.

HEADLINE: 3 Presidents Defend Bid To Belong To NATO

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The three Presidents of the Central European countries that have been invited to join NATO are unlikely to make an appearance in the Senate committee rooms in Washington where the debate over expanding the alliance will heat up early next year.
But in an "if you were there" exercise, Transitions magazine, a Prague-based monthly, asked the three leaders to imagine just such an encounter. 
 Their articles are to be read as the most persuasive rationales for these three former Soviet satellites to be embraced by the Western military alliance, the executive editor of Transitions, Michael T. Kaufman, said.
The three leaders, who are likely to send their foreign ministers and American boosters for the real debate, appear to understand well the counterarguments they face. They warned against American isolationism, stressed their ability to pay their way and played down the threat of Russian opposition to NATO expansion.
A two-thirds majority is required in the Senate for the expansion of NATO, the toughest hurdle before the three proposed members can formally join. The legislatures of the 15 other NATO members must also approve the move for it to take effect.
Poland's President, Aleksander Kwasniewski, called American isolationism an "anachronism."
"It is surely obvious today that the absence of the United States in European policy in the years preceding both world wars was not the best way to defend America's vital interests," he wrote.
At the same time, he said Poland did not expect a free ride in NATO. Poland had pledged to increase its military budget three percentage points faster than its economic growth rate, he said, adding, "We want to occupy a place in the civil and military structures of the alliance proportional to our contribution and our strategic position."
The Poles, suspicious of Russia after more than a century of occupation during czarist times, are by far the most enthusiastic supporters of joining NATO. Surveys say that more than 80 percent of Poland's nearly 40 million people consistently want their army to be part of NATO.
The Hungarian President, Arpad Goncz, a former dissident and playwright, urged American senators not to worry that United States soldiers might die in the defense of Budapest.
"Some people say that NATO enlargement means that in the case of a major conflict, American soldiers would die protecting Central European cities," he said. "I think those people are wrong. Under the bipolar world order, in the years of bitter enmity, not a single soldier of NATO died for a member state of the alliance."
Mr. Goncz acknowledged that for Hungary -- landlocked, with only 10 million people and coming out a Communist economy -- collective defense was the best option. "Being armed to the teeth is the privilege of rich countries; it is far too expensive and unsuitable for Hungary," he said.
Vaclav Havel, the President of the Czech Republic and also a former dissident and playwright, chose to dwell on the costs of American isolationism. "Some Americans still consider involvement in Central and Eastern Europe an unnecessarily costly, unneeded and untimely undertaking," he wrote. "Europe, however, is connected with America and through thousandfold links and bonds."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Citibank to Buy a Stake in Thai Bank

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Citibank signed an agreement today to buy at least 50.1 percent of the First Bangkok City Bank, becoming the first foreign bank to take a majority stake in a Thai bank.
First Bangkok said the New York-based bank had signed a memorandum of understanding for the purchase but would take 90 days to conduct a review and assess the value of its assets. 
 The price for the purchase has not yet been set, executives of the Thai bank said.
Thai banks have been crippled by the country's first recession in more than a decade. The country's 15 commercial banks have been so overwhelmed by problem loans that Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency, has predicted as many as five will fail by the end of 1998.
Thailand's rescue plan for its troubled financial institutions has consisted primarily of attracting foreign money by dismantling longstanding barriers against foreign ownership.
The Government said last month that it would permit foreign investors to own 100 percent of Thai financial institutions for up to 10 years, after which their interests may be diluted. Previously, the limit for banks was 25 percent.
Since then, the ING Bank of the Netherlands has bought a 10 percent stake in the Siam City Bank. The Laem Thong Bank, the country's smallest bank, sold a 40 percent stake to a group of foreign investors. The Bangkok Metropolitan Bank has sought the aid of Taiwan's Government in persuading four Taiwan institutions to invest in the bank.

HEADLINE: A Healthy Economy Shows Some Signs of Taking It a Little Easier

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
The economy remains strong but is cooling off, Government reports indicated today, showing lower orders for long-lasting goods in October and a little less total output over the summer than initially estimated.
Other statistics showed industrial conditions mixed in three metropolitan areas this month, and first-time claims for unemployment insurance suggested little softening of the job market. 
 "Over all, it looks like the economy is slowing down," said Elliott Platt, a senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "But I don't think it's any slower than 2 1/2 to 3 percent."
That kind of growth rate in gross domestic product for the current quarter would compare with the 3.3 percent for the July-to-September quarter reported today by the Commerce Department, a revision from its 3.5 percent estimate a month ago.
The reports contributed to mild rallies in the United States stock and bond markets, where investors viewed the signs of a slowdown as evidence that the economy would continue to grow without significant inflationary pressure.
Although the Dow Jones industrial average finished 14.17 points lower, broader market indicators gained. In the bond market, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, a barometer of interest-rate trends and inflation risk, fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.05 percent Tuesday.
The Federal Reserve, which has been concerned that overly rapid growth will revive inflation, has refrained from raising interest rates because of the absence of visible price pressures and because of economic turmoil in the Far East.
The latest available minutes of the Fed's Sept. 30 policy meeting showed several members of the Federal Open Market Committee "indicated that economic developments could well require a tightening of policy in the relatively near future."
Most analysts think the economy can only sustain a "speed limit" of 2.5 percent or less without reviving inflation. It has been growing at a rate of 3.3 percent or more for four straight quarters.
Growth is slowing, however. Orders for durable manufactured goods, a future indicator, fell three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the first decline since May. Orders would have tumbled 2.1 percent had it not been for a surge in transportation orders, mainly for airplanes.
The primary metals sector dropped 6.7 percent; electronic equipment dropped 3.3 percent, and industrial machinery dropped 1.9 percent, the Commerce Department's report showed.
Orders for capital goods other than aircraft and military hardware, a closely watched category, fell 4.2 percent, the second big drop in three months. Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis, told clients this decline suggested "some softening in production in the months ahead, which would be welcome news."
Shipments of durable goods, meanwhile, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent in October, also the second decline in three months.
The main reasons for the Commerce Department's lowered estimate of third-quarter G.D.P. were slowdowns in nonresidential building construction, exports of goods and services and business inventories. These more than offset higher estimates for business equipment and personal spending on durable goods.
The chief surprise, analysts said, was that inventories did not show an increase. The decline suggested that production cutbacks may not be needed to keep inventories under control. Personal consumption spending was recalculated at a 5.8 percent rate, up from 5.7 percent a month ago.
The Labor Department's tally of initial jobless claims showed a drop of 31,000, to 303,000, for the week ended last Saturday, more than offsetting a 20,000 rise the week before. On a four-week average, however, claims increased to 316,500, suggesting that payroll growth will moderate, said Stan Shipley, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
Regionally, surveys of corporate purchasing managers showed a modest improvement in industrial activity in New York, a slowdown in Milwaukee and a large increase in Chicago.
Some economists regard the survey of Chicago-area purchasing managers a harbinger of a broader survey done by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which is released at the beginning of each month.
The Government's G.D.P. report also included its first tabulation of third-quarter corporate profits, a gauge watched by policy makers to see whether business continues to improve efficiency at a time when most companies have little power to raise prices.
Profits from current production climbed 2.7 percent for the period, compared with 2 percent in the second quarter, while after-tax profits rose 1.7 percent, the same increase as in the spring.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Edge Up In Shortened Trading Day

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher in a quiet, shortened session yesterday.
Bonds received a lift from Government reports showing a surprise drop in orders for durable goods and slower-than-expected third-quarter growth. The data suggested the economy might be losing steam. 
 "Things are definitely starting to slow down," said Ken Anderson, who oversees about $7 billion in bonds for the Evergreen Asset Management Corporation in Purchase, N.Y. "There is room for bonds to rally."
Slower growth is good for bonds because it reduces the risk of inflation, which erodes the value of their fixed payments.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 6/32, to 101 5/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.04 percent, from 6.05 percent on Tuesday. The difference in yield, or spread, between the 30-year bond and the two-year note is now 33 basis points -- the narrowest in almost three years. Investors' willingness to buy long-term securities at such a narrow risk premium suggests that they are confident that inflation will remain contained.
Trading in the Treasury market ended at 2 P.M. yesterday, and will also be abbreviated tomorrow. Today, the market is closed for Thanksgiving.
Bonds fell in overseas trading amid lingering concern that Japanese investors would sell United States securities to support Japan's banks and brokerage firms. But many bond traders and investors in the United States did not see that happening, noting the higher yield Treasuries offer compared with Japan's Government bonds.
"It doesn't make sense for them to remove their highest-yielding asset from their portfolios," said William Lloyd, head of market strategy at BZW Securities Inc.
At yesterday's yield of 5.84 percent, the 10-year United States Treasury note yields 389 basis points more than the 1.95 percent yield on the No. 197 10-year Japanese bond.
Demand for Treasuries has also been bolstered by investors looking to buy securities so their portfolios mirror several indexes that serve as benchmarks for performance.
"There is enough demand at month-end that the market welcomes any drop in prices," said John Spinello, head government bond trader at Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc.
The securities firms that provide the industry indexes usually revise their structure at month's end.

HEADLINE: Dismissal of Retarded Men Puts Hertz in Federal Suit

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The way the people at Hertz look at it, the Government is punishing them for an act of charity: creating make-work jobs for two men with mental retardation.
But the way the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sees it, the Hertz Corporation is an unfair employer that made no effort to meet the needs of its employees with disabilities, and instead dismissed the men, cavalierly, because of inappropriate behavior by the job coach assigned to help them do the job. 
 The commission has charged Hertz with violating the Americans With Disabilities Act in its dismissal of Donald Klem and Kenneth Miller, two men it hired to pick up litter four hours a day at the rental-car lot on the edge of the Detroit Metropolitan Wayne County Airport.
Since Hertz knew the men could not handle the work without a job coach, the E.E.O.C. said, the company had an obligation to try to arrange for a different job coach. In sending the two men away because of their job coach's behavior, it said, Hertz was blaming the victims, and trampling on their fundamental rights as employees.
The Hertz case is the commission's first action on behalf of retarded people and concerns one of the murkiest, most contentious areas of the Federal disabilities law: how far an employer must go to accommodate an employee with disabilities.
Thousands of people with disabilities like retardation, deafness or restricted mobility can hold jobs only with the help of another person who may coach them on how to perform their tasks, do sign-language interpreting or help with basic needs like getting to the bathroom. Such aides are usually paid by social-service agencies and have no direct relationship with the employer, occupying an ambiguous status in the workplace.
The Hertz case, both sides say, could help to define employers' obligations in dealing with such aides.
Hertz hired Mr. Klem and Mr. Miller in April 1994 after being approached by a job developer from an employment agency for people with retardation. The agency promised to send a job coach with the two men to teach and supervise them, at no cost to Hertz. The agency, Arkay Inc., has about 200 retarded clients, about half of whom are in such "supported employment," mostly minimum-wage work cleaning up fast-food restaurants or doing assembling and packaging in light industry.
The Hertz job was a new placement for the agency, and for nearly two months everything went smoothly enough that Hertz officials expanded the men's tasks to include stocking and cleaning the garage and began talking about upgrading the jobs from seasonal to something permanent. Although Mr. Klem, who is 41, sometimes stopped working to watch the airplanes, and once spat on the floor in the presence of customers, he and Mr. Miller, 57, became fixtures on the lot, exchanging waves with the bus drivers who shuttle passengers to the terminals.
But on June 7, the young woman serving as their job coach, Mary Ann Watson, was visited by Jeff Alred, another job coach from the same agency. Hertz said the two were "passionately kissing and fondling each other" in a car. According to the E.E.O.C., Ms. Watson gave Mr. Alred a birthday gift and the two "exchanged a friendly hug."
Whatever took place, it bothered the Hertz managers who saw it so much that they told the job coaches to leave and not return -- and in the process dismissed Mr. Klem and Mr. Miller. Both men live in group homes and are now unemployed.
Hertz said it would no longer allow Arkay job coaches on the premises and did not respond to a letter from Greg Sundell, the executive director of Arkay, asking for reconsideration.
Mr. Sundell then called the E.E.O.C., which filed suit against Hertz in Federal court in Detroit.
"This really upset us," said Joe Russo, a spokesman for Hertz. "We had made clear that we would be willing to have the guys back. We have nothing against supported employment. But we'd had gross misconduct by two job coaches from Arkay and we did not want to work with that agency again."
Deborah Barno, a lawyer for the commission, said the re-employment offer came only after litigation began, and was too little, too late.
Furthermore, she argues, Hertz failed its obligations to Mr. Miller and Mr. Klem by dismissing them for something they had nothing to do with. As a legal matter, when an employer knows a worker has a disability, the American with Disabilities Act requires that employer make a reasonable effort to accommodate the disability.
In this case, the Government says, if Hertz was no longer willing to work with Arkay, it should have tried to find a similar agency that would have provided a job coach.
Hertz, a division of the Ford Motor Company, said it did not have, and should not be expected to have, any knowledge of other agencies. If anyone should have suggested a different agency, Hertz said, it was Arkay.
Hertz has moved for dismissal, arguing that it had not discriminated against the two men but rather had been generous beyond all legal requirements in creating the jobs.
The case boils down to two axioms, the Hertz brief said: "First, no good deed goes unpunished. Second, do no more than the law requires, since any generosity beyond that may cause you adverse consequences."
The company warned that punishing Hertz would make other employers reluctant to hire anyone who needs a job coach.
"A contrary outcome would have a chilling effect on employers and forever dampen their interest in providing anything more than the minimum that the law requires for fear of being forever bound to do so in the future," its brief said.
Disability groups, too, say the Hertz case is important, but worry about a different message. In a friend-of-court brief filed on behalf of several groups concerned with retardation, Disability Rights Advocates, an Oakland, Calif., public-interest firm, argues that if Hertz is not found to have violated the law, other employers will be free to dismiss disabled employees for all kinds of problems unrelated to their job performance.
"Should a deaf person be terminated for the misconduct of his or her sign language interpreter?" the brief asks. "Will an employer be permitted to fire a wheelchair-using employee because a third party built a ramp incorrectly?
For thousands of people like Mr. Klem and Mr. Miller, the growing acceptance of supported employment has made a world of difference. The brief said supported-employment programs had provided job opportunities to more than 140,000 people with severe disabilities who had previously been excluded from the work force. While Mr. Russo, the Hertz spokesman, said he was unaware of any other place where the company had hired a retarded person accompanied by a coach, other large companies, including Marriott, Burger King and McDonald's routinely make such arrangements.
"The importance of this case cannot be overstated," the disability advocates' brief said. "Supported employment in this country has led people with mental retardation from the nightmare of state-funded institutionalization to the freedom and efficiency of the private-sector workplace. This transformation of people from tax burdens to taxpayers has resulted in dramatically enhancing the quality of life for people with mental retardation."
Mr. Sundell, the executive director of Arkay, is not happy that a small problem on the Hertz placement is turning into a big test case.
"Our job is to develop good relationships with the companies we work with," he said. "This was just two young job coaches kissing in a parking lot, and while it's turned into an interesting academic issue, I wish it could have been resolved in a polite conversation with Hertz."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hertz dismissed Kenneth Miller, left, and Donald Klem after a dispute involving a third employee from the agency that placed them on the job. (Andrew Cutraro for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1458 words

HEADLINE: RUSSIA IS SEEKING MORE WESTERN AID FOR FINANCIAL ILLS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Worried that the global economic turmoil could overwhelm its financial system, Russia is quietly seeking American support for an expanded program of Western assistance, government officials and private bankers said.
The purpose of the aid would be to strengthen confidence in Russia's Central Bank, which has been using up its reserves in an anxious effort to prop up the ruble. 
 Prompted by the crisis that has rippled through Asia, foreign investors have been fleeing from emerging markets. They have already moved to withdraw some $4 billion from the Russian treasury bill market, Central Bank officials said.
Russian officials and private bankers fear that investors may unload billions more, putting further strain on the ruble and heightening concerns about Russia's financial system among Russians and foreigners.
That would not only be an economic setback. It could also deliver a powerful political blow to the Government of President Boris N. Yeltsin and its agenda of economic reform.
"The Central Bank's reserves are enough to take care of foreign investors," said Pavel Teplukhin, the chief economist for Troika Dialog, a Russian investment bank. "But I am afraid that if Russian investors start panicking and buying dollars, the Central Bank reserves will not be sufficient."
Mr. Teplukhin said the West could ease the crisis by promising to lend up to $5 billion to the Central Bank, though other experts said billions more might be needed.
Publicly, Central Bank officials have sought to reassure the Russian public by putting on a brave face. They have not talked about the possibility of additional assistance or said how much aid they would like to have available to them.
Russian officials estimated last week that their reserves were $21.5 billion, a healthy amount during normal times, but one that is shrinking as the global economic situation worsens.
Sergei Aleksashenko, the deputy head of the Central Bank and Sergei Vasilyev, the deputy head of the Presidential Administration, have been sent to Washington to meet with officials from the Treasury Department and the International Monetary Fund.
Their goal is to explore whether the West can make more aid available to bolster the credibility of Russia's financial system and discourage any perception that it may be too weak to cope with the crisis on the world markets. In effect, the Russians are seeking a kind of insurance policy.
American officials declined to comment on the sensitive discussions. But the United States has generally taken the stance that the Russian request should be handled by the International Monetary Fund, which would be a likely vehicle for any further assistance.
But Russia's relationship with the I.M.F. is complex. The Fund has suspended its $10 billion loan to Russia because of the Yeltsin Government's failure to crack down on tax evaders. The loan was given to Russia in 1996 to help it carry forward its free-market reforms.
Russian and I.M.F. officials have been engaged in intensive talks over steps Moscow can take so that the disbursements can be restarted. And the Central Bank's concern over the global economic turmoil adds a critical new dimension to the high-stakes deliberations.
This is not the way it was supposed to be. When the Yeltsin Government mapped out its economic strategy this year, it had a rather different scenario in mind.
The Government had already conquered soaring inflation. The aim of Yeltsin aides was to generate economic growth and put Russia's fiscal house in order.
The economic planning was part of a broader political strategy. The hope was that a growing economy would give a boost to pro-free market politicians during the next presidential election in 2000 and keep the hard-line nationalists and Communists at bay.
Toward this end, Mr. Yeltsin promised to overhaul Russia's antiquated tax system and undertake other reforms.
The Government also planned to reduce Russia's huge budget deficit and push down the interest rate on Russian treasury bills to 14 percent by the end of the year.
The Russian Government has financed much of the deficit by issuing treasury bills at high interest rates. But Russia's dependence on treasury bills has raised the Government's debt-serving costs, and high interest rates have hurt the chances for economic growth.
Then the Asian economies faltered, triggering a downturn in global stock markets.
Despite its success in stabilizing its economy, Russia discovered it was particularly vulnerable to the disarray in the global capital markets. Korean investors needed money to cover their losses in Asia and began selling their Russian Eurobonds, driving the price down.
As foreign investors reflexively began pulling their money out of emerging markets, the Russia stock market has falen about 40 percent since early October.
Foreign investors also moved to sell their Russian treasury bills. That was particularly worrisome because foreign investors owned an estimated $15 billion to $20 billion in treasury bills, about a third of the treasury market.
To prevent panic selling, the Central Bank has established a system that requires foreign investors to give a month's notice to sell the bills and convert the rubles they receive from the sales into dollars.
But now a month has almost elapsed since the onset of the crisis, prompting Sergei K. Dubinin, the Chairman of Russian's Central Bank, to call this a "decisive" period.
The Central Bank took one important step: It raised the interest rate of treasury bills to 28 percent from 21 percent to encourage foreign investors to stay in the treasury bill market.
There are other strains.
Russian banks lost money on the stock markets and in bonds. Many of them also have contracts with Western investors requiring them to convert rubles into dollars at agreed-on exchange rates. That makes Russian banks particularly vulnerable if Russia's currency is devalued.
Mr. Teplukhin of Troika Dialog said devaluation could also cause panic among ordinary Russians.
"The public does not feel the immediate effect of high interest rates," he said in an interview. "In Russia, we don't have mortgages. What the public looks at every single day is exchange rate policy."
So far, the Central Bank has been basically maintaining the exchange rate by dipping into its reserve to buy rubles. But the Central Bank's reserves are not unlimited, and include $4.8 billion in gold, which cannot be immediately spent.
Economists estimate that the bank is spending another $4 billion or so to cope with the withdrawal of foreigners from the treasury bill market. The Central Bank is spending still more to deal with Russian investors who are converting their rubles to dollars.
Some economists and investment bankers say more needs to be done. They say the Central Bank needs to hike interest rates once again to discourage the exodus of foreign investors.
The Government, they add, needs to reduce spending and step up revenue collection to shrink the deficit.
But some economists also say additional Western assistance may be needed to ease concern that the Central Bank's reserves are not adequate and to help Russia stabilize its currency.
Economists said Russia could gain some short-term relief by resolving its differences with the I.M.F. over fiscal policy, thus prompting the Fund to renew the disbursement of its loan.
The release a $700 million installment held up since October as well as the disbursement for the first part of 1998 would provide Russia with some $1.4 billion.
It would also unlock more than $1 billion in World Bank disbursements, which have also been delayed as the bank waits for the I.M.F. to give its seal of approval to the Russian economy.
In the meantime, the economic turmoil is threatening to take a political toll. Top Yeltsin aides say the Government may no longer be able to fulfill its much-ballyhooed promise to pay back wages.
The delay in paying wages is a politically explosive issue. Mr. Yeltsin has publicly insisted that the wages be paid, but financial aides say the money is just not there.
Compounding the problem in raising Government revenue, a major privatization was deferred this week when a prominent Russian bank could not come up with enough money to make a bid. Economists say the bank was forced to put off a bond issue because of the turmoil in the world financial markets.
Renaissance Capital, a Moscow-based investment bank, noted that the situation is not entirely in Russia's hands. Much will depend on whether the crisis persists in the world capital markets.
"While not a source of the recent waves of emerging market anxiety, Russia could become a victim," it said in a report.

HEADLINE: ON PRO FOOTBALL;
Broncos' Secret Is Out: Psst! It's Rod Smith

BYLINE: By Thomas George 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
It was a locker room filled with spirit, filled with joy, just the kind of emotion expected from one of pro football's top teams.
The Denver Broncos, 34-13 winners over the New England Patriots at Mile High Stadium last month, were absolutely ebullient then in what was their signature game of this season. And their emotion and style from it have endured. 
 "This is nothing new for me," boasted Tim McKyer, a Broncos cornerback and a two-time Super Bowl champion with San Francisco. "I know what this feels like. We mix experience with youth. And that team over there, we've got their number."
Denver (10-2) has soundly beaten New England twice in the last two years, and the Broncos' only losses this season have come on the road in their division at Oakland and Kansas City. Games remain at San Diego, Pittsburgh and San Francisco, and then Denver finishes the regular season at home against the Chargers.
The Broncos are the front-runners to claim home-field advantage throughout the American Football Conference playoffs. They would like to creep quietly there, but the rest of the conference, after watching them dismantle the Patriots, the defending A.F.C. champions, and then after seeing their 31-3 mauling of the Raiders on Monday night, well, the rest of the A.F.C. hears the Broncos' footsteps.
Broncos receiver Rod Smith is that way. He wants to quietly creep up on the enemy. But they already hear Smith's footsteps.
Entering this season, a question mark concerning the Broncos was whether they possessed a big-play receiver who could stretch defenses, a home run hitter. Anthony Miller has gone to Dallas, and was there anyone left who could fill the role?
Enter Smith.
With all of their talent and leadership, Denver's X-factor is Rod Smith. We do not know just how good he can be. He is 6 feet and 195 pounds, a striking figure at receiver, a guy who can block as well as he can catch. He is not afraid to get his uniform dirty. He is hungry.
"Nobody knows me," Smith said. "They don't know what I can do. The defensive backs haven't had time to study me. That keeps me a good part of the game plan. I don't want them to know me -- until the end."
Opponents are getting to know Smith quite well. He has 53 receptions for 899 yards and averages 17 yards a catch, best in the league. He has seven scoring passes, including a 78-yarder.
Football personnel experts knew little and cared little about Smith in 1994. He left Missouri Southern with three degrees (economics, marketing and business administration) and nice receiving numbers. But he was not drafted and signed with Denver as a free agent.
He spent 1994 on the practice squad and spent most of the last two seasons on special teams. He missed six games last season because of a broken collarbone. These were Smith's numbers entering this season: 26 games (2 starts), 22 catches, 3 touchdowns, 23 punt returns. Hardly anything to make a defense shiver.
"I looked over at Terry Glenn for New England, and he has it all," Smith said, referring to the Patriots' wide receiver. "First-round pick. Rookie of the year in a lot of people's books last year. A millionaire."
Don't you make a million, Smith was asked? "Not even close," he answered, laughing.
Smith, 27, is earning $400,000 this season. The Broncos have a steal. And now they have a deep threat that makes them complete, not only on offense, but also an edge that makes them favorites to get to the Super Bowl.
"He is very competitive; he just wants the ball," McKyer said of Smith. "Sometimes with him, there is nothing a defensive back can do."
Broncos back Vaughn Hebron said: "He is a trooper. Easygoing and so athletic. He has been overlooked. He was supposed to be one of our weak spots, but Rod has proved to be a special guy. He makes plays, his actions speak and he is stepping out into his own."
The veteran safety Steve Atwater added, "Rod is the man."
Smith is from Texarkana, Ark., also home of Willie Davis, the former Green Bay Packer and Hall of Famer. Nothing pleases him more than the accolades from his teammates. He is a model of perseverance. How many stars in this league languished on the practice squad and on special teams before reaching the level Smith has?
"I'm just doing my job," Smith said. "I tell my friends: 'There is no difference from me and you. I just have a job that is a little more famous.'
"But I have found in any job that if you follow the rules and work hard you can't lose. Coaches can sense players who are hungry. I never doubted my abilities. There was a time there where I doubted if I would get the chance."
Smith is active in charities and with youth organizations. His teammates say he has an innate giving nature. So, it is little wonder that he wants to share his success.
These Broncos realize that the finish is more important than the start. They were 13-3 last season and then were promptly kicked from the playoffs, at home, by Jacksonville. These Broncos are intent on persevering through this season. They need look no further than one of their own, at Smith, for a model.
"The whole thing is to take advantage of opportunities," Smith said. "Don't sit back and let it slip. Go day by day and get through until tomorrow. Every day I come to work, I say: 'Well, I got another day of work. Another day.'
"Even if the Broncos were to cut me today, how did I fail? I only fail if I quit. The hardest part for me now is to help more people get where I am. To help kids realize their dreams, whether it is football or not. I go out to the kids. I share with people. I want them to see me without my helmet on."

HEADLINE: American Negotiator Hedges Over Climate Treaty Talks

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
Saying that criticisms by other countries of the United States' position on global warming are "ill-founded," the Clinton Administration's new chief negotiator on a climate treaty acknowledged today that it might not be possible to bridge the remaining differences with Europe and the developing world.
"We are not going in with the notion that we have to have an agreement at any cost," Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat said in a telephone conversation with journalists as he prepared to lead the American delegation to talks that will begin next week in Japan. 
 "We will go to Kyoto and make an all-out effort," Mr. Eizenstat said. But he added that he was "neither optimistic nor pessimistic, but realistic," about the difficulties.
"We must remember that nations remain quite far apart," he said, "and achieving agreement will be a challenge."
Whether his comments were meant to lower expectations and pave the way for possible failure or a weakened treaty, or to raise the pressure and persuade other countries to make concessions, Mr. Eizenstat's remarks were more guarded than those made recently by his predecessor as chief negotiator, Tim Wirth. Mr. Wirth had said that differences with Europe, especially, were not so great and were shrinking.
In contrast, Mr. Eizenstat said that the United States had "significant problems" with a central feature of Europe's position: that members of the European Union be considered as a unit in achieving reductions in the emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap the sun's heat like a greenhouse, rather than requiring each nation to achieve reductions. He called it "an artificial advantage, and one that no other country or set of countries has."
The United States, Mr. Eizenstat said, would insist that many developing countries agree to binding reductions in their emissions of those gases "over a reasonable period of time," but he added that these commitments need not be the same as the targets for developed countries.
The commitments must come from the wealthier developing countries, measured by per capita income, and from the developing countries that, because of their sheer size, emit large amounts of such greenhouse gases, Mr. Eizenstat said.
Those countries would probably include, among others, the top five sources of carbon dioxide emissions in the developing world: China, India, South Korea, South Africa and Mexico, which among them in 1996 gave off almost as much greenhouse gases as the United States. Their emissions have been growing much faster than American emissions, although emissions per person in the United States are much greater.
"We are talking about focusing on key developing countries," Mr. Eizenstat said. "They have to make a meaningful contribution."
Mr. Eizenstat said a provision in the current draft of the proposed treaty, allowing developing countries to sign up voluntarily for binding emissions targets, was a positive step toward what the Administration is seeking. But he said that a treaty, to be acceptable, also had to provide for international trading of emission control credits, which would let countries like the United States pay for reductions to be made in other countries instead of making domestic cuts at greater expense.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat said yesterday that talks next week in Japan on a global climate treaty would be difficult. (Chuck Kennedy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Disney in Licensing Deal for Tokyo Park

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 26

 BODY:
Building on the success of Tokyo Disneyland, the Walt Disney Company said today that it had entered into a licensing agreement for a new ocean-theme park on Tokyo Bay.
The $2.6 billion Tokyo Disneysea, to be built on 167 acres of bay landfill, is expected to draw more than 10 million visitors a year, Disney said. 
 The park will be built, owned and operated by the Oriental Land Company, the owner of Tokyo Disneyland. Disney will license its names and characters and act as a consultant in the park's construction and operation, said Jim Cora, president of Disneyland International.
Tokyo Disneyland typically is the company's best-attended park, attracting more than 17 million visitors last year, Mr. Cora said. It also has the highest per-capital expenditures by visitors of any Disney park, said Steve Balgrosky, a theme park industry analyst with Economics Research Associates in Los Angeles.
The announcement was the latest in a series of expansions planned by Disney. The company is scheduled next year to open the 500-acre Disney Animal Kingdom at Walt Disney World in Florida. The company also is starting Disney Quest, high-tech game centers that eventually will be in 20 or more United States cities, and the ESPN Grill, themed restaurants and game centers based on the ESPN sports network.
Disneysea will include seven areas, including one based on the stories of Jules Verne.

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Mixed, With Dow Off 14.17

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Investors gained some solace from calmer markets in Asia yesterday, but uncertainty about the extent of the problems in the region and the fallout on corporate earnings of American multinationals left Wall Street stocks mixed.
While Japan's benchmark stock index rose 1.1 percent yesterday, changing gears after a 5.1 percent stumble Tuesday, multinational companies like Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down 14.17 points, to 7,794.78, as broader market indexes eked out small gains. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.82 point, to 951.64. 
 "I think it makes sense for investors to be wary of what's happening," said Barbara Marcin, senior portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management.
Although American multinational corporations receive only a small percentage of their earnings from Asia, Ms. Marcin believes that the downturn in that region could have a broader impact worldwide by damping demand for other countries' products as well.
Asian markets continued to steady early today. At the midday recess in trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stocks was ahead by 290.41 points, or 1.81 percent, at 16,335.96.
South Korean stocks ended their morning session down 2.32 points, or a half of 1 percent, at 436.38, while Hong Kong stocks were little changed in early trading.
Despite the calm in Asian stock markets, Japan's financial problems are worrying some strategists in the United States.
"This development can't be overlooked; it's not a transitory event," Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Smith Barney said of the recent bank and brokerage firm failures in Japan. But, investors and analysts are having a difficult time gauging the impact because "we don't know how much Asia is going to slow down and we don't know what industries and companies are going to be affected."
As a result, being wary of multinationals is an "appropriate first response," Mr. Acuff added.
And comments from Asian and American leaders at the Asia Pacific economic conference in Vancouver, British Columbia, did not totally reassure investors that the crisis was under control, said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City, Kan.
"The Canada conversations were mostly to say that the central banks are prepared to insure liquidity in the event of more problems," Mr. Herrmann said.
"It's good for depositors, but I don't know that that's all that reassuring" for investors, he added.
While the Asian crisis unfolds, Mr. Herrmann believes investors should avoid cyclical stocks, which would perform poorly if the Asian economic slowdown is a significant drag on American growth, and companies in the capital goods sector, such as heavy-equipment manufacturers.
Instead, they should focus on companies with more predictable earnings from domestic sources and little exposure to emerging markets.
"I think there are opportunities on a long-term basis, but I wouldn't want to be calling the bottom," he said. Clearer signs of the impact on United States companies may not come until first-quarter earnings reports in 1998, he said.
Some investors seem to be in Mr. Herrmann's camp. Alan Bond, chief investment officer for Bond Procope Capital Managagment which oversees $500 million, is reducing his exposure to technology shares like Applied Materials, the leading maker of semiconductor maufacturing equipment, and will not increase his holdings of money center banks with exposure to Asia.
Instead, he's buying retailers like Costco and regional banks like Fifth Third Bancorp in Cincinnati, Sovereign Bancorp in Wyomissing, Pa. and Northern Trust Corporation in Chicago.
"We're not running for the hills, but it's certainly a run for cover," Mr. Bond said of his more domestic stance.
Elizabeth Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear, Stearns, said investors could consider multinational companies with limited exposure to Asia such as American Express and Hewlett-Packard. For Hewlett, "Europe is probably more important to them than Asia," she added.
Ms. Marcin of Citibank said she believed that some declines among multinationals may have been overdone and investors should consider picking up capital goods stocks like Deere, Boeing and Raytheon. Having exposure to overseas markets is still "an attractive long-term quality for a company to have," she said. And some investors believe that even as events unfold, it is safe to stick a toe or even wade into Asian waters.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Asia Lull Helps Markets, But Wall Street Is Still Wary
Calmer markets in Asia yesterday provided some solace to investors in the United States. Although the Dow Jones industrial average retreated for a 14.17-point loss, most stock indexes finished with small gains. 
 But the American markets remained unsettled by the unknown extent of the economic problems that have engulfed the so-called tiger economies of Southeast Asia and now appear to threaten Japan. D3.
 
The Pacific summit meeting in Vancouver produced a reassuring message that Asia's financial crisis will be contained. But there are reasons to doubt that the key players can prevent the crisis from worsening first. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. D2.
 
Japan's promises to restore calm in its banking system helped the yen gain slightly against the dollar, one day after the Japanese currency touched a five-year low. D11.
 
China Sees Danger Signs
China suffers from heavier external debt, more bad loans and a shakier banking system than any of its Asian neighbors. Still, the region's problems may give officials in Beijing -- in particular China's chief economic official, Deputy Prime Minister Zhu Rongji -- the impetus they need to push through change in the financial system. News Analysis. A8.
 
Russia Unsettled by Asian Fallout
Worried about the global economic turmoil emanating from Asia, Russia is quietly seeking American support for an expanded program of Western assistance, primarily to strengthen confidence in its central bank, officials and private bankers said. A1.
 
Cancer Treatment Approved
The Food and Drug Administration approved a new genetically engineered drug for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The drug, Rituxan, will be made and marketed by Genentech Inc. A28.
 
$1 Billion Phone Deal
ACC, largely a long-distance company, agreed to be acquired by Teleport Communications Group, which provides local phone service, in a stock swap valued at $1 billion. D16.
 
Lauders to Pay I.R.S. $40 Million
Relatives of Estee Lauder, the octogenarian founder of the cosmetics company, closed out a stock transaction intended to defer capital gains, now far costlier under the new tax law that the Lauder family's tax-deferral strategy helped inspire. As a result, the Lauders will pay $40 million in taxes. D2.
 
Revolt Against Managed Care
The baby-boomer generation, which has set the national agenda for three decades, is increasingly balking at constraints imposed by H.M.O.'s, slowing the managed-care trend that seemed unstoppable a few years ago. A1.
 
Higher OPEC Production Seen
Emissaries from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met in Jakarta, Indonesia, with the common aim of raising output, and it appeared they could reach an agreement by Saturday. D4.
 
Crude oil prices fell sharply in reaction to the likelihood of higher OPEC production quotas. The January-delivery contract for light sweet crude fell 58 cents, to $19.15 a barrel. Prices for refined petroleum also dropped. D11.
 
Eurotunnel Bankruptcy Averted
Eurotunnel's creditors approved a plan restructuring more than $14 billion in debt amassed by the undersea thoroughfare linking Britain and France. D4.
 
Meditrust Quits Hotel Talks
Meditrust withdrew from talks about buying Interstate Hotels, the nation's largest independent hotelier, for a reported $1.3 billion. Interstate is said to be close to a deal with Patriot American Hospitality. D2.
 
U.S. Markets Closed
Financial markets in the United States are closed today for Thanksgiving. Most overseas markets, however, are open. United States markets will reopen tomorrow.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Russia Seeks Assistance In Avoiding Fiscal Turmoil
Russia is seeking American support for Western financial aid to prevent the global economic turmoil from overwhelming its financial system, Government officials said. A1 

Iraqi Invitations to Palaces
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq invited foreign experts, but not U.N. inspectors, to live in his palaces for a month to refute American accusations that there are weapons hidden in any of them. A Canadian inquiry recommended that thousands of Canadians who contracted the AIDS virus and hepatitis C from contaminated blood should be compensated without having to file suit. The former wife of President Nelson Mandela had tried to ruin the bishop with allegations of sexual abuse. The appeal followed testimony before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is examining Mrs. Madikizela-Mandela's role in a dozen murders and many assaults. A13

Nuclear experts from utilities around the country have told Commonwealth Edison, the nation's largest private operator of reactors, that operations at its Zion plant near Chicago show serious weaknesses in safety management and a "complete lack of progress" in addressing its problems. A1

Attorney General Janet Reno cut short an official trip to Mexico after fainting at a reception on Tuesday and spending the night at a Mexico City hospital, where she complained of nausea and dizziness. Ms. Reno was found to have gallstones, although it was not clear whether that condition was related to the symptoms that led to her hospitalization. She felt well enough to check out of the hospital for a meeting with President Ernesto Zedillo of Mexico and a speech to a conference of prosecutors from the Western Hemisphere. And later, she flew to Florida, where she will spend Thanksgiving with her family. A33
 
Cancer Resistance Studied
A new study describes a way to overcome the resistance cancer cells quickly develop when treated with many drugs. In experiments involving mice, researchers attacked the cells which build capillaries, a network of fine blood vessels that nurture fast-growing tumors. Those cells proved incapable of developing resistance. A28
 
Lymphoma Treatment Seen
The Food and Drug Administration approved a new genetically engineered drug for the treatment of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. The drug, Rituxan, was shown in clinical trials to be comparable to chemotherapy in slowing progression of the disease, but with the advantage of fewer side effects. A28

Saying that criticisms by other countries of the United States' position on global warming are "ill-founded," the Clinton Administration's new chief negotiator on a climate treaty acknowledged that it might not be possible to bridge the remaining differences with Europe and the developing world. A32

Allegations this week of corruption in the District of Columbia's police force have led to another round of despair over the management of the nation's capital. The city's police chief, Larry D. Soulsby, resigned after a trouble-plagued 28 months as the head of a department awash in scandal over unsolved murders, hapless criminal investigations, lost evidence and excessive overtime. A26

Flight 800 pointed to both as potential causes of a mid-air explosion. The directors of food pantries and social service agencies say there has been a significant increase in hunger in New York City since the end of summer, when Federal welfare law cut off thousands of immigrants from food stamps. Many assistance programs have begun to run out of food, and are cutting back their hours or preparing less expensive, meatless meals. City officials agreed to spend an extra $2 million to restock programs that have been running out of food. HEADLINE: Tests on Mice Block a Defense by Cancer

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS WADE 

 BODY:
Many drugs work well at first against cancer, but the tumor cells quickly develop resistance. A concept for getting around the resistance problem has now been proved, at least in laboratory mice, and may well prove relevant to the treatment of human cancer.
The idea is to attack the cells that build capillaries, a network of fine blood vessels that nurture fast-growing tumors. It exploits the fact that the capillary-making cells are normal, genetically stable cells and should therefore, unlike tumor cells, be incapable of developing resistance. 
 Researchers at Children's Hospital in Boston report that the capillary-making cells in mouse tumors did not develop resistance to repeated doses of a recently discovered agent that inhibits their activity. A second finding, both unexpected and unexplained, was that although the tumors at first grew back when the drug was withheld, they did not recur after two or more repetitions. The results are being published today in the journal Nature.
"For years, we thought you could hold tumors in check with angiogenesis inhibitors, but to actually cure them is amazing," said Dr. Noel Bouck, an expert on blood vessel formation, or angiogenesis, at Northwestern University Medical School in Chicago.
Dr. Douglas Hanahan, a cancer biologist at the University of California at San Francisco, said that "the reality is not going to be as exciting as the response in these mice" but that he expected angiogenesis inhibitors in time to become a useful component of cancer therapy.
The idea of retarding tumors by attacking their blood supply system is not new. The first generation of angiogenesis-inhibiting drugs is now undergoing clinical trials. But at least some of these drugs attack the tumor cells themselves, by aiming at the chemical signals with which they trick the vessel-making cells into building a blood supply for them. The tumor cells can switch to other chemical signals and thus become resistant.
In January, researchers from Dr. Judah Folkman's laboratory at Children's Hospital reported their discovery of an agent that singles out active capillary-making cells and shuts them down. The researchers, led by Dr. Michael O'Reilly, named the substance endostatin. Unlike the first generation of angiogenesis inhibitors, which merely retard the growth of tumors in experimental mice, endostatin makes tumors shrink to microscopic size, as does another agent named angiostatin. A speck of angiostatin was first distilled by Dr. O'Reilly in 1994 from about 21 quarts of mouse urine.
With endostatin in hand, the Boston team was able to aim specifically for the capillary-making cells and address the question of whether they would develop resistance. Using mice with a particularly aggressive kind of tumor, they injected endostatin in stop-and-start cycles, a pattern that favors the emergence of resistance to drugs.
At first, the tumors shrank when their blood supply was cut off and then they grew back when endostatin was stopped. As predicted, in cycle after cycle the capillary-making cells did not develop resistance to the agent. Around last Thanksgiving, Dr. O'Reilly noticed that the tumors were no longer growing back after endostatin was withdrawn. Tumor cells were still there but had reverted to a dormant cluster, too small to need its own blood supply, and had not grown back throughout the lifetimes of the mice.
Dr. Folkman reported these results at a recent meeting of cancer biologists in Frederick, Md. When he presented a graph showing the mouse tumors growing and regressing several times and then lapsing into dormancy, there was an audible gasp, Dr. Bouck said.
"It was really one of those magical moments in science," she said.
The ability of endostatin to make mouse tumors regress without developing resistance is "unprecedented and could herald a new era of cancer treatment," Dr. Robert S. Kerbel wrote in a commentary in Nature, adding, however, that the era "could be years away."
It was Dr. Kerbel, a cancer biologist at the Sunnybrook Health Science Center in Toronto, who suggested six years ago that targeting the capillary-making cells should be the way around the problem of drug resistance. Dr. Kerbel said that neither he nor others could test the idea at the time because suitable agents to be directed at the capillary-making cells were not available.
The patent on both the mouse and human forms of angiostatin belongs to Children's Hospital. It has licensed them to Entremed, a small biotechnology company in Rockville, Md., which has been a major supporter of Dr. Folkman's research since 1994. Entremed has in turn licensed Bristol Myers-Squibb, a large pharmaceuticals company, to produce and market angiostatin. The company also has an option, not yet exercised, to develop endostatin.
"We are several years away from clinical trials," Dr. Folkman said, adding that at present his laboratory could barely produce enough endostatin for its own research needs.
Both the angiostatin and endostatin, isolated by Dr. O'Reilly and his colleagues in Dr. Folkman's laboratory, are from mice, but there is every reason to assume that the human versions have the same or similar properties. By one of nature's economies, both agents are part of larger protein molecules. Angiostatin is a fragment of a substance called plasminogen, involved in blood clotting, and endostatin is the tail end of a kind of collagen, a protein of connective tissue.
Both agents become active when cut loose from their parent protein. These fragments may be produced all the time to make sure the blood vessel system is firmly restrained, Dr. Hanahan said, or they may be generated just after processes that require new blood vessels, like wound healing.
Dr. Folkman said he did not yet know how or why the endostatin forced the mouse tumor cells into dormancy, nor is it known how endostatin acts on the capillary-making cells.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Loan Pool for Health Care

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Four of New York City's largest banks have established a $25 million pool of low-interest loans dedicated to building and expanding health care centers in the city's low-income neighborhoods, said the Primary Care Development Corporation, a nonprofit group that will administer the loans.
Loans of up to $3 million, with an interest rate of about 6 percent, are intended for family clinics, dental offices and other health care projects. 
 The group said its first two loans would be for Brooklyn projects: $2.2 million to expand a pediatric center in Bushwick and $1.6 million to convert a warehouse into a family clinic in Flatbush.
J. P. Morgan, the Chase Manhattan Bank, Citibank and Republic National Bank have helped finance the project, which has received grants from the Federal Government and New York State, the group said.
Bank executives said the project enabled them to support health care and economic development in poor areas. THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Andrew Tobias;
Always Playing With Money

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
THE year was 1977, New York City was broke, and a thrifty 30-year-old magazine writer was buying his first apartment: two bedrooms in the San Remo on Central Park West for $41,000. Twenty years later, it will surprise no one that the value of the apartment (more than $600,000) has grown along with the fortunes of the city.
"If I'd had any brains," says Andrew Tobias, who concedes that when he was at Harvard, he was better at making money than going to class, "I'd have spent an extra $10,000 for a view, and it would be worth $1 million now." Still, Mr. Tobias calls the apartment the best investment he ever made. 
 Which is saying something. Mr. Tobias, the financial writer with the sense of the absurd, has sold more than a million copies of "The Only Investment Guide You'll Ever Need" (Harcourt Brace). He grew rich with a line of personal-finance software, until Windows and Quicken made it obsolete. Now, he is the author of "My Vast Fortune: The Money Adventures of a Quixotic Capitalist" (Random House), an amusing look back at the eccentric financial life of a man with a Fifth Avenue childhood and an enormous sense of guilt.
The memoir chronicles the success of an investor who is haunted by a feeling that everything is his fault, or at least his responsibility. Mr. Tobias embarked on his most quixotic adventure when he spent $250,000 battling Ralph Nader and unsuccessfully fighting for no-fault auto insurance in California, where he has never lived. (He joined the battle when a state senator tried to turn a book Mr. Tobias wrote about auto insurance into a California constitutional amendment. "I said great," Mr. Tobias says. "But he said 'Don't get too excited, it won't pass.' ") Mr. Tobias also bought air time in 1993 and 1994 in the former Soviet Union to appear in his own antismoking commercials, on which he spoke the Russian he learned in high school. He measures his success by the parody the commercials inspired on a Russian Ed Sullivan-style show. "The happiest day of my life," he says, pleased that somebody was paying attention.
Mr. Tobias, 50, is talking in the crown jewel of his investments, the San Remo apartment, his home for two fall months of the year. (Today he will be there, too, to crane his neck through the window to watch the Thanksgiving Day parade. Then he'll have turkey at his mother and stepfather's apartment on Central Park South.) Mr. Tobias's primary residence has been Miami since the 1980's, when he lost an elaborate war with New York City over $44,000 in unincorporated business taxes -- he argued that it was absurd to tax a writer as a business, especially for income earned outside New York -- but he eventually gave up, paid, then moved. "I didn't leave over the money," he says. "I left over the way they treated me like a criminal."
In any case, he likes to visit. He takes a guest into the kitchen, opens his refrigerator -- there's fuchsia-colored ostrich meat, flown in from Louisiana, in the freezer -- and offers a Starbucks Frappuccino. For the place of a man who prides himself on frugality, it is decorated well and expensively in the style of fin-de-siecle Upper West Side: two enormous white sofas that swallow up the occupants, deep-blue dining room walls hung with framed New Yorker cartoons, a sleek washer-dryer combination from Germany that cost, with tax and delivery, $4,300.
"I had a heart attack when we bought this thing," Mr. Tobias says.
He liked the apartment's former 1970's look. "I had wonderful Haitian cotton Door Store everything," he says. "I thought it was great."
The decorator is Mr. Tobias's companion of three years, Charles Nolan, who designs the Ellen Tracy clothing line with Linda Allard. Their relationship is a source of happiness for Mr. Tobias, who used the pen name John Reid to write "The Best Little Boy in the World" (1973), a funny, poignant memoir about growing up gay. In the last five years, Mr. Tobias has gradually come out, and relaxed. "It's very nice to be able to be who you are," he says.
He is as cheerful and self-deprecating as his writing, a man who has always liked "being with" money, as he puts it, but has always had the urge to give as much as half of his income away. He gives to, among others, Steven Spielberg's Shoah Project, which videotapes testimony of Holocaust survivors, Zero Population Growth, a scholarship that pays full tuition for a student at Xavier University in New Orleans and, yes, the Democratic National Committee. "Nobody wants campaign finance reform more than me," he says. "It would save me a fortune."
But why no-fault auto insurance?
"It's the last thing people want to think about," he says sheepishly. "Believe me, often I think, 'Oh God, if only I hadn't gotten into this.' But somehow I fell into this thing, and it's kind of my responsiblity. If I'm not going to do it, knowing as much about it as I do, then no one's going to do it." He traces his involvement to the day in 1978 when his literary agent, Nan Talese, brought him a stack of insurance texts that led to "The Invisible Bankers," Mr. Tobias's book about abuse in the insurance industry. The texts were throwaways from Ms. Talese's husband, Gay Talese, who chose to write instead about sex in "Thy Neighbor's Wife."
"Not for nothing does Talese get the big bucks," Mr. Tobias wrote in his new book.
Mr. Tobias takes up 46 pages in his new book with the intricacies of the no-fault insurance battle but does acknowledge on page 100 that he may be the only person who finds it fascinating. He apologizes on page 106, saying he knows it is time to wrap up, but then goes on until page 115. He concedes he is obsessed, but for a reason. "Here's a way that as a nation we could be meaningfully more prosperous and more humane to people who are hurt in car crashes," he says.
His position on true no-fault is that it will usher in a world without lawsuits, in which drivers need buy insurance only to protect themselves. In essence, his California battle was against trial lawyers, and he was horrified to conclude that Ralph Nader, his onetime hero, was on their side. In fact, the title of his book's insurance chapter is "Ralph Nader Is a Big Fat Idiot."
Mr. Tobias will not own up to how vast his fortune is, although he hints that it is somewhere in the $10 million range. It is a "tongue in cheek" vast fortune, he emphasizes, particularly in New York, where he says there are apartments he can't afford. In his view, his friend David Geffen, a founding partner of Dreamworks SKG, has a vast fortune.
"If he has an ocean liner fortune, I have a rowboat," he says. "But most people just have toy boats in the bathtub, so I'm very happy."
Mr. Tobias says he began accumulating his fortune in 1952, when his father, an advertising executive, gave him $5 for his fifth birthday. He liked the feel of dollar bills in his pocket, was competitive and came to see money as a way of keeping score. He grew up in what he calls a "basic, blessed, very upper middle class" home on Fifth Avenue and 68th Street, with weekends at the family's country house in Bedford in Westchester County.
Mr. Tobias's mother adored him and told him regularly that he was a gifted child, although he remembers himself as profoundly "out of it," particularly on the day in the second grade when a new driver on the bus home from Hunter Elementary School asked him where he lived. Mr. Tobias hadn't a clue. "I panicked," he recalls. "Nobody told me there was going to be a quiz."
At Harvard, Mr. Tobias found that he was far less interested in reading Russian novels than in trying to put "Let's Go," then a slender Harvard Student Agencies guide to Europe, into the black. Mr. Tobias installed a WATS line, recruited students to phone bookstores across the country, conducted a customer survey and appeared, 18 and terrified, on "Today." By the time he graduated in 1968, "Let's Go" was making money (today it is a series of 26 travel guides) and Mr. Tobias had earned enough to buy an Acapulco-blue Mustang for $2,411.
He went to work as a writer for New York magazine at $18,000 a year and hardly ever took cabs because they stood in the way of saving money. "I was one of the cheapest guys on the face of the planet," he writes. In 1976, he was given $10,000 "to play with" by Esquire magazine for a monthly column on the stock market. Mr. Tobias was to report to readers on his gains and losses. His first instinct was to invest in municipal bonds that were to mature in 2004, but he realized that this would make for a good column every 28 years, at the time of purchase and the time of redemption. He believed then, as now, that patience, not pizazz, is the best investment strategy.
Nine months later, after adventures in oil-field-service-company stocks and "dumb little stereo and electronics companies that nearly went bankrupt," Mr. Tobias had $13,992. "I did all the things that one shouldn't do," he says. "I bet on tips from friends, and that kind of stuff. It violated all my principles." Today, he owns "a whole other set of dumb stocks," including shares in an umbrella company in Thailand, where the economy is collapsing. "I'm not suggesting this was smart," he says.
Mr. Tobias is also working on a sequel to "The Best Little Boy in the World" and writing a daily financial column on the Internet (available through www.ameritrade.com). His investment advice remains as prudent and simple as ever: make a budget, scrimp, pay off credit cards, quit smoking, fully fund your retirement plan and tomorrow start putting away whatever you can afford in short- and intermediate-term Treasuries, as well as no-load, low-expense stock market index funds.
Mr. Tobias is still something of a tightwad, although he does take cabs now, indulges himself in a historic-document collection (he has a complete collection of signatures from the Munchkins in "The Wizard of Oz") and passes up fatty ground beef for lean ostrich burgers. "They taste like ketchup," he says.
His most amusing indulgence remains parting with his money.
"There's no such thing as altruism," he says. "I'm being selfish. I really get a tremendous charge out of trying to do these things."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday in the House & Home section about Andrew Tobias, the financial writer with a sense of the absurd, and the apartment on Central Park West where he sojourns in the autumn, misstated his affiliation with Nan Talese in 1978. She was his editor, not his literary agent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 38; Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 148 words

HEADLINE: Managed Care Logic

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The health care industry portrays itself as an economic victim of empty beds (news article, Nov. 22), yet those beds are empty by its own design. The beds increase revenue, and like all valuable merchandise they command a high price: more than $264,000 each in 1996 hospital merger deals. 
 The perverse logic of managed care -- denying access while increasing layoffs of the highest skilled care givers -- has become the medical fast track to increased market share and profits. The empty-by-design strategy allows the industry to serve larger geographic areas with fewer beds, fewer services and fewer skilled care givers while dumping the sickest and most expensive patients on public and other underfinanced hospitals.
The strategy works, but not for patients.
 
ROSE ANN DEMORO
Exec. Dir., California Nurses Assn.
San Francisco, Nov. 25, 1997

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

HEADLINE: America's Top Truck Is Turning 50

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE granddaddy of the modern American pickup truck, the Ford F-Series, will be a half-century old next week.
Much has changed since Dec. 3, 1947, when the nation was swept up in postwar optimism and the first F-Series trucks rolled off an assembly line in Atlanta. The 1948 model F-1 -- the smallest, half-ton version of a series that ranged up to the three-ton F-8 -- had chrome trim, boxy fenders and exposed running boards, but they were a big step toward modernity compared with the bulbous trucks they replaced, whose basic design dated to 1938. 
 And the '48 pickup begat a long and successful bloodline. More than 26 million F-Series trucks have been built, and more than 8 million remain on the road. This autumn, the series is well on its way to winning the title of America's best-selling vehicle for the 16th consecutive year. In 1996, Ford sold more than 780,000 F-Series trucks, nearly twice as many as the No. 1 car, the Taurus.
Ford is noting the milestone with a 50th anniversary logo on each 1998 model F-Series; the oval decal shows a 1948 F-1 alongside the new model, and carries the slogan "Built Ford tough." That sentiment hasn't changed much: back in 1948, the slogan was "Built stronger to last longer."
The trucks have come a long way since 1948, when they were mainly workhorses for businesses and farmers. But just as many farm families have migrated to cities and suburbs, so have pickups, which now come gussied up with leather upholstery, CD players and other touches of luxury. Prices have gone upscale, too: in 1948, a brand-new F-1 cost $1,144. Adjusted for inflation, that's about $7,605 now. A 1998 model F-150 starts at $15,375 and runs past $30,000.
And like the trucks, the world has changed since 1948. More than 10,000 workers now assemble the pickups worldwide. Factories in Venezuela, Brazil, Canada and Mexico, along with those in the United States, now churn out the F-Series.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 37; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk
