HEADLINE: Grand Tour of Bites and Bargains

BYLINE: By MIMI SHERATON; Mimi Sheraton is a former restaurant critic of The New York Times whose latest book is "Food Markets of the World" (Abrams).

 BODY:
It seems that I always need something on Grand Street. The lure on the Lower East Side might be yeasty bialys, a concert or bargains in panty hose, linens or toys. In Little Italy, I shop for scamorza, the dried mozzarella properly used in lasagna, or a special pasta cutter or a CD of Neapolitan folk songs. Where Chinatown edges into Little Italy, I buy a bamboo steamer, a fresh-killed guinea hen from a live-poultry market or a palate-tingling Malaysian chili crab. Or I find a glass shade for an antique brass lamp. In SoHo, I am drawn to art galleries, boutiques and the intriguing cuisines of India and Ethiopia.
After so many ad hoc forays, I began to wonder about Grand Street itself. What have I missed? And was the street ever truly grand? There are other famed downtown bargain streets -- Orchard, Delancey, Mulberry, Canal -- but none rivals Grand for a diverse ethnic mix nor for the assortment of merchandise, food stores and restaurants at all price levels. Noshing along this route, you can get fat in at least 15 languages. Most of all, Grand Street signifies the continuing immigrant saga of hope, struggle and achievement. 
 Others share that feeling. Explaining why he chose the name Grand Street for the avant-garde literary quarterly he founded in 1981 (and edited until 1990), Ben Sonnenberg said: "It was partly to honor the memory of my four immigrant grandparents who settled on Grand Street, where my parents met. But it was also the spirit of this long east-west street that had so many different ethnic communities on it. I wanted the contents of the magazine to be just as international and heterogeneous."
Similarly, David H. Goldsmith, chairman of the 76-year-old Grand Street Boys' Association and its foundation, conceded that the organization's headquarters were never on that street. It was not even the home of all 12 original members, immigrants and first-generation Americans who lived in the neighborhood, made good and set about helping others do the same. "Because it was the Broadway of the Lower East Side," he explained, "a big, wide, important street, it symbolized the best of the Lower East Side." On and off for seven months this year, I walked the two miles of Grand Street. I never turned a corner to go even one building north or south, no matter how great the temptation. The user-friendly Streetwise map I followed clearly delineates Grand Street's neighborhoods: the Lower East Side from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive to the east side of the Bowery; Little Italy from the Bowery to the east side of Broadway, with Chinatown making inroads on the south side of Grand Street from Mulberry to Chrystie Streets; and SoHo from Broadway west to Varick Street, where Grand Street ends.
Although Grand Street's building numbers begin at its western edge, its history starts at the East River. But the area richest in lore is the least prepossessing: old buildings long ago gave way to huge housing projects. These include some of the earliest sponsored by the trade unions representing garment workers, like the Corlears Hook Houses. (The name is a reminder of the estate on that site when the Dutch ruled New Amsterdam.)
Called by the British the Road to Crown Point, the former name of the place where the street meets the East River, Grand Street is believed to have been laid out from the river to the Bowery between 1755 and 1766, and received its current name after the Revolution. From the river to Essex Street, it is a very wide boulevard; then it narrows to normal city proportions. It was extended through the years, replacing other street names to the west, until it reached its present border on Varick Street.
From 1830 to 1870, the foot of Grand Street was an important shipbuilding area where Irish immigrants built several clipper ships that were important in the China trade. At its peak, in the mid- to late-19th century, the wide avenue was the site of Ridley's (at Allen Street), the largest department store in the United States until it closed in 1901, and the second Lord & Taylor store (at Broadway), which closed in 1903. That year also marked the beginning of Grand Street's decline, as it was overshadowed by the newly widened Delancey Street, the access road to the just completed Williamsburg Bridge.
 
Lower East Side
Other than the sparkle of light bouncing off the river and the greenery of garden parks, there is little to engage the eye. Here and there, one gets a glimpse of segments of the Williamsburg Bridge to the north, like a piece of abstract sculpture suspended against the sky. The quiet, low-key atmosphere is so peaceful, it is almost ghostly.
The buildings are still occupied by many older Jewish residents, more recently joined by younger families discovering the convenience of city life with a few synagogues and even a kosher butcher in easy walking distance. Many Chinese families have bought co-ops, too, and signs for medical and social services throughout the area are in English, Yiddish and Chinese.
Among the few visible remnants of the past are the worn little houses at 511, 513 and 515 Grand Street, and, at the corner of East Broadway, the elegant red-and-white Classic Revival building completed in 1904. It is now a mikvah, a ritual bath for Orthodox Jewish women. The monogram ATH over the doorway recalls its past as the Arnold Toynbee Hall, a site for political gatherings.
Another piece of history is St. Mary's Church, the oldest Roman Catholic structure in New York City. That distinction refers to the back portion, built of gray ashlar stone in 1832. St. Mary's strangely proportioned red-brick facade with twin spires was added in 1871, when the interior was extended.
Over cloudlike scones and tea with the pastor, the Rev. Neil Connolly, in the Victorian parlor of the rectory, I met Andrew Rudyk, a lawyer and St. Mary's historian. Once a primarily Irish congregation that intermittently included Germans and Poles, St. Mary's now caters to a mostly Hispanic community, rapidly expanding with Mexican arrivals.
In the ecumenical spirit, two street-side vitrines honor the festivals and holidays of other groups in the area, with displays for Passover and Chinese New Year as well as Christmas and Easter. It's a far cry from neighborhood animosities in 1828, when the original church on this site was burned to the ground by bigots who feared the "dangerous interests" of the Catholic Church.
Catering to the social and artistic needs of all the neighborhood groups is the Abrons Arts Center, in the only distinguished modern building along this stretch. Fine and performing arts are taught and exhibited in this 1975 branch of the Henry Street Settlement, which has its main offices in landmark town houses on its eponymous street. There are performances in dance, drama and music at the adjoining Harry De Jour Playhouse, the prettily restored theater that dates from 1915.
Daniel Kronenfeld, the executive director of the Henry Street Settlement, said that each year 1,600 students from the community attend its classes, while 10,000 local children take part in art education programs at their own schools. These include classes in painting, sculpture, ceramics, music and dance; flamenco was recently added at the request of Father Connolly, on behalf of his Hispanic parishioners.
Multicultural is also the word for eating habits here. Ruby (the Fruitman) Baumgarten has catered to a primarily Jewish clientele for 50 years, always stocking greens and root vegetables for chicken soup. Now he also keeps fresh ginger root for new Chinese customers. Savvy shoppers are regularly and loudly berated for squeezing produce, but he takes pride in never stocking anything that is too expensive for his customers. "If they're not going to buy cherries, why should I buy cherries?" he asks rhetorically.
At the glatt kosher dairy cafeteria Shalom Chai, pizzas, calzone and egg rolls are featured along with knishes and hummus. The combination attracts Orthodox Jewish families from other neighborhoods on Sundays, and the older, often infirm locals who gather to schmooze on quiet weekdays and good-naturedly engage strangers in conversation.
Almost next door is Kossar's Bialystoker Kuchen Bakery, my biweekly destination for a freezer supply of homely, chewy onion bialys. The Kossar's ovens issue forth a steady supply of fresh bialys, as well as large, round pletzels strewn with poppy seeds, and the long rolls known as bulkas, all made from the same dough. Kossar's sells bagels but does not make them. "It has to be an entirely different dough," explained Danny Scheinin, who took over from his father-in-law.
Anyone who doubts the theory that one of the 10 lost tribes of Israel wound up in China should be convinced at the Grand Deli. The partners in this three-year-old venture, as well as the Chinese cook and several waiters, are graduates of the bygone Bernstein's on Essex Street, renowned for the same menu mix. In a tidy, quasi-Chinese decorated dining room, quasi-Chinese kosher dishes like wontons, barbecued spareribs (veal) and soft, oniony, old-style chicken chow mein and moo goo chop suey are featured, with matzoh balls, stuffed derma and almost-convincing pastrami and corned beef.
Anyone interested in the fine points of Kashruth in meats, can get a colorful lecture from the bearded and cherubic Moshe Abramowitz, the Jerusalem-born butcher who owns Goldberg's Meat Market. Ask him why hind quarters of four-footed animals are kosher in Israel but not here, and learn a lesson in Talmudic pragmatism.
Dilapidated though it is, the strip of Grand Street from Essex Street to the Bowery has its share of bargains: hosiery, sterling silver, lingerie, children's clothing, home-furnishing fabrics and slipcovers still abound, although the number of stores has dwindled.
Bill Levy, 72, the semi-retired owner of the linen shop Harris Levy, reminisced about the great soups, potato pirogen and apple blintzes at the long-gone Grand Dairy Restaurant. The store was founded in 1894 by his grandfather, Harris Levy, an immigrant, and is now run by the fourth generation: Bob Levy and his wife, Meryle. It prospers not only by charging low prices for brand-name bed and bath linens, but also by specializing in luxurious imported bedding and tablecloths, often customized and ordered nationwide through catalogues.
With Asian merchants inching into this part of the Lower East Side, there are also great buys in kitchen utensils and decorative china at the Tai Cheung Supply Company; in clothes and miscellaneous tableware at the daily outdoor Dragon Gate market, and in lusty Vietnamese, Cambodian and Chinese noodle soups at the Golden Statue, where Grand Street meets the Bowery.
 
Little Italy and Chinatown
By all odds the most colorful human drama is played out where Chinatown meets Little Italy. Streets are jammed from early morning to late evening as Chinese shoppers hunt for the best fish and vegetables. (Although a boon to the neighborhood's economy, the commercial expansion also prompts complaints about garbage and street congestion from longtime residents.)
Here you can buy Chinese or Italian sausages, pasta and pastries, and relax over espresso and biscotti at Ferrara's, or a beef-curry bun with green tea at the Fay Da Bakery or, at the 213 Grand Street Gourmet, wash down dim sum with Hong Kong tea, a strangely addictive brew sweetened with sugar and burnished with evaporated milk.
At the Kamwo Herb and Tea Company, Tom Leung will prepare a custom mix of, say, powdered dried cicada and ginseng, or other nostrums for ailments you never knew you had. There are also bargain prescriptions to be filled at conventional pharmacies, and hard-to-find fittings at Grand Brass Lamp Parts Inc.
The long immigrant history of this area is poignantly illustrated in a small photographic exhibition in the landmark Greenpoint Bank, designed by Stanford White and opened in 1894 as the Bowery Savings Bank. Photographs show dazed, exhausted arrivals clutching bundles and babies, and there are signs with greetings in Yiddish, Italian and Chinese. One can only imagine the awe with which these refugees from the slums of Naples and Canton and the shtetls of Poland and Russia entered this magnificent cathedral of a bank with its marble, brass and mosaics, to deposit small savings proudly.
Also architecturally distinctive is the Police Building, a huge Beaux-Arts masterpiece that was, amazingly, New York City Police Headquarters when it opened in 1909. Looking at the soaring marble-and-crystal lobby, I had trouble imagining an episode of "N.Y.P.D. Blue" played out there. It is now a co-op, with two-bedroom, two-bath apartments going for just under $500,000 and attracting many voluntary inmates.
More modestly, the atmospheric little 1885 bank that is now the real estate office of James Stabile 4th, with its embossed-tin ceiling and bronze teller's cages, is a set piece that would look at home in any small town in southern Italy.
The oldest establishments here are Italian. E. Rossi's opened in 1902 and, in a temptingly crammed setting, sells Italian cookware and dishes, magazines, cookbooks, T-shirts, religious statues, CD's and more than 2,000 titles of sheet music. Lou Rossi, 87, can tell you how to prepare pasta correctly so it can be cut with the Abruzzese chitarra he sells, the only one in New York, he assures you, that is strung with real piano wire.
Ferrara's, almost next door, has just celebrated its 100th birthday; while across the street, the classic cheese shop Alleva is said to be the oldest latticini in the country, opened in 1892. By comparison, Di Palo, a trendier and livelier cheese and sausage shop, is a newcomer at 72. And the 40-year-old Italian Food Center, a mecca for juicy hero sandwiches, is the new kid on the block.
Anyone longing for old southern Italian dishes competently prepared will find them at the glitzy Teresa and Mimmo, but beware of the tonier inventions and the highfalutin northern dishes. Eat Neapolitan appetizers and pastas, and you'll eat well, served by some of the friendliest waiters in town.
For trendier appetites, hungry for nouvelle international fare and not put off by second-hand smoke, there is the breathtakingly beautiful Onieals Grand Street. The kitchen can be great or mediocre, but it's worth a try for its glowing wood-paneled interior. The saloon opened in 1875; 20 years later, a tunnel leading directly from the saloon into the police building was dug. Don't ask why.
My own special reward for this research has been the discovery of Nyonya, a crowded, clean and bright cafe featuring the spectacular food of the Perankans, descendants of Hokkien Chinese whose food is often described as nyonya (grandmother) or babu (grandfather). Having first encountered this tantalizing food in Singapore, I remain intrigued by the blend of Indian, Indonesian and Chinese culinary magic. The inexpensive Nyonya is just one of several Malaysian restaurants owned, at least in part, by an enchanting Peranakan, June Khoo, and her Chinese husband, Suan Lee Cheah, both 30-something New York enthusiasts who arrived from Penang in 1991.
 
SoHo
Grand Street in SoHo looks like a drab backwater, with parking lots, broken sidewalks and many empty buildings. Yet it is the pride of the Cast Iron Historic District. Graceful columns and arched windows, often discernible only above the first floor, are impressive even when veiled in urban grime.
Although it lacks immigrant fervor, this segment of Grand Street is home to strivers of another kind, those with dreams and aspirations in the creative arts: painting, sculpture, fashion, designs in graphics and home accessories, and cookery. Art galleries display works of budding talents as do most of the men's and women's clothing boutiques.
On Sundays, at Broadway and Grand, there is a mad jumble of a flea market with real junk and real antiques and a crazily beguiling collection of refrigerator-door magnets in the form of ceramic fruits, vegetables and fish.
The laid-back SoHo spirit was best expressed at the shop of Alpana Bawa, one of several intriguing fashion boutiques. Eager to get a closer look at the festive shirts and dresses in brilliant Indian silks and cottons shown in the window, I returned several times to find the doors locked. When I finally got lucky, I asked the saleswoman if being open was a new policy. (Most stores in SoHo do not open before 10 A.M. and many not until 11.)
The liveliest scene in this area runs from the Avenue of the Americas, where the Moondance Diner dispenses larger-than-life coffee shop fare around the clock, to West Broadway, where French bistros attract a young, international, black-clad set, many of them guests at the ultramodern SoHo Grand Hotel, half a block south. At the two best spots, Lucky Strike and Felix's, foreign languages seem to outnumber English by about four to one.
There is a diverse ethnic menu even along this short span of Grand Street. At Cucina della Nonna, one can tuck into good pasta in a tiled setting reminiscent of Sostanza in Florence; at Abyssinia, have Ethiopian curry stews served at basket tables. My favorite is the Indian restaurant, A. J.'s Niota. There, Arjun Gualaba, a native of Agra, offers a warm "niota" or welcome, to his duplex restaurant where both setting and food are delectably uncliched.
The city's prime training ground for budding Escoffiers is the French Culinary Institute, at Broadway. Technically in Little Italy, but more SoHo in tone, the school runs a felicitous public restaurant, L'Ecole, where students prepare the food, supervised by professionals. The faculty includes top toques like Jacques Pepin, Alain Sailhac, Andre Soltner and the master pastry chefs Jacques Torres and Diter Schorner.
"Have a grand day," is the message on the telephone answering machine of the Grand Deli. On my forays along this street, I have had many.
 
Tasting the World on Grand Street Without Turning a Corner
 
Here is information about places along Grand Street. Telephone numbers are provided for stores and restaurants; some are closed on Friday evenings and Saturdays.
 
Art and Architecture
 
ART GALLERIES AND CAST-IRON BUILDINGS line Grand Street from Avenue of the Americas to Broadway.
GREENPOINT BANK, 130 Bowery, at Grand Street, is a 1894 Stanford White landmark. Its palatial interior has a modest but touching exhibition on the history of the building and its immigrant neighborhood.
POLICE BUILDING, 240 Centre Street, at Grand Street. Step into the grandiose Beaux-Arts lobby of what is now a co-op and remember that from 1909 to 1973, it was New York City's police headquarters.
ST. MARY'S CHURCH, 440 Grand Street, between Ridge and Clinton Streets. The original rear section, built in 1833 of gray ashlar stone, accounts for its designation as the oldest Roman Catholic structure in Manhattan.
STABILE BROTHERS, 189 Grand Street, at Mulberry Street. Opened as a bank in 1885, the real estate office of Jerome Stabile 4th is a period set-piece suggesting an old bank in a small Italian town.
 
Design
 
ARTMARKET, 75 Grand Street, between Wooster and Greene Streets; (212) 226-4370. Individual vendors display smartly designed books, video tapes and CD's on photography, art, film and architecture as well as art postcards, T-shirts, toys and games.
DRAGON GATE MARKET, Grand Street between Chrystie and Forsyth Streets; (212) 941-8788. A daily flea market of new tableware, flowers, inexpensive clothing and Chinese street snacks.
GALLERY 91, 91 Grand Street, between Greene and Mercer Streets; (212) 966-3722. Impeccably designed, minimalist modern home furnishings, some jewelry and ingenious clocks.
GRAND BRASS LAMP PARTS, 221 Grand Street, at Elizabeth Street; (212) 226-2567. A treasury of fittings, glass shades and chimneys for antique metal lamps, along with ceiling and wall fixtures. Vases and similar vessels can be converted into lamps.
GRAND STERLING, 345 Grand Street, between Essex and Ludlow Streets; (212) 674-6450. Candlesticks, Hannukah menorahs and kiddush cups, along with other sterling holloware at excellent prices. There are also graceful, modern ceremonial cups and bowls of gold-trimmed sterling from Israel.
HARRIS LEVY, 278 Grand Street, between Forsyth and Eldridge Streets; (212) 226-3102. Four generations of Levys have specialized in top-quality, below-list price linens for table, bed and bath, standard and custom made. Surprise specialties are luxurious European imports made of silky Egyptian cotton.
J&B TOYS AND STATIONERY, 379 Grand Street, between Norfolk and Suffolk Streets; (212) 673-7160. All sorts of toys, games and junior sports equipment are sold at discount prices.
SOHO ANTIQUES FAIR, Grand Street and Broadway; (212) 682-2000. Furniture, cassettes, cameras, tableware, bric-a-brac, jewelry, clothing (I spotted new mens' trench coats with zip-out linings for $18) and an amusing collections of food magnets. Every Sunday.
PHILIP WILLIAMS, 60 Grand Street, between West Broadway and Wooster Street; (212) 226-7830. Expect a wild collection of posters on food, theater and other subjects, along with such naive art as paintings on scrap metal from the rural South.
HARRY ZARIN, 318 Grand Street, between Allen and Orchard Streets; (212) 925-6112. A fabric warehouse stacked with wonderful home furnishings fabrics, many from well-known mills. They are bargains by the yard or custom-made into slipcovers, curtains and bedspreads.
 
Clothing
 
ALPANA BAWA, 41 Grand Street, between Thompson Street and West Broadway; (212) 965-0559. Delicate, festive shirts ($140 to $250), pants and dresses in colorful Indian silks and cottons.
IF BOUTIQUE, 94 Grand Street, between Greene and Mercer Streets; (212) 334-4964. Casually smart tailored clothes with original touches. Some of the best are from the Danish designer Ivan Grundahl. Coats from $550 to $850. Many are marked down 20 to 50 percent from now through December.
LISMORE HOISERY, 334 Grand Street, at Ludlow Street; (212) 674-3440. Don't be put off by musty boxes stacked floor to ceiling. Many major brands for women and men are stocked in fresh, sealed packages at just about the lowest prices in town for first quality. Know what you want, because browsing is impossible.
RODNEY TELFORD, 89 Grand Street, at Greene Street; (212) 334-4676. Jackets (about $1,200) with long skirts (about $500) suggesting Edwardian riding suits and some romantic winter coats. Several styles can be made to measure. Many pieces are on sale for the holiday season. (Restaurant buffs may remember this as the original Chanterelle; the embossed tin ceiling is intact.)
WEARKSTATT, 33 Greene Street, at Grand Street; (212) 334-9494. Wedding dresses, both conventional and innovative, along with a few evening gowns, are featured in this bright new shop.
YOHJI YAMAMOTO, 103 Grand Street, at Mercer Street; (212) 966-9066. Neo-classic tailoring in the spacious showroom of the well-known designer. Women's jackets from $800 to $1,000.
 
Food and Cookware
 
ALLEVA DAIRY, 188 Grand Street, at Mulberry Street; (212) 226-7990. Billing itself as the oldest Italian cheese store in America, this 105-year-old latticini with its old tile work is known for superb homemade cheeses, especially mozzarella, available creamily fresh or dried as scamorza. Formaggio fresca, a custardy white cheese formed in baskets, is delicious with ripe fruit. Excellent aged Parmesan is a bargain at $8.95 a pound.
CHINESE SAUSAGE COMPANY, 198 Grand Street, between Mulberry and Mott Streets; (212) 966-8858. Very fresh meats, poultry and savory duck or pork sausages at low prices. Note the artful displays of flattened, dried ducks.
CHUNG CHOU CITY MARKET, 218-220 Grand Street, at Elizabeth Street; (212) 274-9338. What seems to be dried everything (spices, herbs, nuts, grains, shellfish, fish innards) is enticing and makes one want to know all about each specimen. Fortunately, there is usually at least one staff member who can respond.
DI PALO'S OF LITTLE ITALY, 206 Grand Street, at Mott Street; (212) 226-1033. A great variety of excellent cheeses, like sheeps' milk ricotta and stracchino, are among the pungent temptations dispensed by the third and fourth generations of friendly DiPalos. They provide sample tastings and cooking tips, as they have since 1926. Also here are gigantic mortadella (the original bologna from Bologna) and flavorful Giuseppe Cocco pasta from Abruzzo in nicely chewy twists called zitelle.
DONG OU FOOD MARKET, 248 Grand Street, between Bowery and Chrystie Streets; SEAFOOD MARKET, 250 Grand Street, at Chrystie Street; HUNG PHAT SEAFOOD AND MEAT MARKET, 225 Grand Street, between Elizabeth Street and the Bowery, (212) 941-6363. I have found the best selections at these three shops, with an aquarium array of fish and shellfish, some alive and bubbling under water. Prices are low, but it's important to be able to judge freshness.
GOLDBERG MEAT MARKET, 500 Grand Street, between Bialystoker Place and Columbia Street; (212) 475-6915. Glatt kosher meat and chicken are high quality and high priced, with great calf's liver at $8.95 a pound. Now if only someone would sweep the floor when leaves blow in through the hospitable open door.
ITALIAN FOOD CENTER, 186 Grand Street, at Mulberry Street; (212) 925-2954. This 40-year-old delicatessen excels at hero sandwiches, whether hot (sausage and peppers, fried eggplant with mozzarella) or cold (with prosciutto, provolone, salami, peppers and mushrooms). Prepared pastas, croquettes and bruschetta.
KAMWO HERB AND TEA COMPANY, 209 Grand Street, between Mott and Elizabeth Streets; (212) 966-6370. Herbs, teas and dried bugs and gegkoes are among the pharmaceuticals dispensed by Tom Leung.
KOSSAR'S BIALYSTOKER KUCHEN BAKERY, 367 Grand Street, between Essex and Norfolk Streets; (212) 473-4810. Anyone needing a bialy fix can get it 24 hours a day, at the world's best source, for a mere 45 cents.
PHOENIX POULTRY MARKET, 159A Grand Street, between Lafayette and Centre Streets; (212) 226-5455. Rabbits and live poultry including many kinds of chicken, duck, turkey, guinea hen and the gray-skinned "silkie" chicken that the Chinese simmer into soups to build the inner strength, "chi." All are moderately priced.
E. ROSSI & COMPANY, 191 Grand Street, at Mulberry Street; (212) 226-9254. Specialized Italian cooking and serving pieces, cookbooks and food magazines, religious statues, T-shirts, a huge assortment of sheet music and Italian folk and classical music on CD's, records and tapes. Then there's the great conversation with Lou Rossi, 87, whose father opened the shop in 1902.
RUBY'S FRUITS AND VEGETABLES, 400 Grand Street, between Suffolk and Clinton Streets; (212) 982-0160. Discriminating customers know that the self-styled curmudgeon Ruby Baumgarten buys the best-quality fruits and vegetables, but only at modest prices. A dozen Grade A extra-large eggs, some with double yolks, cost $1.09.
TAI CHEUNG KITCHEN SUPPLY, 303 Grand Street, between Eldridge and Allen Streets; (212) 219-8898. Shelves are neatly stacked with reasonably priced, practical Chinese cookware and attractive tableware.
 
Restaurants
 
ABYSSINIA, 35 Grand Street, at Thompson Street; (212) 226-5959. Curry-style stews of meats and vegetables are served authentically: guests sit on three-legged stools and use the crepelike bread injera in place of forks. Try azefa wot (lentil and chili salad), doro wot (chicken in the fiery berber sauce) and ye'beg alitcha (lamb with ginger and garlic). Dinner for two is about $52 with tip.
A. J.'S NIOTA, 337 West Broadway, at Grand Street; (212) 431-6222. Unusual Indian food is prettily presented and exquisitely seasoned, tandoori chicken being the disappointing exception. Try mussels masala, potato patties in mint sauce, chicken masala and balt gosht, a small copper pot of curried lamb, green pepper and onion. A lavish dinner for two with beer and tip runs about $73.
213 GRAND STREET GOURMET, 213 Grand Street, between Mott and Elizabeth Streets; (212) 226-4231. I like mid-morning breakfast at minuscule prices in these bright surroundings. Dim sum and crisp-skinned roast suckling pig on napa cabbage with rice ($5.95) are zestily satisfying. The congee or jook ($3 to $4), a rice porridge with chicken or pork and scallions, beats oatmeal any day.
CUCINA DELLA NONNA, 104 Grand Street, at Mercer Street; (212) 925-5488. The open kitchen does better by homey grandmother (nonna) dishes than creative alternatives. Linguine with garlic, oil and hot peppers; the fish soup-stew zuppa de pesce; chicken campagna with fusilli, rack of lamb and apple tart are delicious. Service is slow, and the room can be stuffy. Dinner for two with glasses of wine is about $70 including tip.
L'ECOLE, the French Culinary Institute, 462 Broadway, at Grand Street; (212) 219-3300. Professional waiters serve good modern French food prepared by student chefs under close professional guidance. Winners include crab cakes, leeks vinaigrette, sausage with potato salad, roast chicken and the herbed rack of lamb, along with pleasant desserts. The menu is very limited after 8 P.M. Prix fixe is $24.95.
FAY DA BAKERY, 214-216 Grand Street, between Mott and Elizabeth Streets; (212) 966-8934. The charm of Chinese sweets escapes me, so I skip the dessert pastries. Instead, I snack on golden baked buns filled with slightly sweet roasted pork or gentle curried beef and soft onions, an eat-in or take-out treat at 60 cents.
FELIX, 340 West Broadway, at Grand Street; (212) 431-0021. Despite the frenetic scene, especially when doors open to the sidewalk cafe, I enjoy brunch and lunch midst the downtown Babel of languages. Pleasing choices are onion soup, steamed mussels, ratatouille omelet, merguez lamb sausages, hamburgers and salads. Belying its reputation, the staff has been polite and accommodating. A three-course meal with wine averages $75 for two.
FERRARA'S, 195 Grand Street, between Mulberry and Mott Streets; (212) 226-6150. At this site for 100 years, the highly commercialized Ferrara's still provides respite by way of gelati, granita, espresso, cappuccino and crunchy anise biscotti. Other pastries tend to be heavy-handed.
GOLDEN STATUE, 237 Grand Street, at the Bowery; (212) 334-6868. Elemental Southeast Asian and Chinese noodle soups with various meats, innards and vegetables are the attractions in this hectic luncheonette. Bypass the rubbery beef balls but try the heady broth with pickled cabbage, shredded pork, bean curd and straw mushrooms, ample for two at $5.95.
GRAND DELI, 399 Grand Street, between Suffolk and Clinton Streets; (212) 477-5200. Chinese food and deli are strange menu bedfellows at this glatt kosher restaurant (closed from Friday afternoon to Sunday). Only observers of dietary laws need delve into the Chinese fare, although the egg drop soup is soothing. There are sustaining sandwiches of acceptable house-made pastrami and corned beef. Pickles are excellent, and the waiters, characteristically chatty. A large dinner for two with tip is about $60.
LUCKY STRIKE, 59 Grand Street, between West Broadway and Wooster Street; (212) 941-0772. As the name promises (or threatens), smoking is permitted throughout this narrow, young-spirited bistro. It is most pleasant for uncrowded weekday lunches. Good choices are the the warm lentil salad, the penne in a spicy tomato sauce, a chewy sandwich of grilled lamb and leeks, and moist chocolate cake. Lunch for two with wine and tip is about $43.
MOONDANCE DINER, 80 Avenue of the Americas, at Grand Street; (212) 226-1191. Super diner food, moderately priced, attracts a trendy crowd. It is most reliable for breakfast (served 24 hours a day) plus good sandwiches, vegetable chili, meat loaf and sauteed spinach. Service can be slow and slapdash.
NYONYA, 194 Grand Street, between Mulberry and Mott Streets; (212) 334-3669. The spicy and colorful cuisine of the Malayasian Peranakans is served in this huge, cheerful cafe that is jammed at peak hours. Best choices: the vegetable salad called Indian rojak, Hainanese chicken rice, coconut shrimp, chili crabs, curried beef redang and toasty peanut pancakes. An elaborate dinner for two with beer is about $45 to $50, but could easily be less; lunch is about $15 a person.
ONIEALS GRAND STREET, , 174 Grand Street, at Centre Market Place; (212) 941-9119. Because it is just shy of 35 seats, Onieals permits smoking, but when it is not too crowded, that is bearable. The kitchen can dish up subtly sophisticated mussel soup with saffron and a hint of orange, warm duck salad on mache, grilled sea bass with sprightly corn salsa, or puffy crabcakes. Other times, those dishes plus others can be lackluster. Dinner for two with wine and tip is about $90.
SHALOM CHAI, 359 Grand Street, between Essex and Norfolk Streets; (212) 598-4178. In this unadorned glatt kosher dairy cafeteria, Kashruth-observing gourmets fare better with the mozzarella and tomato pizza ($1.60 a slice) and calzone than with the Israeli salads, Ashkenazic knishes and Chinese egg rolls. (Closed from Friday afternoon to Sunday.)
TERESA AND MIMMO RISTORANTE, 181 Grand Street, between Baxter and Mulberry Streets; (212) 966-6862. Neapolitan standbys are the best choices in this garish, dated setting: stuffed artichokes, broccoli rape with olive oil and garlic, the fried cheese sandwich called mozzarella en carrozza, clams Posilippo and pastas like linguine with white clam sauce and penne arrabbiata. Dinner for two with wine and tip is about $80. MIMI SHERATON

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Rewards In Galleries Uptown

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
"Get Down Uptown" is the clever advertising slogan with which Barneys New York segued out of its West 17th Street store, as if it were necessary to remind its hipper clients that there is life above 23d Street. But sometimes reminders can help, especially with the relentless focus on the states of mind, style and real estate -- not to mention retail -- loosely known as downtown.
What you find in the uptown gallery world may not qualify as exactly "down," in its current application as the height of cool. But this world, which is at its densest along 57th Street between Park and Seventh Avenues and on, or near, upper Madison Avenue in the East 70's, is plenty substantial and should be a regular stop for all art lovers. 
On view uptown is a lot more history, often in galleries with sizable histories of their own, than you usually find farther south. Twentieth-century modernism prevails uptown, presented in segments that often complement museum shows. But if the area sometimes feels like the Land of the Dead White Male, it is not devoid of galleries dedicated to the young and living, or of nonprofit spaces that are "alternative" in one sense or another.
At the moment, the uptown galleries are at their autumn peak, spurred by auctions, museum exhibitions and perhaps the rising need for extra-special holiday gifts. Some of the stronger exhibitions include the dense survey of Man Ray's work at the Emmerich Gallery, the juxtaposition of Mondrian and Ad Reinhardt at Pace Wildenstein and a meaty account of Franz Kline's development, told mostly in small paintings and works on paper, at the Allan Stone Gallery.
At the Ubu Gallery, a survey of Sol LeWitt's work includes a large wall relief from 1962, never previously exhibited, in which the word "objectivity," repeated four times in booming bright letters, recedes progressively into a shallow ocher grid, or marches forward, full of Minimalist attitude.
Also to be seen are Yves Kline's "Anthropometries" at Danese, an informative survey of the French painter Nicolas de Stael at Mitchell-Inness & Nash, Cy Twombly's latest sculptures at the Gagosian Gallery and, at Joan T. Washburn, a revealing comparison of finished and unfinished canvases of Myron Stout.
But that's not nearly all. The top layer of exhibitions along 57th Street and upward is unusually deep right now. Further recommendations follow.
For starters, there are two group shows that define some of the uptown gallery extremes. At the Sidney Janis Gallery is "20TH-CENTURY MASTERS," -- a tony show, even for a concern in its third generation, that runs the gamut from big names to quirky talents. At one end is a 1920 collaboration of Marcel Duchamp and Man Ray, "Dust Breeding," a famously ambiguous photograph of common house dust impersonating an earthwork; at the other, Oyvind Fahlstrom's mordant "Column No. 3 (Chile F)," which diagrams the dark side of the late 60's and early 70's.
In between, there are a corner full of Jean Arp's vivacious sculptures, a wall of Abstract Expressionist drawings, three of Joseph Albers's reverberating squares and much more.
 
Younger and Smaller
Slightly to the east lies proof that small young galleries also call uptown home. Baron/Boisante Editions would fit into one of the back rooms at the Janis Gallery. It feels like a fastidious cockpit, perfect for the house speciality: "WORKS ON PAPER," -- as its current show is called.
It clocks the persistence of the human figure in art, making some telling connections (Norris Embry next to Joseph Beuys), introducing some unfamiliar personalities (the Dutch artist Anton Heyboer) and lassoing several knockouts (a spinning, two-headed blur by Arnulf Rainer and a Jean-Michel Basquiat in which several faces are described in gnarled labyrinths of line).
At Brewster Arts Ltd., the incomparable LEONORA CARRINGTON -- is having her seventh New York show since her debut, in 1948, at the Pierre Matisse Gallery. Ms. Carrington, now 80, began life as an English debutante with artistic ambitions, ran off with Max Ernst at the age of 20 and never looked back. Living in Mexico since the onset of World War II, she also never stopped painting.
Her tiny paintings reflect a fantastic Surrealism that draws on Goya, Bosch, Sienese paintings and Egyptian art, with just a pinch of Edward Gorey. Scenes of mysterious rituals conducted by elaborately costumed spirits and imaginary animals are rendered in soft, glowing colors that swirl and drift, like so much mist. The small scale and thin, turbulent surfaces have affinities with the work of the young painter Elizabeth Peyton.
In "Feral Horse," a pensive monkey sits atop a horse of fiery orange, backed by soft brown mountains and a plum sky, colors that Mark Rothko could have used. Ms. Carrington's imagination is fertile, but it is her palette and the whispering passion of her brush that make her best work so convincing.
Also worth a visit at this address is "JOSE BEDIA: THREE-DIMENSIONAL WORKS," -- at George Adams, a series of small wood toylike wall pieces that are uncharacteristically delicate for this Cuban artist and are steeped in the Afro-Cuban religious practices of Santeria and Palo Monte.
Back on the south side of West 57th, the Michael Rosenfeld Gallery is showing "BURGOYNE DILLER: THE THIRD DIMENSION, SCULPTURE AND DRAWINGS, 1930-1965." -- This bittersweet exhibition suggests that the best American painter to fall under Mondrian's spell may actually have been a sculptor manque.
In the early 40's, Diller translated Mondrian's perpendicular lines and primary colors into real space with painted wood sculptures that are remarkable for their tensile economy. In the early 60's, when Diller had the time and money to make sculpture again, his work was simpler, bolder, more original and more than a little prescient of Minimalism. The seven sculptures and reliefs in this show are seen against bright blue walls on which dozens of purposeful drawings brim with new ideas, most never realized.
 
It's a Gallery Mall
The Rosenfeld Gallery is at 24 West 57th Street, one of the area's several "gallery malls." (Uptown had them before downtown, and in more civilized form.) Right now this building is especially packed with interesting sights.
A floor above Rosenfeld, Galerie St. Etienne has pulled out all the stops with "EGON SCHIELE, 1890-1918: MASTER DRAFTSMAN," -- a concentrated examination of the artist's preferred medium, timed for the Museum of Modern Art's retrospective. Smaller, more succinct and less feverish than the retrospective, it reflects the gallery's 50-year involvement with Schiele's work and brings the viewer in unusually close contact with his charged virtuosity.
The 75 drawings span his brief career, tracing his intensifying engagement with both his medium and his models, whose faces can have the psychological immediacy of photographs, while their bodies seem carved out of the page. The tautness or speed of line, its relation to negative space and to color (which sometimes stands alone), the shaping of these formal elements to the human subject, the degree of finish: everything shifts from work to work, but usually bears the signs of an unremitting scrutiny that makes this show enormously compelling.
At the other end of the hall from St. Etienne is the Fischbach Gallery, which has evolved over the years into a mecca of Realist painting. There, THOMAS CORDELL AND SUSAN SHATTER -- turn in solid performances: he with muscular, abbreviated scenes from San Francisco to Jodhpur, India; she with monotypes that stay put and move in close, recording with appropriate fluidity the shifting light and tides on a patch of rocky coast in Maine.
Four floors below, at the Marian Goodman Gallery, where a group show called "20/20" -- is in progress, water figures prominently in "Disappearance at Sea," an impressive 14-minute film by the young English artist Tacita Dean. Its subject is the sun setting over the ocean, distorted by the revolving structure of thick lenses that magnify the lamps of a lighthouse. The camera shifts between close-ups of this magnificent, distorting apparatus and the darkening view it surveys, accompanied by the rising cries of gulls. Finally there is only a pale shaft of light, moving through the dark, picking out occasional whitecaps.
Simple, yet powerfully elegaic, Ms. Dean's film pits nature's overwhelming indifference against human determination, personified by the light's implacable mechanism. It counts as one of the best new works of art on view in Manhattan.
 
Feathers and Blood
Retrospective light is shed at Galerie Lelong, in "ANA MENDIETA: BODY IMPRINTS AND TRANSFORMATIONS, 1972-74," -- a show of the early photographic work and documented performance pieces of the Cuban artist Ana Mendieta (1948-1985). While still in school at the University of Iowa, Mendieta pushed energetically at the boundaries of performance, body and feminist art. In usually sequential images, most of which star herself, she manipulated the body as both a sculptural object and metaphor. Pasting white feathers all over a friend, she created a Mayan bird-god. Pressing panes of glass against her face or naked body, to ghoulish effect, she personalized Process Art. Wearing wigs and making faces, she anticipated Cindy Sherman.
More sensationally, Mendieta used blood, dripping it on her face so she appeared wounded, and writing with it on walls. She assumed the position (tied up) of a struggling female victim. These are not her best efforts, but their bluntness is endearing, and they are disturbing to see, considering her early, violent death in a fall from a window.
Nearby are complementary shows devoted to MILTON AVERY. -- Around the corner at the D. C. Moore Gallery on Fifth Avenue, "Milton Avery: Paintings and Works on Paper" feels somewhat routine and lacks a truly great late landscape, but with 27 works, there is still plenty to look at. "Milton Avery: An Intimate Scale," at Long Fine Art (back on West 57th and next door to Marian Goodman), is more modest but also livelier, a display of small works in various media, mostly figures and landscapes, that skips around from 1918 to 1960, confirming that Avery sustained his inimitable touch from start to finish.
 
Into the Fuller Building
In the venerable Fuller Building, at 41 East 57th, a longtime, unusually commodious gallery mall (all those elevators), one of the best shows is "FORMS AND RHYTHMS" -- at the Barbara Mathes Gallery. An exercise in compare and contrast, it features three prewar modernists whose abstracting impulses matched Avery's: Alexander Calder, Stuart Davis and Fernand Leger. They, too, never abandoned reality, but subjected it to rigorous abbreviations, exaggerations and deletions. In other words, they put style, form and color first.
Calder kept in touch with the world by dropping hints like the tulip-shaped bit of metal in "The White Tulip," one of several terrific mobiles. Leger's solution, repeated a little too often here, was to unleash big ribbons of color behind his floating figures. Davis assiduously reworked his own earlier images, making them bigger, brighter and less specific, while maintaining the sense of streetwise vernacular. In all, a very pungent conversation.
Among the other impressive exhibitions at this address, "FROM INGRES TO PICASSO," -- at the Jan Krugier Gallery, is largely as good as it sounds, while "RICHARD POUSETTE-DART: PHOTOGRAPHS," -- at Zabriskie, reveals a little-known side of this second-generation Abstract Expressionist on the occasion of his retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art: lustrous black-and-white close-ups of natural forms that echo the sunburst motifs of Pousette-Dart's paintings.
When you leave East 57th Street for points north, a good first stop is Berry-Hill, where "AMERICAN STUDIES: OIL SKETCHES BY CHASE AND HIS CONTEMPORARIES" -- awaits in a small back gallery like a box of bonbons. The best flavors, besides William Merritt Chase, include Robert Henri, Ernest Lawson, George Bellows, Childe Hassam and Edward Potthast.
Such lush, miniaturized opulence is scaled up in "SARGENT ABROAD" -- at the Adelson Gallery. Here one sees John Singer Sargent's fabled facility, mostly expended upon landscapes, slipping in and out of control, veering between the academic and the Impressionist. A view of the Libreria in Venice is painted in such fat, melting strokes that we seem to be looking at its reflection in the Grand Canal. In "Alpine Pond" the surrounding peaks are rendered in strokes so fluttery that an avalanche seems imminent.
In a downstairs gallery, there's an array of Sargent's watercolors, where his technique, while equally dazzling, is more consistent. Don't miss the tiny room of watercolors by Emily Sargent, the artist's older sister and traveling companion. Quieter, decidedly clumsier, many still have a rightness all their own.
Upper Madison Avenue's version of the modernist extravaganza at Janis is the "AMERICAN WORKS: 1945-1975," -- at C & M Arts, a gallery on two floors of a lavish town house that can be a little intimidating, despite its regular public hours. The brackets here are Jackson Pollock and Brice Marden, between which are works by Jasper Johns, Phillip Guston, Rothko and several other important artists, including, inexplicably, several sculptures by the French artist Aristide Maillol.
 
Better Than It Sounds
Across Madison, dip into Reinhold Brown for "THE INFLUENCE OF RUSSIAN CONSTRUCTIVISM ON INTERNATIONAL GRAPHIC DESIGN." -- Nowhere nearly as dry as its title, the show roams through several decades of posters, proving that while Stalin may have squelched the Russian modernists, their innovations in composition, photomontage and typeface were irrepressible.
One block north, Salander-O'Reilly Galleries on 79th Street has two exceptional shows. "ELIE NADELMAN: THE CLASSICAL TRADITION" -- contains a number of rare early works by this eccentric, imperious sculptor, who was born in Poland, seasoned in Paris, where he may have helped plant the seed of Cubism, and more or less forgotten in New York, where he lived from 1914 until his death in 1946. He is much better known these days, especially for the elegantly pneumatic folk-artish wood sculptures he made after coming here, but there's still a way to go.
Containing 25 works made between 1906 and 1926, this exhibition fills some gaps and makes palpable Nadelman's versatility and his strange balance of radical and conservative impulses as well as a restless mixing of sculptural styles and types that is almost post-modern. From the years before 1910 come cubistic figures, in carved wood relief; suave Neo-Classical heads, their smoothed-out features dreamy and withdrawn, and a female nude, in bronze, whose elongated curving limbs suggest El Greco's distortions, but done with a compass.
Especially intriguing is the expressive figure of a seated woman, hands neatly poised in her lap (where they imply her missing arms). The piece demonstrates a little-known fact: that Nadelman translated the inflated volumes of the wood sculptures into marble. (It is also interesting to think of the alternately sharp and rounded vivacity of his work in relation to the Arps at the Janis Gallery.
 
Small and Sumptuous
On Salander-O'Reilly's ground floor is a sumptuous show of small landscape paintings by PIERRE BONNARD, -- which vibrate with color, light and idiosyncratic wet-on-wet paint handling, each in a key that seems all its own. In one seascape, the water is black and deep green, and the waves are defined by thick little scallops of salmon pink. The canvases bring to mind several American artists -- Avery, Marsden Hartley and, in front of "Soleil Couchant," from about 1920, George Inness.
Finally, there are two of the area's alternative exhibition spaces.
Ensconced in an ornate town house on Fifth Avenue opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art is the Goethe-Institut New York, whose many functions include exhibiting the work of German artists. At the moment, REINER LEIST, -- who lives in midtown Manhattan, is showing "Window," an exhibition of nearly 20 large photographs made with a 19th-century full-plate camera.
Shot from what seems to be a high floor in a building in the West 30's, each image shows the same man-made canyon at different times of day and night, in various weather. These images have too much company to stand on their own, starting with O'Keeffe and Stieglitz and Berenice Abbott, but they attest to the continued allure of New York as artistic subject, and in handsome terms.
 
Off the Gallery Path
Somewhat off the beaten uptown gallery path, in an old carriage house, is the Sculpture Center, whose current exhibition, "SUSPENDED INSTANTS," -- is half of a show of American and Brazilian artists that has been organized with Art in General, an alternative space in lower Manhattan. The theme is timely: the tendency of contemporary artists to use small common objects, in unexpected ways, or obsessive quantities, often turning the modest grandiose.
Heidi Fasnacht makes wall pieces suggesting city maps, or atomic models, out of metal springs and knobs of black clay, while Jose Damasceno creates an even vaster network out of only rubber bands and nails. Enrica Bernardelli tangles the gold-colored metal chains used in Brazil for holy medals into startlingly heavy masses that the viewer may rearrange, strength permitting.
Brigitte Nahon achieves a magical suspension with thread and clear plastic balls. And Ana Linnemann takes small rocks, drills them with holes and sews them together with thin copper wire, making what she calls "Rock Lace."
The second part of the show is as good a reason as any to go downtown.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Violins In the Wings

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS; A. M. Rosenthal is on vacation.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
"You have to distinguish between means and ends," Albert Carnesale said. "What's important here is the end, diversity. Affirmative action is just one means to that end."
Mr. Carnesale is the new Chancellor of the University of California at Los Angeles, a great public university in a diverse city. He moved here in July from Harvard, where he was dean of the Kennedy School and then provost. He arrived at a turning point for affirmative action in California. 
 A new policy of the Regents of the University of California, effective this year at the graduate school level, forbids giving preference in admissions on the basis of race or ethnicity. Proposition 209, which has just gone into effect, makes that a rule for all state institutions.
As a result of the Regents' policy, the number of Hispanic and black students at the U.C.L.A. Law School has dropped sharply. Last year 104 blacks were admitted, this year 21. Of the 21, only 8 enrolled. (At Boalt Hall, the University of California Law School at Berkeley, none of the black students admitted this year actually came.)
To Al Carnesale, figures like those -- and what they indicate may happen in undergraduate admissions -- represent a profound challenge. He outlined three reasons he believes diversity is essential to U.C.L.A. fulfilling its responsibilities.
"First," he said, "we have to provide the best possible education for our students. And I have no doubt that education is markedly advanced by diversity -- because students learn from each other. Teaching foreign policy at Harvard, I saw it at work. The differences in perspectives were so informative.
"Second, it is our responsibility to prepare leaders for all segments of our society. We are a public university. And the way to do that is to provide high-quality education for potential leaders in all groups.
"Third, one of the things that sets the United States apart is access to social and economic mobility. And the key to that is education. Go around the table at a meeting of business leaders, and half the stories you hear will have violins playing in the background."
If Mr. Carnesale feels strongly about that, it is because his own story has plenty of violins in the background. He was brought up in a Bronx tenement near Yankee Stadium, the son of a taxi driver, and then lived the American dream: Bronx High School of Science, nuclear engineer, adviser to Presidents on arms control.
"What can we do to maintain diversity now?" he asked. "We can encourage minority students whose records make them eligible to apply, and then encourage those admitted to enroll. We have to make sure people know they're welcome. In fact, the message is that they're wanted.
"In the medium term, we have to get more minorities eligible. It means we have to be much more engaged in the high schools.
"In the long run, there has to be something like equal opportunity for all kids to get a good education in this country. Better-off people will always have an advantage, but equal opportunity should be a goal, an aspiration."
The passage of Proposition 209 may make people think that California now requires the university to admit students solely on the basis of academic scores. That is not so. In fact, the rules require that at least 25 percent of each class admitted reflect qualities apart from school records and test results.
"We use affirmative action all the time," Mr. Carnesale said. "It is not by looking at academic merits alone that we have a football team with a 9-2 record, going to a bowl.
"In going over applications for admission you notice that applicants come from different countries, or this one plays the cello, or that one is a published poet or has overcome great personal obstacles in her life. We may notice all those things -- but not race or ethnicity or gender."
The fact is that, in California and everywhere, values apart from test scores do figure in university admissions policies -- and should. A society that has prospered in diversity cannot want monochrome higher education.

HEADLINE: James Bender, 92, Eclectic Educator, Dies

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
James F. Bender, an eclectic educator who started out training speech therapists in the 1930's and ended up teaching business in the 1970's, but only after he had done star turns as a public pronunciation specialist and pioneering pop psychologist, become a high-paid business consultant and made a fortune on Wall Street, died on Sunday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 92 and the founding dean of the Adelphi University School of Business.
To say that Dr. Bender had a passion for education would hardly do justice to a man who spent a week pedaling a bicycle from his home in Dayton, Ohio, to Clinton, N.Y., so he could attend Hamilton College. 
 For Dr. Bender, whose father was a teacher, the bicycle trip was an economy measure, as was his decision to leave Hamilton a year later. Unable to find enough work in Clinton, he moved to New York City, where he worked his way through the Columbia University School of General Studies working at everything from waiter to doorman.
To suggest that Dr. Bender had an original turn of mind and a sense of possibilities would be something of an understatement. He was, for example, a man whose experience administering routine psychological tests to City College employees led him to specialize in speech therapy, write his Columbia doctoral thesis on the personality structure of stuttering and found a City College speech clinic before becoming a professor of psychology at the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute and moving on to the new Queens College, where he became the founding director of the college's Speech-Language-Hearing Center in 1942.
Dr. Bender's tenure at Queens College was short. After he was censured in 1943 for exaggerating his academic credentials (claiming a Columbia master's degree he had earned but not received) he resigned, much to the consternation of college officials.
Their anguish was understandable. Dr. Bender had become a star attraction, repeatedly making headlines whether by compiling the widely publicized NBC Handbook of Pronunciation, making Queens College the first educational institution in New York City to acquire a "continuous recording and transcribing machine," or by emerging as a latter day Henry Higgins, using the recorder to demonstrate the stunningly improved speech and enunciation of a group of street urchins he tutored in the social graces.
It did not hurt that Dr. Bender dubbed the group 'the Dead End Boys."
The choice reflected a shrewd sense of public appeal that blossomed during the next phase of Dr. Bender's career. As the founder of something he called the National Institute for Human Relations, he was soon a ubiquitous national expert on everything from correct pronunciation, vocabulary and American speech patterns to salesmanship and marriage.
Although he had turned out his share of learned texts and scholarly articles in the 1930's, it was as a language maven and psychologist to the masses that Dr. Bender hit his stride, churning out some 250 newspaper and magazine articles in three years.
It was an index of his feel for the public pulse that his 1944 article in The New York Times Magazine, "Ninety Million Speak General American," set a reprint record for the magazine when it was picked up by a dozen other publications.
Although some of his works were discursive, the typical Bender article was an eye-catching list (of circus terms, for example) or a series of short questions and answers on a common theme (like how women had changed in 50 years).
Dr. Bender, whose books of that era included "How to Talk Well" and "Do's and Don'ts of the Sales Interview," concentrated increasingly on the psychology of the work place, a specialty that created such a demand for his expertise in the world of big business that he folded his institute and reinvented himself anew, this time as a business consultant.
A man with an instinct for where opportunity would be knocking next, Dr. Bender made millions from a series of shrewd investments in everything from gold to depressed Oregon real estate.
For all his business success, however, Dr. Bender was so devoted to education that he returned to academia in 1960, teaching business administration at Adelphi and serving as dean when its business department was elevated to school status in 1964, partly as a result of his own donations and money he raised from others.
He left Adelphi in 1966 and spent seven years at Pace University and at C.W. Post College, where he taught money management so well that a student-managed portfolio of stocks, bonds and real estate donated by Dr. Bender and others tripled in value in three years and helped finance Post's Money Management Institute.
Returning to Adelphi in 1973, he served first as acting business dean, then as dean of the Center for Banking and Money Management and finally as dean of special programs, a euphemism for persuading Adelphi alumni and others to be as generous as he was.
By the time he retired in 1985, Dr. Bender had made a new name for himself as a fund-raiser and philanthropist, among other things raising money for endowed chairs at both Adelphi and Post and endowing two chairs, in music and psychology, at the Columbia School of General Studies.
The school, the university's arm for continuing, or adult, education, had never had an endowed professorship before, but then, as the school recognized when it gave him its highest alumni award, it had never encountered anyone quite like Dr. Bender before.
Dr. Bender, whose first wife died and whose second marriage ended in divorce, is survived by his wife, Vera Evangeline, his one-time next door neighbor in Roslyn, N.Y.; her son, Ted Sattler of Chappaqua, N.Y.; a sister, Mary Jane Perez of San Antonio, Tex., and two step grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Chicago Mayor Meets Nation of Islam Leader, to Chagrin of Some

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 27.

 BODY:
When Mayor Richard M. Daley met with the Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan recently, he told Mr. Farrakhan to establish better relations with Jewish leaders and hinted that if he did not, he could expect rough sledding at City Hall.
Many Jewish leaders, though, were more bothered by the meeting than pleased by the warning. 
 The Mayor implied to Mr. Farrakhan that building permits for developments planned by the group might not win city approval unless Mr. Farrakhan, who has called Judaism a "gutter religion," sincerely reached out to Jews.
"In order to do developments, you need people of all different faiths" working together, Mr. Daley told Mr. Farrakhan in meeting him for the first time, last Friday.
Mr. Farrakhan plans to build a bakery, printing press and other shops, under the auspices of the Nation of Islam.
Leaders of Jewish groups in Chicago expressed alarm and dismay that Mr. Daley would meet with Mr. Farrakhan at all, and said it would be pointless for them to talk with the Nation of Islam leader.
Richard Hirschaut, executive director of the Anti-Defamation League here, said the Mayor had unwittingly "conferred an air of legitimacy upon Mr. Farrakhan," whom Mr. Hirschaut called a "rank bigot."
Some Jewish leaders noted that prominent rabbis in Chicago had met with Mr. Farrakhan a few years ago, hoping to build a working relationship, but that it had proved fruitless.
Mayor Daley, in defending his meeting, noted that Mr. Farrakhan was a Chicago resident with a large constituency and considerable property. Simply meeting someone, Mr. Daley said, scarcely amounted to an endorsement.
Mr. Daley said he began last Friday's meeting by expressing his disagreement with things Mr. Farrakhan has said about Jews over the years. Mr. Daley noted that "many of my friends are Jewish," and warned Mr. Farrakhan against trying to "blame one group of people for the problems of others."
Leonard F. Muhammad, the chief of staff of the Nation of Islam, said Mr. Farrakhan would be willing to sit down with any Jewish leaders and "discuss our differences." But while saying he was extending an olive branch, Mr. Muhammad was also highly critical of Jewish groups.
"It is amazing how they can support peace initiatives between Israelis and Palestinians, and yet refuse to meet with the premier leader of black people in America," Mr. Muhammad said. "Any disrespect shown to Minister Farrakhan is disrespect to his constituency."
The chairman of the city's Commission on Human Relations, Clarence Wood, said he would be willing to organize a meeting between Mr. Farrakhan and Jewish leaders.
Jonathan Levine, the Midwest director for the American Jewish Committee, said it was "utter nonsense" to construe criticism of Mr. Farrakhan as effrontery toward black Americans. Mr. Levine, while criticizing Mr. Daley's meeting with Mr. Farrakhan, described the Mayor as being "very sensitive to the concerns of the Jewish community."
Mr. Levine said there was no point in Jewish leaders meeting with Mr. Farrakhan "unless and until the anti-Semitic rhetoric stops," because it was absurd to seriously discuss outrageously bigoted charges.
"Farrakhan has accused Jews of everything from slavery to the economic conditions of African Americans to you-name-it," Mr. Levine said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
A Housing Plan Where Stores Have Been Included

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Hundreds of new and renovated low-to-middle-income housing units have been built in the easternmost corner of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, and hundreds more are planned. But this growth has not been matched by the development of retail shops.
That will begin to change soon. In the next month, construction is scheduled to start on 20,000 square feet of retail space on a vacant lot at the corner of Fulton Street and Ralph Avenue, and 30,000 square feet will be added later elsewhere along Fulton Street, the area's main business corridor. 
 The project is the first of several planned throughout New York City to help revive distressed neighborhoods where new housing has gone up. The projects' goal is to supply these areas with what city housing officials say is a critical element: retail services. Developers have retail projects in early stages at 36 sites in eight commercial corridors.
The 20,000-square-foot retail complex in Bedford-Stuyvesant, called Fulton Ralph Plaza, has been leased to a Rite Aid drug store, a State Farm Insurance office, a beauty salon and a laundry business. The entire development is being built by the Hudson Companies Inc. of Brooklyn, which is completing 58 two-family homes for middle-income people in the neighborhood and will start 71 similar homes in March.
Fulton Ralph Plaza is part of the city's 18-month-old Alliance for Neighborhood Commerce and Home Ownership program, or Anchor, which is sponsored by the city's Department of Housing, Preservation and Development and the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce Inc., a nonprofit business organization.
Under the program, $11 million in public financing has been set aside to provide incentives like construction loans, loan guarantees and second mortgages to developers to build retail projects on empty sites leased from the city. Developers must attract additional financing from private sources and market the projects to tenants.
"In the past, there was undue attention paid to housing and not enough attention to retail services," said Richard Roberts, Commissioner of the Housing Department. "Both are needed to stabilize neighborhoods."
Steven A. Brown, vice president at the New York City Partnership, said that the project tries to encourage local, regional and national retailers to open stores, which will create jobs and spur further development and commerce in the neighborhoods.
The program is expected to generate 437,000 square feet of retail space over the next five years on several sites. In addition to Fulton Street, the sites include Broadway and Mermaid Avenue in Brooklyn; Guy R. Brewer Boulevard in Queens; Frederick Douglass and Malcolm X Boulevards in Harlem, and Third Avenue and Southern Boulevard in the Bronx. About 15,460 housing units have risen in neighborhoods in and around those corridors since 1992, and thousands more are expected to be created over the next three years, according to the partnership.
One of the planned projects is an eight-story mixed-used building with 35,000 square feet of ground- and basement-level stores topped by 126 condominium apartments that will be built on the corner of 116th Street and Fifth Avenue, near Malcolm X Boulevard, in Harlem. It will be developed by Full Spectrum Inc., with ground-breaking expected in the second quarter of next year.
Also, 100,000 square feet of retail space is planned on 10 scattered sites, not far from the Broadway corridor in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The developer, the Beechwood Organization of Williston Park, N.Y., is constructing 78 two-family homes in the area for middle-income people.
The program faces some hurdles. Although these neighborhoods have only limited retail areas, residents and local merchants are worried that new stores might displace the shops that are there. Another challenge is attracting large retailers who are willing to gamble that the neighborhoods' slow recovery will continue. Developers say that such tenants are needed to secure financing from private sources and to draw other retailers.
"Convincing retailers and lenders they can make a go of it in these neighborhoods is a challenging assignment," Mr. Brown said. But he and other proponents of the Anchor program are hoping Fulton Ralph Plaza will demonstrate that it can be done.
The Chase Manhattan Bank provided a $2.7 million construction loan for Fulton Ralph Plaza, which will cost $3.5 million; the rest came from public sources. Getting the financing pieces to work together took six months, said Alan R. Bell, a principal of the Hudson Companies. Although the public money makes these projects economically feasible, "signing on a credit-worthy tenant is the only way they can happen," he said.
State Farm Insurance and Rite Aid fit the bill, although the drug store was greeted with some local resistance, particularly from the proprietor of a drug store a few feet from the new retail center. A local entrepreneur is opening the other two businesses at the plaza: the beauty salon and laundry. Mr. Bell said Fulton Ralph Plaza is expected to be completed by the end of 1998.
Meanwhile, the Hudson Companies is winding down construction on 58 two-family homes along nearby Sumpter Street between Saratoga and Howard Avenues. Each house has an apartment with two floors and 1,600 square feet of space for the owner and an 800-square-foot rental unit. All but one of the homes, priced at $168,000, have been sold to people whose annual incomes do not exceed $70,000. Mr. Bell said that the 71 additional two-family homes his company plans to build four blocks away on Hull and MacDougal Streets will be similar in size and price.
"The retail project will help sell the housing," Mr. Bell said. "Neighborhood development is more than plunking down some houses."

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief May Propose Easing Restrictions on Sale of Iraqi Oil

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General is considering recommending an increase in the amount of oil that Iraq is allowed to sell in order to buy food, medicine and other goods, diplomats said today.
After hearing reports of the plight of Iraqis suffering under trade sanctions, the Secretary General, Kofi Annan, is expected to ask the Security Council to raise the current $2 billion limit to $3 billion for the next six-month period when the plan comes up for renewal on Dec. 5. 
 The oil-for-food program -- which was begun a year ago to alleviate the impact of sanctions that were imposed on Iraq when it invaded Kuwait in 1990 -- allows critical goods into Iraq under controlled conditions.
But the politics are intricate. The United States may reject any action, saying the Council should wait a few weeks to make sure that Iraq first lets United Nations inspectors carry out their work unimpeded as they search for weapons of mass destruction. The inspectors have recently returned to Iraq but are still arguing with Saddam Hussein over the extent of their access to possible weapons hideaways.
Some diplomats predict that Mr. Annan will not ask for a specific increase, thereby avoiding putting Washington on the spot.
One diplomatic source at the Security Council, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the 15-member body would probably end up continuing the $2 billion limit without changes, in part because of the United States' opposition, but may promise to consider an increase later.
Britain, usually a close supporter of Washington's hard-line policies on Iraq, could break ranks in this case and favor more oil sales, as do most other important members of the Council. "The United Kingdom is quite ready to push the envelope," the British Ambassador, Sir John Weston, said on Wednesday.
Timed to influence the report, the United Nations Children's Fund, or Unicef, released a survey Wednesday that showed youngsters under 5 years old were underfed and underweight, despite the oil-for-food program. "It is clear that children are bearing the brunt of the current economic hardship," said Philippe Heffinck, the Unicef representative in Baghdad.
Washington has been the chief advocate of the oil-for-food program as it gives the United Nations control over goods arriving in Iraq. But Iraq objects to it, viewing it as a substitute for lifting the sanctions.
Iraq has close to $1 billion in oil revenues not yet spent on humanitarian goods.
Baghdad has argued that this is partly due to American blockages on ambulances and other items on order, though the Americans argue that Iraq had not turned in enough proper contracts. "The current list has things like musical instruments, rowing machines, dental floss," said one diplomat. "A straight increase would raise the amounts of those things pro rata, but are they essential humanitarian needs?"
