HEADLINE: Across Asia, a Pollution Disaster Hovers

SERIES: POISONED LANDS: First of two articles.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF

DATELINE: BADUI, China

 BODY:
This little village is hauntingly beautiful, a patchwork of mud-brick shacks framed by the vastness of the Yellow River on one side and rugged gray mountains on the other. But as peasants shuffle along the ocher paths, their eyes following their children and aching at the sight, the hamlet suddenly seems chilly, frightening and grotesque.
One-third of the peasants in this hamlet in Gansu Province in western China are mentally retarded or seriously ill. Most people die in middle age, the women report unending miscarriages and stillbirths, many of the children are trapped in toddler-size bodies that they never grow out of, and even the goats totter and stagger into trees as they go blind and insane. 
 In the entrance to one house stood a boy named Wei Haiyun, only 29 inches tall -- the height that an average American baby boy reaches at 12 months, but Haiyun is 8 years old. Haiyun, who is mentally retarded as well, casually urinated on the floor and then played with his fingers in the puddle, as his mother watched and bit her lip and admitted that the only word he ever utters is "Ma."
The peasants believe that the horrors of Badui village are the result of polluted water discharged by the state-run Liujiaxia Fertilizer Factory next door. The factory, which sometimes denies the accusations and mostly ignores them, dumps its wastes into the Yellow River just upstream from where the villagers draw their drinking water.
The pain here in Badui is emblematic of the growing environmental catastrophe all across Asia. The cost of Asia's "economic miracle" is a rising tide of pollution that is proving a burden not just for Asia but for the entire earth.
Already, Asia has what many experts consider the dirtiest water in the world, the filthiest air, the most worrisome overfishing, and the fastest-disappearing coral reefs. One study by the United Nations suggested that 13 of the 15 cities with the worst air pollution in the world are in Asia.
"The worst pollution in the world is unequivocally in Asia," said Daniel C. Esty, director of the Center for Environmental Law and Policy at Yale University and co-author of a new book on Asia-Pacific environmental issues. "The statistics about China are stunning, and right behind those Chinese cities stand almost every other major city of Asia: Bangkok, Manila, Jakarta are all right up there among the top polluted cities of the world."
When delegates from the United States and more than 150 other countries gather in Kyoto, Japan, beginning on Dec. 1 for a conference on global warming, one of the fundamental underlying challenges will be how to accommodate the economic rise of Asia. Aside from the United States, China is already the biggest source of the greenhouse gases linked to global warming, and -- perhaps more worrying for the long run -- the two fastest-growing sources of these emissions are China and India.
More than 1.56 million Asians die each year from the effects of air pollution alone, not counting 500,000 more who die each year from dirty water and bad sanitation, according to estimates published recently by the World Health Organization and the World Bank. Another new study, also from the World Bank but using different assumptions, calculates that 2.03 million people die annually in China alone from the effects of water and air pollution.
All these figures represent statistical stabs in the dark, so all the numbers in this article may well be incorrect. But whatever the precise figures, it appears that considerably more people die each year from pollution in Asia than died in the Indochina wars centered on Vietnam (about 1.4 million, from the 1950's through the 1970's).
Industrialization vastly magnifies the impact that humans have on nature, and so for the last two centuries it has been the transformation of America and Europe that has had the most dramatic consequences for the planet Earth. But many experts believe that in the coming decades, it is the industrialization of Asia that will pose fundamental new stresses for the ecosystem. Not only does Asia have 60 percent of the world's population, 12 times as much as North America's, but Asia's industrialization is also taking place at triple the pace of the industrial revolution in the West.
"Asia's potential effects on global warming are certainly going to be much larger than in the past, and its potential effects on other aspects of the environment, and particularly its own environment, are likely to be greater as well," said Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development and co-author of a major study on Asia's development. "And what that really means is that Asia has got to be a lot smarter than it has been in environmental management."
 
The Air
Two Bangkok Girls Gasp for Breath
The paradox is that Asians are not fleeing the filth but embracing it. From India to China, Asians vote with their feet -- moving from rural areas with relatively clean air to the squalid mega-cities that are among the filthiest places on earth.
To an American, the endless Howrah slums in Calcutta, India, or the shantytowns outside Jakarta, Indonesia, seem hellish intersections of gritty air and contaminated water. But to many rural Indians or Indonesians, the slums sing of opportunity, of jobs, of schools, of hope to break out of subsistence poverty.
So peasants take a calculated risk, accepting that their children may die of respiratory infections or diarrhea in exchange for the chance that they may become educated and rich. It is a dangerous gamble but not necessarily a foolish one, and for many people it pays off.
Partly as a result of such risk-taking, most Asians are living longer and better than ever, and others are choking to death.
The stakes are evident in the sparkling black eyes of Kittiya Soisingh, a 14-month-old girl in Bangkok. Her parents moved to a Bangkok slum to get a better life, and as a result Kittiya may lose hers altogether.
Kittiya lives in a dark hovel beside an elevated highway, cars and trucks spewing out black exhaust beside her and above her, and so the air is dense with grit. She almost died recently after a respiratory infection and spent a month in a hospital, but now she is out again, lounging on a table on the cracked sidewalk outside her home, watching as the cars and trucks whiz by, waiting to be rushed to the hospital the next time.
"I'm always afraid," fretted her mother, Vilgi Ratchamphu, 20, as she played with the girl on the street. "I'm always afraid that she'll just stop breathing."
The problem for Kittiya is the particles in the air. In Bangkok and most Asian cities, these particles total more than the danger level of 100 micrograms per cubic meter. Among the worst cities are Taiyuan, China, and Delhi, India, each with more than 500 micrograms. Even worse is the "indoor air pollution" caused by cooking or heating with coal briquettes; indoor particles in China have been measured at 11,000 micrograms.
These particles can trigger asthma and respiratory infections in children like Kittiya, and although such infections are rarely thought of as deadly in the West, they are the third leading cause of death in the world today, after heart disease and cancer. Moreover, cancer and heart disease tend to kill the elderly, so statisticians say acute respiratory infections cause more "years of life lost" than any other ailment in the world today.
Particles are also associated with higher rates of lung cancer, of heart attacks and especially of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, a fancy way of describing what happens when particles clog up the lungs so that people cannot breathe. This is the leading cause of death in China and kills Chinese at five times the rate in the United States.
To be sure, it is not just the particles that kill children, but also poverty.
Across town from Kittiya's slum, at one of the best nursery schools in Bangkok, 13-month-old Alisa Srirat also suffers from asthma and sensitivity to respiratory infections. A vivacious little girl with chipmunk cheeks, Alisa was born in England, where her father was studying at a university, and she began gasping for breath almost immediately after moving to Thailand and encountering Bangkok's air.
The girl's father, Wichai Srirat, a 33-year-old university lecturer, was able to afford good medical advice, and he ended up buying an air filter for his car to shield his daughter from air particles on the roads. That has largely resolved the crisis.
Mr. Srirat smiled as he watched his daughter play on a jungle gym at the nursery school. "She's so much better now," he mused."
For poorer parents like Kittiya's, stuck in the dirtiest neighborhoods and limited to third-rate medical care, if any, the deadliness of urban air in Asia creates an excruciating dilemma.
"She can be treated, but she can't be cured, and the doctor says we should leave this area," Kittiya's mother noted sadly. "If we stay, she'll never get over this. Her lungs won't be able to take it. But we have no place to go."
That is not exactly true, for the family could go back to the village that it left only a year ago. But a Bangkok slum, despite the bedraggled rats that amble along the gutters, still offers better schools, clinics and jobs than the countryside.
So Kittiya's parents are not being irrational in risking her life. She may die, but she may also be the first in her family to break out of a cycle of subsistence poverty. It is a gamble that leaves her mother breathless with fear, but one that she still accepts.
 
The Water
Lead and Bacteria Foul Asia's Rivers
One of the greatest scientific mistakes of the 20th century was the decision to add lead to gasoline to improve performance. The lead in the air from car exhaust maims children intellectually, permanently impairing their brain development.
In Chinese cities like Shanghai, the roads are clogged with new cars that are one of the most dazzling signs of China's economic triumph. But various studies have found that at least 65 percent of Shanghai children have lead levels higher than the point considered dangerous to mental development. The retardation is permanent, and half a century from now, most of these people will still be living out their lives, the flotsam of Asia's industrial revolution.
Most of the lead comes from auto exhaust and hangs in the air, but because of factory discharges, Asia's rivers also average 20 times more lead than the rivers in the industrialized world.
Asia's water is almost as deadly as the air, for hundreds of thousands of people die from drinking polluted water, particularly in places like India, where the rivers sometimes function simultaneously as water sources and sewage systems. The average Asian river has 50 times more bacteria from human feces than World Health Organization guidelines allow.
Perhaps the worst slum in the world is in on the edge of Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on a muddy slope leading to the Bassac River. As one strolls along the wooden planks that serve as sidewalks over the stinking mud and excrement, making conversation with exhausted women trying to prepare dinner and look after their brood of naked children, nearly every mother acknowledges having lost a child or two over the years.
It is easy to see why. The tens of thousands of people who live in the slum drink the river water, which is polluted with industrial effluents and also functions as the toilet for the entire community.
There are countless other environmental challenges in Asia, like deforestation -- the continent is losing 1 percent of its forests each year -- and the loss of rare species of animals, particularly in countries like Indonesia that are treasures of biodiversity. But those problems seem a bit unreal to many workers and peasants; the giant panda may become extinct, but every year tens of thousands of Chinese children die from pollution for every panda that is poached.
 
The Complexities
Unclear Causation Vs. Clear Prosperity
The study of pollution is so invested with the language of science, with everything measured in micrograms or milliliters, that it all sometimes seems tidy and precise. But in fact, one of the fundamental challenges is that at ground level in Asia, there are enormous uncertainties about how to assess the dangers, and these unknowns make regulation all the more difficult.
In Badui and its surrounding villages in China, just downstream from the fertilizer factory, the precise reason for the health problems remains as murky as the factory's effluent. The only thing that is entirely clear is that something is dreadfully wrong.
In the hamlet of Qidui, which is three miles from Badui and also relies mostly on river water with factory waste, there are about 13 births a year, estimates the village leader, Li Genchen. Of these, he said, eight are stillbirths or children who die in infancy, and a couple more survive but with tiny bodies. Only about three of the births lead to normal children, he said.
As for adults, he said, most die in their 40's.
Circumstantial evidence is clear: The problems in Qidui and Badui began around the time when the factory started operations in 1971, and they went away in a nearby village that got piped water in 1989. Factory officials acknowledged that they have dumped dangerous chemicals, including arsenic, into the water, although they say they stopped releasing arsenic in 1978.
"Water pollution has been a serious problem, and local villagers have been making trouble over this issue," said Fu Youai, an official in the local environmental protection bureau. "The pollution is too high and has gone way over the levels set by the state, and it's harmful to human beings."
"Every year, we order the factory to correct the problems," Mr. Fu added. "But because of budget constraints, the factory hasn't been able to do so."
Tests of the water conducted on samples carried out to Japan show the presence of ammonia, nitrites and trace metals. The tests also showed arsenic in levels that exceed safety standards, but not by a large margin, and in any case these would not normally produce precisely the symptoms seen in these villages.
Doctors and chemists consulted in Japan and in the United States noted that a single sample is often not reliable, because chemicals can be released irregularly. They added that the causation of health problems can be extremely complex.
Something in the effluent might build up in fish, they said. Or some chemical in the effluent might act in combination with a mineral deficiency in the peasants, and they suggested that identifying the problem might take years of research.
Such complexities are common, for in Japan's most famous pollution case it took years to prove that inorganic mercury used by a factory in Minamata was turning into a highly toxic substance called methyl mercury. The methyl mercury then accumulated in fish and caused birth defects in babies born to women who ate the fish.
Yet for all the mystery about the ailments of Badui, there is one overwhelming practical certainty in Badui that has an echo all across Asia: The polluting factory is crucial to the regional economy. The factory employs 3,000 workers and annually produces 160,000 tons of urea fertilizer, which in turn improves the diet and raises the living standards of millions of people in Gansu Province.
If the factory was forced to close, the increased local poverty would almost certainly lead to more people dying of mundane diseases and fewer children being able to afford to go to school. So officials at the factory, which is only marginally profitable, are not at all sympathetic to the peasants and dismiss them as troublemakers grasping for compensation payments.
"The villagers are lazy and unreasonable," scoffed Zeng Qingang, a factory director. "They say, 'We should get rich by living off the factory.' "
Moreover, even some of the villagers are wary of thorough investigations that might harm their own livelihood -- like raising fish in ponds full of the tainted water. There are several of these fish farms, and although the villagers say the pollution kills up to half the fish, they sell the surviving fish on the market in the nearby city of Lanzhou.
"The fish taste different from the fish raised in cleaner water," acknowledged Cui Tengxiong, a local fish farmer. "I'm a bit afraid that they'll test the fish and then tell us not to sell them."
The heartbreak here in Badui and across Asia is so numbing that one sometimes forgets that the pollution is only half of the seesaw, and that the other half -- economic development -- is even more stunning.
Industrialization may be poisoning hundreds of thousands of people each year, but it is also resulting in new hospitals and schools that are saving even more lives.
Even in Badui, the peasants acknowledge that for all their difficulties with death and disease, their lives have improved dramatically. As recently as the great famine of 1959-61, many starved to death in Badui.
So some of the peasants, even as they sorrowfully watch their retarded children, bear the hardships that they attribute to pollution remarkably well. They suffer tragedies but keep them in a kind of perspective.
"My husband's stomach is sick, so he can't do much," Qi Chunnu, a stooped farm wife with downcast eyes, said tiredly as she stood in the entrance to her home in Badui. "My eldest child is mentally retarded. My second child is deaf and can't speak right."
And then she beamed: "But my third child is O.K."
NEXT: Public obliviousness to the health risks of Asia's environmental disaster.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Pippen Is Right, But Wrong

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
THE school teacher trying to run a class of disadvantaged kids in an inner city has to laugh to keep from crying when Scottie Pippen complains that his contract to play basketball -- a seven-year deal worth $22 million and in its last year -- has become a slap in his face.
The garbage collector or the candlestick maker, as well, must wince when they learn that Scottie Pippen grumbles that he gets no respect from the Chicago Bulls, from whose base it is estimated he has made more in endorsements than in salary. He is demanding a trade or, he threatens, he will not play this season. Pippen has been sidelined from the beginning of the season after having undergone foot surgery, and suggests he is about ready to play, but won't -- for the Bulls. 
 Now, in America, after all, we pay top dollar to be entertained, and Scottie Pippen, a smooth operator on the court, has emerged as a great entertainer. He is one of the 10 to 15 best players in basketball, and second only to M. J. Jordan as a player responsible for the five National Basketball Association championships in the last seven years the Bulls have won.
And as everyone who follows basketball, or the gross national product, knows, Pippen is currently not receiving market value for his extraordinary skills. Which is not quite the same thing as saying that he is, as some have termed it, "grossly underpaid."
Yet Pippen sees a second-year player like Kevin Garnett signing a $126 million contract for six years. Or a veteran player like Charles Oakley making around $3.6 million. In fact, Pippen's salary -- currently at $2.775 million a year -- is 122d in the league.
"I would rather leave things as I can remember them as a player and go on," Pippen recently said, in an adieu of sorts to the Bulls. "It's very difficult. I have a lot of respect for teammates and the fans in Chicago. I've enjoyed my 10 years playing here."
Memories, like Pippen's, are obviously highly selective. Does Pippen remember when hometown fans booed him and he lashed out at them for being "racist"? Does he remember when, in one of the most disgusting moments in recent sports history, he threw a monumental pout and refused to enter a tie game in the playoffs in 1994 against the Knicks with 1.8 seconds to go because the play wasn't designed for him?
And does he remember that, before signing his current contract negotiated by him and his agent in June 1991, it made him one of the highest-paid players in the game?
Does he remember when the Bulls' owner, Jerry Reinsdorf, told him: "Scottie, in my opinion, I think you will regret signing because salaries will be going up in the N.B.A. and if you continue being a good player, it'll turn out you're underpaid?"
"I remember him telling me at the time," Reinsdorf said recently, "that he wanted the security because of the back surgery and he might be injured. I said, 'Scottie, if you sign, we're never going to renegotiate.' " Pippen eagerly reached for the pen.
As part of the collective bargaining agreement between the league and the players' union three years ago, a team is prevented from renegotiating an existing contract.
"We'd like to pay him more money -- he deserves more money," said Jerry Krause, general manager of the Bulls and an ample target of Pippen's dissatisfaction, "but all we could do now is extend his contract by a maximum of 20 percent a year. But we know he's looking for a much larger payday."
What about his not getting respect from the Bulls? "How do you spell respect?" asked Ernie Grunfeld, the Knicks' general manager, who answered his own question: "M-o-n-e-y."
Meanwhile, Pippen, when not giving full value -- such as not playing because of a tantrum, or because of injury or surgery (he could have had the foot surgery earlier last summer but opted to go on a promotional tour for the shoe company he sponsors) -- has never offered to return any part of his salary to the organization.
And his public grousings have made it ever more difficult for the Bulls to trade for equal value when other teams feel that, with a 32-year-old player coming off injury, Chicago must deal from weakness.
Despite current market tendencies, Scottie Pippen indeed signed a contract that, to most people, would be commensurate with a king's ransom.
The classy thing to do would be to shut up and live up to it.

HEADLINE: In Oakland, Jerry Brown Sees Forum for Change

BYLINE: By DON TERRY

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif.

 BODY:
Dressed in black from his banded-collar shirt to his shoes, a balding, 59-year-old man walking along the waterfront of this city of hills and faded factories looked vaguely familiar to a group of tourists from Atlanta.
He was a dead ringer for that guy who followed his daddy's footsteps into politics and was a two-term Governor of California, who fed the hungry at the side of Mother Teresa and marched with farm workers and most recently was host of a radio talk show, "We The People," an "intelligent" antidote, he will be the first to tell you, to all the right-wing pap poisoning the airwaves. 
 "You're Jerry Brown," one tourist said. "You ran for President."
"Three times," the man in black said.
But these days, Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown Jr. has more modest ambitions. He wants to be the next mayor of Oakland, his adopted hometown.
He swears he is not kidding.
For most of his life, Mr. Brown, the son of power and privilege, has played in the major leagues of American politics, far away from places like Oakland, the other city by the bay. But he said rather than being a step down -- the last stop perhaps of a once promising political career -- becoming mayor of a medium-size city with big problems is a much better place to help rebuild the "foundation of America, our cities."
"Here's where reality is, even though very powerful decisions are made elsewhere," Mr. Brown said. "Economic, environmental, racial, educational, crime, art, welfare -- all the factors that go into the national dialogue -- are right here. I've tried it at the national level, but at the local level, you can mobilize people and do good regardless of money politics."
Mr. Brown announced his mayoral ambitions in early November, and the news was greeted with smirks, smiles and sighs. He is used to the mixed reaction. He has been called every name in the book -- good and bad -- including quirky, flaky, smart, visionary.
"I think he is a sort of tortured soul in some ways and feels he needs to reinvent himself," said Larry Arnn, president of the Claremont Institute, a conservative think tank in Claremont, east of Los Angeles. "From the perspective of California politics, where there is a lot of strange stuff, he is the strangest."
H. Eric Schockman, a professor of political science at the University of Southern California, said Mr. Brown "is a man looking for an office."
"He is a wonderful, inspirational speaker who can move masses of people, but that's not what big cities need," Professor Schockman said. "They need someone to roll up their sleeves and fill potholes."
With a population of 370,000, Oakland is the sixth-largest city in California and the 39th largest in the country, according to the 1990 Census. It is a blue-collar city in a world of computer chips, roller coaster stock markets, runaway factories and pink-collar low-end jobs.
"There's a driving down of wages for a significant number of Americans, and a lot of them live here," Mr. Brown said. "We're a factory town in transition. We're going to need to attract a lot of private capital and do a lot of bootstrap pulling."
Although Mr. Brown was vague about exactly how he would bring jobs to the city, he has said he would use his years of political experience and contacts to attract development.
That may not be easy. Oakland is a long way from the national spotlight, which, when it shines on Northern California, usually hits San Francisco, the city of glamour and cable cars with its own Mayor named Brown, as in Willie L. Brown Jr., the former longtime speaker of the California Assembly.
"I think the example of Willie Brown had to have had some influence on Jerry's decision to run," said Bruce E. Cain, acting director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California at Berkeley. "Jerry saw that being Mayor of a city is a very good platform to talk about some of the critical issues facing contemporary California and, indeed, urban America."
Mr. Brown moved to Oakland, a racially and culturally diverse city, where minorities are the overwhelming majority, in 1993.
He lives in the old factory district on the city's west side near the Port of Oakland in a sprawling building that also houses his nonprofit organization and radio show.
"Oakland is a beautiful city," Mr. Brown said. "And it is full of unspent potential."
All that potential is one reason a crowded field of five or more is anticipated in this nonpartisan June election, even though the city has a weak mayor form of government.
The two-term incumbent, Mayor Elijou Harris, has not officially declared his intentions, but he is not expected to seek re-election.
Others expected to run include a city council member, a county supervisor, a chamber of commerce official, and Edward J. Blakely, an urban affairs professor at the University of Southern California, who has spent most of his life in Oakland.
"Everybody sees Oakland is turning around, and that's why Jerry is interested," Professor Blakely said. "A lot of people have paid very high prices to get Oakland into this position, and Jerry wasn't one of them."
On the streets of Oakland in interviews with business owners and homeless loners, with college students and architects, Mr. Brown's candidacy was greeted with a rainbow of outright enthusiasm, downright pessimism and guarded hope.
Hampton Hancock, a 54-year-old architect who works for the city, said he had significant reservations about Mr. Brown's ability to manage such a diverse place.
"Has Jerry ever faced in life what most families have faced?" Mr. Hancock asked. "I think he's a good man, and I think he's a serious man, but every time he has a problem he takes off to study Buddhism and some Zen master in Japan."
Carol Denise Mitchell, a writer and executive secretary, said Mr. Brown, as a white man, was the wrong person to lead Oakland. The city's last two mayors have been black and Ms. Mitchell, who is black, does not want that to change.
"I don't think anybody is doing much good for Oakland right now, and I would like to see other black candidates give it a try because Oakland is a minority city," she said.
Her views were not shared by George Gary Warren, 44, who also is black and who is a Brown volunteer.
"He's a guy people always wrote off, and he always came back," Mr. Warren said. "The same thing happens to Oakland. People are always writing us off. I think Mr. Brown can help bring us back."
Mr. Brown was headed back to his headquarters recently when another group of tourists shouted hello.
Mr. Brown waved and smiled and then told about the time he and his father, Gov. Edmund G. (Pat) Brown Sr., were riding with John F. Kennedy through Oakland during the 1960 Presidential campaign. The candidate waved at everyone, a lesson that has stuck with Mr. Brown.
"There are very few people who have as much experience in politics as I do," Mr. Brown said. "This is what I know how to do best."

HEADLINE: The Worries About Lobster In Maine Rise By the Pound

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: FRIENDSHIP, Me.

 BODY:
Donald Simmons Sr. had little company when he began setting lobster traps in Muscongus Bay more than 25 years ago.
These days, hundreds of boats and more than 200,000 brightly colored lobster buoys crowd the same 80-square miles of the bay. 
 Hoping to find less crowded and more lucrative waters, Mr. Simmons and four fellow lobstermen from Friendship, a small town about 75 miles northeast of Portland, bought state licenses last fall to fish in a 32-square-mile area traditionally reserved for residents of Monhegan (pronounced mon-HEE-gun), an island about 25 miles southwest of Friendship.
The move outraged Monhegan's 12 lobstermen, who put out about 6,000 lobster traps in the area. It also sparked a statewide debate that could influence the future of Maine's lobster industry.
At stake, Monhegan fishermen argue, is a way of life that has sustained their offshore community for hundreds of years. State officials worry that the territorial dispute is a symptom of a larger problem: an out-of-control lobster fishery.
Lobster fishing has risen sharply over the last decade, state officials and fishermen agree. Maine licensed 2.6 million traps in 1996, the first year the state kept such records.
Part of the growth has been driven by conservation efforts that forced some fishermen to switch from species like halibut and cod. That has been coupled with record lobster catches and profits in the 1990's. Lobsters are selling for $2.90 a pound at the dock, and the price is expected to rise.
Last year, Maine fishermen caught 36.2 million pounds of lobster worth more than $107 million.
At the same time, faster boats have allowed fishermen to set traps farther and farther from their homes, and some of the informal rules and unofficial boundaries that grew up around the state's 90 or so lobstering harbors have eroded, said Col. Joseph Fessenden, chief of the Marine Patrol, the law-enforcement arm of Maine's Department of Marine Resources.
Many fishermen argue that the rising catches are a sign of a healthy industry, but biologists contend they are not sustainable.
"The time has come for us to move ahead with more stringent conservation measures in order to protect the stock into the future," said Jay Krouse, director of the agency's biological monitoring division.
Maine began taking steps to protect lobster fishing several years ago, with restrictions on the number of new lobster licenses also setting a limit of 1,200 traps for each fisherman, and an apprenticeship program that limits the number of people entering the industry.
Fishermen formed local management groups that were empowered to adopt more stringent conservation rules, including lowering the limit on the number of traps. Several local groups did just that, and others are considering it.
Monhegan has had a more stringent trap limit since 1974, when residents agreed to a maximum of 600 traps for each fisherman.
In addition to the trap limit and a January-to-June fishing season set by the State Legislature in 1907, Monhegan fishermen also informally adopted a two-year apprenticeship for anyone wanting to join the fishery, said Doug Boynton, a Monhegan lobsterman who has been fishing around the island for 30 years.
"What has kept lobstering a healthy fishery is that people have had to look after their own backyard," he said. "We had to be sure that next season there was something there."
Of the island's 70 residents, 24 make a living from winter lobster fishing, when prices are highest. Unemployed Monhegan residents, Mr. Boynton pointed out, cannot just get into their trucks and drive to the next town for part-time work.
"If we lose the winter fishing area, the community is going to die out and become a tourist attraction," Mr. Boynton said.
Monhegan's fishing traditions date to the early 1600's, when English explorers established a base there for cod fishing.
Friendship fishermen scoff at the idea that adding five new fishermen to those in the Monhegan area would deplete the lobsters there or put locals out of work.
A state-hired mediator met with the lobstermen in November and worked out a compromise allowing Monhegan's fishing season to open a month early, on Dec. 1, and splitting the area to allow both sides to fish until January, when the Legislature convenes and can consider the issue.
But disputes like this will continue unless fishermen and state fisheries managers can reduce the number of traps in the water, said Colonel Fessenden of the Marine Patrol.
"Its probably going to lead to eroding of traditional fishing areas that have existed for the last 100 years," he said, "and probably to the demise of the fishing industry."

HEADLINE: Public Backs Tough Steps For a Treaty On Warming

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
As the world's nations gather in Japan to discuss how best to counter the threat of global warming, the American people are far more willing than their Government to take early, unilateral steps, a New York Times Poll has found.
They appear to be unimpressed by arguments that cutting the United States' emissions of heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere might cause undue economic harm, as industry groups opposing a treaty have contended. 
 Sixty-five percent of those polled said that the United States, which releases more such greenhouse gases than any other country, should take steps now to cut its own emissions "regardless of what other countries do." The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Only 15 percent of the 953 people polled by telephone on Sunday and Monday said the United States should delay acting until many countries agree how to address the problem together.
Better-educated people are most likely to favor early action by the United States. Fully three-quarters of college graduates favor acting even without a binding treaty, as do 59 percent of high school graduates. Men and women are equally likely to favor unilateral action.
Delegates from 166 nations are assembling Monday in Kyoto to try to negotiate a tougher, binding treaty on controlling emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases that trap the Sun's heat in the Earth's atmosphere and threaten to change the planet's climate. The treaty would supplant the voluntary pact that was adopted five years ago at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro.
The Clinton Administration's position going into the talks has been criticized by European nations who say it would delay action for too long, and many Third World nations have been resisting the Administration's insistence that developing countries join the industrial nations in pledging to cut emissions.
American emissions of greenhouse gases have been increasing ever since the world's industrial nations agreed five years ago to try to reduce them by the turn of the century. The Administration has proposed a binding treaty stabilizing emissions at the 1990 levels, but not until another 10 or 15 years have passed.
The poll suggests that the public rejects the main arguments against such a treaty that have been voiced by industry groups, some unions and their allies in Congress. Rather, most Americans tend to agree with the position on the talks taken by major environmental groups.
Still, just 1 percent of all respondents offered the environment when asked what was the most important problem facing the country; crime topped the list. When asked what environmental problem was most important, people were more likely to name air and water pollution than global warming. Twenty-seven percent said they had heard or read a lot about global warming and 38 percent said they had heard or read "some" about it. About a third said they knew "not much" or "nothing" about it.
Generally, Americans strongly favor environmental protection despite its costs, the poll showed. Sixty-one percent of respondents favor protecting the environment even it it costs jobs in their community; 57 percent said environmental improvements must be made regardless of costs. Majorities have taken that view for 15 years.
Major industries, including companies that produce and consume large amounts of fossil fuels, have criticized the Administration for moving too quickly on global warming, saying that the science of global warming remains uncertain and that limiting energy use or raising energy prices could needlessly harm the American economy.
But neither of these arguments appear to carry much weight with the public.
Fifty-seven percent of those surveyed agreed that the American economy would become more competitive if the nation controlled greenhouse gas emissions "because these efforts will result in more efficient energy use, saving money in the long run." Only 17 percent agreed that cutting emissions "will cost too much money and hurt the U.S. economy."
Only 16 percent said that they believed global warming results from normal fluctuations in climate rather than from emissions released when people burn fossil fuels like coal, oil and gasoline.
Asked when serious effects from global warming might be expected, an even smaller minority, 13 percent, said they believed global warming would have no serious effect.
In contrast, 23 percent said they believed global warming's impact was already serious.
Another 43 percent said global warming's effects would not be felt until the future. Despite that belief, 6 out of 7 people in this group said steps were needed right away to counter global warming.
Younger adults, especially those less than 30 years old, were more likely than older ones to believe that the effects of global warming are already being felt. And older people, especially those older than 65, are more likely to believe it will not have a serious impact at all.
Most people said they would be willing to spend money on efficient appliances, insulation and other energy-saving investments to cut emissions of greenhouse gases and save money on gas and electric bills. Only 20 percent said they would not be willing to do so.
Forty-one percent of the people in the sample said they would be willing to spend money to cut energy use even if it took as much as five years of reduced gas and electric bills to cover the cost of the investment.
Far and away the most popular approach to cutting emissions was for the Government to impose energy efficiency standards on manufacturers of cars, appliances and so on.
Fifty percent said they would favor this approach, while 20 percent said they favored tax breaks for nonpolluting energy like solar and wind power. Only 2 percent said they favored extra taxes on gasoline or other fossil fuels.
It appeared that people were not ready to endorse the Administration's proposed approach to reducing emissions of greenhouse gases, which would involve a complicated system of trading pollution permits.
When this system was described and people were told that it "would give companies a financial reason to reduce their emissions of greenhouse gases," 49 percent said they did not know enough to judge the proposal's merits. Fifteen percent said it was a good idea, and 17 percent said it was a bad idea.
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted on Sunday and Monday with 953 adults across the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that calls would be placed to residences only. Within each household one adult was designated at random to be the respondent for the poll.
The results from all regions were weighted to reflect the actual adult population of the nation. The results have also been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines and to adjust for variations in race, sex, age, and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points either way from what would have been obtained from all American adults.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Union Pacific's Rail Troubles Take a Toll on Texas Businesses

BYLINE: By The New York Times

 BODY:
Growing delays in rail traffic since Union Pacific Railroad became the nation's largest railway have cost Texas businesses $762 million, and the losses could climb to $1.3 billion, according to a study commissioned by state regulators.
The report by Bernard Weinstein, an economics professor at the University of North Texas, came as the Texas Railroad Commission sought to force Union Pacific to give other railroads access to the Houston market by selling about 250 miles of track there to an association of carriers. 
 The congestion problems, caused in part by Union Pacific's merger with the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation last year, have resulted in trouble throughout the West. But Texas, with more than one-sixth of Union Pacific's 36,000 miles of track, may be faring the worst.
Severe traffic delays and a lack of rail cars have prevented utility companies from getting enough coal, forcing some to look to natural gas at a time of rising gas prices. Grain elevators, full with record harvests, have had to store grain on the ground, where it could spoil.
Since June, lost production and freight charges have cost the Texas chemical industry $289.2 million, and paper and forest product companies $208 million, according to Professor Weinstein's report, which was issued on Wednesday.
John Bromley, a Union Pacific spokesman, told The Associated Press that the railroad believed the report had overestimated the costs, but he added that the railroad had not undertaken a study of its own.
Union Pacific's problems began in late summer in the former Southern Pacific switching yards in Houston and radiated from there throughout the Union Pacific system, which extends from Chicago to California.
Last week, the Texas Railroad Commission approved a request to the Federal Surface Transportation Board to force Union Pacific to sell 250 miles of track in and around Houston to an independent entity that would give other railroads access to the Houston market.
"I don't think any of us believe that monopolies have been good for this country," the railroad commission's chairman, Charles Matthews, said, "and that's what this issue is all about.".
Under the commission's proposal, Union Pacific would be forced to sell its tracks on both sides of the Houston Ship Channel, which connects Houston to the Gulf of Mexico, as well as tracks that run from Houston to the Texas cities of Galveston and Beaumont. The majority of the tracks would be operated by the Port Terminal Railroad Association, a neutral switching carrier that has operated in the region since 1924.
The Surface Transportation Board, the successor to the Interstate Commerce Commission, is under no obligation to implement the Texas proposal. So far, it has been cautious in its approach to Union Pacific's problems. On Oct. 31, the board issued an emergency order requiring Union Pacific to share some of its track south of Houston with the Texas Mexican Railway Company, based in Laredo. The board will meet again on Dec. 3 to review Union Pacific's progress and to consider the railroad commission's proposal.
Mark Davis, a spokesman for Union Pacific, contended that the commission's plan "will not help." The railroad "needs all the rail lines serving Houston," Mr. Davis said. "They play a very vital role in being able to offer new and better service not only in Texas but across the whole system."

HEADLINE: Students in Germany Protest Cuts in University Spending

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: BONN, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of students marched through central Bonn today, blowing whistles and blasting trumpets in a demonstration that crowned weeks of protests and years of discontent over the underfinancing and overcrowding of Germany's colleges and universities. Thousands more boycotted classes across the country.
The protests were the biggest displays of student anger in Germany for more than two decades. But, while a previous generation's protests focused on such political themes as the American presence in Vietnam, the huge turnout today reflected student annoyance at overcrowded lecture halls, libraries without books, long waits for access to computers and suggestions that tuition fees be introduced in Germany's state-financed universities similar to those in the United States. 
 Germany's 230 colleges and universities were intended to accommodate some 950,000 students but, over the last 20 years, the number of students has risen to 1.8 million, many of them spending much longer than is usual in the United States to complete their studies.
At the same time, spending reductions have cut teaching staff, leaving lecture halls bulging with students who say they sometimes wait for years to meet with professors. One protester today, Barbara Muller of Cologne, said some seminars were so crowded that she started lining up for a seat at 4 A.M. "and I still didn't get a place."
The protests today, after demonstrations and strikes by students in other cities in recent weeks, were the latest reflection of a broader crisis in Germany -- Europe's biggest economy -- as it struggles to pare away a padded welfare state to meet the challenges of economic globalization and European plans for a single currency based on fiscal restraint.
The students, from 40 universities, converged on Bonn in a cavalcade of buses and four special trains. One small group bicycled the 400 miles from Berlin. There were as many as 40,000 protesters, according to estimates by the police and organizers of the march. Students at 50 universities and colleges boycotted classes today to back the protest.
Many carried banners urging the Government to spend money on higher education rather than on a projected European warplane, the Eurofighter, for which Germany has committed $13 billion. "For a billion marks, 6.5 Eurofighters or 6,481 smart students -- which do we need more in the future?" a banner said.
Student leaders maintain that universities are underfinanced by as much as $3 billion a year.
The complaints have drawn broad support from professors, lecturers and politicians. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who said he sympathized with the students, blamed mismanagement by Germany's 16 federal states, most of which are run by the opposition Social Democrats, for the crisis -- an assertion denied by the Social Democrat leader Oskar Lafontaine.
The question of introducing tuition fees -- raised by some state legislators -- has drawn criticism from students that universities will become elite establishments for the rich. The federal Education Minister, Jurgen Ruttgers, said on television today that the Government wanted "people to be able to study in Germany, whether they are rich or poor." That was met with some skepticism.
"Ruttgers hypocrite," a marchers' banner replied.
A new law, currently before Parliament but not yet approved, seeks to streamline education by making universities compete for state financing, reducing the time it takes to get degrees and introducing a credits system. It does not provide specifically for the introduction of tuition fees, but Mr Kohl's Government has refused to rule out the idea -- as the students demanded today.
Many academics maintain, though, that the proposed law does not address the basic issue. "We in Germany are faced with a question, and it's a value judgment," said Klaus Borchard, vice chancellor of the university here. "What price do we set for the education of our young people?"

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL: The Two Sides of Allan Houston;
Knick Guard Combines Suburban Style With City Smarts

BYLINE: By SELENA ROBERTS

 BODY:
There was school busing, and in a way, it made the suburban curtain that hung between Allan Houston's new world and the inner city of Louisville, Ky., appear invisible.
He had been a city kid until he was 10 years old. He lived in a small home on a tidy block, within earshot of the projects. Houston was far from impoverished, but there were financial constraints and plenty of unfulfilled window-shopping. And yet Houston also had everything a child could need: two loving parents and a Big Wheel tricycle. 
 "I was all over the yard with that Big Wheel," said Houston, now 26 and the youngest player for the Knicks. "I had two friends, and we would circle the house 300 times. That was when I lived downtown. I must have been 4 or 5. It seemed like I had that Big Wheel forever. But I don't know what happened to it when I moved."
The city's skyline slipped away in the rear-view mirror. Suburbs straight ahead. A two-story house and a more comfortable life awaited his family. His father, Wade, had just become an assistant coach at the University of Louisville. It was not big money -- no lucrative Nike contracts to fortify salaries back then -- but there were perks. The family had a van from the school and travel opportunities. Very suburban.
A kid could grow soft in this environment. And there is an undercurrent of thinking about players from middle-class neighborhoods: they don't have the edge that those from more desperate backgrounds do. Is that why Houston -- with his shy, almost slumped exterior -- is considered passive at times? It's an image he has been disproving since he moved from the inner city.
"I think there is a certain aura about growing up in a different environment," Houston said. "What I always did, I tried to gain the respect of certain people by interacting. In my high school, they had busing. A lot of my teammates lived in the projects. My mother would worry a little, but I would go down there and hang out with them just to play basketball. I didn't think anything of it. These were my teammates and my friends. I don't know what that says, but that's how I went about my way."
Houston's way makes for a contradiction in personality. He has a tranquil core that has helped him remain calm during a confusing and frustrating second season as the Knicks' $54 million investment in the future.
He has dealt with the anxiety of a wrist not yet healed and handled rumors that he would be traded for Mitch Richmond with grace and prayer. He has absorbed criticism over the mental block he has shown against his old team, the Detroit Pistons. He will face that issue again tonight, when the Knicks play the Pistons in Auburn Hills, Mich.
"Yeah, I'd like to have a good game," Houston said. "But they don't have a way to guard Patrick Ewing. So I'm not going to say, 'Give me the ball.' "
This season, the ball has come to him with less frequency. But so far, he has buried any doubts he has had over his role while a hot John Starks continues to melt down his minutes.
Doesn't Houston just want to shout: "Hey, give me some playing time? Let me show you I'm fine?"
"All the time, every game," said Houston, who has averaged 28.6 minutes of playing time, compared with 33 minutes a game last season. "But I try to put the negative stuff out of my head. I try to be positive. There may be a time when I ask the question, 'What's going on?' But right now, I have to do the best with the time I have on the court."
Just when he seems free of aggression, he will challenge anyone who considers him too passive. "Half the guys you think are hard and tough are not," Houston said. "So what is soft? It's just a perception. I'm never going to back down from anything."
Underneath the placid waters running through his veins bubbles a passion for the game. Underneath, there is an activist, too. His voice tightens when he hears about a player not living up to his responsibilities, and when he sees money isolate professional athletes from their communities. There are days when Houston pulls out of the driveway of his Greenwich, Conn., home and makes a path toward Harlem. He parks on the street, gets out of his car and walks. He just wants to meet people, shake their hands and ask how they're doing.
"Sometimes, they'll look at me and say, 'Aren't you. . . .,' " Houston said. "It's not really a big deal. I just like to say hello to people."
It's a way to reach out. He has never known another way. Houston grew up in a family of coaches, from his grandfather to his uncle to his father, each in tune to those in need around them.
"Allan grew up hearing about his grandfather a lot," said Wade Houston, who was the head coach at Tennessee when his son played there from 1990 to 1994. "A lot of the kids who played for him didn't have much, and their families were from low economic areas. And rather than have them go home after school without any food, he would take them over to his house and he would feed them and let them sleep a couple of hours. Allan grew up hearing and seeing that kind of giving back. It became a part of who he is."
Houston is heavily involved with Big Brothers/Big Sisters, and he is the league's representative for its Team Up volunteer program.
He has never made a scene, not even under tedious questioning about Richmond. Even though Houston was never going to be traded, he had to endure two weeks of rumors.
"I prayed about it and I said, 'I think if God really meant for me to be here, he wouldn't have said go to New York for a year, and then go to Sacramento,' " Houston said. "If it would have happened, it was meant to be. But I just did not believe it was going to happen."
If he had been shooting with his normal motion, the speculation might have died quickly. But Houston has struggled to find his rhythm, shooting 40 percent from the field and a dismal 12.5 percent from 3-point range. Not only are his minutes dropping, but Houston is also missing the playing time he needs to loosen his surgically repaired wrist.
"You have to go with who is hot," Coach Jeff Van Gundy has explained when discussing the way he divides time between Houston and Starks. "That's the way it is going to be for everyone."
Houston has never been in this situation before. He has always been a team star. "Even last year, there was a time when I got to a point where I was comfortable and everyone was comfortable with me," said Houston, who averaged 19 points and 40 minutes a game in the playoffs. "My minutes were consistent and my shots were consistent. Even with the talent on the team last year, there was consistency. Now, it is tough. I need time to play. But it's not my call."
He is not playing passively. In the past two weeks, he has been noticeably energetic on offense and defense. But then so much of what Houston does -- on and off the court -- counters his serene image. He is kind, yet he can poke fun at a teammate with a cunning impersonation. He has Charles Oakley down. "Oak's an easy one," Houston said with a smile. "All you do is mumble and complain a lot."
Houston can be sly and shy all at once. And he can be as laid-back as he appears, too. This has become clear during 15 months of marriage to his wife, Tamara. They are best friends, but complete opposites.
"It's like the other day, we were going to enjoy the afternoon at a movie," Houston said. "We were getting out of the car. And she just took off. She was sprinting to the movie. And I'm like, 'Why are you in such a hurry?' I'm getting popcorn, and she's in the theater. She's so energetic, and I'm laid-back."
And then again, he can be as assertive as an activist and as aggressive as a baseline dunk. He can be reserved, and yet extroverted on the street. He can be suburban, but feel comfortable in any neighborhood.
"I've been in both circumstances," Houston said. "Being a product of both probably formed who I am."

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Asia's Economic Miracle Carries a Deadly Cost
The price of Asia's "economic miracle" is greater pollution, and more than 2 million people in Asia die each year from the effects of contaminated air and water, according to some international organizations. A1 

Iranian Agents Active in Bosnia 
Western and Bosnian officials say that Iranian intelligence agents are mounting operations in Bosnia and have infiltrated the American program to train the Bosnian Army. The officials said they had identified 200 agents who have insinuated themselves into Bosnian Muslim circles, apparently to gather information and thwart Western interests. A1
 
Tabloids Skewer Diana's Kin
After the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, her younger brother, Earl Spencer, became a celebrity for his condemnation of the tabloid press. Now the British tabloids are giving extensive coverage to his messy court hearing in South Africa, meant to decide whether his divorce case should be heard in Britain or Cape Town. A3
 
Apartheid Scars Live On
Azhar Cachalia, a former anti-apartheid colleague of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, told South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission that Ms. Madikizela-Mandela was either aware of or took part in the murderous assaults her bodyguards performed during the late 1980's. Mr. Cachalia and other witnesses said that President Nelson Mandela's former wife ignored appeals from Mr. Mandela himself, who was in jail at the time. A3
 
Netanyahu May Remove Troops
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu proposed to carry out a single Israeli troop withdrawal in the West Bank within five months, if the Palestinians take adequate steps to fight terrorism, and to start talks immediately on a final peace settlement. The offer seemed designed to strike a balance between growing pressure from the United States to move peace efforts forward and from Mr. Netanyahu's right-wing coalition partners not to cede more land to the Palestinians. A6
 
German Students Protest
Tens of thousands of German students marched through Bonn in a demonstration that crowned weeks of protests and years of discontent over the state of Germany's colleges and universities. Thousands more boycotted classes across the country in the biggest displays of student anger in more than two decades. A8
 
Spanish Safety Fears
Spain has been rocked by two disasters this month: flood waters tore through a provincial capital in western Spain and killed 21 people, and 9 others died after a municipal water tank exploded in a Spanish protectorate in North Africa. The incidents have increased national concern over Spain's lack of modern safety precautions. Many say the basic problem is that thousands of Spanish homes were built in flood-prone areas. A9
 
NATIONAL A16-36
 
F.D.A. and Drug Maker Seek Rules for Thalidomide
Women of child-bearing years who have illnesses that respond to the drug thalidomide have had a difficult time acquiring prescriptions because of the drug's link to horrible birth defects. The Food and Drug Administration and a maker of thalidomide say they are working to impose enough controls to prevent future tragedies, but not enough to prevent women from getting a medicine that could prolong or even save their lives. A1
 
Support for Pollution Controls
As the world's nations gather in Japan to discuss how best to counter the threat of global warming, the American people are far more willing than their Government to take early, unilateral steps, a New York Times Poll finds. They appear to be unimpressed by arguments that cutting the United States' emissions of heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere might cause undue economic harm, as industry groups opposing a treaty have contended. A36
 
Rev. Moon Plans Mass Blessing
In a bid for respectability, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who once presided over a mass wedding of his Unification Church members in Madison Square Garden, is now inviting 35,000 married couples -- most of whom do not belong to his church -- to attend a marriage "blessing" ceremony Saturday at RFK Stadium in Washington D.C. Mr. Moon has been reaching out to conservative Christians by emphasizing shared goals such as support for abstinence outside of marriage, and opposition to homosexuality. A16
 
On the Trail of a Rare Cougar
Wildlife officials have been prowling the woods around Jasper, Tenn., for the past month in search of an animal that has long been presumed extinct -- an Eastern cougar. No one has actually seen a real Eastern cougar -- also called a mountain lion -- in at least 20 years. But three months ago in the southern Appalachian mountains, reports of sightings began coming in. A21
 
Jerry Brown Campaigns Again
Edmund G. (Jerry) Brown, the former governor of California and former presidential candidate, is running for the mayor of Oakland, Calif., and said that rather than being a step down -- the last stop perhaps of a once promising political career -- becoming mayor of a small city with big problems is a much better place to help rebuild the "foundation of America, our cities." A16

Medical Marijuana Plan

NEW YORK/REGION B1-13
 
4 Hurt at Macy's Parade As Float Topples Light Pole
Sudden bursts of punishing wind disrupted Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, as many of the parade's signature helium-filled balloons were damaged. Four spectators were hurt when one of the giant balloons struck a lamppost, plunging the top part of it into the crowd. Two people were hospitalized with severe head injuries. The accident was a strange counterpoint to a day in which most of the two million spectators were far away from the accident and had no idea it happened. Several balloons could not finish the parade, including Barney, the Cat in the Hat and the Pink Panther. A Macy's spokesman said the company had discussed with the police the possibility of removing the balloons from the parade, but decided against it because they thought the wind was subsiding. A1
 
A Shelter in the Holocaust
Nechama Singer Ariel of Borough Park, Brooklyn, was reunited this week with Mikhail and Nikolai Vavrisevich, the two Greek Orthodox brothers, who along with their parents turned their home in Ukraine into a life-saving shelter for seven Jews, including Mrs. Ariel and her mother, during the Holocaust. A1
 
The Hardest Foster Beds
New York City's most unwanted children -- truants, runaways, psychotics and battered girls -- are routinely refused by foster parents who prefer young children to troubled adolescents, but the rush of these children into the foster care system has presented New York City with one of its biggest challenges in years. Since January, more than 1,000 of these children, most of them teen-agers and large groups of brothers and sisters, have slept in a second-floor office in Manhattan while the city scrambles for more foster beds. Airlines to Limit Carry-Ons
After years of complaints, the airlines are moving to clear out their increasingly crowded baggage rooms in the sky, by limiting the amount of bags and baggage passengers can bring on board with them. But they are likely to face a new round of complaints, from infrequent leisure travelers, since most business travelers apparently will be exempt from the baggage restrictions. Northwest Airlines is already limiting many passengers to one carry-on bag on its routes, and the United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation will try out similar restrictions on some routes on Monday. D1
 
Cigar Maker Expands
Spain's dominant cigar maker, Tabacalera, which tried unsuccessfully two years ago to buy control of General Cigar Holdings, one of the largest American cigar makers, is now pursuing the $355 million purchase of two United States and two Central American cigar companies. D1
 
Psychological Tests Grow
Companies large and small are turning to psychological tests, developed by a virtually unregulated test-publishing industry, to try to determine who is too impulsive, who falls short in the integrity department or who is too self-absorbed to make the cut. But in their search for ways to weed out unsuitable candidates, companies are relying too much on the tests while glossing over their limitations and flaws, critics say. D1

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Mixed in Asia; Tokyo Shares In a Rebound

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Stock prices in Asia were mixed early today.
Prices continued to rise in Tokyo as investors continued to buy shares in banks and brokerage houses. These stocks fell in recent days because of fears about the health of the institutions. 
 The Nikkei average of 225 stocks was up 143.55 points, or 0.86 percent, to 16,746.75 at the midday break.
 Investors were also encouraged today when the Minister of Finance, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, said he expected no more bank failures soon, after four collapses in a month.
But in Hong Kong share prices slipped early today on profit-taking. The Hang Seng index lost 78.48 points, or about 0.7 percent, to 10,504.62 shortly after opening.
And in South Korea, share prices fell 3 percent early today because of concern that conditions set for a bailout could depress the market.
"Since there is no positive news, reports of the on-going negotiations over the conditions for the I.M.F. bailout are still hurting the market," said a dealer at Dongsuh Securities.
Asian currencies were largely stable in early trading.
Most Asian currencies weakened a bit from Wednesday. The Singapore dollar stood at 1.5930 against the United States dollar, versus 1.5905 on Wednesday; the Malaysian ringgit was 3.5000, from 3.4830; the Thai baht was 39.90, from 39.73, and the Philippine peso was 34.72, from 34.67.
The Japanese yen weakened to 127.73 to the dollar, from its previous close of 127.05.
In Bombay, the Indian rupee hit a record low of 38.85 to the dollar at the start of trade on fears of new elections, the fifth record low this week.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
South Korea's Needs Grow
 SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- The Finance Minister said today that a $20 billion package of assistance from the International Monetary Fund would not be enough to solve the nation's problems.
But he said the World Bank and the Asia Development Bank were willing to contribute resources of their own. "Forget about the $20 billion figure," said the minister, Lim Chang-yuel.
After weeks of denying it needed help, South Korea sought assistance from the I.M.F. a week ago. Some estimates of South Korea's needs run to $40 billion or more.
 Mr. Lim said Hubert Neiss, head of the I.M.F. delegation to South Korea, had assured him that the World Bank and the A.D.B. were interested in helping to bail out South Korea, the world's 11th-biggest economy.

HEADLINE: For Capital Pundits, Money for Speeches Is Scarce This Year

BYLINE: By JILL ABRAMSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
For the capital's "buckrakers," those media celebrities who rake in lucrative speaking fees on the lecture circuit, 1997 may be remembered as the year that the bucks stopped here.
It seems that Washington's inner workings and the political prognostications of the capital's leading journalists no longer enthrall the trade associations and industry groups that once happily doled out $10,000 -- and sometimes much more -- for an hour of punditry. 
 Margaret Carlson, a Time magazine columnist who found herself in demand on the speaking circuit after she became a panelist on "The Capital Gang" on CNN in 1994, said she could not recall making any paid speeches this year.
For David Gergen, editor at large at U.S. News & World Report, 1997 has been his slowest year for speeches in recent memory. Mr. Gergen's earnings from speeches once prompted President Clinton to joke about them after Mr. Gergen joined his White House staff and reported earning $239,460 for 50 speeches he gave in the first five months of 1993. (He earned $466,625 in speaking income in 1992.)
"When I saw how much more David Gergen had earned before I got him back in the Government, I realized that all of you were doing so much better than we are, you should lighten up on us," Mr. Clinton said at an anniversary party for U.S. News & World Report at the Library of Congress in 1993.
But in the first six months of this year, Mr. Gergen's earnings from speeches were not nearly as big. As probably the only star pundit who discloses his earnings from speechmaking, Mr. Gergen, who was also an adviser in the Reagan White House, earned a more modest -- at least for him -- $83,250.
Mark Shields, Mr. Gergen's former sparring partner on "The NewsHour with Jim Lehrer" on PBS and now paired on the program with Paul Gigot, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal, also reported a fall-off. For example, the lucrative group bookings Mr. Shields used to enjoy with fellow members of "The Capital Gang" disappeared this year.
He attributed the dry spell to the "status quo" nature of the 1996 election, which lacked the excitement and complexities of the more historic contests of 1992 and 1994. Mr. Gergen said the dip was seasonal, since there were no major political races in 1997, though he acknowledged that this year had been more severe. (But he said he expected 1998 to be more brisk, with invitations already beginning to pick up).
Ms. Carlson said there were no new Washington characters to fascinate audiences who once wanted to know all about such White House aides as George Stephanopoulos or the brand of ale consumed by Speaker Newt Gingrich. Now, along with her speaking fees, Ms. Carlson said, "even George is gone." Mr. Stephanopoulos has himself become a pundit for ABC News since leaving the White House earlier this year.
Agents who book the buckrakers confirm the trend.
"It's down for a lot of journalists, especially the ones who were just breaking into it in 1996," said Jay Callahan of Keppler Associates. Mr. Callahan agreed with Mr. Gergen that some drop-off was normal after Presidential election years.
But there is more to it than the ebb and flow of the political calendar, Mr. Callahan said. The same apathy about Washington that is felt by the public has spread to trade associations and companies that used to feel their annual meetings were not complete without a speech by a bona fide Washington insider.
"People are less inclined to want to hear about the inside story of Washington," Mr. Callahan said. "The stories that are big now turn off the public."
He cited the campaign finance scandals that have consumed so much coverage this year.
Don Walker, the president of the Harry Walker Agency in New York, represents many star media pundits, including John McLaughlin of "The McLaughlin Group," a syndicated public affairs program.
"These cycles come and go," Mr. Walker said, "but the really big names float above the cycles."
Mr. Walker said demand was still brisk for most of his clients, though he conceded that he was recently accosted in Washington by journalists who complained about the paucity of speaking opportunities.
Not all Washington journalists are unhappy about this change.
James Fallows, the editor of U.S. News & World Report, assailed the practice of buckraking in his 1996 book, "Breaking the News: How the Media Undermine American Democracy." Mr. Fallows argued in the book that large speaking fees that journalists were accepting from industry groups covered by their news organizations presented an untenable ethical conflict. He wrote that the lecture circuit, which he called "the gravy train," turned journalists into entertainers.
The harsh words of Mr. Fallows and other media critics, who spotlighted the $30,000 speaking fees going to network news stars like Cokie Roberts and Sam Donaldson of ABC News, provoked a debate within journalism circles, although few news organizations have moved to ban paid speeches or require reporters to publicly disclose their fees. The New York Times, for example, forbids members of the news department to speak for compensation to groups whose activities they cover.
Mr. Fallows permits his staff to receive payments for speeches before groups he calls "non-controversial." He also recently published a list in his magazine of speaking fees earned by full-time members of the magazine's staff. His own speechmaking income of $43,500, mostly from academic institutions, was the only sizeable one. (Mr. Gergen's fees and those of another columnist, Gloria Borger, were not included because they are not full-time on the magazine's staff). Mr. Fallows said that he would not do any more paid lecturing while he was the editor of U.S. News & World Report and that the fees he reported were for 1997 engagements booked before he joined the magazine.
Asked whether the marketplace was providing its own solution to buckraking, Mr. Fallows said, "You could call it a market amelioration."
Yet the speaking drought has not affected everyone.
"The superstars will always get theirs," Mr. Callahan said. "I wish I had a nickel for every time we get asked for a Barbara Walters or a Diane Sawyer."
Several columnists for The New York Times, including William Safire and Thomas L. Friedman, maintain active speaking schedules. Mr. Safire said that nonelection years were often slower but that he had not noticed a big change in the number of speaking invitations he received.
And media speakers who can reach beyond politics to other topics, like the economy, are attracting offers. Mr. Callahan said business journalists, like Stuart Varney of CNN, were in demand as business news dominated the headlines.
For Washington pundits, it helps to have a niche. Mr. Shields, who has a moderate-to-liberal point of view, has done paid face-offs with conservative speakers in the last year, recently sparring with Robert Novak, the conservative columnist and CNN pundit, before a gathering of the fast-food industry.
The conservative pundit William Kristol, the editor of The Weekly Standard magazine, said his fees had remained healthy in 1997, in part because his critique of conservatism and the Republican Congress offered a particular perspective.
Political figures themselves are still in demand as paid speakers, in part because they continue to bring a celebrity aura to industry conventions and corporate gatherings. Former Presidents like George Bush, and such luminaries as Gen. Colin L. Powell, still command speaking fees well into six figures. The Keppler Agency has had little trouble booking Bob Dole, known for his wit as an after-dinner speaker, or former Vice President Dan Quayle, who is making speeches to earn money as well as to increase his visibility before an expected run for the Republican Presidential nomination in 2000.
The Washington Speakers Bureau, the best-known booker of speakers in the circuit, recently added a new political star to its stable of clients, former Prime Minister John Major of Britain. Executives of the agency did not return repeated phone calls.
But for most journalists, the well has gone dry.
It used to be that a steady perch as a regular on a television public affairs program was an instant ticket to lecture circuit riches. The phenomenon began to crest in 1992, with a new Administration coming into the White House and an explosion in the number of television public affairs programs. Such programs were relatively inexpensive to produce and supplied a constant flow of political chatter for the burgeoning number of cable and other news outlets, some of them operating 24 hours.
Ms. Carlson said she was amazed by the speaking lucre that easily came her way in 1995 and 1996.
"I thought, 'So this is what it's all about!' " she recalled.
Although there are no industry-wide figures available, buckraking might have reached an apogee in 1996 and then hit a wall.
"It just came to a full stop," Ms. Carlson said.
Because most Washington pundits and media celebrities are extremely well paid to begin with, the lean times have not really been felt.
Some pundits are devising strategies to weather the downturn. Clarence Page, a syndicated columnist for The Chicago Tribune and sometimes member of "The McLaughlin Group," said a seasonal upswing meant that he would soon be making up for the fall-off in group bookings that once flowed from his participation on the program.
"The period between Dr. King's birthday and Black History month are my busy season," Mr. Page said.
He said he and other African-American journalists jokingly referred to their paid speaking engagements in January and February as "black pundit payback time."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Allstate to Aid Community

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
The Allstate Insurance Company has pledged $5.8 million in loans and grants over five years to various housing, youth and community development programs in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.
The company, which is based in Chicago, announced the pledge last week as part of a larger $45 million intitiative to help seven stuggling urban neighborhoods around the country, from Cleveland to Los Angeles. 
 Allstate said it chose Bedford-Stuyvesant because the neighborhood has a lot of privately owned housing. The company insures about one fifth of all owner-occupied housing in Bedford-Stuyvesant, according to Monica Williams, Allstate's urban development manager.
Included in the pledged sum is a $3.5 million loan to a local minority-owned bank for the purpose of making low-interest home-improvement loans. (Allstate has not yet selected a bank.) The company also plans to give $1.25 million to Neighborhood Housing Services of Bedford-Stuyvesant and the 81st Precinct Community Council, local nonprofit groups, to help pay for youth programs, revitalization projects and insurance education. LISA W. FODERARO
