HEADLINE: Don't Rush to Spend City's Revenue Windfall

 BODY:

To the Editor:
New York City's projected additional revenue of $319 million (news article, Nov. 26) creates a tempting opportunity. It is difficult for any politician to resist the call for school construction or repair, increased child welfare services, environmental controls or socially and politically sensitive programs. 
 However, it would be a mistake to return to past practices and use the unanticipated revenue to restore those programs or to bring new pressing concerns into the fray.
A major corner was turned at the start of the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani when serious cuts were made to bring the budget more in line with expectations and the city's fiscal capacity. These cuts were painful, and the pressures brought to bear did more than establish a reputation for those who made the decisions.
Each time we ratchet up expenditures, we mortgage the city's future in ways that outweigh any social benefit. One of the main expenditures over the last 30 years that has restricted well-meaning administrations from meeting long-term as well as short-term initiatives has been the huge interest costs New York City must pay to maintain fiscal security and ratings.
A downgrade in the city's rating can cost the city billions of dollars in interest payments that will strap its future.
 
WILLIAM J. LAWRENCE
New York, Nov. 28, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of economics at the New York Institute of Technology.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); 

STATE: NEW YORK, USA (92%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%);

HEADLINE: Dollar Nears 5-Year High Against the Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the yen yesterday, approaching a five-year high, as concern about Japan's weak economy and financial system made traders reluctant to hold the Japanese currency.
Japan reported that unemployment rose to a post-World War II high in October and industrial production, housing starts and large retail sales fell. The figures show Japan's six-year economic slump is far from over. 
 "They have a long row to hoe for recovery," said Richard Koss, market strategist at MFR Inc., a money management and consulting firm.
In New York trading, the dollar settled at 127.82 yen -- its highest since August 1992 -- up from 127.73 yen in Asian trading on Thursday and 126.97 yen in New York on Wednesday.
Turnover was light yesterday, as many currency trading desks in New York were staffed by skeleton staffs after Thursday's Thanksgiving holiday.
The dollar was little changed at 1.7645 marks, down from 1.7651 marks in European trading on Thursday, but up from 1.7613 marks in New York on Wednesday. The dollar has been held back against the mark because Germany is viewed as less vulnerable than the United States to Asia's economic turmoil. The British pound rose to $1.6886, from $1.6736 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Foxes' Friends in Commons Back Ban on the Hunt

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Parliament voted overwhelmingly today for a proposal that could one day ban the traditional British sport of fox hunting.
After a boisterous five-hour debate, and with supporters of blood sports parading outside in country tweeds and red hunting jackets, the House of Commons backed a measure calling for an end to hunting with hounds. The vote was 411 to 151. 
 Despite the 260-vote margin and a new poll showing nearly three quarters of the public behind a ban, the proposal will not become law because it was not given the required time for parliamentary debate and for committee review by the Government and must therefore await a place in the legislative calendar in the years to come, or possible inclusion as an amendment to Government legislation this year.
The young administration of Prime Minister Tony Blair has been concerned that the high emotion surrounding the issue could prove to be a damaging distraction to the pursuit of its 26-bill legislative program, and it has distanced itself from the debate.
A Government official compared the fox hunting issue in Britain to the gays-in-the-military argument in the United States, a controversy that unexpectedly emerged in the early days of the Clinton Administration's first term and derailed its progress.
Mr. Blair said he was in favor of the ban, but he and nine of his Cabinet members managed to be away today during the vote. The Evening Standard today took notice of Mr. Blair's one-day trip to visit British troops with the headline, "Blair Goes To Bosnia, Out of Hunting Range."
Passions have been running high. Promoting a ban, full page advertisements feature vivid photographs of animals killed by hunting hounds, and opposing ads feature comments from people with known liberal views arguing that hunting is the most humane way of culling foxes and is a central element in traditional British country life.
The debate has brought to the fore tensions that cross party lines. They respond more to attitudes about city living and the countryside, a place of mythical dimensions to many Britons. "Country Truths, Not Urban Myths," read the placard of one protester seated on a bale of hay in Parliament Square.
While the lawmakers debated, a barge floated by outside the Thames-side Houses of Parliament with a large banner proclaiming, "73 Percent Say Ban Hunting."
Inside, the speech-making was punctuated by jeering and growling shouts of "Hear! Hear!" as more than 50 lawmakers made formal statements before colleagues who waved papers above their heads and banged on their desks.
Mike Foster, the Labor Party member who introduced the bill, said it was aimed at protecting foxes from "cruelty and from the unnecessary pain and suffering inflicted in the name of a so-called sport." He said, "prevention of cruelty is the center piece of this particular bill."
Mr. Foster said he knew that "to many people witnessing a hunt is to feel part of English history, and the sight of a full field of horses and hounds is absolutely thrilling."
But to him, he said, it is "wanton cruelty conducted in the name of sport."
Speaking for the opposition, Michael Heseltine, the former Deputy Prime Minister, sought to dispel the notion that fox hunting was just an outing for upper-class people in red jackets and argued that tens of thousands of working-class people depended on the sport for their livelihood. Referring to the Labor Party, he asked, "How is it that a party which spends most of its life arguing about the creation of jobs, in one piece of legislation is going to decimate the jobs throughout some of the more remote and fragile economies in the country?"
Summoning up a fear held by many followers of country sports, he said today's measure was "merely part of an agenda" that, he said, "will move relentlessly through fishing and shooting and angling." At stake, he said, was the "cohesion of the countryside."
Supporters of the ban are hoping that the sheer scale of the vote will cause the Government to overcome its reluctance to put it on its legislative schedule. Opponents argue that the overwhelming numbers pose a challenge to another cherished British principle, the right of a determined minority not to be dictated to by the majority.
"We live in a nation where there is legislation to protect minority groups," Kate Hoey, a Labor member, said in Commons. "I therefore cannot understand why a country that prides itself on its pluralism and tolerance can be so prejudiced against its own rural inhabitants."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Seven hunts from the East Midlands in England, including hundreds of horses and dogs, assembled at Melton Mowbray on Thursday for a joint meet seeking to demonstrate the importance of hunting to the rural economy. Yesterday Parliament endorsed a call to ban fox hunting. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Incomes and Spending Climbed in October

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Personal income and spending recorded healthy gains as the Christmas shopping season approached, a positive sign for retailers.
The Commerce Department said today that personal income grew half a percent in October, the 12th consecutive monthly rise. The increase met analysts' forecasts and was bigger than September's gain, which was revised downward to three-tenths of 1 percent from the four-tenths of 1 percent initially reported. 
 Spending also rose half a percent in October, exceeding expectations. September's increase was revised upward to three-tenths of 1 percent from two-tenths of 1 percent.
Changes in income indicate how much consumers will be able to spend. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's output of goods and services.
Low unemployment and a high level of consumer confidence suggest that spending will be healthy during the holiday shopping season. The unemployment rate in October was 4.7 percent, the lowest since October 1973. And a report issued earlier this week showed that consumer confidence in November had not been hurt by the economic crisis in Asia, the recent turmoil on Wall Street or the recent announcements of big job cuts at a number of large companies.
Moreover, low inflation and discounting give consumers "the incentive to go out there and shop," said John Konarski, vice president of research for the International Council of Shopping Centers in Jersey City.
The Commerce Department also said today that consumers' disposable income, the money left over after taxes, increased half a percent in October after having risen three-tenths of 1 percent during September. The personal savings rate was unchanged at 3.6 percent.
Interest payments to businesses, counted separately from the spending figures over all, grew six-tenths of 1 percent during October after September's increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: Ford Sees India As Export Base

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BOMBAY, India, Nov. 28

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company said today that it planned to make India a base for exports worldwide and would introduce new models despite a sluggish Indian economy that forced it to lower forecasts for the 1998-99 fiscal year.
 Ford is optimistic about Asian prospects over all, despite the wave of economic and financial turmoil in the region, Wayne Booker, vice president of Ford, the No. 2 United States auto maker, said at a news conference here today.
 
 "The currency crisis has not adversely affected us substantially," Mr. Booker said. "Our overall investment plans in Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam and China have not really changed because of the economic crisis."
 Ford's Indian arm, Mahindra Ford India Ltd., is setting up a plant near Madras, capital of the southern state of Tamil Nadu, with an annual capacity of 100,000 vehicles.

HEADLINE: Moody's Again Cuts the Thai Credit Rating

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service cut Thailand's credit rating today to one notch above junk status, in another potential setback for the beleaguered Thai economy. Analysts said the move reflected fears that the country would halt repayments on its $95 billion in foreign debt.
In its third downgrade of Thai credit this year, Moody's, the United States credit-rating agency, cut the rating two notches, to Baa3 from Baa1. Lower credit ratings often make it more expensive for countries to borrow money. A further downgrade is possible, Moody's said. 
 That would put Thailand, deemed a top-flight investment since 1987, in the ranks of just two other Southeast Asian nations whose bonds are rated "speculative," or junk: Vietnam and the Philippines.
Thailand was the first domino to fall in Asia's economic and financial crisis. A fall in exports and overlending to the property sector led to the closing of more than half the country's finance companies this year.
In another struggling Asian economy, the benchmark Korea Composite Stock Price Index fell 21.19 points today, or 4.9 percent, to close at 411.91, the lowest in more than 10 years. The stock index has dropped 37 percent so far this year.
The plunge was led by bank stocks, which began falling sharply after Moody's downgraded South Korea's foreign-currency ceilings for bonds, notes, and bank deposits. Dealers said investors feared that the downgrading would make it more difficult for Korean banks to borrow abroad.

HEADLINE: On Black Friday, a B+ (for Bargains);
At High and Low End, Season Starts With Quest for Good Price

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
It was only 10:30 A.M., but things were already getting ugly.
Dozens of shoppers flocked around a jewelry case at the Kmart on Broadway in lower Manhattan, where signs trumpeted discounts of 70 percent. Someone forgot to take a number. Chaos ensued. People started jostling in line to pay for their 10-karat gold rings, diamond-encrusted crosses and silver watches. Sales clerks did their best to keep order. "Who's next?" "Stop pushing!" "Where's the lady with the pendant?" 
 A few feet away, though, where red and green lingerie was hanging at full price, the only sounds were of light music wafting from the public address system. The racks remained neat and untouched.
And so it went yesterday on the first official day of the holiday season -- known to retailers as Black Friday, because they hope it will push their bottom lines strongly into the black. Shoppers all over the country piled into stores as early as 7 A.M. By the time the stores closed, one thing was clear: despite the robust nature of the economy, most people were hunting for bargains and giving cold shoulders to a lot of things that were not marked down.
"What shoppers are really looking for -- no question about it -- is deals," said Debbie Wendell, a store manager trainee at the Wal-Mart in Portsmouth, N.H.
While retailers tend to monitor activity obsessively over the entire Thanksgiving weekend, the kickoff to the crucial holiday buying period has lessened in importance in recent years as more and more shoppers choose to buy closer to Christmas. Thanksgiving weekend can also be deceiving. Last year, the season started with a bang and ended on a mediocre note. At other times, the weekend has provided a sluggish start to an otherwise good period.
Nonetheless, certain trends tend to emerge over the weekend and resonate through the season, and Black Friday often lifts the curtain on what consumers are gravitating toward. In the toy sector, for example, many shoppers said yesterday that Beanie Babies, Sing and Snore Ernie dolls and electronic virtual pets were hard to come by, and Barbie was her usual coveted self.
Patterns appear to be holding, too. Stores on the high end looked to be doing well yesterday, the obvious exception to the push for bargains, as did the discount and off-price shops.
"The dichotomy of American retailing continues," said Jeffrey Feiner, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers in New York. "The upper-income stores will continue to do well, as will the lower-end stores because they offer value. And the guys in the middle seem to have the problems."
In any event, where the price was right yesterday, there usually was action. A Sears, Roebuck store in Woodbridge, N.J., was packed. In Beaumont, Tex., shoppers lined up at the crack of dawn waiting for a Target store to open. At Bloomingdale's, in Manhattan, shoppers moved to sweater racks festooned with bright red sales signs like deer to a salt lick; two feet away, racks of shirts offered at full price went untouched.
Bargains were visible in the Wal-Mart in Portsmouth, and people were there to take advantage of them. Gesturing toward a rack of marked-down clothing and the cluster of shoppers around it, Ms. Wendell, the manager trainee, said, "See, that's where they're shopping."
Donna Carter, 46, of Epping, N.H., was among those looking for bargains. "I came here first for the deals," Ms. Carter said. "The smart move is to look for the sale prices and at the stores where you know the price is way down."
But many stores were short on traffic yesterday, sales or not. An Ann Taylor store on Madison Avenue was tomblike. Movement in the aisles at the Westside Pavilion mall in Los Angeles was hardly inhibited. At the Siani Bag Company store there, clerks stood around waiting for shoppers to appear. "Usually, the first few days after Thanksgiving aren't so busy here as we would like," said Jasmine Martinez, the store manager. "But once we get into the first and second week of December, things start picking up."
In many cities, people went to the malls in droves but were reluctant to buy more than decorations for the home.
"I spent a great deal of time in the Menlo Park mall," near Edison, N.J., said Kurt Barnard, editor of Barnard's Retail Trend Report, an industry newsletter. "And it seems things are off to a slow start. I find a lot of stores have big signs that have 30 percent off in the window and not a customer in the store. The parking lots are packed 10 deep and very few shopping bags."
Indeed, many shoppers said the day after Thanksgiving was the time to look, but not necessarily to buy.
"I came knowing I do not expect to buy," said Debbie Pielech, 41, a teacher from Winchester, Mass., who went to the Fox Run Mall in Newington, N.H. "With Christmas shopping, there's a process you go through before you get what you want. Or have to, because of the time."
Stores that have been popular all year seemed to be continuing their good run. Old Navy, that mecca of low-priced clothes, saw its outlets packed.
At the Timberland store in Manhattan, there was a lot of Merry-Christmas-to-me going on, in sales of the shoes that have been popular among hearty hikers and trendy teen-agers both. "I am buying boots for myself," said Carmen Brun, a hotel manager. "I do my shopping for everyone else the week before Christmas."
And it seemed that early shoppers got the best bargains.
Wanda Dowden, a home health nurse in Fred, Tex., got up at 4:30 to go to the Parkdale Mall 100 miles east of Houston. By noon she was in good shape. She had secured a 13-inch television set for her husband and a seat pad for his pickup truck, a set of screwdrivers, an electronic fishing game and a measuring tape.
Nan Northcut, who was visiting Manhattan from Nashville with her family, said, "I shop early because I would rather not do it when things are crowded." Her husband, Joseph, heavy with bags from T. J. Maxx and Old Navy, assessed his position: "I'm just the holder."
At the Oak Court Mall in Memphis, Carol Boker, 52, a freelance writer, said that yesterday might have been too late to begin looking for the best buys.
"In the past, there have been better bargains on the day after Thanksgiving," she said. "But this year, the department stores have had more sales earlier and are not waiting until today to start. So I think I found better stuff earlier."
Stores encouraged this sort of early bargain snooping. Garden Ridge, a chain of housewares superstores, opened at noon on Thanksgiving and will stay open until 10 P.M. on Sunday. Sears, Roebuck & Company offered $500 gift certificates to some customers who managed to show up at its stores between 7 and 10 yesterday morning.
Early shopping is a family tradition with Joyce Farrish, 55, a bookkeeper at an elementary school in suburban Memphis. Every year, she and several relatives get together at 6:30 A.M. on Black Friday, put on matching sweatshirts made the day before and hit the malls. This year, they had also gone in for a little hair frosting for the occasion.
"We get there when the doors open at 7," Ms. Farrish said during yesterday's adventure. "We will shop until about 6 or 7 at night. The children stay with their dads all day, and the men are supposed to decorate the houses for Christmas while we are away.
"We try to get the early bird specials," she added. "But this year it seems like the sales aren't as good. There aren't as many bargains."
In fact, many shoppers said they were finding fewer deals than last year. But when they did, business tended to be brisk.
At the Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, for example, the fur salon was empty on one side (nothing on sale), and buzzing on the other (40 percent off). In the Giorgio Armani shop, suits on sale drew the curious while the full-priced clothes were jilted.
With shopping today and tomorrow still to go, retail executives have a lot more nail-biting ahead. Much will be revealed next Thursday, when retailers report same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least one year, for November.
Whatever those numbers show, shoppers like Vera Morris, 72, who lives in Chicago and was visiting New York, will keep retailers on edge until Christmas morning.
"I am like everyone else," said Miss Morris, who sat in the career clothing section of Bloomingdale's, weighted down with relatives' coats. "I start the day after Thanksgiving and finish the day before Christmas. That's how it is."

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Dressing Down Rudy

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Marion Barry thinks Rudolph Giuliani is at "the bottom of the barrel."
The very lax Mayor of Washington is outraged at the very strict Mayor of New York. He is writing a letter to Mr. Giuliani, who hosted "Saturday Night Live" last week, complaining about the New Yorker's appearance in a skit mocking Mr. Barry as a drug-addled hustler. 
"I think the part about me and Giuliani was just despicable, the implication had to do with drugs, the person playing me was rubbing his nose," the D.C. Mayor said last night, calling from his limo phone, on his way to see "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil." He said he would not have minded if he had been spoofed for a governmental action, rather than a personal attack.
"As a fellow mayor, he participated in extreme character assassination," said Mr. Barry, who spent six months in jail in 1990 after getting caught on tape smoking crack cocaine in a Washington hotel. "I've been clean over seven and a half years and I've been an inspiration to a lot of the recovering community. There have been no allegations -- even from my enemies -- since 1990. When they gave Giuliani those lines, he should have just refused to say them. It was the bottom of the barrel."
Mayor Barry also complained that "there were racial overtones. The guy had a beeper, trying to sell a bicycle. They would not have done a white mayor -- a famous white person -- that way. They low-downed it." He has talked to lawyers about a defamation suit against NBC and has demanded a public apology.
The skit, in the segment called "The Joe Pesci Show," featured the comic Jim Breuer playing Pesci as a psychotic talk show host who whacks "disrespecting" guests with a bat.
The Pesci show welcomed Mayor Giuliani, playing himself, and Mayor Barry, played by Tracy Morgan in gray suit and kinte cloth.
When the Barry character said he was the mayor of "this great nation's capital, Atlanta," and dozed off, the Pesci character sneered, "This is a mayor. This is a mayor on drugs." The Barry character tried to raise cash by selling a dozen D.C. garbage trucks -- lowering the price from $50,000 to $5 -- and a bicycle to "my man, Rudy." Then, as Mr. Giuliani looked on, the Pesci character bludgeoned the D.C. mayor, saying "the crime rate just went down."
Cristyne Lategano, Mr. Giuliani's spokeswoman, said that Mr. Barry should "lighten up." You know you're in trouble when Rudy Giuliani wants you to lighten up.
Mayor Barry has not been getting much respect lately. Stripped of almost all his power by the financial control board, he has been complaining about "the rape of democracy." That rape included the loss of his $625,000 skybox at the new MCI sports center, yanked by the control board chairman, Andrew Brimmer.
"That's a little drop of water in the ocean," the Mayor says, dismissing the lost skybox.
Much to the dismay of human rights groups, he even complained about the lack of democracy in Washington at a conference of mayors in Nigeria, which is run by a murderous military government that paid for the Mayor's trip.
"Any country with a military dictatorship, you know there'll be contention about it," he says.
Compared with Mr. Barry's unenlightened democracy, Mr. Giuliani's enlightened despotism does look tempting. While it may be the best of times at one end of the shuttle, it is the worst of times at the other.
Every time I fly up, New York is preening over some new sugarplum, surplus millions, dropping crime, bristling economy.
Every time I come home, Washington is getting bailed out by the Federal Government and roiling with some ludicrous new scandal. The schools are literally falling down. The drinking water is periodically contaminated. Two-thirds of D.C. homicides are unsolved. The latest corruption scandal claimed the police chief.
So you have to ask yourself: Better a guy who plays the fool on "Saturday Night Live" than on "Nightline"? With "Nightline" cameras rolling on him last August, Mayor Barry bizarrely raced down a one-way street, sirens wailing, to keep a tennis date.
Better a mayor in drag than a drag? Better a geeky control freak who is at the scene of every crisis than a cheeky good-time guy who can never be found in a crisis? Better a mayor who cracks down on crime than a mayor whose crime was crack?

HEADLINE: Miami Lends Good Name, And Bad, to Needy Region

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 28

 BODY:
When residents of Dade County voted this month to rename their county Miami-Dade, they acquiesced to arguments by public officials that they should bank on the "magic" of the name Miami to attract more business.
But Miami, the signature city among the 30 in the county, is short on magic right now. 
 While outsiders conjure images of tourism, trade and culture wrapped in international glitz, locals are reeling from high taxes, fiscal mismanagement and government corruption. Where visitors see cosmopolitanism, residents grapple with ethnic voting and intensely personal politics in a mayoral election that has taken a decidedly surreal turn.
This winter, as usual, millions of snowbirds are flocking to Miami the major tourist destination to bask in the sun. But in Miami the hometown, the winter wonderland is under the cloud of a series of scandals that, taken together, are unlike anything this city has seen.
Miami has enjoyed its raucous reputation over the years, but now many civic leaders fear that the city has gone too far, hurting efforts to woo the new business and investment the area needs. Some studies have reported that the number of multinational corporations moving to Miami-Dade is shrinking and that companies are taking jobs to South Florida urban areas deemed more desirable, like Broward County, home to Fort Lauderdale and its suburbs, partly because of concerns about crime and corruption.
The city's latest woes stem from the twists in the recent mayoral election, in which a former Mayor, Xavier L. Suarez, defeated the incumbent, Joe Carollo, in a runoff.
Or so it seems. Criminal investigators are looking into possible absentee ballot fraud in the election that preceded the runoff, including voting by the dead. Mr. Carollo is suing and hopes for a new election. And an investigation by the state's attorney's office into possible violations of the city charter by the new Mayor could result in his removal.
Add to that the landslide re-election of a city commissioner with Teflon qualities who was appointed by Mr. Suarez to preside over the City Commission, despite his pending trial on Federal charges of mortgage fraud and money laundering.
The latest scandals come on the heels of a Federal corruption investigation last year that led to the imprisonment of the city manager and a commissioner; a projected $68 million deficit was subsequently discovered. That financial crisis caused the city's credit rating to sink below investment grade, where it remains, and resulted in the appointment of a state oversight board with the power to approve spending.
This, at a time when the area longs for an image of stability to lure companies here so that jobs keep pace with population.
"We can no longer continue to believe our own press releases," said Jerry Haar, director of the Inter-American Business and Labor Program at the North-South Center at the University of Miami. "We're like a fading beauty queen that keeps telling everyone I was this or I was that."
Alex Penelas, Mayor of Miami-Dade County, is trying to tackle the unemployment rate of 7.1 percent, which is well above the national rate. "All that doesn't help," he said.
Miami, the city, is only part of the bigger area the world best identifies with the brand name: the newly named county, with more than two million residents, half of them Hispanic, and cities like Miami Beach, Coral Gables and Key Biscayne.
Miami has about 360,000 residents and is the fourth poorest major city in the United States. Many immigrants have made it a first stop -- the 1990 census found it had the highest percentage of foreign-born residents of any American city -- and whites and upwardly mobile black and Hispanic Miamians have fled. It is left with a tax base insufficient to meet services, despite high property taxes, a problem worsened by a shrinking of the downtown real estate market.
Miami's political problems are viewed by some business and academic leaders as the growing pains of a city that began to boom only about 30 years ago. Some Miamians note that the same political chicanery and unwavering ethnic loyalties can be found throughout history in neighboring communities like Miami Beach and Hialeah and bigger cities like Chicago and New York.
"It's just as American as apple pie and handguns," said Howard Kleinberg, a South Florida historian. "Miami gets the publicity because we somehow manage to do it in comic opera."
Tom Fiedler, political editor of The Miami Herald, said Miami was typical of new-immigrant cities, where elections are often driven by personality rather than issues, and the tendency for factions is to win at all costs, enjoy the spoils of war and "rationalize unacceptable behavior," like voter fraud. In this case, with two Cuban-Americans facing each other in the mayoral race, the political war was waged almost entirely in Spanish-speaking Miami. In the runoff, Hispanic voters cast two-thirds of the ballots but made up only half of the registered voters.
Other analysts explain Miami's troubles as a symptom of a frontier mentality where anything goes and where counterbalancing forces like civic pride are still developing.
"We have to keep the unfortunate corruption and political shenanigans we've seen in perspective," said Robert G. Beatty, general counsel for the utility Bellsouth Florida and a member of both the state oversight board and a local economic development organization.
"These issues must be viewed in a time context out of which we will evolve," Mr. Beatty said.
But the turmoil at Miami City Hall does not help the packaging of Miami as a growing center of international commerce, as "the crossroads of the Americas" and "forefront of the future," as President Clinton has called it.
While officials like Mr. Penelas try to promote the booming airport and seaport, the diverse work force and an infrastructure "well-suited to the international business person," news reports focus on the criminal investigation of the absentee voting that helped Mr. Suarez, who served as Miami Mayor from 1985 to 1993, win.
Mr. Carollo, after dominating at the polls but trailing in absentee ballots, was short a 50 percent-plus-one majority in the first election by only 155 votes. He asked a judge to throw out the absentee ballots and declare him the winner, a request that awaits a hearing. That has not stopped Mr. Suarez from taking over with a vengeance, dismissing and demanding resignations of administrators and predicting he would restore the city's credit rating and lower city taxes by 18 percent by selling city property and cutting staff.
But Mr. Suarez now faces an inquiry by the state's attorney's office, which is questioning whether he exceeded his authority in removing top administrators like the city manager. If violations to the city charter are found, Mr. Suarez could face criminal sanctions and his removal from office. And he has caused nervousness in some quarters by pledging to work to get rid of the state oversight board, which Governor Lawton Chiles has said he has no plans to dissolve until Miami is on sound financial footing.
After winning the runoff by riding the coattails of Humberto Hernandez, the indicted Cuban-American commissioner whose boyish looks have made him the darling of older Cuban immigrants, Mr. Suarez raised eyebrows by appointing him to preside on the City Commission.
"Hernandez is my best legislator in the sense that he has the same philosophy that I do," Mr. Suarez said in an interview last week.
What is not in question is that Miami can ill afford more bad government, urban affairs experts say, and that it finds itself at a critical juncture to regain some of its past glory. While there has been significant progress on the financial front over the last year -- the city registered a $13 million surplus this year -- a blue-ribbon panel that reviewed the delivery of basic municipal services said in a report released this week that "the city remains in grave administrative distress."
Miami residents, who defeated an effort to abolish the city and merge it with the county in a referendum earlier this year, are watching events unfold with a mixture of cynicism and hope for better times.
"All we can do is wait and see," said Allyson Warren, 45, who works as a paralegal and voted for Mr. Suarez's opponent. "I'd like to see him do a good job for the sake of all of us."
Mr. Suarez, meanwhile, promises to put Miami on the path to becoming "the most exciting global city in the United States."
"Miami is the teen-ager that is emerging and all of a sudden had a big pimple," he said. "This particular pimple is pretty easy to cure. That teen-ager is going to be a beauty queen, a Michael Jordan, a Bill Gates."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The newly named Miami-Dade County includes poorer cities like Opa-Locka, above, where children play in the dusty streets and unemployment is high, and tourist meccas like Miami Beach, below, a magnet for snowbirds. Officials hope that tacking Miami to Dade attracts businesses to the county. (Photographs by Phillipe Diederich for The New York Times)(pg. A10)

HEADLINE: 'Buy Nothings' Discover a Cure for Affluenza

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
News flash: Dozens of people did not shop today.
And not only did those people pointedly refrain from buying anything themselves, but they also dared to challenge publicly the very institution of the Christmastime consumption season on this, the day it traditionally begins. 
 To the tune of "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" they caroled, "Uh oh, we're in the red, dear." They passed out "gift exemption certificates." And they suggested sweetly to shoppers that they spend their time with loved ones or resting instead of herding automatically to the stores.
From Vermont to Seattle, these shopping-mall subversives advocated a new designation for the Friday after Thanksgiving: Buy Nothing Day.
Well, maybe Buy Nothing Day activities did not stretch all the way from Vermont to Seattle in one great anticonsumerist wave. In fact, the Buy Nothing Day action was largely limited to utopian-tinted places like Vermont and Seattle -- and the handfuls of quixotic counterpropagandists were outnumbered nationwide perhaps one million to one by glassy-eyed shoppers.
But there were signs that six years after it was originated by the Media Foundation, a group based in Vancouver, British Columbia, that is bent on fighting consumer culture, Buy Nothing Day was starting to take on a life of its own, and a certain momentum.
"All I know is that there are these spontaneous outbursts of street theater, of mall invasions, of pranks and shenanigans of all kinds," said Kalle Lasn, director of the Media Foundation. "And this is nothing we're pushing heavily; it's just happening spontaneously."
There were scattered reports today of Buy Nothing Day posters, which could be downloaded from the Media Foundation's Web site, (http://www.adbusters.org) cropping up on college campuses around the country, and of related events, from seminars to singalongs, in a dozen spots, Mr. Lasn said. Anti-consumers in more than a dozen other countries put on similar events, he said.
In Vermont, Chapin Spencer, a part-time carpenter, said he had not heard of Buy Nothing Day until he recently saw a public television program about "affluenza," the spiritual and environmental ills brought on by American-style overconsumption.
Then Mr. Spencer and a friend who is a college professor quickly cobbled together a group in the Burlington area that drafted a couple dozen people, Quakers, college students and others, to staff tables outside stores. Braving the slush today, they passed out about 600 "gift of time" certificates that offered the recipient a block of the giver's time instead of a material gift, he said.
At the Church Street Marketplace in downtown Burlington, merchants concerned that the protest would hurt their sales asked the Buy Nothing demonstrators to move from their entrances to a vacant Woolworth's storefront, which they did. But in general, there was little negative reaction, Mr. Spencer said.
"The message is a positive one, not a confrontational one," Mr. Spencer said. "We're not telling people we shouldn't buy what we need, but we need to look at what we're buying and what the effect of that is personally, socially and environmentally."
In downtown Seattle, where "Buy Nothing" activities were held at the Westlake Mall, an ad-hoc singing group calling itself "The Frugalettes" crooned satirical carols with lyrics like "Big business has been telling us what Christmas means today" and "shopping like Santa's zombies." Their version of "God Rest Ye Merry, Gentlemen" began, "Slow down, you frantic shoppers, for there's something we must say."
Some Buy Nothing advocates passed out checklists to help shoppers buy more consciously; they included questions like "Do I need it?", "How many do I already have?" and "Can I do without it?" And others dispensed advice from a booth much like the one Lucy occupied in the comic strip Peanuts, under a sign reading "The affluenza doctor is in."
"We can take control of how we celebrate this holiday," said Vicki Robin, co-author of "Your Money or Your Life," a bible of the "Voluntary Simplicity" movement, which advocates consuming less.
"If you weigh the amount of press for Buy Nothing Day against the wad of ads that came in yesterday's paper, it's no contest," said Ms. Robin, who lives in Seattle. "But ideas planted on Buy Nothing Day can make a difference in people's lives."
It was Ms. Robin who suggested to the Media Foundation that it move Buy Nothing Day from its original date in September to the day after Thanksgiving, which it did last year, Mr. Lasn said. Since then, it has taken off, he said.
Among passers-by who stopped to take in the Buy Nothing tableaux in Burlington and Seattle, virtually none had ever heard of the holiday-in-the-making. While a few grumbled at it, most caught its gist quickly and seemed to agree.
"Ads just try to get you on a guilt trip to come in and start running up your credit card," said Paul Byron Crane, 46, an environmental planner in Seattle.
Opponents complained that Buy Nothing Day was a guilt-inducer as well, and that retailers provide the economy millions of jobs and billions of dollars in income.
"It doesn't make any sense," said Allen Parker, a 39-year-old dishwasher in Burlington. "People should be able to buy whatever they want without being made to feel guilty about it. To do for others, you have to spend money."
Still, many would like to spend less. The Center for a New American Dream, a group in Burlington that advocates "sustainable consumption," recently commissioned a survey that found that most Americans would welcome lower spending and less emphasis on gifts during the holidays.
The survey, conducted last month, found that 15 percent of its 800 respondents were still paying off their 1996 holiday bills.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rev Shannon of Shop Free Zone, which opposes holiday shopping, dressed as Mr. Megabux yesterday in Seattle. Chris Grialin, 8, didn't get it. The group gave the above list to shoppers. (Larry Davis for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Checklist for Shopping"
The Buy Nothing Day campaign in Seattle distributed this checklist to let shoppers evaluate things they were thinking of buying.
 
Do I need it?
 
How many do I already have?
 
How much will I use it?
 
How long will it last?
 
Could I borrow it from a friend or family member?
 
Can I do without it?
 
Am I able to clean, lubricate and/or maintain it myself?

Am I willing to?
 
Will I be able to repair it?
 
Have I researched it to get the best quality for the best price?
 
How will I dispose of it when I'm done using it?
 
Are the resources that went into it renewable or nonrenewable?
 
Is it made of recycled materials, and is it recyclable.
 
Is there anything that I already own that I could substitute for it?

HEADLINE: Buoyed by Japan Gains, Dow Rises 28.35

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks ended higher in a shortened session yesterday, bolstered by three days of gains in Japanese stocks.
Expectations that Japan will use public money to right its financial system eased concern that the failure of banks and securities firms in the world's second-largest economy will cut into United States corporate profit growth, investors said. 
 "The focus of the U.S. equity market is on Japan," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Zurich Kemper Investments, which oversees $80 billion. "The market has snapped back from its overreaction to what potentially could happen to corporate profits."
In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues rose 33.06 points yesterday, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 16,636.26. Japanese stocks rose 3.5 percent on Thursday and 1.1 percent on Wednesday.
Stocks in South Korea, however, continued to slide. The market's main index tumbled more than 5 percent early today, falling below 400 points for the first time since 1987. Stocks recovered to end the half-day Saturday session down 4.05 points, or 1 percent, at 407.86.
Still, it was the seventh consecutive decline as investors dumped shares on fears that more companies might go bankrupt. Yesterday, the index fell 4.9 percent.
Other Asian markets slumped yesterday. Hong Kong's benchmark stock index slipped 56.18 points, or half of 1 percent, to 10,526.92.
Thai stocks fell as investors fretted that about deepening corporate losses after Moody's Investors Service cut Thailand's credit rating, making it harder and more expensive for Thai companies to get foreign loans. Thailand's benchmark index fell 3.96 points, or 1 percent, to 395.47, the lowest level since Jan. 4, 1988.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.35 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,823.13, led by Travelers Group, which yesterday completed its $9 billion acquisition of Salomon. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also gained four-tenths of 1 percent, rising 3.76 points, to 955.40, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 6.05 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,600.55.
The stock market was closed on Thursday for Thanksgiving, and trading yesterday ended at 1 P.M., Eastern time, three hours earlier than usual.
Computer-related stocks, which saw some of the worst losses in the last month, were among yesterday's most active stocks.
Compaq Computer gained 5/8, to 62 7/16, and Dell Computer rose 5/16, to 84 3/16. Lucianne Painter, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, reiterated her "buy" recommendation on Compaq, with a 12-month target of $100.
The networking equipment maker 3Com gained 1, to 36, and the semiconductor equipment maker Applied Materials rose 13/16, to 33.
ACC jumped 2 1/2, to 46 3/4, after the long-distance and local telephone company agreed to be acquired by Teleport Communications Group for $50 a share. Tel-Save Holdings also had bid for ACC. Teleport fell 1 1/2, to 49, and Tel-Save gained 1/8, to 21 5/8.
Telephone shares rallied for a third day. Bell Atlantic was up 15/16, to a new high of 89 1/4, and Ameritech gained 11/16, to 77 1/16. Investors are attracted by the stable earnings of the phone companies and their relatively fat dividends.
Also, more mergers may lie ahead for telephone companies. GTE rose 11/16, to 50 9/16, after USA Today reported the company was in talks to be acquired by British Telecommunications. Both companies failed in recent bids to buy MCI Communications. British Telecom's American depository receipts fell 1/2, to 78.
Travelers rose 1 5/8, to 50 7/8. The purchase of Salomon, the world's biggest bond trader, makes the new Salomon Smith Barney the second-largest securities firm.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-7
 
Asia's Regional Pollution Becomes Global Problem
The smoke from Indonesian forest fires that fouled the air from Thailand to the Philippines is an example of public obliviousness to the health risks of growing pollution and the increasingly cosmopolitan nature of Asia's waste. A1 

Indian Government Resigns
India's fourth Government in 18 months resigned, deepening the political chaos and economic uncertainty that have overtaken the country since a 1996 election produced a fractured Parliament and minimal political leadership. Prime Minister I.K. Gujral resigned after such pandemonium in Parliament that the speaker, fearing violence, adjourned the session indefinitely. A1
 
End to Fox Hunting, Maybe
After a boisterous debate, the British Parliament voted for a proposal that could one day ban the traditional British sport of fox hunting. The proposal passed by a wide margin, but will not become law because it was not given the required time for parliamentary debate and committee review and must await a place in the legislative calendar. A3
 
U.N. to Increase Haiti Force
The United Nations Security Council voted to extend the mission of a multinational police monitoring force in Haiti for a year. The move reaffirms the United Nations' commitment even as it removes the last of its peacekeeping troops. A3
 
Pakistanis Storm Court
In Pakistan, supporters of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif climbed over iron gates and stormed the Supreme Court building, forcing the court to suspend contempt proceedings against the Prime Minister. The melee deepened the country's political crisis, which began earlier this month when Mr. Sharif criticized the high court, a crime in Pakistan. If found guilty of contempt, Mr. Sharif can be removed from office. A6
 
Congo Mission Will Proceed
Despite his threats to withdraw a team of human rights investigators because of Congo's obstruction, the United Nations Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, has decided to go ahead with an inquiry into allegations that Rwandan refugees in Congo were massacred. After meetings between team leaders and Congo Government officials, Mr. Annan wrote President Laurent Kabila informing him that the team would proceed with its mission. (Reuters)
 
Iraq Bars Inspectors
Though the standoff over Iraq's secret arsenal was supposed to have ended, Iraq is still barring United Nations inspectors from its presidential palaces, military bases and intelligence headquarters. The sites, which could hide armaments, tons of poisons and weapons research, may be the last stronghold of President Saddam Hussein's power to terrorize his enemies. In response, the United States has threatened tighter sanctions or stronger measures. A4
 
NATIONAL A8-12
 
Denver Woman Beaten In Latest Skinhead Attack
Five skinheads were charged with beating a 26-year-old black woman who had stopped at a 7-Eleven convenience store to buy nachos on Thanksgiving Day in Denver. The attack is the city's most recent in three weeks of skinhead violence, which has left one policeman dead, one African immigrant dead, one skinhead dead by suicide, and one witness paralyzed by a skinhead's bullet. A9
 
Berrigan's Crusade Endures
Anti-nuclear activist Philip Berrigan is serving time in prison, again, for damaging weapons of war and staining them with his own blood. He is aware that he appears frozen in time, acknowledging in a recent public letter that even sympathizers would say his peace group, Plowshares, "looks ridiculous now . . . ignored by Government and media, the public no longer listening." Yet Mr. Berrigan, a Catholic priest, sees it as a requirement of his faith, he said in the visiting room of the Maine Correctional Center recently, to "confront the institutions of injustice" by fighting nuclear weapons and demanding a shift in spending from defense to social needs. A1
 
A Few Americans Buy Nothing
Buy Nothing Day, a pointed response to the annual consumerism of the Friday after Thanksgiving, has been very slowly spreading since it was launched by the Media Foundation, a group based in Vancouver, British Columbia, six years ago. There were scattered reports this year of Buy Nothing Day posters, which could be downloaded from the Media Foundation's website, cropping up on college campuses around the country, and of related events, from seminars to sing-alongs, in a dozen spots. A8
 
F.B.I. Presents Bomb Evidence
Prosecutors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial showed jurors a small piece of wood they said was important evidence linking the defendant, Terry L. Nichols, to the 1995 blast that killed 168 people. Prosecutors said crystals of the same type as those of the fertilizer used in the bomb and found at Mr. Nichols's house were imbedded in the wood as well. A16
 
Woman Jumps From Car
A woman jumped from her family's moving vehicle and died after attending an acrimonious Thanksgiving dinner in Washington state. The woman was on the way home from her parents' home in Elk with her husband and their two young sons when she apparently jumped. The vehicle was traveling about 55 to 60 miles an hour. (AP)
 
Fur Protests Commence
Anti-fur demonstrators kicked off a month of events aimed at retailers during the holiday buying season by occupying a crane overlooking Macy's and Union Square in San Francisco. The protest was one of many taking place at major department stores across the United States for "Fur Free Friday," held each year on the first official shopping day of the Christmas season. (AP)
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5
 
Giuliani Orders Review Of Macy's Parade Safety
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he had directed top aides and police officials to investigate whether tighter regulations should be applied to the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, after an accident in which a six-story-high balloon knocked down part of a lamppost, injuring four spectators, one of whom remained in critical condition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. B1
 
Times Square Sidewalks Full
City officials and business people say the surging popularity of Times Square as a tourist destination has brought its always busy sidewalks to the brink of gridlock. The city and a local business group are looking for ways to ease the congestion. The main problem is the sheer volume of workers, shoppers, theatergoers and tourists. A study done for the Times Square Business Improvement District counted up to 7,000 pedestrians an hour passing a given point at peak periods. B1
 
A House Where Dylan Wrote
"Big Pink," a salmon-colored three-bedroom ranch house in the Catskills where Bob Dylan and a group of musicians spent seven months in 1967 in the cinder-block basement, recording more than 100 songs, is back on the real estate market, spurred by renewed interest in nearby Woodstock. B1

ARTS & IDEAS B7-18
 
'Magic School Bus' Detour
Ms. Frizzle, the world's wackiest science teacher, will drive her magic bus on a major detour next fall, leaving PBS for the Fox network, joining shows like "Power Rangers," "The X-Men" and "Goosebumps." "The Magic School Bus," the animated science series now in its fourth season on public television, has been sold to Fox, which as a commercial broadcast network needs educational programs to comply with new Federal Communications Commission regulations requiring three hours of such programming every week. BUSINESS DAY D1-16
 
Japanese Crisis Persists
The sense of crisis looming over Japan's vast financial system subsided a bit, although investors, analysts and Government officials remained edgy. Jitters about what might happen forced the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company to issue a statement this afternoon denouncing market rumors that have painted it as the next of Japan's big banks headed for disaster. D1
 
U.S. Stocks Up Slightly
U.S. stocks ended higher in a shortened session, bolstered by three days of gains in Japanese stocks. Expectations that Japan will use public money to right its financial system eased concern that the failure of banks and securities firms in the world's second-largest economy will cut into United States corporate profit growth, investors said. In Tokyo, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues rose 33.06 points to 16,636.26. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.35 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,823.13. D2
 
Accounting Merger Nears
The partners at Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, two of the world's largest accounting firms, have voted overwhelmingly to merge their practices into one. The merger, however, must still be approved by the Department of Justice, which is now looking at whether four or five major accounting firms are enough to audit the books of the nation's public companies. And the firms are still on the prowl for a name for the combined entity. A similar merger has been proposed by two other major accounting firms -- Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick. D2
 
Personal Income Grows
Personal income and spending recorded healthy gains as the Christmas shopping season approached, a positive sign for retailers. The Commerce Department said that personal income grew half a percent in October, the 12th consecutive monthly rise. The increase met analysts' forecasts and was bigger than September's gain. D3

PUB-DATE: November 29, 1997

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1533 words

HEADLINE: Fitting the Lord Into Work's Tight Schedules

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
It is Wednesday, and Louis Tuchman's appointment book is packed, as usual. At 9:45 A.M., he huddles with a fellow lawyer to fine-tune two major real estate deals. At noon, he skips lunch to return phone calls and sign documents. But at 12:30 P.M., Mr. Tuchman steps into his firm's boardroom on the 14th floor of the Chrysler Building for what he calls the most important meeting of all.
The weekly Torah class. 
 Mr. Tuchman is part of a wave of thousands of professionals who, pressed for time and afraid they have neglected their faith, are organizing religion classes in hundreds of companies across the nation. From Bible study lunches at Northrop Grumman to noon Torah classes at Microsoft and Islamic study groups at Intel, these classes are proliferating at what religious scholars say is a breathtaking pace.
"People are rediscovering religion in their own terms," said Max L. Stackhouse, professor of Christian ethics at Princeton Theological Seminary. "This is happening all over the place, and it's increasing like mad."
Indeed, church attendance has been flat for decades, but other signs of an interest in religion are rising: sales of religious books, music and even clothing are increasing, religious retreats are overbooked and thousands are turning out for Promise Keepers, the Christian men's movement. In all, there is a sense that people are not only embracing religion in different ways, but also have become more comfortable in the public expression of their faith. With that, the barriers separating work and religion are crumbling.
"The taboo against using the 'r' word has been broken in corporate America," said Laura Nash, who teaches business ethics, corporate culture and religion at Boston University. "There's more of a confessional tone among employees, the whole Oprah stuff."
So not only is there Koran study for Boeing workers in California during the workday, but Torah and Bible study classes as well. And the same is happening at Lucent Technologies in New Jersey. And while companies seldom sponsor the classes, executives are granting permission and often allow them to be held in company conference rooms.
Levent Akbarut, an engineering manager at a Boeing plant in Long Beach, Calif., attends the weekly Muslim prayer and Koran study sessions on Fridays at noon in a conference room ordinarily used for engineering presentations and meetings with suppliers. He also attends monthly lunch meetings to discuss topics such as what Islam says about modern finances, diet and dress codes.
"Before, I had to spend two and a half hours out of my day to go to the mosque and pray," Mr. Akbarut said. "Now, we schedule it like any other business meeting."
Not all employers are comfortable with the classes. Officials at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., a Government organization, temporarily suspended a Torah class last year, concerned that the separation of church and state was not being observed.
And in August, the White House, concerned about several complaints from Federal employees who said they were harassed at work because of their religious beliefs, issued guidelines protecting religious expression in the Federal workplace. Torah classes already exist on Capitol Hill (organized by Congressional aides) and at the National Institutes of Health (organized by doctors).
No comprehensive surveys have been taken to document the growth in Jewish study classes, which attract anywhere from three to three dozen people. But Rabbi Yehuda Krinsky, a spokesman for the Chabad Lubavitch movement, one of the earliest and most active groups in the field, said Chabad emissaries alone conducted about 60 such classes in New York City and 720 around the country.
Rabbi Krinsky estimated there may be 250 Jewish study classes in New York City and perhaps 1,200 around the country led by rabbis from groups like Chabad Lubavitch, Aish Hatorah, Ohr Somayach International and others. By contrast, he said, in 1985 there were about 90 classes -- in the entire country.
There are also no surveys of the number of Muslim classes, said Salam Al-Marayati, director of the Muslim Public Affairs Council, a nonprofit educational organization in Los Angeles. But Mr. Al-Marayati estimated that the number had grown from "a handful" 10 years ago to "maybe a couple of hundred today."
For Christian classes, Don Kline, vice president of field ministries with Fellowship of Companies for Christ International, estimated that there were up to 10,000 Christian study classes in the workplace around the country, double the number of 10 years ago.
Two years ago, Tom Foth, principal engineer at General Signal Networks, a telecommunications and computer networking company in Shelton, Conn., said he and several of his colleagues felt that eating lunch was not the best way to use their increasingly precious time. So they organized a Bible study class, borrowing a conference room with the consent of the company. And now, a group of five to six engineers -- including a Pentecostalist, an Episcopalian, a Catholic and a Lutheran -- meets twice a week at noon for Bible study class.
At Bell Atlantic, Lionel Harvey, a manager in the circuit management department, organized a Bible study class in his Manhattan office six years ago. At first, a half-dozen people attended; now, up to 34 people show up to study and pray on Mondays and Wednesdays at noon.
"Crisis situations tend to draw people to faith," said Mr. Harvey. "So people look forward to the class with great anticipation because of the business of the day and the vicissitudes of life."
In general, the Jewish classes differ from Christian sessions because they focus less on liturgy and faith and more on ethics, law and philosophy, all based on the Torah, the Talmud and even the writings of Maimonides, some of the most important texts in Judaism. The classes resemble college seminars, open to men and women of all backgrounds, whether they are Orthodox, Conservative, Reform, or even non-Jewish. The classes usually last an hour. Lunch is sometimes catered. Yarmulkes are optional.
"If you simply schedule classes in the evenings, nobody has time, because people want to try to remember what their children look like," said Rabbi Pinchas Kasnett of Ohr Somayach International, a Jewish educational organization. "So we said to people, 'We'll just get you in your office and we'll do it right there.' "
At a recent class at the Tenzer Greenblatt law firm in Manhattan, for example, Rabbi Yaacov Haber of the Orthodox Union, the umbrella organization for about 1,000 Orthodox synagogues, talked about the High Holy Days and the story of King Menasheh in the Talmud. The king, Rabbi Haber said, was a dictator who, upon suffering tremendous pain late in life, asked God for forgiveness, but only if he was healed. And God accepted that conditional repentance, despite the objections of the angels, who called God a "softie," Rabbi Haber said.
"The bad, with repentance, can be transformed into something good," Rabbi Haber explained to an enraptured group of about 12 people. "As a businessman would say, 'Every problem is an opportunity.' "
Afterward, Mr. Tuchman, a tax lawyer at the firm, described the class as "a shot of caffeine."
"I'm grateful that the rabbi can come, because otherwise I wouldn't be able to do this," said Mr. Tuchman, 37, a father of four, adding that on a good day, he returns to his home in Queens by 10 P.M.
Thinking about the convenience of having an office delivery, Russell Roberts said, "It's not much different from Domino's Pizza." Mr. Roberts, director of the Management Center at the Olin School of Business at Washington University in St. Louis, said, "It's just one more way people can economize their time."
On the other side of the country on Wednesday, in Redmond, Wash., a noontime class was held at the Microsoft Corporation. There, Rabbi Mordechai Farkash, director of Chabad Eastside Torah Center in Bellevue, Wash., presided over a class of 10 engineers and programmers in a windowless conference room equipped with a television and a VCR. There, students not only listened to the rabbi, they also used their laptops to search the Internet for more information.
"A lot of the Torah is cross-referenced," said Gershon Parent, a software design engineer who organized the class three years ago. "It just begs to be hyperlinked."
The middle- and upper-middle-class professionals respond to the classes because they fill a spiritual void created by years of secular, career-driven focus, said Rabbi Yitzchak Rosenbaum, program director of the National Jewish Outreach Program.
In fact, some institutions have become quite comfortable with the routine of the religion classes. When Jay Knopf, vice president of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, a Wall Street brokerage firm, invited a visitor to attend a recent afternoon class at the American Stock Exchange with options traders wearing their blue smock-like traders' jackets, he offered these instructions:
"Once you get there, walk inside and check in with the guard; his name is Dave," he said. "Just say, 'I'm here to see the rabbi,' and he'll send you right up."

"Crisis situations tend to draw people to faith," he said. Six years ago, he started with 6 people; as many as 34 now attend. (Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Gain in Japan Stocks Helps Bolster Wall Street
Stocks rose yesterday in the United States, helped by the third straight advance in the battered Japanese stock market, where fear of more financial failures abated somewhat. 

 The Dow Jones industrial average ended 28.35 points higher to close at 7,794.78, narrowing its weekly loss to 57.94 points. Broader market indicators also gained in holiday-shortened trading hours. But other Asian markets slumped. South Korea's market fell 1 percent early today after falling 4.9 percent yesterday. Page D2.
 
The dollar rose against the yen on resilient concern about Japan's weak economy and financial system, despite the eased atmosphere of crisis. D4.
 
Earnings and Spending Show Gains
The Government reported stronger-than-expected increases in October personal income and personal spending, reflecting the economy's vibrancy and the increased affluence of American consumers. The data also provided statistical cheer for American merchants, coinciding with the traditional first day of the holiday selling season. D3.
 
Bonds were little changed on the strong economic numbers. Although the gains in income and spending suggested the possibility of higher inflation, forecasters asserted that the longer-term trend was for an economic slowdown. D2.
 
Vote for Accounting Merger
Partners at Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, two of the world's largest accounting firms, have voted overwhelmingly to merge. The deal still requires the approval of the Justice Department. D2.

Total Takeover for Vendome
Cie. Financiere Richemont, which owns 70 percent of Vendome Luxury Group, will buy the rest for $1.73 billion, strengthening its hold on the group's global luxury brands like Cartier jewelry and Montblanc pens. D14.

Canadian Real Estate Deal
Oxford Properties Group of Toronto will acquire the Canadian real estate company Burcon Properties Ltd. for $428 million (United States). Burcon owns a majority stake in Oxford, which owns and manages commercial real estate. D3.
 
Fox Buys Children's Show
"The Magic School Bus," an animated children's program on science, is leaving public television for the Fox network. Fox needs educational programs to comply with new Federal regulations. B17.
 
India in Ford's Headlights
Ford said it would make India a base for exports worldwide and would introduce new models there despite a slowdown in India's economy. Ford also said it was optimistic about Asia's condition over all. D2.
 
Finding Religion, Again
Fearing they have neglected their faith, thousands of time-starved professionals are organizing religion classes in hundreds of companies. From Bible study lunches at Northrop Grumman to Torah classes at Microsoft to Koran study groups at Intel, such classes are proliferating. A1.
 
Bingo Battles Back
Bingo, the anchor of charity fund-raisers hurt by an onslaught of legalized gambling, is making a comeback with the aid of modern electronics. Thousands of grandmothers across the country have been dragged into the high-tech age via the use of small computers that enable them to increase their chances of winning at bingo. A1.
 
Some Markets Closed
Commodity exchanges in New York were closed yesterday. Commodity exchanges in Chicago, the stock market and Treasury market had abbreviated hours. All United States markets were closed Thursday.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1447 words

HEADLINE: Consumer Counterculture

BYLINE: By Gerald Marzorati; Gerald Marzorati is the articles editor of The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:

The Conquest of Cool
 Business Culture, Counterculture,
 and the Rise of Hip Consumerism.
 By Thomas Frank.
 Illustrated. 287 pp. Chicago:
 The University of Chicago Press. $22.95.
 
Commodify Your
 Dissent
 Salvos From The Baffler.
 Edited by Thomas Frank
 and Matt Weiland.
 287 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. Paper, $15. 
 If Thomas Frank were to happen upon a young man with his hair dyed Manic Panic yellow, wearing a 70's-retro Gucci shirt and plain-front khakis from J. Crew and whiling away an afternoon in Starbucks with a copy of Details and a Sony Sports Discman cranked loud enough for a passerby to detect a song by Toad the Wet Sprocket, he would be seized with despair -- though not the kind that might seize the kid's father. Frank, who is sort of young himself (he's 32), is the editor in chief of a small zine-like journal called The Baffler and also its most influential contributor. The Baffler has published exactly nine issues since its founding in 1988, but that has been enough to establish Frank as perhaps the most provocative young cultural critic of the moment, and certainly the most malcontent.
Frank is a radical leftist, but not of the French Theory strain. Although he has been to graduate school -- "The Conquest of Cool" is a book-length essay derived largely from a dissertation he wrote at the University of Chicago -- both his thinking and his prose hark back to a time when the radical left was something more in America than conferences and seminars attended by Foucault-steeped professors. Frank has thrown off the mandarin jargon; for him it's about wealth and power, haves and have-nots, loud and simple -- it's as if he were channeling Herbert Marcuse and C. Wright Mills and Thorstein Veblen through a boom box. He's just about the last thing you'd expect to come along in these relatively sanguine times (or then, maybe not): a lonely, seething avatar of a new New Left.
What mostly has Frank in a righteous rage isn't wage stagnation or the excessive compensation of corporate executives but the conspicuous consumption of the young and hip, those "self-proclaimed subversives, few of whom have any problem with the terrifying economic-cultural order into which we are blithely stepping on the eve of the millennium," to quote from the introduction that he and his Baffler colleagues wrote to "Commodify Your Dissent," a collection of essays drawn from various issues of the journal. It's Frank's thesis that the business culture and the counterculture today are essentially one and the same thing. Corporations cleverly employ the slogans and imagery of rebellion to market their products, thereby (a) seizing a language that ever connotes "new" and "different," two key words in marketing, and (b) coaxing the young effortlessly into the capitalist order, where they will be so content with the stylishly packaged and annually updated goods signifying nonconformity they'll never so much as consider real dissent -- dissent against what Frank sees as the concentrated economic power of the "Culture Trust," those telecommunications and entertainment giants who, he believes, "fabricate the materials with which the world thinks." (What form this dissent should take, and toward what future, Frank does not spell out. He's a cynic, not a dreamer.)
To have suffered the calculated pseudotransgressions of Madonna or Calvin Klein, to have winced at the Nike commercial in which the Beatles' "Revolution" serves as a jingle, is to sense Frank is on to something. (After reading Frank, in fact, you'll have a hard time using words like "revolution" or "rebel" ever again, at least without quotation marks.) And the acuity with which he dissects the mass media's relentless questing after the next new youth subculture, and the next and the next, makes clammy-handed reading for an editor. (The Baffler reported the news of sorts several years ago that a glossary of "grunge" slang published in this newspaper's Styles of the Times section was a hoax perpetrated by a Seattle record-company employee.)
But what is Frank on to, ultimately? His assumption, largely unexamined, is that society's most banal and ephemeral pop texts -- the cannily outrageous ads, the breathless trend stories, the recycled fashions and derivative rock bands -- hold the Big Meaning. Thus he chooses to ignore the many college radio stations, "indie" record labels and pamphleteering Web zines that thrive at some remove from any "economic-cultural order," or, anyway, from Time Warner and Viacom. (In many respects, pop culture in America has never been so decentralized -- which is one way to understand the slump the mainstream record business is in.)
This polemical reductionism of Frank's reaches its apotheosis in "The Conquest of Cool," wherein he attempts to explain how the counterculture was never much of a counterculture to begin with by looking mainly at several advertising campaigns of the 60's. Nowhere in the book do you hear from hippies, war protesters, feminists, eco-freaks, Stonewall rioters or California consciousness-expanders. What you get are the strategies and reflections of those who Frank feels mattered -- the men, for example, who created the "Pepsi Generation" campaign. "The Pepsi-Cola Company wanted Americans to question the 'establishment' in the most real sense of all, to turn away from the established tastes and preferences," Frank writes. It might also have had something to do with their wanting people to drink less Coke, but that's not what Frank is talking about.
Actually, Frank is unsure of the story he's telling. Sometimes he seems to be arguing that the admen, with an eye to tapping the huge baby-boom market, sought to co-opt the counterculture with a "fake counterculture." Other times, he seems to be saying that it was more a matter of copywriters and art directors at the newer "boutique" firms valuing individual expression and seeing in the youthful nonconformist a "symbolic ally in their own struggles against the mountains of dead-weight procedure and hierarchy." Discussing at some length the "Pepsi Generation" campaign, created by BBDO, Frank first says it anticipated the youth movement; then reports that some of those closely associated with the campaign feel that they were guilty of contributing to "the divisiveness of the late 60's" and are sorry for it; then notes that in the crucial counterculture years of 1967 through 1969 Pepsi pulled its "generation" ads altogether and aimed simply to establish that the drink tasted better than Coke.
It's all too much and, at the same time, nowhere near enough. Who in the counterculture back then gave any thought at all to the cola he drank? What Frank does in his book, as in his essays, is find it convenient to conflate "counterculture" with "youth culture" -- of which the former is only a small segment. And his motive? What he really wants to get across, I think, is that the 60's counterculture was never really a movement of the radical left -- and thus no challenge to consumer capitalism.
About this, of course, he is absolutely right. In "The Conquest of Cool," the only authentic rebel who turns up is Abbie Hoffman, whose "Steal This Book" -- a Yippie handbook for surviving by theft that Hoffman wanted readers to shoplift from stores -- is, to Frank's mind, "profoundly hostile to the consumer order" but no less critical of "the softer, gentler counterculture of 1967." But few counterculture types were into Hoffman, or the New Left in general. Leaders of the New Left were more often than not the sons and daughters of Socialists and Communists, and their main battles -- waged most fiercely in their interminable meetings -- were with their parents and with one another.
The counterculture was made up mostly of trembly romantics, rock-and-roll hedonists and libertarian humanists. They felt that there were manifestations of misery and oppression that had little to do with consumerism, and they left class resentment to those who were into it, the Weathermen and George Wallace (and that paradox, I think, is telling). The hippies and student freaks and the rest didn't pull the plug on consumer capitalism. They merely altered manners and attitudes in nearly every conceivable way -- not only here but in Paris and Mexico City and Berlin and, most lyrically and deliriously, in Prague, where in 1989 the prized imported sneakers and knockoff jeans and black-market rock albums failed, somehow, to dampen the urge among youths to take the lead in toppling that economic-cultural order. Which is complicated, way more complicated than Frank allows, and also pretty cool.
