HEADLINE: Small Business

BYLINE: By David Gonzalez; David Gonzalez writes the About New York column at The New York Times.

 BODY:

Around the Block
 The Business
 of a Neighborhood.
 By Tom Shachtman.
 Illustrated. 325 pp. New York:
 Harcourt Brace & Company. $28. 
 Despite their city's sprawling scale, New Yorkers know that at its best the metropolis is a collection of neighborhoods, each defined by unique rhythms of daily life. Indeed, the recent incursion of hangar-sized megastores with towering racks of everything from clothes to food has some urbanites worrying that national chains can make their neighborhoods look and feel like suburban strip malls.
The arrival of the big stores has been felt most keenly by small business owners, as the gains and losses of the large companies that dominate the headlines reverberate in the neighborhoods. So what lies ahead in New York's economic upswing for the thousands of small businesses that have existed for years in middle-class neighborhoods?
In an attempt to answer that question, Tom Shachtman chronicled the commercial life of a single block in Chelsea, bounded by 17th and 18th Streets between Seventh and Eighth Avenues and abuzz with a wide variety of businesses, from generations-old plumbing supply companies and publishers to trendy and ever-changing restaurants and clothing stores. The result, "Around the Block: The Business of a Neighborhood," provides half an answer, at best.
Shachtman offers up several good examples of how larger trends can filter down. His most dramatic story involves a lumber dealer who despairs that he will lose his business when the bank calls in his loan. It did not matter that he had made his payments on time; the bank needs to raise cash after a souring in the real estate market has left it holding millions in uncollected loans from the city's large developers.
Shachtman makes a fair enough assumption when he says that the personal and the professional are intertwined, whether in the matter of a father fretting over handing the business to his children or of how the neighborhood's new gay population has promoted the growth of stores catering to them. The personal, as it applies to service, also gives some reason to be hopeful that small businesses will survive the onslaught of the chain stores. A neighborhood video store resists the arrival -- across the street, no less -- of the appropriately named Blockbuster Video by tailoring its selection to eclectic neighborhood tastes and having workers who are knowledgeable about more films than the usual commercial fare. But Shachtman often undercuts himself by failing to analyze his material. He talks about putting a human face on capitalism, but too often the face is obscured by a blizzard of detail that reads almost as if it had been directly transferred from his notebooks.
The human element is badly needed to help provide a social context for the economic forces at work in two crucial areas. Shachtman, who is also the author of "Skyscraper Dreams" and other books, gives us a cursory look at the neighborhood's residents, presumably the core market for its retail businesses. And while he focuses at length on the entrepreneurs, he relegates the people who work for them to the background, even though, in his chapter on ways to help neighborhoods, he recommends that employees be given a chance for ownership. The bulk of his prescriptions run along the lines of greater access to government support and encouraging creativity and education. He follows up with a brief chapter on the block's high school -- where, as might be expected, the students are stick figures.
Another issue not adequately addressed is one worrying many entrepreneurs: New York City's unending and wearying list of regulations. Another key concern of neighborhood retailers throughout the city, proposed zoning changes for large stores, became a center of debate after 1993, when Shachtman was reporting his book. But it is a dominant issue today. Keep in mind that the store closest to the block he chronicled where his book can be purchased is probably the Barnes & Noble on the Avenue of the Americas.

LENGTH: 896 words

HEADLINE: Habitats/180 South Fourth Street, Williamsburg;
A Young Artist Finds You Can Go Home Again

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER

 BODY:
JUDITH L. TREZZA lived with her family in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, for 20 years before moving to Manhattan as a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology. She traveled widely in Europe studying art, but she called TriBeCa and Times Square home when she returned.
So when it was suggested several months ago that the 26-year-old artist consider a loft in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, her first reaction was: No Way. 
 "The thought of moving back to Brooklyn just made me crazy," said Ms. Trezza, who also manages a rental photography studio. "It's like going back to an old hometown after having made it in the city."
In addition, she said, many Manhattanites attach a kind of stigma to the other boroughs.
"People are like: 'A 718 area code? You live in Brooklyn?' " said Ms. Trezza -- who with a pierced tongue and yellow hair going toward neon green doesn't seem the type to worry about what others might think of her area code.
But the economic reality of space in Manhattan can be persuasive. Ms. Trezza looked at some 40 spaces in two months. She had budgeted about $2,000 a month, but her situation was complicated because she also needed studio space for her work. Her plan was to find a one-bedroom for about $1,200 or $1,300 and then rent studio space separately.
"Everything was either too expensive, too small or rundown," said Ms. Trezza. "If it was in my price range it was really rundown."
WITH loft space in TriBeCa and SoHo really out of her budget, a real estate agent suggested she consider a two-bedroom loft apartment in Brooklyn at the base of the Williamsburg Bridge. Ms. Trezza, whose two most important requirements were light and space, thought she had nothing to lose by looking at the building at 180 South Fourth Street (the main entrance is actually on South Fifth Street).
"Once I saw the space, that was it," she said. "It was flooded with light."
At $1,900 a month, it fit her pocketbook and her needs perfectly. Not only was there an extra bedroom, which she could use as an office and for visitors -- of which she has many as a result of her travels -- but the large open living area fit in nicely with her love of entertaining. Her favorite feature, however, was a closet-size room with a window, which she uses for her gilding projects. She has a degree in art history with a minor in archeology, and is working toward a degree in restoration at F.I.T.
"I've only been here a month, and my favorite place is my gilding studio," she said. "No one's allowed in there but me. I read and I listen to music and I think. It's like my little escape."
IT'S also imperative to the type of work she does. In gilding, the materials used to make the gold leaf adhere to the surface must stay at a constant warm temperature to be applied properly. A small room makes it easy to maintain that temperature.
Ms. Trezza has found her neighborhood a rich source of the old pieces of furniture and decorative items she needs to practice her art. "I need to get old pieces I can restore without them being very, very valuable," she said, noting that there were a variety of junk stores in the neighborhood with prices well below what she would find in Manhattan.
Still, Manhattan is just one subway stop away. And she frequently rides her bike to work at Studio With a View, which is on West 31st Street near the Hudson River. "It's a 30-minute ride door-to-door," she said.
While she still does much of her grocery shopping in Manhattan, she said, a number of cafes and galleries are beginning to appear in her neighborhood as it becomes more popular. "There's a lot of artists living down here," she said. "They couldn't afford Manhattan rents anymore, much like what's been happening in Dumbo," she said, referring to another artists' enclave in Brooklyn: Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass.
Artists started moving to Williamsburg more than a decade ago. Jeffrey Cohen, a real estate agent with Citi Habitats who worked with Ms. Trezza, said the trend had been picking up recently as the market heated up in Manhattan.
Ms. Trezza said that the tenants in her building include a graphic artist, photographers, models and a tattoo artist. The building, which originally had 35 units, has been converted into 12 apartments, two on each floor of the six-story building.
MS. TREZZA said some of her friends still refuse to cross the river for her dinner parties and Ping-Pong games. But her 1,600 square feet has not gone unnoticed by other artist friends. One has set up a light table, and another stores photography equipment there -- but in such a large space it is barely noticeable.
From the large windows surrounding her living room, Ms. Trezza looked out at the base of the Williamsburg Bridge over the dome of an old bank, which is being restored for a church. From another angle, children could be seen skateboarding in a park across the street.
"At 6 o'clock in the morning as the sun rises this place is flooded with gorgeous red and orange light," she said, "and it sets through my studio window."
Her die-hard Manhattan attitude has all but vanished.
"You can go to Manhattan and work and you can actually come home and have a life rather than working all the time to pay the rent," she said. "Now I'm a Brooklyn spokesperson. It's nice because it's helping me to get back to my Brooklyn roots."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Judith Trezza's living room, top, is framed by windows. She can see the sun set through window of her studio, below. Bedroom of the $1,900-a-month Williamsburg rental. (Photographs by Linda Rosier for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1997: MARIJUANA;
Go North, Young Man

 BODY:
Anne Drennan, a Police Department spokeswoman in Vancouver, B.C., frankly says that "Vancouver is known for having the highest-grade marijuana in the world," adding that busting potheads "is not a priority with us." This climate has given rise to places like Hemp B.C., a Vancouver head shop that features an attached eatery and smokery called the Cannabis Cafe. The cafe is one of North America's only pot bars that allows any adult -- not just "medicinal" users -- to smoke openly, and the place isn't shy about this technically illegal arrangement. In fact, in full-page newspaper ads that ran recently, it invited delegates in town for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation trade forum to drop by for a freebie. Here's what awaited the curious.
 What You See "Welcome to Hemp B.C.," reads a handwritten greeting, adding: "... we request that you be 18 or older to smoke pot. Thank you." The head shop and cafe sit in the historic Gastown neighborhood, and feature bongs of many colors and a painting of the Virgin Mary clutching cannabis leaves. Marijuana is not for sale in the cafe, though giveaways are common. Each table is set with a domed vaporizer, which cooks rather than burns the pot for a vapory hit of THC mist. 
 The Cause Marc Emery, Hemp B.C.'s owner, opened the cafe in July, as an "activist statement" to support his pro-pot political agenda. Though Emery has not gotten in any trouble for the cafe itself, he's facing marijuana-trafficking charges in a case in which the police bought and then cultivated Hemp B.C. seeds to prove that they grew into mature, smokable pot. "I'm not looking forward to the trial because the lab results are disappointing in terms of THC content," Emery says, meaning that the THC level wasn't high enough. "It would be embarrassing in court -- though, it could be due to their poor cultivation techniques."
 What You Get Along with tasteless vegetarian food, a chance to light up. Emery says most customers are American tourists. On a recent Saturday night a scruffy pair of 20-year-old road-trippers from Maryland, who declined to give their names, said they specifically came to Canada for the cafe. Reaction? They liked it, especially the vaporizer. According to the printed instructions, the units "change the molecular formation of the THC within plant matter ...to a steam or 'vapor.' " Reading this to the guys with a flight attendant's efficiency, a waitress gives them final instructions before liftoff: "Remember, this is not smoke -- so there will be no THC in your exhale, because the vapor will be absorbed by the lung lining. Neat, eh?"

LENGTH: 711 words

HEADLINE: The Glow, the Glitter of Fine Antiques

BYLINE: By BESS LIEBENSON 

 BODY:
THE Antiquarius show in Greenwich is known as an esthetically glowing antiques show, one in a class by itself that frequently serves as a curtain-raising event for the Winter Antiques Show in Manhattan.
Antiquarius also serves as a barometer of what's fashionable and sometimes as a forecaster of the economic climate. Though it appears no dealers wanted to tackle the economic question, new trends are an issue of another kind. 
 "New trends always show up at the Greenwich show," said N. Pendergast Jones, manager of the 40th Christmas antiques show, which is open Friday through next Sunday at the Greenwich Civic Center in Old Greenwich.
"This is a happy convergence of a very up-to-date audience that appreciates great material," Ms. Jones says, and one that "is always looking for the superb piece as well as an interesting bibelot."
She also says there is great interest in Continental furniture "that is not palace furniture: like Swedish painted furniture and French country pieces." Guy Regal Ltd. of New York, a new dealer invited to fill that niche, is showing a set of 12 painted and carved chairs from France signed "Lelarge" and a Swedish gilded and painted eight-arm chandelier circa 1780. Mr. Regal described the pieces as "crisp and clean in form with a lot of style."
"The garden is always hot," Ms. Jones added. Barbara Israel of Katonah, N.Y., an antiques dealer specializing in garden ornaments, said she has "witnessed an explosion of interest in decorations for the garden." Her own interest began as a child playing in a Japanese garden abounding with Foo dogs, lanterns and carved stones, which she recalled as "a romantic ruin." Today some of her garden items have found their way into Winterthur and Smithsonian collections. At Antiquarius she will create a garden with a two-tiered fountain dominated by a terra cotta figure.
In an atmosphere of twinkling Alberta spruce trees, other booths will beckon -- some arranged as room settings with American and English furniture, Oriental rugs and accessories ranging from needlework to American Indian baskets, from Canton and Staffordshire porcelain to paintings, prints, jewelry, boxes and historical documents.
Fletcher Copenhaver Fine Art of Fredericksburg, Va., specializing in 19th- and early 20th-century American and European art, will feature the English artist Greta Delleany, whose delicate pastoral landscapes reflect the influence of Whistler and Degas.
Anthony Scornavacco's H & B Gallery in Minneapolis will highlight a pair of 18th-century French candlesticks, a sterling epergne and 17th-century tapestry panels.
One of the most crowded jewel box settings is always Sallea Antiques from New Canaan. This year's cachet will include an English tortoise shell miniature spoon box with six silver spoons and an English double tortoise shell tea caddie with cut crystal pieces.
The Spare Room, of Baltimore, Md., will display a collection of silver broaches inscribed with names or messages. And Schuyler Field and Elizabeth Ruprecht of New Canaan will showcase a striking sure-to-be conversation piece, a late 19th-century mahogany French cabinet with removable dark green leather drawers for papers or artwork.
At Antiquarius's preview party, Thursday from 6 to 9 P.M., guests will enter a holiday decorated area to have a first look at the show's pieces and to sample food at buffet. A dessert display will be crowned with a miniature spun sugar Bush-Holley House, a bow to the Historical Society of the town of Greenwich, the show's beneficiary. Claire Vanderbilt, who was chairwoman of the first fund-raising antiques show in 1958, which helped to restore and furnish the newly acquired Bush-Holley House, will also be honored.
On Friday at 9:30 A.M. a Continental breakfast-slide lecture on "Fancy Finishes: American Painted and Gilded Furniture, 1790-1860" will be offered at the Garden Education Center, Bible Street, Cos Cob. On Saturday at 10 A.M. a Continental breakfast and walking tour of the antiques show will begin at the Greenwich Civic Center, Harding Road, Old Greenwich. Show hours Friday and Saturday are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $10. The number to call for further information is (203) 869-4966.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Dena Boronkay and Michael Rashes

 BODY:
Dena Ellen Boronkay, the daughter of Serena and George A. Boronkay of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening to Michael Scott Rashes, the son of Sylvia and Bernard D. Rashes of Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Stephen A. Klein performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead in New Rochelle, N.Y.
Mrs. Rashes, 23, is a loan officer with the New England Corporate Banking Group of Bank Boston in Boston. She graduated from Wellesley College. Her father is a managing director in asset-based lending at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. Her mother is a teacher's aide at Scarsdale High School. 
 Mr. Rashes, 25, is the chief economist at Farallon Fixed Income Associates in Cambridge, Mass., and is also a doctoral candidate in economics at Harvard University, from which he received a master's degree in economics. He graduated from Stanford University with two bachelor's degrees. His mother is the controller of Center Laboratories Inc., a pharmaceuticals manufacturer in Port Washington, N.Y. His father is an audit manager at New York City Transit.

HEADLINE: Alternative to State Plan for Lilco

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
FOR months the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, Richard M. Kessel, and other backers of Gov. George E. Pataki's $7.3 billion plan for a partial state takeover of Lilco have sounded the same refrain.
What are the alternatives, they asked, to a plan to cut electric rates an average of 17 percent? Where else could Lilco customers turn for relief from the highest rates in the continental United States? 
 As the plan slogs through the middle innings of a game whose outcome is in doubt, an expert on utility finances, Charles M. Studness of Manhasset, is offering an alternative that is changing the tenor of the long debate over energy on Long Island.
Relying on voluntary actions by the Long Island Lighting Company, Mr. Studness's proposal envisions a way out from the $4.5 billion debt for the long-closed Shoreham nuclear power plant, a major past, present and future cause of high rates.
Mr. Pataki's plan calls for the state to sell $7.3 billion in tax-exempt bonds to buy the Lilco transmission and distribution systems and its 18.5 percent share in an upstate nuclear plant, Nine Mile Point 2 in Scriba, and, most important, to buy and refinance the Shoreham debt.
Mr. Studness's plan, which its author described last week as a plan B that Lilco would consider only if Mr. Pataki's plan foundered, would give Lilco eight years to recover what it can of the Shoreham debt through operating efficiencies.
In that period, with a trend toward a competitive electric industry, Lilco would drop its rates 3.5 percent a year, and the utility would have incentives to improve transmission and delivery in preparation for competition.
When competition arrives the cost of the Shoreham debt would not be added to transmission fees.
Lilco, opposing the plan, called it unrealistic and unworkable.
Aside from variations reflecting the Shoreham problem, Mr. Studness said, his plan was "just the sort of thing that is being done everywhere else" to shepherd the old highly regulated monopolistic utility industry into an era of free competition. He said Pennsylvania, Illinois and California had used similar approaches.
"The important thing here is that rates are capped but there are no caps on Lilco earnings," Mr. Studness said. "If Lilco can reduce expenses it can produce cash to pay off Shoreham."
His plan, which has an extensive array of other elements, has been embraced by critics who regard Mr. Pataki's plan as a turkey stuffed for Wall Street, because of fees and commissions associated with what would be the largest bond sale of its kind, and rich in trimmings for Lilco.
"The Studness plan is an approach being employed increasing all over the country," the chairman of Taxpayers Against Lilco Bailout, Maurice Barbash, said. "It allows a utility to recover most or all of its stranded assets. And as soon as a utility is deregulated and has to go out there and compete you will be amazed at how efficient it becomes."
Critics of Mr. Pataki's plan say it would lock Long Islanders into more than 30 years of paying off the Shoreham debt while blocking competition. The critics add that innovations that would let businesses and homeowners generate their own electricity using microturbines or fuel cells would be on the market in a few years, allowing customers to disconnect from the main power grid.
If Mr. Pataki's proposal is approved, the critics said, the loss of customers would eventually mean insufficient revenues to pay off the bonds, leading to a spiral ending in a state bailout that would be charged, inevitably, to Long Island residents and businesses in higher rates and new taxes.
Mr. Kessel said such a scenario was alarmist. "The only death spiral on Long Island is if we don't get these rates down now," he said.
New technologies, Mr. Kessel added, "are not going to solve rate problems on Long Island."
"It's ridiculous to think every Long Islander is going to generate their own electricity," he added.
Critics of the state plan disagreed about new technologies. "They are real, they are credible, and they are going to revolutionize the way people get electricity in this country," said Mr. Barbash.
Mr. Kessel also lambasted Mr. Studness's plan as "Soviet-style junk economics," warning that it could bankrupt Lilco and force thousands of layoffs. Lilco has more than 5,000 employees.
Lilco unions, equating efficiencies with layoffs, have also opposed the plan. Local 1049 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers said the plan would "create a crisis for working Long Islanders" while threatening service.
Lilco has generally avoided comment while Mr. Pataki's plan and its projected merger with Brooklyn Union Gas are pending, but it spoke out on Mr. Studness's proposal. Lilco condemned as impossible any plan for reducing rates by one-quarter over eight years while simultaneously paying off the $4.5 billion Shoreham debt with nearly $600 million a year in operating expenses.
"This is not a realistic plan," a spokeswoman, Stefanie Gossin, said. "We do not view it as a viable alternative."
Mr. Studness said that that stand was to be expected, adding: "If they can have a takeover that gives them their money up front, never in the world would they want to do this. But suppose the takeover is off the table, what is the next best alternative? In that case I can see Lilco becoming very much interested."
Such a major change would require state legislation and cooperation from the State Public Service Commission. The P.S.C. has held Lilco apart from initiatives to introduce competition pending the outcome of Mr. Pataki's plan.
Mr. Kessel said last week that the Long Island Power Authority and Lilco were awaiting a so-called private letter from the Internal Revenue Service, advising whether Lilco would be exempt from $2 billion in capital-gains taxes. The authority also wants confirmation of its exemption.
The exemptions, particularly for capital gains, are critical to the state plan, because the plan includes them in its projections.
Opponents said it was improper for the I.R.S. to issue a private letter in a case involving a public agency. One group, the Citizens Advisory Panel, has petitioned the I.R.S. to hold hearings. The panel has also sued the state's Public Authorities Control Board because it approved Mr. Pataki's plan in July without a required study of its environmental effects.
"In their hurry to get this deal approved they forgot to play by their own rules," the executive director of the group, Gordian Raacke, said.
Mr. Kessel said that despite such challenges "the deal is moving forward with the strong backing of Governor Pataki and most of Long Island, and I am hopeful that we will get rates down by the middle of next year."
Mr. Kessel said the authority and Lilco were nearing an agreement over the wholesale price that Lilco wants to charge the authority.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 37; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: TELEVISION VIEW;
Showing a Harrowing World But Not How It Got That Way

BYLINE: By Samuel G. Freedman; Samuel G. Freedman is the author most recently of "The Inheritance: How Three Families And America Moved From Roosevelt to Reagan And Beyond."

 BODY:
MIDWAY THROUGH Frederick Wiseman's harrowing new documentary, "Public Housing," a handsome young bureaucrat arrives at Chicago's Ida P. Wells projects with the promise of $300 million in government contracts. All the residents have to do, he explains to a group of them, is create a business of their own. An elevator-repair company, he suggests, or an energy-conservation firm. Then, under a new program, the enterprise could qualify for a share of that $300 million without even going through the usual competitive bidding.
Offered such a bonanza, not one listener responds. For the residents of Ida Wells, as the documentary makes clear, the economy largely consists of barter, scavenging, welfare and crime. None show a flicker of recognition at the mention of competitive bidding, a staple of financial life in the public sector. Their polite silence is the sound of isolation. 
 This single scene distills what is most powerful and also most troubling in "Public Housing," which will be broadcast nationally on PBS at 9 P.M. tomorrow. In more than three hours of footage, Mr. Wiseman captures both the bleak monotony and unvanquished humanity of life in the projects; he brings an unflinching eye and a capacious heart to the mission.
Yet he does so without providing any sort of historical context. Only fleetingly in a much later scene, for instance, does a viewer learn that the bureaucrat with the millions works for the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. Never does the film explain that H.U.D. seized control of public housing in Chicago from the city's Housing Authority because of its abysmal management record. It was at Ida Wells, for instance, that in 1994 two boys aged 10 and 11 dropped a 5-year-old out a 14th-floor window to his death.
In a broader sense, the film's exclusive focus on the present omits the overarching tragedy of public housing in America, its journey from being one of New Deal liberalism's greatest triumphs to one of its greatest failures, from being a stepladder for the working poor to a sinkhole for the welfare poor. How odd it is that PBS provides the press with program notes detailing this sad history while leaving the rank-and-file viewer ignorant.
Admittedly, anyone familiar with Mr. Wiseman's work will not expect a larger backdrop to the richly detailed portrait of Ida Wells. In an acclaimed career of 30 films spanning as many years, Mr. Wiseman has hewed to a specific aesthetic. He immerses himself in social institutions, ranging from a mental hospital in "Titicut Follies" (1967) to a dance troupe in "Ballet" (1995), and chronicles them without supertitles, narration or background music.
"Public Housing" belongs to a particular strain within the Wiseman oeuvre -- the documentaries like "Hospital" (1969), "Juvenile Court" (1973) and "Welfare" (1975) that bear witness to what Michael Harrington famously dubbed "the other America." The image that best defines both Ida Wells and "Public Housing" is a brief, hazy shot of the Sears Tower in Chicago's Loop, just five miles away and yet impossibly distant.
Sealed off by forces of class and race alike, Ida Wells plods through its days with a listlessness that the film's resolute pace utterly captures. A homeless man, his shopping cart loaded like a caravan camel, shambles past a vacant lot. A young mother smacks her daughter across the face. Two police officers comb through rubble and weeds for a streetcorner dealer's stash. The sirens and gunshots that periodically sound barely disturb the routine. Instead, the most unsettling noises in "Public Housing" are the children's songs jingled out by an ice-cream truck, so alien in a place that literally and metaphorically murders its young.
Even when Mr. Wiseman wants to demonstrate the potential for change, his journalistic integrity refuses to indulge easy hope. The film shows workshops for Ida Wells residents on "manhood training," birth control, employment and family preservation, among other topics. These scenes reveal a chasm dividing African-Americans, as it is invariably a middle-class black who addresses an underclass black audience and often grows exasperated in the process.
"Can you really afford to say, 'Yeah, I want to work, but not for $5.50?' " a job-training specialist says to one recalcitrant woman. A drug counselor, evaluating a crack addict for admission to a treatment program, breaks from his standard intake questions to cry, "You belong to a group of people, the only group in the whole industrialized world, whose life expectancy has fallen in the last 10 years."
The life signs in "Public Housing" appear in less therapeutic moments. When an exterminator gives an elderly resident tips for snaring roaches, or when a police officer handles the eviction of a disabled man with gentleness and respect, "Public Housing" brims with the generous spirit of an August Wilson play.
EVEN AT ITS MOST affecting, though, the film inadvertently betrays its weakness. One set-piece features the grandmothers of a sewing circle -- surely a remnant of the decent place Ida Wells once was. In another scene, the president of the Tenants Council presses the project's management to find an apartment for a teen-age mother and her infant. "What good is it going do to screen people?" the tenant leader asks, adding later, "Some rules are made to bend."
Any reading of the history of public housing suggests that its demise stems partly from the reluctance of the local authorities -- under incessant legal assault during the so-called "rights revolution" of the 1960's -- to continue their practice of evaluating applicants. But that fundamental piece of history is nowhere to be seen or heard in "Public Housing." Nor is the history, especially in Chicago, of segregating public housing in black slums. Nor is the effect of Federal, state and local budget cuts on public housing, which have made preventive maintenance nonexistent in many projects.
Without even hinting at any of that, Mr. Wiseman has still produced an indelible picture of underclass existence. But he has also raised a question he probably never intended to: Doesn't history matter?

HEADLINE: FILM;
An Author Adapts To Being Adapted

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
RUSSELL BANKS HAS HAD A long and tangled history with the movie industry. In the past, his wintry, critically admired novels have been snapped up by Hollywood, attracting the enthusiasm of A-list directors from Jonathan Demme to Wolfgang Peterson, but have stopped short of being turned into films.
This year has been different. "The Sweet Hereafter," adapted by the Canadian director Atom Egoyan from Mr. Banks's 1991 novel about the aftermath of a disastrous school bus accident, was a favorite on the film festival circuit and has just opened to glowing reviews. A second film, "Affliction," adapted by Paul Schrader from Mr. Banks's 1989 novel about a small-town cop whose life spins out of control, is completed, though it is unclear when it will be released. 
 Now that these films are finished, Mr. Banks is not about to join the ranks of writers like William Faulkner, J. D. Salinger and Nelson Algren who felt betrayed when their work was translated onto the screen. Nor was he shut out of the filmmaking process, like Jane Smiley, who was disappointed when the recent filmed version of her Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, "A Thousand Acres," omitted a scene that was crucial to "transforming the story from a melodrama to a tragedy," as she put it.
Mr. Banks is not complaining. At the Telluride Film Festival, where the two movies based on his novels made their North American debuts last summer, he was a visible figure, beaming like a proud uncle, signing books and practically handing out cigars.
The success of the movie version of "The Sweet Hereafter" has made Mr. Banks, 57, a hot property. No fewer than three of his other novels are being developed as movies, including the 1985 "Continental Drift," until recently his best-known book, with Willem Dafoe in the leading role. He is writing the screenplay, his first. He now wears his gray hair in a fashionable buzz cut. (His 13th novel, "Cloudsplitter," will be published in March.)
It is not surprising, Mr. Banks said in a recent interview, that the current adaptations were low-budget productions by auteur director-screenwriters who work outside the studio system. "My work is generally considered fairly dark and pessimistic and bleak, and Hollywood doesn't embrace that attitude very enthusiastically," he said. Indeed, despite a cast that includes Nick Nolte, James Coburn and Mr. Dafoe, "Affliction" does not yet have an American distributor.
OF THE TWO BOOKS, "The Sweet Hereafter" posed the more daunting challenge for a screenwriter. Set in an economically depressed town in upstate New York very much like Keene, N.Y., where Mr. Banks has lived for the last 10 years, the novel consists of a series of monologues delivered by four principal characters, including a lawyer who tries to goad the townspeople into bringing a lawsuit. That structure, Mr. Banks said, forced Mr. Egoyan to take numerous liberties.
"Atom had to take the book apart and put the story back together in an utterly different way," said Mr. Banks, who has a cameo role in the movie as a doctor. "I like to think he structured it horizontally and layered it, whereas I had it structured in four separate vertical narratives."
Mr. Schrader's film, by contrast, is such a faithful translation of the novel that it is almost an homage, although inevitably some scenes and characters from the 350-page book are omitted. But if the car on the page is a blue Plymouth, so is the car on the screen. "If you really respect the voice of the author," said the 51-year-old Mr. Schrader, whose adaptation of an Elmore Leonard novel, "Touch," was released earlier this year, "then you have to capture that voice, not just the dialogue, but the detail, the theme and the moral voice as well."
"Affliction," a searing tale about the legacy of male violence, is drawn from events in Mr. Banks's own family history, and the movie, like the novel, takes place in a New Hampshire town resembling the community where the author's father was brought up. After his wife leaves him and his young daughter loses respect for him, the cop, played by Mr. Nolte, becomes obsessed with the possibility that a murder is being covered up and passed off as a hunting accident. The novel caught Mr. Schrader's eye at a Manhattan bookstore, and gripped him with the first paragraph, he said. He and the producer, Linda Reisman, struggled for seven years to raise the $6 million for the film.
"Both films are utterly loyal to the book in the same essential ways," Mr. Banks said. "It wouldn't matter to me how Paul or Atom structured the story as long as they structured it in an effective cinematic way. But what they both managed to do was go to the meaning of the stories and maintain that." As it happens, both films were shot in Canada by the cinematographer Paul Sarossy.
When Mr. Egoyan first sought the rights to "The Sweet Hereafter," they were held by 20th Century Fox. But according to Mr. Banks the studio abandoned the picture after the box-office failure of the 1992 film "Lorenzo's Oil," starring Susan Sarandon and Nick Nolte. "They said: 'We don't want to do another depressing story about a child who's sick,' " the author recalled. Mr. Egoyan said he learned that the rights were again available after the writer Margaret Atwood introduced him to Mr. Banks.
AS A NOVELIST WHO SEEKS meaning in the concrete details of ordinary, and often overlooked, lives, Mr. Banks had trouble seeing what he had in common with a filmmaker 20 years his junior who "seemed to go straight for the abstract without the intervening layer of detail." But after watching Mr. Egoyan's 1994 film, "Exotica," he began to realize that they shared similar obsessions, including a fascination with "the relationship between the individual, the family and the community," he said.
Along the way, Mr. Egoyan, who had never adapted a book before, tried out every proposed change on Mr. Banks -- from opening the story with a scene between the lawyer, portrayed by Ian Holm, and his troubled daughter (played by Caerthan Banks, the novelist's daughter) to adding the Robert Browning poem "The Pied Piper of Hamelin" as a recurring motif.
"There was no contractual need to get his approval," Mr. Egoyan said. "I was so taken by the book that I felt I needed his blessing. I've been quite surprised at how satisfying it is to serve a book that one admires." He and Mr. Banks spent a day going over the screenplay together line by line.
Mr. Egoyan traveled to Keene to videotape the courthouse, the gas station, the quarry, and other locations that the novelist had in mind when he was writing "The Sweet Hereafter" which was filmed last year in British Columbia."I wanted to enter into his experience of the story, to taste this process in as complete a way as possible," Mr. Egoyan said. Mr. Banks said he found it "a little unsettling" to see how accurately Mr. Egoyan had captured the places he had visualized.
Having grown up in Michigan, in what he describes as "small-town winter America," Mr. Schrader saw no need to make a similar tour for "Affliction." But he gave Mr. Banks a chance to approve all the sets and locations before the filming began. At a party in Montreal after filming was completed, Mr. Schrader recalled, Mr. Banks confided in the crew that it had been intensely moving to see a barn that looked exactly like his grandfather's burn to the ground in a climactic moment in the film. "He got quite emotional about it," Mr. Schrader said. "I could see how deeply he had been pulled into the realization of this fictional story he had written."
Their collaboration was so close that Mr. Schrader, who wrote the screenplay as well as directed, once called Mr. Banks from the set and got him to write a few lines of voiceover narration. "He said, 'It's snowing like hell up here, and we've got to explain it,' " Mr. Banks said.
Despite his happy experiences, Mr. Banks has become wise to the ways of Hollywood. Recently, he was disheartened to learn that Carl Franklin, the director of "Devil in a Blue Dress" and the much-admired "One False Move," is no longer in the running to direct "Rule of the Bone," based on Mr. Banks's last novel. To avoid such disappointments in the future, Mr. Banks said, he has signed on as a producer for the movies being developed from "Continental Drift" and another earlier novel, "The Book of Jamaica," because "that's the only way you're going to have any control over who directs it, who writes it and who acts in it."
"And if you care about these things as I do," he added, "then that's the way to do it."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1267 words

HEADLINE: Lyndhurst Earning Keep as a Film Site

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
OVERLOOKING the Hudson River in Tarrytown on 67 landscaped acres is Lyndhurst, one of America's finest Gothic Revival mansions, formerly the estate of the railroad magnate Jay Gould and now the property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation.
What, then, are all those little boys doing on those manicured lawns? Why are two identical vintage Cadillacs parked in the raked gravel driveway? 
 Quiet!
Orders are barked.
Lights! Camera!
The making of a movie is under way. A crew is filming "Gloria," a new version of the 1980 John Cassavetes movie starring Gena Rowlands. This "Gloria," directed by Sidney Lumet, starring Sharon Stone and Jeremy Northam, is scheduled for release next summer.
History for hire, or Lyndhurst as a film location, takes on economic importance as budget cuts to cultural institutions have been exacerbated by the reduction in funds from the National Endowment for the Arts, down to $98 million for fiscal 1998 from $99.5 million in fiscal 1997. And there is a new cap of 15 percent on funds to any one state -- proposed under the Interior Appropriations Bill on the amount of money arts institutions can receive from the endowment fund -- meaning that financing for New York, which has received 27 percent in the past will be cut almost in half.
"With money scarce, it's a financial challenge to try to earn more," said Susanne Pandich, director of Lyndhurst. "It costs $1 million a year just to keep Lyndhurst operating, to say nothing about capital costs. We've reduced salaries and staff and we're constantly looking at creative uses of our property so we can become more self-sufficient." Marketing Lyndhurst as a location site is approached in a business-like manner. "We are listed in all the location guides, and scouts come by regularly," Ms. Pandich said. "A lot of TV commercials have been shot here, and this is the second time Sidney Lumet has used Lyndhurst as the location for a major motion picture. 'Reversal of Fortune' about Claus Von Bulow was done here."
Because location rental fees account for about 1 to 5 percent of an entire production budget, the financial benefits are considerable. "Our fees are set on a scale of $2,000 to $8,000 a day, depending on what is required," Ms. Pandich said, adding that it is important for administrators of historic properties to understand what a film company is proposing to do before contracts are signed.
"We have a responsibility to the public to see that the property in our care is protected," Ms. Pandich said. "At Lyndhurst, for example, special effects come under scrutiny. Before we agree to any use of special effects, we must be assured that any special effects won't harm the landscape, the building or the furnishings. For interior shoots, for example, all our furniture is removed by special fine arts movers and by our own people. The movie company is charged an additional $1,000."
On the first day of shooting, Ms. Pandich walks through the house with the film's production manager, making notes. The same procedure is repeated on the last day.
"We follow guidelines set down for filming by the National Trust," she said. "Tradeoffs such as excessive wear and tear must be weighed against economic gain. The project must be appropriate for our property."
Ms. Pandich was involved in about a dozen film productions during her 10-year tenure as curator at Biltmore, the National Trust property in Asheville, N.C. "That's where I learned how to deal with film companies," she said. "Every aspect of the project was carefully examined. In every instance, we had to weigh the care of the property against the dollars that the film would produce."
With the increased use of historic resources by film makers, a publication to help preservationists become knowledgeable about all aspects of the process has been issued by the National Trust for Historic Preservation. "It gives detailed information about what the location experience entails, examines both the benefits and the drawbacks and proposes solutions to potential problems," Ms. Pandich said, adding that the economic impact of filming at Lyndhurst is greater than the location fees.
"The benefits have a ripple effect. The tourist industry in the area gets a boost because of the increase in visitors who want to see where movies have been made. They spend money in restaurants, shops and hotels, and they also visit other historic sites in the Hudson Valley. It's a win-win situation for all of us."
In the movie "Gloria," Lyndhurst is transformed into a Catholic school for boys, a spokesman for the movie company said. "It represents a sanctuary upstate for the leading characters fleeing the mob. It's an ideal site. Sixty-seven acres with great river views and only 40 minutes away from mid-Manhattan. For us that means big savings in hotel bills, food, rental cars, and what's more, the crew can go home at night and sleep in their own beds. Makes for a happier ship."
When asked about the wear and tear on the mansion during the shooting, he said, "Our location manager, who acts as a liaison between Lyndhurst and us, sees to it that we leave the place better than we found it."
Movies, television commercials, advertising stills, fashion shoots all produce revenue crucial to the continuing restoration at Lyndhurst, and weddings, too, have become lucrative. Lyndhurst was the first museum property in the area to open its doors for weddings and social events.
"The place lends itself to grand events, generating business we can use," Ms. Pandich said. "We have a commercial kitchen and a full-service caterer and wedding planner on site, Fabulous Foods, to help with every aspect of weddings from menus to music to flowers."
The busiest time for weddings is from April to October. "Many couples choose the Rose Garden as the site for their wedding ceremony," Ms. Pandich said. "The setting is beautiful. A charming gazebo in the garden is surrounded by hundreds of varieties of roses, planted, cultivated and tended for over 26 years by volunteers of the Garden Club of Irvington-on-the-Hudson. Lyndhurst's 1865 brick Carriage House, newly restored, is also a popular place for weddings."
For large weddings, the Carriage House's courtyard can be covered with a tent year round, accommodating as many as 350 guests. Ms. Pandich also said that Lyndhurst offers a romantic setting unduplicated anywhere. "Where else can brides arrive at their ceremony in an antique carriage drawn by a matched pair of Morgan horses and then, following the ceremony, have a reception on the veranda of the mansion? And during the reception, the mansion itself is opened for touring by the wedding guests."
Fees range from $250 to $3,000, and part of the fee is tax deductible because the proceeds go to restoration of the property.
Another popular time for parties at Lyndhurst is December when corporations hold holiday parties in the Carriage house. In addition, on Saturday and Sunday evenings from Dec. 13 to 28, candlelight tours of the mansion, decorated for Christmas, will be offered. "The mansion will be lighted by candles and elaborately decorated with turn-of-the-century trimmings," Ms. Pandich said.
Virtually every room will be decorated for the season. Visitors will be able to wander through halls decked with festoons of pine and laurel, see the mansion's Victorian Christmas trees, listen to live music and drink mulled cider. Admission is $10, $6 for children. Reservations are required and are now being taken. For reservations or more information, the number to call is 631-4481.

HEADLINE: Girls and Computers Still an Issue

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN

 BODY:
SISTER JEAN BAPTISTE, principal of the Ursuline School, a Roman Catholic private school in New Rochelle for 6th through 12th-grade girls, said she knew she had made the right decision this year in requiring incoming sixth graders to buy laptop computers.
She recalled a conversation that she had had recently with the father of an eighth grader. "This parent, who is in the business world, came up to me and said: 'Sister, you can't imagine what a difference it makes if a woman can do computers. It really cracks the glass ceiling,' " Sister Jean Baptiste said. "The world these sixth graders will move into will be totally computer run. We want to give them the self-confidence and skills to move into that world. That's the point of a women's school. We have to give our young women an edge. We started with the sixth grade partly because there are only 25 of them, while I have 180 girls in ninth grade, and partly because I want to catch them before they turn off." 
 Keeping girls interested in technology and allowing them to keep their career options open later on was the theme of a daylong conference on "Women, Girls and Technology" earlier this month at the Marymount Institute for the Education of Women and Girls at Marymount College here. The conference was sponsored by the institute, the Marymount Academic Computing Center and the Lower Hudson Regional Information Center. Attending the meeting were teachers, administrators, parents and students from Briarcliff, Chappaqua, Croton-on-Hudson, Elmsford, Harrison, Greenburgh Central 7, Ossining, Pocantico Hills, Scarsdale, Somers and White Plains school districts as well as from the newly formed Young Women's Leadership School of East Harlem, which is an all-girl junior high school in Manhattan.
Many educators have expressed concern that girls -- specifically those entering the middle school years when social identity and popularity are often more important than academic pursuits -- associate computers and technology with boys, and that the girls are reluctant to enter what they see as a male domain.
"We're hitting a brick wall with the girls," said Jim O' Brien, a technology teacher at Somers High School, echoing classroom experiences that many teachers shared. "I have 4 girls out of 25 in one tech class, and 5 out of 25 in another. The guidance counselor who refers the most girls to these classes is male. Home economics has bridged the gender gap. Why do we have such hurdles? It's depressing to me that there's such a clear-cut stereotype, that 'technology is for boys.' We tried to structure a facility that's inviting, that doesn't look like a machine shop or a garage, and we try to make our activities nongender biased, but it's frustrating."
Students have also expressed frustration.
"A lot of girls are afraid of the challenge and are afraid to be put down or to fail," said 17-year-old Taniqua Ward, a junior in the Greenburgh Central 7 School District. "They automatically walk in there scared."
In other schools, teachers and administrators have found that even the most carefully designed technology centers attract more boys than girls.
"We've got all this stuff available, all the equipment and software, but we see a situation where boys knock down the door during lunchtime recess, but we don't see a lot of girls knocking down the door," said Peter Lisi, principal and superintendent in the Pocantico Hills School District. "I honestly do not know why. We're concerned about our girls not having the same opportunities as our boys. We don't want to see our girls left behind or our boys victimized because of their interest. One question to address may be the whole issue of stereotyping."
In some districts, where the schools have established gender equity committees to address such stereotyping concerns, there are still potential problems.
"In middle school, young women can lose their voice," Dr. Joan Weber, an assistant superintendent in Scarsdale, said. "Our district has a two-year-old gender equity committee to make sure there is equality for boys and girls."
To some experts, the problems lie in how boys and girls view computers. Jo Sanders, director of the Center for Gender Equity at the Washington Research Institute in Seattle and the conference's keynote speaker, said: "Males tend to see computers as something of intrinsic interest, or as a power expression, another form of manhood testing. Girls see computers as a means to an end. Girls have been socialized to believe that it's not quite an appropriate thing for them. You have to provide opportunities and experiences for girls to succeed and excel in technology."
What often happens, some experts said, is that teachers who encourage boys to tackle a problem until they solve it on their own tend to rescue girls who face similar problems by providing the solution and reinforcing a girl's feeling of inadequacy.
Dr. Sanders continued: "As technology is becoming more prevalent in schools, girls are taking themselves out of it. Teachers have to make sure that in the technology classroom they're not letting classmates put down the girls."

HEADLINE: Now About Bob and Those TV Spots . . .

BYLINE: By BILL RYAN 

 BODY:
TO people who watch television in Connecticut -- and that's most people -- he's like the fly that keeps buzzing around until he seems like part of everyday life and you get the impression that you'd miss him if he flew away somewhere. Or maybe not.
His name is Bob. 
 Now you get it. He's the guy in the commercials, some 500 a week, over the state's network and cable stations, passionately telling, sometimes yelling, about the bargains at Bob's Discount Furniture. Again, and again and again, day and night, he appears, a skinny guy with a high-pitched voice extolling the virtues of living room sets or bedroom sets, usually ending with an invitation to "Come on Down" or exulting that he's "Gotcha" by the low prices and high quality.
The pitchman has become a celebrity of sorts. Wherever he goes, someone is sure to yell "Hey, that's Bob," or sidle up and say, "Hi Bob! " as though they have been friends for years.
That's the public Bob. There is, however, another Bob. This Bob is quiet-spoken, self-effacing, reflective, a complete turnaround from the manic Television Bob. They do dress alike though: open shirt, pullover sweater, jeans, sneakers.
"I feel like a fraud sometimes," said the private Bob Kaufman. He was relaxing in one of the soft chairs in his Orange store and talking about his double identity. "I am rather introverted," he said. "People who know me say its amazing when they see me on TV." So why does he do the television commercials that force him to change from Introvert Bob to Extrovert Bob? It's simple; they work.
Bob's Discount Furniture was started modestly in 1991 with one store in Newington. The "Come on Down" and "Gotcha" commercials started in 1992, a disastrous year economically for Connecticut in general.
In the years since, in equally distressing economic times, more stores have been opened and now they total a dozen in Connecticut and two more in western Massachusetts. Last year, Bob's Discount Furniture was rated as the 63d largest furniture company in the nation.
The commercials that have fueled the remarkable growth are about as elemental as can be. They are written and produced by Bob and two others connected to the company, Stan Adelstein and Andy Bricker.
"It's not complicated," says Bob. Their studio is an upstairs room in the Manchester Bob's store. They set up an arrangement of furniture, use one camera, some lights, and Bob goes into action. That's it. Occasionally they go on location. A commercial featuring Bob with Carla Berube, a former UConn and now New England Blizzard basketball notable, was shot at East Catholic High School, also in Manchester.
Bob has no illusions about the artistic merits of the commercials but he defends them. "Who is better to tell about products than someone who believes in them?" he asks.
He acknowledges that the commercials get a mixed reaction. "Some people love them and some people hate them. One time, a guy came up to me and I thought he was going to beat me up. 'I hate those ads,' he said, 'but I like you.' " Bob says he thinks most people approve of him because of his sincerity about the products he is selling. "If I had to fake it, I couldn't do it."
He says he is not dismayed if some people reach for the clicker when he appears. "We all watch too much television anyway," he says. Besides, there is much worse on the tube. "I heard a statistic the other day that a kid by 18 has seen 18,000 murders on television."
He also well knows that "Come on Down," taken shamelessly from the television show "The Price Is Right," is a cliche of cliches by now. "I hope no one wants to put it on my tombstone."
When he first decided to appear in the television commercials, one of the least enthusiastic people was his father, Leo Kaufman, who for decades had run an advertising agency in Hartford with many furniture accounts. " 'Look at you,' he said. 'And you've got a voice that sounds like chalk on chalk.' " Today, Leo likes to accompany Bob when he is invited to speak on his career as an entrepreneur.
Bob Kaufman, who is now 45, grew up in West Hartford and was graduated from the University of Connecticut in l974 with a degree in marketing.
His first job was with Radio Shack in Groton. He enjoyed it, he said, but something happened a few years later that was to change his life dramatically.
He was going to a meeting on his motorcycle when he noticed that the gas in one tank was almost depleted. He bent down to switch to the second tank, lost control, and crashed into a pole. His right leg was badly shattered and for a time in danger of being amputated. The leg is still partially paralyzed. He took months to recuperate and had to give up his job with Radio Shack.
He worked in other jobs, including a stint as a supervisor in a factory, but eventually decided to try something else. He had been sleeping on a waterbed, relatively new at the time, because it was supportive of his injured leg. So he became an entrepreneur, in waterbeds.
"I became the waterbed king," he says cheerily. He would lease space in stores to sell waterbeds with a proviso that the stores would be paid only when he had his profits. It was a no-risk deal for him and by the end of the 1980's, he had space in 24 stores in four states.
But the waterbed craze was ebbing in the early 1990's when Bob Kaufman and Gene Rosenberg, who had owned a chain of furniture stores and was considered an expert in special promotions, took over a building in Newington where a furniture store had gone into bankruptcy. The building, an early casualty of a growing state recession, became the first Bob's Discount Furniture store, with Mr. Rosenberg owning two-thirds of the business and Bob one-third under an agreement that still exists.
The recession actually helped the business, Bob says today. "As we got successful, we started to get calls from owners of buildings that were vacant because other stores had gone bankrupt. They wanted to fill them up. The second store was in Windsor, then Middletown, then Willimantic" and so on.
As the chain has expanded, the stores have became fancier, and more dignified: arrangements of furniture in tasteful patterns, coffee for patrons to sip, freshly baked cookies, huge jars of candies for children.
Bob says he is always amused at the reaction to the stores from people who have seen his antics on television. It's a different world. "We don't pressure anybody," he said. "We don't have markdown sales. If you buy something today it's the same price tomorrow. Our salespeople don't hover. Some people come in for lunch. We don't care. They'll be back."
He is also amused by some of the more affluent people who come to his stores to shop but don't tell their neighbors. "You'd be suprised at how many times someone in Avon or Farmington asks if we can deliver the furniture in an unmarked truck."
At age 45, the off-camera Bob is a contented man. "I think I'm the most blessed man in this state," he says.
In a way, his good fortune extends to the accident that nearly cost him a leg. "Know where I'd be if is wasn't for the accident?" he said. "I'd still be at Radio Shack."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At his store in Orange, the entrepreneur Bob Kaufman shakes hands with Mary Formica, a customer who recognized him from his television commercials. (Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Loyal Partners at Devil's Den

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
THE placid waters of Godfrey Pond in Weston reflected the orange-red leaves of the trees surrounding it as Howard Pierpont, a 72-year-old Stratford man, dug his pitchfork into a mound of wood chips made damp by a weekend of solid rain. Now it was Monday morning, and Mr. Pierpont was using the chips to cover a woodland trail.
"You need it to prevent compacting the trails over the winter, and so people can get a better footing with all these leaves around," he said of his work. "We were supposed to work on the trails this weekend, but we had to cancel because of the rain. Hopefully we'll get to it this weekend, but I wanted to get some of it done today while the weather was good." 
 Considering Mr. Pierpont is no paid groundskeeper but a retired volunteer, his dedication would seem noteworthy. Yet it is hardly unusual at Weston's Lucius Pond Ordway-Devil's Den Preserve, the largest piece of protected open space in Fairfield County. Owned by the private Nature Conservancy, the 1,700-acre wildlife sanctuary tends to bring out the nature-loving philanthropist in many, including Weston's local government.
Over the past decade, Weston has embarked on a series of joint ventures with the Nature Conservancy to enlarge this woodland tract, buying available land contiguous to Devil's Den. This history of cooperative land-buying is unusual for the Conservancy, an international organization based in Virginia. Denise Schlener, executive director of the Conservancy's Connecticut chapter, calls it a "breakthrough."
"As we protect larger natural landscapes, partners are critical to our success," she said. "Jointly owning land is a real opportunity. I know we couldn't do this by ourselves. We wouldn't want to do this by ourselves."
By "this," Ms. Schlener meant the latest of 4 land purchases over the past 10 years in which Weston played a key role. The land in question this time, a 32-acre parcel near the Den's signature feature, Godfrey Pond, is a farm owned by Leon Lachat, a long-time Weston resident who is said to be selling the land well under market value because of a desire to see the town retain some rural character in the face of increased development.
Large-lot zoning is the general rule, with a two-acre minimum requirement for houses, but Weston has not been immune to the development fever which has swept through Fairfield County since the 1980's. "When I was a kid, growing up here in the 1940's and 1950's, there were a lot of farms with meadows," the Weston First Selectman, George Guidera, said. "Not anymore."
Mr. Guidera, a Republican in his sixth term, said Devil's Den is one place where residents from Weston and surrounding communities can get away from encroaching civilization. The only downside to Devil's Den, he added, is that "it's all in one place. But when you get in the center of the thing, it's tremendous. You can't believe you're only 45 minutes from Manhattan as the crow flies."
The town began buying land with the Conservancy in April 1988, after a court ruled that a 16-acre parcel in the center of Devil's Den, thought to be in Conservancy hands, was actually owned by a man who immediately talked about building houses there. The Nature Conservancy, Mr. Guidera recalled, threatened to sell its entire Weston acreage rather than maintain the preserve in so compromised a state. Lacking the funds to buy the would-be developer out, they asked the town government for help.
"The Conservancy had come to the prior First Selectman, and she said there was nothing she could do," Mr. Guidera said. "They smartly came back when I came in and said that they could raise $425,000, could I raise the other $425,000?"
Mr. Guidera recalled balking at donating town money to a private charity, but suggested an alternative: For the same $425,000 price, Weston would buy the conservation restrictions from the Conservancy for the entire Devil's Den preserve, and the Conservancy could then use that money to help buy the central parcel.
Holding such restrictions meant that even if the Conservancy were to sell the preserve to a developer, the land could not be developed.
"It was a no-brainer," Mr. Guidera recalled. "Everything we've decided to do with them has been a no-brainer. That was cheap when you consider the alternatives."
The alternatives include allowing parcels up for sale to be developed and adding to a local population that has risen from 660 people in 1942 to about 10,000 today. That, town officials say, would mean more roads to maintain, citizens to protect and children to educate. In other words, higher property taxes.
Mr. Guidera said that even those in Weston who do not visit the preserve understand this. In 1990, with the state in the midst of a recession and local governments scrounging to make cuts, Weston bought 85 acres of land next to Devil's Den from the Bridgeport Hydraulic Company at $6,950 an acre. When it came time to ratify the purchase, at an open town meeting in which all voting-age Weston residents can participate, it was resoundingly approved.
That time Weston bought the land on its own, without the Conservancy's help. Two years ago the town joined with the Conservancy again when People's Bank sold an undeveloped 70-acre parcel, again adjacent to the preserve, which a bank had foreclosed on for $200,000. Weston again paid half of that for the development rights.
"In this market, that's nothing," said Stephen Patton, co-director of the preserve along with his wife, Lise A. Hanners.
Overseeing a 1,700-acre preserve would seem a formidable task for anyone, especially with limited staffing and a yearly Conservancy budget of $250,000. The couple, both ornithologists, arrived at Devil's Den in 1990 and spend a considerable portion of time studying the activity of migratory bird species like the worm-eating warblers, which summer in the Den, one of the last remaining large-scale habitats of its kind.
Devil's Den has a long history, but it came into being as a preserve only in the late 1960's, when Bridgeport Hydraulic sold the land to the Conservancy in three separate pieces. Katharine Ordway of Weston willed the Conservancy enough money to make those initial purchases and it is for her father, Lucius Pond Ordway, that the preserve is partially named.
"Ordway left an extraordinary legacy to the Nature Conservancy, which led us to a whole other period in our history," Ms. Schlener said. "Thanks to her, we were able to be more aggressive. For many of us, Devil's Den is a core preserve that has value extending beyond its biological importance to the role this woman played in the development of the Conservancy."
The name Devil's Den may have been derived from a cloven-shaped imprint found on a rock there during Colonial times. The name did not scare away settlers, nor did the sloping topography that prevented most farming. A saw mill was built on the site before the Revolution, damming two brooks to form what became Godfrey Pond. Fishing, hunting and trapping also took place, but more lucrative was charcoal-making, a procedure which involved burning dried cordwood in sealed mounds for as long as a month. More than 40 sites at Devil's Den, most of them little more than isolated clearings with scattered stone debris, have been linked to this activity. A display has been set up near one such site on Laurel Trail to show how this long-ago practice was performed.
Perhaps because it is so close to the Devil's Den entrance at the end of Pent Road, Laurel Trail is one of the most frequently traveled and documented of all the preserve trails. There are more than 20 miles of trails in all, and visitor recreation is limited to hiking, nature-watching and, on some trails, cross-country skiing.
Even dog-walking is prohibited, because dogs pose a danger to birds and other native wildlife.
Such regulation might not go down well with everyone, but it would be hard to tell from the preserve's deep pool of volunteers. There are 140 active volunteers, according to the preserve's program coordinator, Lillian Willis, which helps when an average of 40,000 people visit Devil's Den a year.
"We are unique in the area," Ms. Willis said. "There's nowhere else you can go and hike for 20 miles."
Many volunteers "adopt" a portion of a trail to maintain. Others lead guided tours of particular areas for adults or for school groups. Some, like Mr. Pierpont, do both.
"I don't think of it as work," said Cia Marion, a volunteer from Westport. "I think of it as fun."
Frank Waters sometimes demonstrates the collier's work regimen for young visitors. A Norwalk resident since 1955 who lived in Weston for a time before then, he said that children from urban areas like Norwalk and Bridgeport who visit with school groups seem especially appreciative of Devil's Den's bucolic features.
"One of the things we try to do is get the commitment to encourage protection, so that they and their grandchildren can see what true nature is like," he said.
Because several farm buildings are located at the Lachat property and because it is directly connected to Godfrey Road, a main Weston thoroughfare, the Conservancy wants to put a "conservation center" there. Mr. Patton said a center will help teach nature appreciation to people in the community and provide an indoor gathering place for volunteers.
The Lachat deal still has several hurdles to clear, culminating in a town meeting on Thursday where the Weston half of the $1.5 million purchase price will be decided on.
For the first time, the town will be a full partner with the Conservancy -- buying half of the land itself. (The partners would also hold a three-year option for the purchase of another 10-acre piece of the Lachat estate.) Mr. Guidera said he anticipated no serious opposition to the expenditure.
"It's the most fantastic working relationship I've seen anywhere between a government and a private group," he said. "We trust them, they trust us. When we argue, it's a minimal argument."

HEADLINE: Back Again In Stamford: Speculative Building

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
WHEN the business boom of the last decade ended in 1988 with a deep recession and fortunes lost, no industry in Connecticut was in worse shape than commercial real estate. Everywhere, empty office buildings were gaunt reminders of reckless excess. Many in the industry predicted they would never see speculative office construction again.
Suddenly, though, steel is rising again. The last four years has seen new manufacturing and retail buildings constructed all around the state, and in the last 12 to 18 months new office buildings have started going up again. In parts of Fairfield County, investors are even planning to build office structures on speculation. 
 At a recent real estate financing seminar, Jeff Sussman, president of the Louis Dreyfus Property Group in New York, stunned a gathering of brokers, investors and municipal officials by announcing that his company would build a 21-story office tower on speculation in downtown Stamford, the first there in a decade. "That's news!" cheered the city's economic development director, Kip Bergstrom. Then there is Shelton, where another office building, albeit smaller, is being built on speculation. Elsewhere in throughout the state, however, experts on the commercial real estate market said similar development is still several years off. Brokers and investors alike said Stamford has been more pushed by influences from outside the state than pulled by forces from within. Many of the companies seeking to move out of New York City are leap-frogging Westchester and landing in Fairfield County. Over the last year they have occupied just about all the available vacant top-quality office space with 75,000 square feet or more in the Stamford market and environs. In the real estate business, the use of vacant office space is termed "absorption."
"Fairfield County, in particular, has a shortage of office space," noted Chris Cooper, a spokesman for the State Department of Economic Development. Declining vacancy rates have pushed rents for Class A office space in Stamford to around $32 per square foot. Although rents of $35 per foot or more are required for new construction to be profitable, developers are pressing on under the expectation that rents will climb to that range by the time that they are ready for tenants to move into them. Rents in Stamford have been rising at a rate of 10 percent a year, Mr. Bergstrom said, "so we're going to get there pretty quickly."
New methods for financing real estate development are helping the process along. Banks -- the dominant sources for real estate capital in the 1980's -- have been replaced by real estate investment trusts and commercial mortgage-backed securities. A lot of money has poured into these financial vehicles during the past few years, and fund managers like the state.
During the mid-1980's, the banking industry had shifted from its traditionally conservative approach to financing development, demanding that builders line up tenants in advance before approving mortgages (which is know as "building to suit,"), to the riskier strategy of financing speculative development. The result, Mr. Bergstrom said, was too much office space. When the recession struck, the banks found themselves holding mortgages for vacant buildings. Some banks were forced out of business.
The real estate investment trusts and securities funds, however, are more diversified in the markets and properties they invest in, and presumably less subject to loss if a property or a whole regional market becomes unprofitable. Connecticut's recovery from the recession has been very slow, but the state still has several advantages, including a good transportation system, schools and colleges, a skilled labor force and attractive communities. These were factors that lured the Swiss Bank Corporation to move its huge headquarters out of Manhattan to Stamford, which in turn has drawn other investors, including Mr. Sussman's company.
"Stamford is becoming a very unique market," he said. "It has both urban and suburban characteristics that major companies want. We think it's a great place."
Mr. Sussman observed, however, that building on speculation for the office market is still a gamble. Most office projects still need commitments from enough tenants, preferably including a single, large company that is in effect an anchor, before lenders will agree to finance their construction. But he says he believes half his building will be rented before he puts a shovel in the ground.
Likewise, David Mack, a partner with the Davis Companies, a Boston-based developer, said a 100,000-square-foot office building he has planned in an office park in Shelton may be fully leased before it is completed, possibly even before construction begins on it. Shelton is attractive because land costs are lower than Stamford. Companies there also don't face the traffic congestion that plagues Stamford and New York City. "You have one accident, and everybody in your company gets to work at 10:30 in the morning," he said.
Stamford and Shelton, in fact, have a relationship. "Just as we're New York's suburb, they're our suburb," said Mr. Bergstrom. Just as companies from New York are relocating to Stamford, companies from Stamford are relocating to Shelton.
Strong office real estate markets tend to radiate out from their centers. Greenwich has decided it has grown enough, Mr. Bergstrom said, so Stamford's overflow has moved east along the shoreline and Merritt Parkway corridors, and north along Route 7 and Routes 25 and 8.
For the moment, it has skipped Bridgeport. Harbour Place, a $950 million complex of stores, hotels, a conference center, theaters and offices, has been proposed for a 50-acre property on Bridgeport's waterfront. But Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's Director of Planning and Economic Development, said office rents there aren't high enough to make new construction profitable, so the two office buildings in the project aren't scheduled to be built until its final phase, well into the next decade.
Danbury has experienced low office vacancy rates and has seen some new construction, which has radiated into its suburbs. All of it has been build to suit, however; no speculative development.
Meanwhile, the Hartford and New Haven markets have been improving, but both still have substantial vacancy rates. "We've had no new building since 1988," said Bob Daglio, a broker with CB Commercial/Whittier. But whereas five years ago a company might have had its choice from among 20 office buildings with 75,000 square feet of floor space, today, its choice would be limited to about five buildings. "We're all cautiously positive that it's getting better," he said.
While most of the rest of the state struggles to win over investors and restore their economies to pre-recession levels of growth, Stamford has begun to experience growing pains. Mr. Bergstrom said some developers are concerned if there are enough construction workers available to build everything planned. Traffic congestion on the major highways is worse than ever.
The city might support an additional two million square feet of office space above the three million now under construction or approved, he said, but then it might have reached its limit for growth.
That prospect doesn't make Mr. Bergstrom unhappy, however.
"The rest of the state would love to have the problem of trying to decide how big they want to be," he said.
