HEADLINE: IN BRIEF

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:

Postal Lawsuit
Julio Ramos, a Puerto Rican mail handler working at the United States Postal Service's distribution center in Harrison, has filed a Federal anti-discrimination suit, accusing the Government of discriminating against him by setting an English-only policy on the job. 
 The suit was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, and names Postmaster General Marvin Runyon as the defendant.
Juan A. Figueroa, president and general counsel of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, the civil rights organization representing Mr. Ramos, said: "It is ironic. We're United States citizens who come here to be treated like second-class citizens."
The lawyer, who said that Mr. Ramos was told by one of his co-workers to go back to Puerto Rico if he wanted to speak Spanish on the job, said this was the fifth case in a year brought by his organization to dispute English-only rules.
But Pat McGovern, a spokeswoman for the Postal Service, said there was no policy discriminating against the use of Spanish on the "workroom floor" of the distribution center. She explained that many workers speak second languages at work. "It's done every day of the week," she said. "We have a diverse work force."
Workers are required to speak English only when conducting official business, for example, in the personnel office, she said, adding that speaking any second language was considered an asset in dealing with the Postal Service's many customers.
The English-only issue has become increasingly controversial. In Amarillo, Tex., two women were recently discharged by an insurance agency for speaking Spanish on the job, leading to a boycott of the agency by two Hispanic groups and threats of lawsuits. Two years ago, an Amarillo judge sparked a national controversy when he ordered a Mexican-American woman involved in a custody dispute to speak English to her 5-year-old daughter.
 
Public Housing
The Greenburgh Housing Authority recently received a failing grade on an assessment performed by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and United States Representative Sue Kelly thinks an injustice has been done.
At the very least, it is a bureaucratic error that the Congresswoman wants corrected, she said to Andrew M. Cuomo, secretary of the Federal agency.
Last year the Greenburgh Housing Authority received an A-plus. But this year, when an inspector visited the site, the newly hired maintenance supervisor, who was unfamiliar with the office's filing system, was unable to find documentation required for the audit. Thus the failing grade.
When Wesley Lee, executive director of the authority, telephoned the next day to tell Mr. Cuomo's agency that the papers were available, he was told by a worker that the F grade was final.
Referring to Mr. Lee and his staff, Ms. Kelly said in a letter to Mr. Cuomo that she "would hate for a bureaucratic technicality, such as this, to needlessly mar their careers."
 
Water Quality O.K.
The results from water-quality testing of Long Island Sound this summer and fall show that three Westchester harbors had a marked improvement over last year, said Steve Yergeau, a researcher at the environmental group Save the Sound.
Although it is still not known why the improvement occurred, Mr. Yergeau said he believed that cool, dry weather was a contributing factor. But he emphasized that comparing one year's data with the next cannot be used as an indication of long-term trends.
The environmental organization, which studies issues in New York and Connecticut, currently monitors 50 sites in 11 harbors and coves in Westchester, Fairfield and New Haven Counties. Trained at the beginning of the season, 123 volunteers in the group's Adopt-a-Harbor program collected data on dissolved oxygen, nitrogen and chlorophyll in the water and on water salinity and the presence of algae.
None of the three harbors tested in Westchester -- Echo Bay in New Rochelle, Milton Harbor in Rye and Mamaroneck Harbor -- became hypoxic, which occurs when oxygen levels in the water drop precipitously.
Despite the influx of excess nutrients, sewage spills at the beginning of the summer season did not lead to excess algae growth, which in turn leads to low oxygen levels, the report said. The high pathogen levels, however, did keep swimmers out of the water for part of the summer.
 
Rating Reaffirmed
Westchester has done it again: the county's impeccable credit rating has been upheld.
With the selling of $83 million in municipal bonds, Moody's Investor Service, Standard & Poor's Corporation and Fitch Investors Service reaffirmed their confidence in the county's financial stability by rating the bond issue AAA or an equivalent.
Municipal bonds are sold to finance capital improvements undertaken by the county. The bond agencies' ratings are equivalent to a credit rating, which if high, enables the county to borrow at relatively low interest rates.
"The county has maintained a stable financial position despite slower revenue growth and substantial expenditure pressure," Standard & Poor's reported.
The county's Finance Commissioner, Eric Langeloh, reported that Westchester sold the bonds, which were purchased by Merrill Lynch & Company, at a net interest rate of 4.62 percent.
"In the current market, this rate is a good one," the Commissioner said.
Among the items to be financed by the sale of the bonds are improvements at the Westchester County Medical Center, repairs and rehabilitation of sewers, work on county roads, bridges and buildings and improvements at Playland and other parks.
 
Funds for Women
The Westchester Fund for Women and Girls recently awarded grants to the following groups:
*$3,000 to the Guidance Center, a New Rochelle organization, to provide domestic violence prevention and early intervention services to Port Chester Hispanic immigrant girls and women.
*$2,500 to the Community Planning Council of Yonkers for outreach and workshops for immigrant mothers of children attending the Fermi School, which is in an economically distressed neighborhood.
*$4,800 to the Northern Westchester Shelter Office in Pleasantville for legal services to women.
*$5,000 to Westchester Jewish Community Services in Hartsdale to develop a directory of services for women and girls.
*$4,000 to the Westchester Community College Foundation in Valhalla to develop training workshops for students and faculty to increase awareness of family violence issues.
*$1,000 to the New Rochelle school district for a girls' fitness program known as Physical Activity and Teen-age Health. ELSA BRENNER

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2321 words

HEADLINE: Building Is Booming -- in Some Places

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
WHEN she drives the 20 miles from her home in Oxford, Conn., to her office in Monroe in northwestern Fairfield County, Laura Maksymiw said, it seems as if a new subdivision is going up on every street. "And the houses are selling before the framing's put in," she said.
As executive officer of the Homebuilders Association of Fairfield County, Ms. Maksymiw remembers how recently such activity was absent. "The last four years, building dried up," she said. "By the beginning of this year, it began to pick up. In fact, my builders say there's a shortage of framers and other skilled construction workers. Many of them left the area and went to Florida or North Carolina when the market went down, and never came back." 
 Ms. Maksymiw echoes what many in the building trades in the metropolitan area are saying: Home building is booming, but only in certain areas, due primarily to their proximity to Manhattan or other commercial centers or to their cachet as second-home communities. They also note that while building permits and other measures of activity are up, they are still far from the boom years of the 1980's.
In the Town of Southampton on Long Island, for instance, building permits are up by 10 percent over the last year, and land values have been steadily appreciating, in some sections by as much as 50 percent.
In Westchester County, where developers have been scrambling to find appropriate land to subdivide, building permits are up by 54 percent over 1996. And in New Jersey and Connecticut, where the number of building permits has increased by 11 and 24 percent, respectively, some sections have benefited by the boom more than others.
"Places like Greenwich, Darien, Stamford and New Canaan, although they don't have much land left, have never been slow," Ms. Maksymiw said. "People who have money always have money. But now places like Monroe and Newtown are also hot."
The Town of Newtown, which is just outside of Danbury, has the most available land in the state, Ms. Maksymiw said. "It's accessible, highly desirable and the houses being built there are priced between $250,000 and $350,000."
Of course, no one would be building houses if they weren't selling, Ms. Maksymiw said. "I think low interest rates is the main reason business is good. And the fact that we've had a good winter. Last year was mud city. Everybody is busy now putting in their foundations before thefrost."
In the first three quarters of 1997, 1,539 building permits were issued in Fairfield County, a 38 percent increase over the same period last year, according to the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development. In New Haven, where 1,607 permits were issued, there was a 37 percent increase from 1996. And in Hartford, there were 1,627 permits issued, up 26 percent from last year.
Steve Temkin, president of T & M Building Company in Torrington, has just started Milford Chase, a development of 34 single-family homes, priced from $220,000 to $325,000 in Milford, which is in New Haven County. "It's the first town out of Fairfield," Mr. Temkin said. "A lot of the people buying houses there commute to Fairfield."
He is also in the last stages of completing another project in Milford, called Settler's Ridge, which Mr. Temkin said had been sold out. The base price for a three-bedroom colonial had been $206,900. "I'm now looking for another tract," Mr. Temkin said. "Milford's been a proven market for me."
On Long Island, 25 percent of all residential construction activity is concentrated in Brookhaven, the island's largest town, where 1,100 building permits were issued through last September compared with 880 last year, said Robert A. Wieboldt, executive vice president of the Long Island Builders Institute. Activity is greatest in the Three Village area, which includes the villages of Stony Brook, Port Jefferson and Setauket, Mr. Wieboldt said.
Charles Mancini, a vice president with the Park Ridge Organization in Ronkonkoma, which builds in the Three Village area and elsewhere on the island, said business was up 15 percent over last year.
He's currently working on a number of projects, including a 250-unit town-house development in Port Jefferson, with a price range of $130,000 to $160,000; a 55-home development in Setauket in the $280,000's to mid-$300,000's price range and 57 homes in Dix Hills, where the homes sell for $500,000 to $1 million.
"By spreading out the price ranges we offer, it helps us as a company to get through the rough spots," Mr. Mancini said.
On the East End, where the market is more dependent on second homes, building activity is definitely up, said Vincent J. Cannuscio, Supervisor of the Town of Southampton. "The activity is divided between east and west of the Shinnecock Canal," he said. "East of the canal, most of the building taking place is on old subdivided lots. And west of the canal is where most of the activity and new subdivisions are being built."
In the Town of Southampton, 317 building permits were issued through last September, compared with 283 the same time last year, said Mr. Weiboldt. Four out of every 10 houses in Southampton are second homes.
A custom-home builder, James V. Zizzi, is used to working on single lots and has built a total of 250 homes on the East End. He said a real trend now was to buy an older home and knock it down just to get the land. "They'll pay between $800,000 to $900,000 for the house." He added that an acre in Westhampton Beach would cost $800,000, "if you could find it."
Mr. Zizzi is now starting work on his first subdivision, with 18 houses, in Quogue. "We're getting our final approvals now," he said, adding that he expected the houses to be priced at $550,000 to $700,000.
THERE'S been a real appreciation in land values in the last two years, Mr. Cannuscio said. "In Water Mill and Bridgehampton, for instance, a one-acre lot used to cost between $75,000 and $95,000. Now it would cost $150,000."
Developers say they're aggressively looking for new sites. "We're looking at about five new sites now," said Patrick Kalian, president of Kalian Companies, in Red Bank, N.J., which is now building six single-family home communities in various parts of the state, with prices ranging from $150,000 to $700,000.
Even though they're looking, developers say it's not the best time to buy. "We're at the top of the market right now," said Jeffrey S. Doynow, a principal with Glickenhaus/Doynow, a development company, in Chappaqua, in Westchester. "Everyone's bidding now, forcing the prices up," he said. "If you meet the market and it takes three to ten years to get your approvals, it's a gamble."
Mr. Doynow is now working on seven different projects, mostly in Westchester and concentrating on the high end of the market. "The high end is very strong now," Mr. Doynow said. "A lot of people are doing very well."
Mr. Temkin, the Torrington builder, said one reason people were anxious to buy now was their fear that prices would soon be going up. In a project he is now finishing called Settler's Ridge, in Milford, Conn., the base price for a 3-bedroom colonial was $206,900 for the last units. In 1994, it was $189,900.
William H. Ethier, executive vice president of Homebuilders of Connecticut, cautioned against reading too much optimism into the increased number of building permits issued in certain areas. Even though the state as a whole saw a 24 percent increase in building permits compared with last year, "You've got to remember that 1996 was the second worst year on record," he said.
In 1996, a total of 7,714 permits were issued, Mr. Ethier said. "Only 1991 was worse, with 7,700," he said, noting that the state has projected that a total of 8,300 permits would be issued this year, with the number climbing to 9,500 by the year 2000. "These numbers should be kept in perspective in relation to the 1980's when we averaged over 17,000 units a year," Mr. Ethier pointed out.
A lot of developers and others in the building trades are calling the current market good, but not overheated. "I've doubled my business since last year," said Mr. Kalian, the Red Bank, N.J., developer. "But it's never going to be the 80's, and that's O.K. It's the 1990's version of the 1980's."
In Connecticut, Clifford Cooper, a Litchfield County architect, said that his business had also doubled this year. "I've been practicing in Litchfield since 1975, and business has always been in line with the economy," he said. "It was up in the 1980's, then there was a lull. Now it seems like the 80's again."
A great deal of the building in Litchfield is of second homes, and one change he has noticed since the 80's is that "people want real value now, not inflated value," Mr. Cooper said.
"Also I think my business has really benefited since the advent of the home office," he added. "People can work one or two days from home. This has led to an increase in the residential market, and also the commercial market, as far as retail space, in order to service these people."
In Westchester County, sales at the high end of the market were so strong in the third quarter of this year that they pushed the average price of a single-family house over $400,000 for the first time.
Mr. Doynow, who is building seven single-family home developments in which prices range from the mid-$300,000's to $2.5 million, said he prefers working at the high end. "It gives me an opportunity to really cater to my clients," he said.
AT Hardscrabble Lake, in New Castle, he has sold 45 of 93 houses, priced from $800,000 to over $1 million. "Most of my customers are from the financial world," Mr. Doynow said. "A lot of them are kids who are making a lot of money. I also get a lot of doctors."
 Housing starts in Westchester increased 54 percent for the first 10 months of this year, according to F.W. Dodge, a division of the McGraw-Hill Construction Information Group. Broken down, that translates into an 8 percent increase in single-family homes, and a 199 percent gain for multifamily units.
One of the most active town-house developers in the county is Ginsburg Development, in Hawthorne, which expects to close on over 160 units this year, compared with 150 in 1996. Its latest project is Mystic Pointe on the Hudson River in Ossining. Now starting its second phase, it has sold 79 of 168 homes, priced from the low $200,000's to the high $400.000's.
"There's a tremendous unmet need for houses for people making $50,000, $60,000, $70,000 a year," said Martin Ginsburg, president of the company. "It's very hard to offer houses at reasonable prices with the price of land and the tremendously costly approval process in a place like Westchester."
The huge number of multifamily starts in Westchester is due, in large part, to a proliferation of luxury rentals in the county, developers and brokers say. One of the most active companies is Avalon Properties of Wilton, Conn., which is now planing projects that would add a total of 1,540 units to the county's rental roster.
"We've definitely been filling a need created when co-ops and condos were the only thing being built," said Alexander Twining, a vice president for real estate for Avalon. "We've been backfilling that need, and think it will continue at least for a few more years."
Rentals have become increasingly attractive, Mr. Twining said, because more people are looking for short-term living situations and "real estate is no longer a good short-term investment," he said.
Avalon is also very active in Connecticut, where it is working on 1,046 rental units; in Long Island, on 1,197 units and in New Jersey, on 1,388 units "When the market is really strong you'll see more condodevelopment," said Mr. Twining. "When condos and co-ops are hot, we're not building."
Applied Companies, in Hoboken, N. J., also specializes in luxury rentals. This has been the company's biggest year ever. "We're building close to 4,500 units," said Michael Barry, a vice president.
It is now working on the first luxury rental to be built in Morristown, N. J., in nearly three decades. Called the Chancery, the 131-unit, six-story apartment building is expected to attract upper- and middle-income residents to the downtown district, Mr. Barry said. Rents are expected to range from $1,100 a month for a one-bedroom apartment to $1,400 for a two-bedroom. The company just completed a 117-unit luxury apartment complex in New Brunswick and a 300-unit luxury rental on the Hudson River in Jersey City.
"We were able to acquire a lot of the land we're building on now in the early 1990's when the market was down," said Mr. Barry. "We picked up a lot of properties in default. But there's not a lot of that around any more. It's all been absorbed."
THROUGH August, 18,150 building permits were issued in New Jersey compared with 16,299 in the same period in 1996. But when you shake out the differences between the two winters, the years are about even, said Patrick O'Keefe, chief executive officer of the New Jersey Builders Association.
"There were two distinctly different weather patterns," Mr. O'Keefe said. "In 1997, we were able to continue construction throughout the year. The first four months of the year were 25 percent ahead of last year. But if you look at it historically, building is subdued. In the 1980's the state averaged 38,000 units a year. Now we're on a par with the rate of construction in the 1940's."
Most of the construction now in progress, he said, is concentrated in the central part of the state and at the upper end of the market. Sixty percent of all construction is taking place in six counties: Monmouth, Ocean, Middlesex, Somerset, Burlington and Morris. "It's a question of perception," Mr. O'Keefe said. "If you're living in those sections, you'd probably think things were robust. But that wouldn't be the case if you lived somewhere else."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
High-Tech Teaching Is Losing Its Gloss

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER

 BODY:
TWO Pilgrims, Priscilla Mullens and Elder Brewster, went on line this month to answer questions from schoolchildren around the country about the first Thanksgiving in 1621.
The actors who played them, guests of the Scholastic Network, were from Plimouth Plantation, the museum in Massachusetts, and they offered an austere picture of life in the colony, where surgeons bled their patients and John Alden's bride-to-be treasured the wooden shoes her father made her. 
 Their appearance, like those of the astronaut Pete Conrad and the children's authors Jan and Stan Berenstain, is the kind of event computer enthusiasts point to when they hail the possibilities of the World Wide Web for education.
School systems nationwide are investing in high-priced machines and software in the conviction, fostered by the White House, that there is no greater good America can offer schoolchildren than computers.
While cuts in many programs have continued, spending on technology for schools is expected to rise to $5.2 billion this year from $4.3 billion last year, an increase that far outpaces inflation, according to a report in a recent issue of Education Week. The Texas Board of Education is looking into giving all students laptops instead of textbooks.
Yet much of what passes for education on computers is a far cry from the well-crafted programs of Scholastic. Most of it is akin to glorified video games offered in the vague but firm belief that access to endless information, regardless of quality, must be good.
But given the price and the lack of data on the benefits, the conviction that computers are fundamentally altering the modern era, and that therefore children ought to be involved with them at the earliest possible age, is facing an intellectual backlash.
Some of the skepticism is coming from computer experts themselves, who point out that since it doesn't take 12 years of school to master computers, they can become a distraction from other learning that takes longer. Automobiles also changed an era and schools now offer driving courses. But the classes last one semester and come later, in high school.
 
'A Glitzy Toy'
David J. Gelernter, professor of computer science at Yale, put the issue this way: "Computers themselves are fine. But we are in the middle of an education catastrophe. Children are not being taught to read, write, know arithmetic and history. In those circumstances, to bring a glitzy toy into the classroom seems to me to be a disaster. It reinforces our worst tendencies. The idea that children are in educational trouble because they don't have access to enough glitz and what they really need is a bigger database is staggeringly ludicrous. They need practice in the basics."
Raising questions about the costs and benefits of computers, Samuel G. Sava, executive director of the National Association of Elementary School Principals, wrote in this month's newsletter: "In the U.S., 37 percent of students use computers in at least some math lessons -- nearly triple the international average. Yet this increased use seemed to make no difference to our math results. In sum, if computers make a difference, it has yet to show up in achievement."
The computer debate is actually part of a larger one on the nature and purpose of education, on whether to emphasize the view of children as flowers to be cultivated or beasts to be tamed.
Mixed in with all the new-dawn perspective on computers is a strain of child liberation talk. Computers, many of its advocates insist, will free students from the constraints of authoritarian teachers and rote learning.
For this group, computers are producing a new kind of young intellectual explorer, what Don Tapscott, author of "Growing Up Digital" (McGraw Hill), calls the "Net Generation" and what Idit Harel, founder of MaMaMedia, a creative new educational Web site for children, calls "the clickerati."
Mr. Tapscott says that the current generation is "beginning to process information and learn differently than the boomers before them. New media tools offer great promise for a new model of learning -- one based on discovery and participation."
He, like Dr. Harel and others, says computers will allow a shift from teaching to "the creation of learning partnerships and learning cultures. The schools can become a place to learn rather than a place to teach."
The other side of the argument is often represented by Clifford Stoll, an astronomer and computer expert in Oakland, Calif., who says learning, no matter what the tool for it, will not -- and should not -- change.
 
'Learning Is Work'
"Maybe I'm the weird one," Mr. Stoll said, "but I never thought learning was supposed to be fun. It requires discipline, responsibility and attention in class. Learning is work. Turning scholarship and class work into a game is to denigrate the most important thing we can do in life. Someone has to react against all this bogus stuff."
And yet, the stuff may not be all bogus.
Research on the impact of computers on learning has produced some encouraging results, at least in the upper grades. College and high school students learning algebra with computers have done markedly better than those without them in a series of tests, according to Kenneth R. Koedinger, professor of psychology and computer science at Carnegie-Mellon University.
And while basics like reading and arithmetic have not yet been shown to be affected, other skills like communication, presentation and initiative-taking have been.
Many experts also point to the ease with which writing and editing are done on a computer screen and to a computer's ability to track individual achievement by recording the progress of each child.
As a better edited, age-appropriate version of the Web is provided to youngsters, by Scholastic, MaMaMedia and the like, the more useful computers will be.
Linda G. Roberts, director of the Office of Educational Technology of the Department of Education, says that I.B.M. is on the verge of a breakthrough whereby computers will recognize the individual speech of pupils, allowing the machines to give feedback to children reading aloud.
The difficulty, of course, is that technology developers always seem to be on the verge of something big and it is hard to know which high-priced invention will pan out. Early Apple computers, seen as so vital a decade ago, were never much used and are sitting in dusty corners of schoolrooms across the country. CD-ROM's may go the way of the phonograph if the Internet really becomes easy to manipulate.
 
Rethinking
Meanwhile, billions of dollars are spent, music and art programs suffer neglect, libraries go unstocked. And therein lies the dilemma.
"At the moment, the most mindless use of computers is at the elementary school level," said Judah L. Schwartz, professor of education at Harvard University. "I hope that the introduction of computers will produce a rethinking of the structure and content of the curriculum. In fact, if putting computers in the schools produces only that, it will make it all worth it."

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
The Metropolis in a Square Block

BYLINE: By MARCIA BIEDERMAN 

 BODY:
A SIGN on a building at the corner of Seventh Avenue and West 18th Street bears the names of two dentists, Dr. Andrew B. Schenkel and Dr. Joseph Sachs. "Used to be just Dr. Schenkel," said Tom Shachtman, struggling to contain his curiosity as he walked past. "I haven't called them. At this point I'd just be bothering them."
Not long ago, any evidence of change in the commerce of this block would have found Mr. Shachtman on the scene, notebook in hand. An award-winning documentary film maker and author of books on subjects from serial killers to beautiful villages in New England, Mr. Shachtman has just come out with a new book, "Around the Block: The Business of a Neighborhood" that chronicles a year in the life of one square block of Manhattan, from Seventh to Eighth Avenues between 17th and 18th Streets. 
 Starting in spring 1993, this chunk of Chelsea became his Samoa. In his scrutiny of entrepreneurial life, he came to admire virtually every small business owner he studied.
"I was knocked out by how hard they all work, how much raw intelligence they bring to the task," Mr. Shachtman said.
Though the book has enough nuts-and-bolts economics to qualify as a text in a business course, he has a Master of Fine Arts degree in theater, not an M.B.A. One could almost hear Gypsy Rose Lee's mother singing about her disdain for the humdrum life in "Some People" from the musical "Gypsy," as Mr. Shachtman spoke of "a certain vitality to small business that appeals to people who want more than to just pay the rent."
Though he says he chose the block for its ordinariness, it served up a generous share of human drama. Maxwell Lumber, for example, owes its continued family ownership to a suicide committed for insurance money. Jung-ok Hwang, the Korean-born owner of the House of Cheers liquor store, who had bought and sold furs in Europe and Canada, had to take courses to learn about wine and the liquor business before the Italian owner of the shop would agree to sell it to him.
Mostly, though, the book chronicles mundane setbacks and advances: a dry cleaner's sacrifice of space to raise money for repairs, the instant success of a bakery's oversized muffin, a bicycle messenger service's race against fax machines. Triumphs were in abundance.
Mr. Shachtman said he chose the year of his study arbitrarily. "I thought, let's snip off these frames of film and see what we can see there," he recalled. It turned out to be an action movie. A budding economic recovery, relatively low rents and Chelsea's booming gay scene had entrepreneurs primed for risk-taking, and that is what stirs Mr. Shachtman's blood.
His interest in business did not, however, entice him into the midsized Manhattan textile concern founded by his grandfather and handed down to his father. Second-generation proprietors have a place in his book, but what fascinated him most were the neophytes, like Myron Michaels.
A former Long Island high school science teacher, Mr. Michaels opened an optical shop, Sight on Seventh, just as Mr. Shachtman began his research. Mr. Michaels, whose shop was initially criticized by a neighboring merchant for being "too Upper East Side," became progressively more hip, both in the kind of merchandise he carried and in the way he dressed, as he fell in love with the neighborhood.
It is not, strictly speaking, Mr. Shachtman's neighborhood. A Manhattan native who is 55, he lives in Greenwich Village with his wife, Harriet Shelare, who works in public relations, and a 17-year-old son, Daniel. (Another son, Noah, 26, is an editor at a New York publishing house.)
Mr. Shachtman, who has written 20 other books, several with co-authors, reports regularly to a desk at the Writers Room on Astor Place, which he calls "an urban writers' colony."
But for this book, he spent hours on "his" block in Chelsea, logging numbers of passers-by, watching waves of workers emerge from the subway in the morning and conducting exhaustive interviews in grubby printing shops and glitzy restaurants.
With more than 100 little businesses and only 3 big ones (at the time, Barneys New York; Cahners, a publishing company; and Nynex), the block generated a gross annual product Mr. Shachtman estimated at $1.5 billion for 1992, about 0.5 percent of the city's total. It was an ideal laboratory. Mr. Shachtman interviewed the owners of some 75 businesses.
He had already studied family businesses in "Skyscraper Dreams: The Great Real Estate Dynasties of New York," published by Little, Brown in 1991. In "Around the Block" he wanted to explore the dreams of more modest business owners. His enthusiasm for the people he met during his research for that book had him itching to take a visitor around the block, where, he said, "I'm not a well-known neighborhood character. I am more a fly-on-the-wall thing."
But this is a fly who knows how to buzz with the locals. He dropped by House of Cheers to say hello to Mr. Hwang, and stopped into James Harb's architecture studio, where he admired a photograph of a spectacular home Mr. Harb had built in the Catskills. At the Chisholm-Larsson Gallery, he chatted with Robert Chisholm, the gallery's co-owner, about a recent exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
Mr. Shachtman's book has been well thumbed by some of its subjects. "Of course when I saw it had an index, who could resist going to those parts first?" said Mr. Chisholm, whom Mr. Shachtman credits with being a pioneer on the block, even before Barneys New York stamped the area as chi-chi in the early 80's with its expansion and purchases of real estate.
Mr. Harb, who opened his office on the block around that time because Barney's had commissioned several projects from his firm, said, "I found it very illuminating that on this little block one walks every day there are eight million stories." He added, "I think the neighborhood is such a terrific mix."
In Mr. Shachtman's view, small businesses will remain part of the mix. Barney's downtown store is closed, and some of the other businesses discussed in the book have failed or relocated. But half of them have expanded or plan to, he said.
Mr. Shachtman says "Around the Block" is not an only-in-New-York story. "It could be replicated all over the United States," he said, in cities with pockets of similar population density and affluence. But even if names and addresses were concealed, this Chelsea block would be about as well disguised as Gotham City.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Shachtman in the Viceroy restaurant at Eighth Avenue and 18th Street, part of the square block he made his laboratory. (Philip Greenberg for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "PULSE -- STREET ACTION"
Some examples of the ebb and flow of commerce on one Chelsea block from 1993 to 1994:
 
CALL IT LUCK -- A radio host criticizes the Raymond Dragon boutique on Seventh Avenue and 17th Street for its window display of two scantily clad male mannequins embracing. Passersby spit on the window but the display draws customers. The store launches a catalog and expands its manufacturing business.
 
ARTIST IN, SCHOOL OUT -- William Wegman, known for his Weimeraner photographs, buys the West 18th Street building that houses the Chelsea Day School and puts in a studio and rooms for dogs. The school moves to West 14th Street.
 
GOING UPSCALE -- The Pasta Pot, a struggling shabby restaurant on the southeast corner of 18th Street and Eighth Avenue, finally closes. A sleek new bistro, the Viceroy, takes its place and packs them in.
 
PACKING IT IN -- With mounting debts, outmolded equipment and an inability to broaden his client base, Carl Berman folds his business on West 18th Street, Guild Mailing Service, in the spring of 1994. Mr. Berman, an amateur herpetologist who collects rare lizards, moves upstate.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
South Korean Chaos Could Eventually Mean Opportunity

BYLINE: By ANNE TERGESEN

 BODY:
AN investor in the Mexican stock market at the beginning of 1995, when the country was mired in a currency crisis, could have doubled his money over the last three years.
So with the International Monetary Fund putting together an aid package for South Korea, aggressive investors are no doubt pondering: Will stock opportunities prove to be as appealing this time around?
With its mighty industrial base, educated work force, and high savings rate, South Korea may well be a good place for investment in the long run. But as was true with Mexico, there is no reason to rush in. 
 Even though the devaluation of the Mexican peso occurred in late 1994, and an American-led rescue was cobbled together quickly, the stock market did not hit bottom until March 1995. Anyone who sat out the entire year and then ventured into the Mexican market still enjoyed a 75 percent gain for the last two years.
In South Korea, the political and financial situation will remain uncertain for some time. The I.M.F. has not yet announced its proposals for change in return for financial assistance. And a new Government in South Korea -- to be elected on Dec. 18 -- will have to set its economic policies.
Even in the best-case scenario, if the country's leaders muster the political will to take austerity measures, strengthen the banking system and secure a generous international aid package, South Korea will not return to financial health soon.
"Countries do not emerge from banking crises in six months," said Morris Goldstein, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics and a former I.M.F. official. "It usually takes three to four years."
Given the unpredictability of the financial crisis engulfing Southeast Asia, caution is urged in South Korea.
"Certainly, it is not a time for the general investor to look at investing," said Jeffrey Shafer, vice chairman of Salomon Brothers International and Under Secretary for International Affairs at the Treasury Department during Mexico's crisis. Still, "people who know the country very well may be able to find attractive opportunities."
After paring their holdings to the bone, some money managers specializing in Asia are starting to bottom-fish. They say the slide this year in Korean stocks, 37 percent in the local currency and 54 percent in dollars, has left several of the country's healthier blue chips trading at fire-sale prices.
"I don't see how these world-class companies can go down any more," said Frank Chiang, manager of the Montgomery Emerging Asia Fund, who added that he sold his Korean holdings in early November. "When market sentiment changes, these stocks should pick up 20 to 30 percent."
Mr. Chiang said he would tiptoe into a few Korean stocks in the next few weeks, stopping at about 2 percent of his $35 million portfolio, which has declined 19 percent this year through October. The market now trades for well below book value, he said, versus one to two times book a year ago.
John J. Lee, manager of Scudder, Stevens & Clark's closed-end Korea Fund, likes Pohang Iron and Steel, known as Posco. Stock in the steel producer is now trading for less than 10 times this year's expected earnings. The American depository receipts closed Friday at $16.75. Because the amount that foreigners can own in a South Korean company is limited, foreign investors paid a premium of 40 percent for Posco as recently as three months ago, he said. That premium has now virtually disappeared.
Mr. Lee said another good bet is SK Telecom, South Korea's dominant mobile telecommunications provider and his fund's biggest holding. Although he expects earnings to grow by a hefty 35 percent this year, the stock now trades for a mere 14 times this year's earnings. The A.D.R. closed Friday at $5.9375, and its premium has dwindled to 5 to 10 percent. Because his top priority is to insulate his fund -- already off 49 percent this year -- from excessive risk, Mr. Lee says he now has 15 percent in cash.
He is also sticking with large, well-known entities, particularly exporters whose goods will become more attractive as the Korean currency, the won, falls. He is shunning banks and companies with excessive debt.
Many of South Korea's problems can be traced to excessive Government influence in banking decisions, a practice that has caused banks to funnel loans to favored companies regardless of risk. In recent years, that has led to excessive investment in the automobile and petrochemical industries, among others. With other Asian countries pursuing similar markets, seven of Korea's vaunted industrial conglomerates have gone bankrupt this year, leaving the nation's banks with a mounting pile of bad loans -- much of it to be repaid to foreigners in yen, dollars and marks. With the won losing value, that debt has become expensive to service, and foreign lenders are reluctant to roll it over.
Though the I.M.F.'s presence will help, recent declines in the Thailand and Indonesian markets have shown that it will not be enough. To win investors' confidence, South Korea will need to make significant changes in its banking system, improve corporate disclosure, strengthen regulatory agencies, open its financial markets and break the lifetime employment habit in corporations. This bitter medicine could depress the economy and stock prices even further.
Even worse, if Asia's troubled economies unleash exports onto world markets, Korean companies could be caught in debilitating price wars with rivals.
"Earnings are not necessarily going to be there in the short term," said Douglas Wilde, international investment strategist at Merrill Lynch. "If you are willing to take a longer-term view -- say, from three to five years -- you could be generously rewarded, because Korean companies are world-class companies and they will come back."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Fitness Gurus

BYLINE: By EDWARD LEWINE 

 BODY:
THE man and the woman were facing each other, crouched down low, their arms out in front of them as if to ward off blows. They were sweating as they hopped around menacingly to the arena rock thumping in the low, hot, mirrored basement of the Crunch gym on Lafayette Street. Then the instructor barked a short command and Michael Linstroth, a 25-year-old actor, grabbed the right arm of a 25-year-old teacher named Robyn Poarch and slung her over his shoulder.
A coed wrestling class may not seem like the ideal activity at 9 A.M. on a cold, damp November Saturday, but about 10 women and 4 men, most in their 20's, showed up for it. The program, which was really more aerobics than wrestling, lasted about an hour, and when it was over the reviews were ecstatic. 
 "How many times do you get to flip a woman in public and get praised for it?" said Mr. Linstroth, chuckling.
Even by the city's Darwinian standards, competition in the New York gym business is tough these days. From employing drag-queen aerobics instructors and live deejays in the weight room to installing in-line-skating-simulation machines, the local gyms are trying harder than ever to entertain their jaded customers.
"Ten years ago New York was lackluster in its development of first-rate, dynamic, energized and entertaining fitness clubs," said John McCarthy of the International Health, Racquet and Sportsclub Association. "Today it has taken the lead from Los Angeles in terms of trends."
The owners of the hot local gyms -- the New York gym gurus -- are driving this. Most of them are survivors of the 80's when the aerobics studios folded into the weight-lifting rooms and health spas to form full-service gyms; and of the 90's when there was a gym-building boom and many less savvy operators went under.
Today the gurus are tensing up for a new round of conflict. Most plan to open new sites and while they all offer just about the same equipment and services, they have strikingly different visions of the future.
Roland W. Betts of the Sports Center at Chelsea Piers is banking on a huge, mall-like gym with an accent on sports, while Bob Giardina of New York Sports Clubs has the Gap approach. He wants a gym in every neighborhood. Doug Levine of Crunch is using theatrical exercises and marketing techniques to sell his gyms and his products to the MTV generation while the Erricos of Equinox Fitness Clubs are promoting wellness to stay in touch with the aging customer. Alan Finger sees the future in yoga. David Barton is keeping it simple. And Richard Miller of the Gym Source is looking for the next hot exercise machine.
They shy away from criticizing one another in public, but behind the scenes they are locked in a death struggle for clients, gym-friendly real estate and most important, the sexy new trends that will keep them ahead of the curve. Some of what they come up with may seem a bit over the top, but there are hard business reasons behind it.
"The real reason is nobody wants to exercise," Mr. Miller said.
Conventional wisdom is that gyms lose at least 20 percent of their members a year because most members find exercise boring and frustrating. The successful gyms are those who have learned to keep their members happy by distracting them with endless rounds of new gadgets and games. And a new trend can give a gym identity.
Whatever their strategies are, all of the gyms are planning to expand and many of them have gone into debt to do so. And there are many people in the business who believe that not all of them will survive, particularly if there is a downturn in the economy.
"There will be a shakeout in this industry," said Kevin Sagafi, chief operating officer of New York Health and Racquet Club. "Some of the clubs will go down and they will be bought out by the others."
On the other hand, there are many who say that as the baby boomers worry more about death, and as the children they raised to believe in fitness get some money, the gym boom will be booming for some time.
"I think there is still room for more clubs, which is sort of amazing," said Nicole Dorsey, who covers the gyms for Fitness magazine.
Ponder the future of fitness with the gym gurus of New York.
 
 
 
Roland Betts And the Show at Chelsea Piers
 The six-lane swimming pool at the Sports Center at Chelsea Piers was filled with grown men and women, their bodies stuffed into large inner tubes, their legs in the air. It was 9 P.M. on a recent Thursday and they were sloshing around after a little ball, laughing and shrieking at the referee of this weekly game of coed inner tube water polo.
"This is like being on vacation," said a 37-year-old pet-supply retailer, Amy Shapiro, as she relaxed in the hot tub after the game. "This is, in essence, a place to play."
Ms. Shapiro's reaction is music to the ears of Mr. Betts, 51, a movie producer who is part-owner of the Texas Rangers and the Chelsea Piers complex, where the Sports Center is located. It is Mr. Betts's vision that the future of gyms lies in combining sports that people do for fun, like basketball, Rollerblading and water polo, with the more traditional forms of exercise like running or weight lifting. His idea is to make his gym fun, rather than a place for a quick, painful workout.
"People care about the equipment they work out on and they want all the sports," Mr. Betts said. "This is a place not to spend a half hour, but to spend a good amount of time."
Most clubs combine sports with exercise these days. But the Sports Center, which opened in 1996, has taken this to a new level. Members don't just take a kick-boxing class, they learn in an actual ring. They don't kayak in a pool but in the Hudson River. When they run, they do so on a quarter-mile indoor track. Volleyball games are at an indoor sand beach. Aside from its sophisticated equipment, the Sports Center's main advantage is its size; it is built on a restored pier that juts about three football fields into the river, giving the gym 150,000 square feet of space on one level.
The Sports Center is part of a movement toward building ever-larger gyms. The Reebok Sports Club/NY, a 140,000-square-foot gym on six floors, opened on 67th Street and Columbus Avenue in 1995. Mr. Betts and Nanette Pattee Francini, who lives in Los Angeles and runs the Reebok club in New York, say the future is in such big gyms, which can offer the best of everything under one roof. It's the mall approach.
 
 
 
Bob Giardina: The Gap Approach
 But there are many in the gym business who say that New Yorkers prize quickness and convenience above all else.
Bob Giardina, the president of New York Sports Clubs, envisions a neighborhood gym of the future with a lightning-fast check-in system, computer kiosks that give members useful information and a gym that can easily be converted as exercise fashions change.
"The focus here becomes, how can I get you what you need in the quickest amount of time and still make it entertaining and fun," said Mr. Giardina, a lively 40-year-old who has been in the business about 20 years.
His first step is having as many gyms as possible. New York Sports already has 30 places in the city, and the company just raised around $85 million to buy at least 10 more. At about $1,100 for a first-year membership, the clubs do not feature all the luxury of a Reebok, the city's most expensive at about $3,000 for initiation and a year's dues, or the grand gadgetry of a Chelsea Piers, which is about $1,400 for the first year.
"New York Sports is the club that ate New York," said Ms. Dorsey of Fitness magazine. "It is a quality club for the masses."
Mr. Giardina is experimenting with electronic check-in cards that will allow faster entry and exit and allow his staff to monitor when, where and how long each of the company's 80,000 New York City clients is using the gyms. If a client is not coming, he or she will receive a telephone call asking if there is anything New York Sports can do to improve the situation. Personal attention like this, Mr. Giardina says, will become more important as competition between gyms grows.
He is also anticipating that stretching will become quite important as more people deal with exercise-related injuries. But New York Sports gyms are not designed with any areas dedicated to one fitness trend. Mr. Giardina envisions the gym of the future as an empty box filled with equipment that can be moved in, out and around as exercise tastes change.
"If I am flexible and stay close to my customer then I don't need to know how I'm going to change," he said. "I know I'll be able to do it."
One way that he intends to stay close is through computers. Today, you can log on to the gym's Web site and get a trial membership, or discover the times and locations of classes they want to take. Soon they will be able to use interactive terminals at the gyms to learn about nutrition, plan a workout, meet other gym members or advertise their business.
 
 
 
Doug Levine: Sweat and Theater
 High up in his University Place office, Doug Levine, the 38-year-old former stockbroker who started Crunch in 1989, is pondering a future in which gyms and exercises will become more theatrical and gym logos will be marketable on clothing and other products. An example of his thinking is at the just-opened Crunch in Los Angeles, where a frosted-glass passage runs between the men's and women's showers, exposing the outlines of the bathers to passers-by.
"People say Crunch is like a record company," Mr. Levine said. "We try to find the next hit."
Mr. Levine has five gyms in New York, in addition to the one each in Los Angeles and Tokyo. Membership costs about $800 a year. But what keeps the gym's mostly young clientele coming back is its skillful marketing, which tries to stay one step ahead in an urban, self-mocking and inclusive way. Crunch's motto is: "No judgments."
One typical Crunch advertisement features a photograph of a man in a bunny suit holding a basketball and standing by a graffiti-covered wall. The text reads: "The thing that really creeps me out about basketball is when you're playing against some guy you've never met before, yet he knows all this secret stuff about your mama."
Exercise classes at Crunch are also outlandish. In addition to coed wrestling, members can take Abs, Thighs and Gossip, presided over by a drag queen named Anthony Truly, who says things like, "It's no fun being beautiful if nobody hates you"; recently the club offered Cyked, a yoga class taught on stationary bicycles in a candle-lighted room; and a current offering is Capoeira, described as an "Afro-Brazilian blend of dance, aerobics and self-defense." It is this kind of class that Mr. Levine hopes to parlay into salable products.
Crunch now sells creams for hair and skin, videos, CD's and clothing. There are plans in the works for sneaker and sunglasses lines. The Crunch exercise program is broadcast twice a day on the cable station ESPN2.
On the gym front, Mr. Levine is looking to put exercise machines in virtual-reality caves that would simulate any environment or let the exerciser play a video game. Other ideas under development are rooms that act as living video games. Chelsea Piers already has something like this: a floor covered in large dots that light randomly while a person hops around trying to touch them.
 
 
 
Richard Miller: The Limits of Technology
 Recently, manufacturers have been experimenting with strength-training machines that can add or subtract weight electronically and tell the user whether he or she is lifting that weight properly. Richard Miller of the Gym Source says this approach will not work.
"People love to put on the weight themselves and hear them crash," he said. "It's people's last link to being physically bohemian."
Mr. Miller was sitting in the basement office of his store on East 52d Street recently, surrounded by a veritable medieval torture chamber of metal and plastic devices. Where he does see computerization working is in so-called cardiovascular machines like treadmills, stationary bicycles and rowing machines.
"The cardio machines will get more computerized, especially in monitoring the body," he said. "And there will be a great deal of virtual reality."
The talk around the gyms is that elevating one's heart rate to specific levels for specific amounts of time is the most efficient way to get results. So the newest machines have metal pads on the handlebars to show one's heart rate. The equipment will also do more and more things to divert and inform.
"You will be able to watch television, log on to the Internet, trade bonds," Mr. Miller said. "And the machine will remember every time you ever exercised on it."
 
 
 
The Erricos Appeal to Aging Boomers
 If you want to know where the Errico siblings, Lavinia, Vito and Danny, think the gym business is going, head over to the 45,000-square-foot Equinox gym they are constructing at 63d and Lexington. Pass the juice bar and the retail shop, the aerobics and spinning studios, the sound-proofed yoga room, the pool and the spa. And go directly to the women's showers, where each client has her own changing stall.
"We know that our customers are getting older," Vito Errico said. "And with that new dynamic, we really felt that people might like more privacy."
The Erricos will have five gyms in the city when the Lexington branch opens in December. Like the gyms, the siblings are chic, upscale and a little flashy. It costs about $1,400 for a first-year membership.
The age of the gym client is going up in general, as the baby boomers move into middle age. The Equinox theory is that people in their 30's and 40's are less concerned with being thin and more concerned with feeling good, and that people in their 50's and up just want to stay healthy.
"When we first got into this it was all physical," Lavinia Errico said. "Now we realize that you can be fit but unhealthy."
Equinox is betting on a future in which people use gyms for what is often referred to in the business as mind-body. The approach includes stretching, dietary changes, vitamin supplements (which Equinox will sell) and meditation to promote good digestion, sleep, sex and a sense of well-being.
"In the future, insurance companies are going to work with health clubs to make sure their clients are staying healthy," said Mr. Sagafi, of the New York Health and Racquet Club, which features underwater treadmills for older knees. "There will also be physical therapists in gyms."
 
 
 
Alan Finger: Betting on Yoga
 About 40 people stood on mats, bent at the waist, with their left arms pointed at the ceiling. Alan Finger, the founder of Yoga Zone, a five-year-old company with two locations in the city, walked among them, his hand straying here and there to correct a posture.
"In and out," he said in his South African accent. "Exhale. Hold your breath. Use your breath to start to shape your consciousness."
In Mr. Finger's view, the future of physical fitness will not entirely belong to the gyms. He knows that almost all of the aerobics studios of the 80's were forced to close when gyms began to offer their sport. He also knows that gyms are now all offering yoga. But he says there is room for a smaller studio.
"Yoga will grow more and more," Mr. Finger said. "The gyms will try to incorporate yoga, but I think yoga is too profound and deep to be merged into a gym, because it is spiritual."
Mr. Finger, and his wife, Greta, have taken on a partner -- Howard Maier, the man responsible for the famed "Buns of Steel" videos -- and have just come out with their first catalogue of products and a yoga-at-work program. But they are not about to add many new studios or sell out to the gyms.
 
 
 
David Barton Getting Personal
 While his competitors race to add every new service available and expand as fast as they can, David Barton, who has three gyms in the city, is taking a more conservative approach. "I don't want to be all things to all people," he said, though he said he will add a few gyms.
Mr. Barton is an unlikely spokesman for simplicity. He is a 33-year-old fire plug of a man, so laden with muscles that it affects his posture, who is given to dying his hair and wearing T-shirts that say: "Look better naked." It is his theory that the future will go to gyms that are small, offer personal training and achieve results with as basic and economical a workout as possible.
"There will be a gym on every corner," he said. "And a place that can get results will win out over this corporate fast-food philosophy."
 
At Low End, Health's Not What Counts
THE future of gyms does not belong just to the rich and famous. Lucille Roberts, an immigrant from Siberia who opened her first gym in 1969 and has big plans, caters to the low-cost customer.
"It is only the upper classes who are into exercise for health," she said. "The middle classes just want to look good. We have tried health classes. They just want to fit into tight jeans."
In New York City, most of the cheaper gyms -- say, those under $700 for a year's membership -- are the less-sophisticated neighborhood clubs with only one or two locations. Many are being bought by chains, especially New York Sports Clubs, which upgrade them and charge more.
For Lucille Roberts, whose gyms are named after her, the key to the future is rapid expansion and corporate uniformity.
"We are working on a standardized exercise program," said Ms. Roberts, who says her under-$200-a-year gyms are pitched at female clients like the secretary, the teacher and the policeman's wife. "It will be like a McDonald's, where you know what you get in every place."
Each gym would have a computer with instructions that would tell staff members how to arrange the equipment, run the club and teach exercise classes down to the last step. In short, members would have the same experience, no matter which Lucille Roberts club they worked out in.
This year, Ms. Roberts bought 17 gyms in the region from the troubled Living Well Lady chain. She now has 47 clubs in the area. The 24 in the city have more than 300,000 members. Her plans are to double those numbers in the next decade and to franchise her name across the world.
Ms. Roberts says that lower- and middle-income customers need new machines and new exercises just as wealthier ones do. But with all the innovations and differing recipes for good health, she also sees a backlash.
"People are very confused with everything that is out there," she said. "They don't know what to do, and so they are headed back to basics." EDWARD LEWINE

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Paying Off a Mortgage: Is Fast Always Smart?

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
FOR years, prepaying a mortgage by putting extra money toward principal each month seemed like sound financial advice for those who have extra cash. Recently, lenders have started preaching the prepayment gospel with a new fervor, aggressively marketing mortgages that are paid off every other week rather than monthly, one of the hot products in the home loan business these days.
And at first glance, these loans -- known as biweekly mortgages -- look like no-brainers; make 26 half payments a year instead of 12 full payments, and the extra annual payment shortens a 30-year home loan to about 22 years, saves a homeowner tens of thousands of dollars in interest and builds equity much faster. Many biweeklies are based on direct withdrawals of the payment by the bank, too; lenders love this, as it takes away the borrower's "float" and eliminates paperwork. 
 The hype, however, may not match the amount of help these biweekly mortgages provide borrowers. "I don't think there is a tremendous benefit to the biweekly mortgage -- it's nominal at best," said Neil E. Bader, the chief executive of Skyscraper Mortgage Company, a mortgage broker in Manhattan.
He said that a borrower, before prepaying a mortgage, should always pay off non-deductible debt and debt that has a higher interest rate than the family mortgage -- which means virtually all debt, especially on credit cards. "If you get a mortgage at like 7 or 8 percent, you are really only paying 4 or 5 percent after the tax deduction," Mr. Bader said. "It's probably the cheapest money you will ever borrow."
Then there is the time value of money. Even in these low inflation days, it matters. Why pay off a long-term loan with 1997 dollars? Ten years from now, that same monthly mortgage payment will have, effectively, shrunk by 30 to 50 percent even if inflation stays at 2 to 4 percent over the next 10 years. "When you take inflation into account, and most people don't, I don't really think it pays to prepay," Mr. Bader said.
Consider, too, the fees on biweekly mortgages. Lenders say they like biweeklies because such mortgages reap a little extra fee income and keep customers happy and in the lender's loan portfolio; they charge up to $500 in advance and $5 or so a month for the life of the loan to convert an existing mortgage to a biweekly schedule or originate one. On a $100,000 mortgage, that means a borrower would be paying the equivalent of a half a point, just for this service. (A point is an origination fee that is equal to 1 percent of the mortgage amount; by paying points up front, a borrower can obtain a lower interest rate.)
Small change compared with the thousands saved by paying biweekly? Well, true. But also consider that prepaying is something borrowers can do quite easily themselves -- for free -- on most mortgages.
Keep in mind, too, that a borrower who has a biweekly mortgage has, essentially, a 22-year mortgage rather than the 30-year loan she qualified for. That sounds great if the only reason she took a 30-year was because she could not qualify for a shorter-term loan.
But considering that with a biweekly mortgage the lender's interest rate exposure is shortened, in theory, the interest rate on the loan should be lowered, as well. At least, that's what happens when a homeowner chooses a 15-year mortgage instead of a 30-year mortgage. The gap between the interest rate for the two terms is currently about a third of a percentage point.
Small change again? Sure, but if that biweekly mortgage was even a sixth of a percentage point lower than the 30-year rate, the savings would cover the fees for the program and then some.
"Biweekly mortgages are unnecessary, and there are very few people for whom they would be a good idea," said Marc Eisenson of Elizaville, N.Y., an authority on mortgage prepayments and the author of "The Banker's Secret." (Good Advice Press, 800-255-0899)
Mr. Eisenson says those who still want to prepay can -- by making the regular monthly payment, then adding any prepayment amount, for example, one-twelfth of the regular monthly principal payment.
Making the extra payments that way also gives a borrower flexibility; should a financial calamity hit -- layoff, illness -- the borrower can scale back to the regular payment.
Of course, flexibility is also the reason why most people cannot stick to a voluntary program of accelerated payments. John P. David and Pamela J. Gonsky bought a home in Miami in April and recently converted their $154,000, 30-year mortgage to a biweekly one.
"Like most people with a new 30-year mortgage, we have grand plans to try to pay off our mortgage earlier, make payments against the principal and try to cut the term, " said Mr. David, a public relations executive. "But we haven't made any additional payments, yet. Maybe with the 'accelerated payments' as they call it, we can make a dent just by paying every other week -- and have something to hold us to it, like direct deposit."
Though they will save $90,000 in interest over 20 years with a biweekly mortgage, Mr. David also said it was unlikely that they would keep this loan that long, so the savings would be smaller; on average, mortgages are paid for seven years before the home is sold or the loan refinanced. He noted, too, that they will pay about $1,500 in fees over the life of the loan. "Unfortunately, the banks have a zillion ways to take our money," he said. "At least, in this case, I get some benefit."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 3; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1826 words

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
The Shoe Leather Debate

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
AMID the typical pre-Thanksgiving torpor and buzz, a few clues last week hinted that something was amiss at the New York University Department of Journalism and Mass Communication. There were the uncollected messages on the office door of the graduate studies' chairman. The cancellation of his Tuesday class. And the letter posted in the elevator that announced, in the terse style of a man accustomed to economy of expression, his resignation.
The decision by the chairman, William Serrin, to quit the helm of N.Y.U.'s graduate program in journalism after two and a half years came less than a week after a rancorous faculty meeting that had been convened to discuss the future direction of the department. Mr. Serrin's make-the-deadline approach (he is a former New York Times reporter) angered some faculty members; he, in turn, described some of the criticism at the meeting as "savage." 
 The dispute reflects a larger debate about how journalism education should respond to changes in the profession, where the definition of news seems to be constantly shifting and traditional media like newspapers, magazines and television are both embracing and competing with new media like Web sites.
For N.Y.U., the question is whether to emphasize an intellectual attitude toward journalism that encourages students to analyze and critique the media or to focus primarily on teaching practical skills like its uptown rival, the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.
"The division is over whether the profession can best be improved through criticism or through performance," said Michael Norman, who teaches writing and a course on journalistic traditions at N.Y.U.
Mr. Serrin, who as head of the department had made an effort to upgrade instruction in reporting and writing, said he had worked "to keep a foot in both camps." But some faculty members still saw him as more of a traditionalist.
The Columbia program, often called the boot camp of journalism because of the way it intensively drills students in the skills of reporting and writing, has also been re-evaluating itself. But the school, now under the stewardship of a new dean, Tom Goldstein, has long been committed to a nuts-and-bolts approach to training future journalists. Its response to the changes in the profession has been largely practical. It is putting the finishing touches on a Center for New Media, for example, and all students are now required to master the basics of print, broadcasting and computer-based media.
And though the school is in the midst of what Mr. Goldstein called a self-study, administrators are exploring not the philosophical underpinnings of the program but such questions as whether it has too many students, whether it crams too intense a workload into nine months and whether it should add courses so students could specialize in particular areas, like business or art.
While journalism at Columbia is taught in a separate professional school in the university, journalism at N.Y.U. is taught in a department in the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences. Perhaps that helps explain why the N.Y.U. program has a more academic bent.
At N.Y.U., there seem to be as many answers to the question of what a journalism education should offer as there are faculty members. "It's a very democratic department," said William Burrows, a professor there for 23 years. "Maybe to a fault." Mr. Serrin said there has been a longstanding split between the "critics and essayists" and the "so-called professional journalists."
Mr. Norman, another former New York Times reporter, is among those who argue that the department ultimately serves students and the profession best by teaching aspiring journalists to write and report.
"I think we need to embrace the profession much more," he said. "We need more programs to bring professionals in, and we need to send professors out to work in newspapers."
Robert Manoff, the director of the department's Center for War, Peace and the News Media, favors what he calls a "radical approach." He said the program should push students "to get at not the situational truth, but the existential truth," and to say "something deep about the human condition."
Mitchell Stephens, a department professor who studies the fall of the written word and the rise of the image, put it this way: "Instead of merely replicating the practice of journalism, we are trying to encourage it at its most thoughtful." He added, "This is where journalism is being rethought."
In the N.Y.U. journalism department, where it takes three semesters to earn a master's degree, the curriculum seems as eclectic as the faculty. The offerings include, on the one hand, "Writing and Reporting I" with Richard Blood, an adjunct professor and newspaper traditionalist who says he resents seeing people who have never practiced journalism teaching it. "Details, details, details," Mr. Blood thundered at students in a class on feature writing. "Show, don't tell. Too many of you tell me, tell me, tell me."
On the other hand, there is a course called "The Journalistic Tradition," which covers Dickens through Joan Didion. One of its instructors is Jay Rosen, a professor who is also head of the department's Project on Public Life and the Press and who has been a key figure in the controversial public journalism movement, whose supporters argue that journalists have an obligation to promote good citizenship. In a recent seminar, Mr. Rosen led students through a discussion of the points of view a reporter could take on any given story, before analyzing Norman Mailer's coverage of the 1960 Democratic National Convention.
At Columbia's Journalism School, the basic courses have expanded over the years to include broadcast and new media, but most of the course work still focuses on developing skills and professional ethics. During the two semesters it takes students to earn a master's degree in journalism, many students spend more time prowling the city for stories than debating ideas in class. Few do internships, unlike their counterparts at N.Y.U., who can get course credit for work at a newspaper, magazine, broadcast outlet or Internet company.
When it comes to reputation, Columbia has the edge. For one thing, it is more competitive. Out of 1,005 applicants for this year's class, 291, or 29 percent, were accepted. N.Y.U. received 400 applications from prospective students who wanted to enroll last fall and accepted 180, or 45 percent, of them.
Though a Columbia degree is no guarantee of a job -- many graduates end up in careers outside journalism -- the perception among applicants is that the program opens doors, in part because there are plenty of alumni in high-ranking media positions. That perception may be why more than three-quarters of those who were accepted into this year's class decided to enroll, compared with about half of those admitted to N.Y.U.'s graduate program.
"Columbia has the pedigree; N.Y.U. is more innovative and dynamic," said David Dent, a Columbia Journalism School alumnus who teaches journalism at N.Y.U.
Situated in Greenwich Village, N.Y.U. is also geographically well situated for a romance with nearby Silicon Alley, a fact that has not gone unnoticed at Columbia's Journalism School. "For most people in Silicon Alley, anything above 59th Street is basically Maine," said Andrew Lih, the director of technology at Columbia's Center for New Media.
Yet it is Columbia that has surged ahead in providing an education in new media to students, some of whom plan to go on to jobs at Internet-oriented companies or to start their own Web businesses. N.Y.U., meanwhile, has been trying for months to find a new director of digital journalism; the previous director, John Garcia, left to take a job at MSNBC.
Still, the N.Y.U. journalism program has come a long way in the last decade. It has its own six-story building on Washington Place and a full-time faculty of 19, many hired since 1990. (Columbia has a faculty of 32.) Recently, N.Y.U. spent several hundred thousand dollars on computer equipment for the department, and N.Y.U.'s dean of arts and sciences, Philip Furmanski, has agreed to allow it to hire several new instructors.
"I certainly see them as competition," Dean Goldstein of Columbia said of N.Y.U.
But rather than challenging the Goliath uptown head-on, the N.Y.U. journalism department appears to be maneuvering around it by carving out specialized niches that will distinguish it from Columbia.
For example, N.Y.U.'s science and environmental reporting program, which Mr. Burrows started 15 years ago, has gained a reputation for producing science journalists. And the cultural reporting and criticism concentration, started in 1994 by Ellen Willis, the feminist writer, has drawn a diverse pool of students more interested in media or arts criticism or alternative journalism than daily newspaper work.
Ms. Willis said the concentration had been inspired partly by the failure of journalism schools to address the "explosion of journalistic forms that started in the mid-1960's." Students practice and study everything from "social milieu reporting" to performance art criticism, using Greenwich Village culture as fodder.
But the cultural concentration has its critics in the department. "It's much too narrowly focused," Mr. Norman said. "It's lower Manhattan cultural reporting and criticism. There is no attempt to embrace the mainstream strains of American culture."
The department is considering several new specializations, in urban affairs and, like Columbia, in business and economics. And it is trying to develop another niche where Columbia does not have a dominant presence: magazine editing. The plan is to have students learn the history of magazines and how to generate ideas for articles and new publications. The department recently called in editors from magazines like Mademoiselle, Newsweek and Money to bounce the idea off them and see if they would participate in the program.
In the wake of Mr. Serrin's resignation, several professors sounded optimistic, saying the faculty would find a way to blend its intellectual and professional missions. And some said that the diversity of opinion is one of the department's strengths. "If everyone thought how I thought," Mr. Burrows said, "I would quit."
But several students waxed somewhat nostalgic not just for their departing chairman but also for what he seemed to represent. Bo Rosser described it as "hard-core journalism experience." She said: "You need some people like that. Otherwise, you become way out there."
Mr. Goldstein, meanwhile, seemed inclined toward a little N.Y.U.-style noodling. "In my ideal world," he said, "we would have a course on evidence and judgment -- understanding how lawyers, sociologists, journalists know things, and how they make judgments, how they are influenced by market questions and cultural relativity."
