HEADLINE: Getting Credit for Being White

BYLINE: By Margaret Talbot; Margaret Talbot is a senior editor of The New Republic. This is her first article for the Magazine.

 BODY:
At the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, teaching part time on the faculty, there is a young academic who calls herself White Trash Girl. She's a performance artist of sorts: think Roseanne hopped up on post-structuralist theory, Larry Flynt toting an M.F.A. In a faux hillbilly accent, she will tell you all about her fictional identity as "an inbred biological disaster turned superhero," the product of "a 14-year-old girl and her funny uncle." She parades around the blue-collar neighborhood where she lives in tacky resplendence: white cowboy hat, T-shirts bearing slogans like "I'm baby soft," short, tight skirts. She makes White Trash Girl videos and trading cards, and is quick with pronouncements about the provocative importance of her own work, which, as it turns out, has as much to do with whiteness as it does with trashiness.
Laura Kipnis, an associate professor at Northwestern, interviewed White Trash Girl for a recent anthology called, yes, "White Trash." The interview gave White Trash Girl (whose real name is Jennifer Reeder) the opportunity to tell the world why embracing and exploring a white identity was an entirely justifiable pursuit. "I think a lot of people have this white guilt, so any reference to white culture becomes about white supremacy," she said., whereas she sees her whiteness as a fact that should never be ignored and that determines her point of view on just about everything. "It describes a certain esthetic, but I think it's also a socioeconomic situation, and a way of perceiving the world around you and your own place in the world." Reeder revels in white trashery -- and applauds herself for doing so. "I am busty, and I am loud, and I love bad taste. I am bad taste." 
 White Trash Girl represents an extreme -- the far shore where fanzine culture and art-school self-indulgence and identity-chic meet. Yet she is also perfectly representative, the mascot of a new, very hot academic field called whiteness studies. As a discipline in progress, whiteness studies offers many things, but among them is the promise that no groovy young theorist need ever be "just this white girl" or "just this white boy" again. For in taking as its subject white culture and white privilege, it accords whites the same kind of critical, even obsessive scrutiny that self-defined marginalized groups have long trained on themselves.
The emergence of whiteness studies has all the hallmarks of cutting-edge research in the humanities today: a casual disdain for liberalism and a romance with political extremes; a fondness for the confessional mode of writing; a serious infatuation with pop culture. The discipline, like a lot of trendy new scholarship, has produced some worthwhile history -- and a lot of silly posing. It is often fractured and incoherent; its central values have unintended and sometimes disturbing implications, and for all of these reasons, it offers a cautionary tale of sorts for life in academia now.
Intellectual trends move quickly on campus, almost as quickly as the pop culture to which they are often responding. And whiteness studies, whatever else it may turn out to be, is the academic trend du jour. Like porn studies a few years ago and queer theory before that, whiteness is furiously generating conferences and panels and dissertations and an entire cottage industry of textbook-style readers like "Critical White Studies" (Temple University Press, 1997); anthologies of modish, theory-driven essays like "Displacing Whiteness" (Duke University Press, 1997); carefully researched and often-illuminating historical studies of 19th-century America like Noel Ignatiev's "How the Irish Became White" and Grace Elizabeth Hale's forthcoming "Making Whiteness," an exploration of how whites in the post-slavery South remade the idea of white superiority.
There is even, in suburban New Jersey, a Center for the Study of White American Culture, which sponsors talks with titles like "Turn a Whiter Shade of Pale: The Search for an Alternate Albinity" and offers diversity consulting and sensitivity training to corporations. It promotes the idea that "consciousness on the topic of whiteness" helps "white Americans participate in building a multiracial society."
Contrary to the worst fears of conservative critics, academic courses on whiteness studies -- or porn studies or queer theory, for that matter -- have not yet replaced Beowulf or Chaucer, Austen or Dickens. They have merely taken their place alongside the canonical subjects. Liberal-arts departments today are like bazaars in which a little of everything is available and no one school of thought predominates.
In any case, nobody really wants to see whiteness honored with a department of its own; the whole idea is too politically sensitive. "If you got money for something like that, you'd wonder what the donor's motivations were," says Annalee Newitz, a Berkeley graduate student who co-edited White Trash" and spoke at a whiteness-studies conference on campus last May. "It's so open to misinterpretation and it's so easy to move in the direction of, 'Hey, let's hear it for white culture. Isn't Spam great?' "
Tucked into the undergraduate curriculum, whiteness studies might in time mean seminars on the history of blackface, the social geography of trailer parks, or the politics, such as they are, of white kids who love hip-hop. For now, it tends to mean asking white students to cogitate about being white, so that they might have some hope of shaking off what Sartre called the privilege of "seeing without being seen." At Macalester College in St. Paul, for example, an associate professor of anthropology named Anna Meigs teaches a class called "Race, Race Privilege, Whiteness" in which students interview their classmates about their experiences of racism and whiteness.
Of course, if whiteness studies is an academic whirligig, it is also the product of the world beyond the campus gates. Is it only coincidence that the scholarly preoccupation with so-called white trash has emerged now -- when we have an Elvis-imitating, fried-food-loving, quasi-good-ol'-boy from Arkansas in the White House? In some ways, whiteness studies can be seen as a means of smuggling considerations of class -- besmirched in recent decades by association with crude Marxism -- into the analysis of American society and culture. Maybe a period of economic prosperity like the one we're in now affords greater license to think about the class divisions that persist.
Then too, whiteness studies is almost certainly a symptom of the kind of agonized muddle that well-meaning white Americans tend to find themselves in when it comes to racial politics. Wouldn't it be easier to retreat into transfixed contemplation of one's own racial identity than to try to breathe new life into the project of integration? More charitably, might the first goal somehow serve the second? Some of the undergraduates who take whiteness studies courses seem to think so. For them, the classes offer the kind of consciousness-raising lessons they might get from, say, an African-American studies class, if they ever took one. "I went to high school in Lincoln, Nebraska, and I'd never really thought about the fact that almost all of the people I was surrounded with were white," says Amelia Buttress, a junior at Macalester who was in Professor Meigs's course last spring. "In the class we talked a lot about that kind of thing. Why are some places all white? Why, if you're white, don't you notice?"
Whiteness scholars say they want to examine what it means to be white in this country because they want to purge themselves of any remnants of racism. The goal, as they would put it, is to "problematize" whiteness. Yet the whole enterprise gives whites a kind of standing in the multicultural paradigm they have never before enjoyed. And it involves them, inevitably, in a journey of self-discovery in which white people's thoughts about their own whiteness acquire a portentous new legitimacy.
While ethnic studies and women's studies were premised on the assumption that their subjects were chronically understudied -- orphans of history to be brought in from the cold -- whiteness studies can hardly make the same claim, and it doesn't. The idea isn't that "European Americans" have not been studied enough; it is that they are always being studied, under another name. But ethnic studies has a certain logic, bequeathed to it by the idea of marginalized people moving to the center, and whiteness studies cannot entirely escape that logic -- the sense that in naming a new field of scholarship it is bestowing attention, and even validation, on the hitherto neglected. The risk is that by trying to limn something called white culture, you make a fetish of it.
"There's a suspicion among African-Americans that whiteness studies is a sneaky form of narcissism," says Michael Eric Dyson, a professor of African-American studies at Columbia University whose next book will be partly devoted to whiteness. "At the very moment when African-American studies and Asian-American studies and so on are really coming into their own, you have whiteness studies shifting the focus and maybe the resources back to white people and their perspective."
Not that the field of whiteness studies can really be described as a coherent whole. Though only a few years old, it has already given rise to hostile camps. There are those -- mostly younger, post-structuralist-type scholars -- who clearly adore the idea of white trash culture, for example. And there are those who think that it is naive and maybe dangerous to say there is any such thing as white culture.
In the former camp, you could include Annalee Newitz and Matt Wray, who together edited "White Trash," which along with the interview with White Trash Girl includes essays on slasher movies, Elvis worship, hillbilly lore and country music. And in the latter camp, you find scholars like Noel Ignatiev, a historian who edits a truculent little journal called "Race Traitor" (motto: "treason to whiteness is loyalty to humanity").
For Ignatiev, studying whiteness is merely a necessary stage en route to what he calls "the abolition of whiteness" -- just as, in Marxist analysis, class consciousness is a necessary stage en route to the abolition of class. "Abolishing whiteness" would seem to decree not, say, a cult-style mass suicide of America's palefaces, but a mass renunciation of all the perks that come with being one. And until the day of renunciation comes, in the view of the rather ascetic Ignatiev -- a former steel-mill worker and 60's radical who is a fellow at the W.E.B. Du Bois Institute at Harvard -- nobody ought to be having too much fun with whiteness.
Not surprisingly, Ignatiev scoffs at the idea of claiming, let alone celebrating, any sort of white culture. "There is youth culture and drug culture and queer culture; but there is no such thing as white culture," Ignatiev said in a talk at the Berkeley conference. He went on, "Without the privileges attached to it, the white race would not exist, and white skin would have no more social significance than big feet." To the field's post-modern types, Ignatiev is something of a relic, and a worrisome one at that. He and the other so-called new abolitionists bum the younger crowd out. They are asking us "to demonize whiteness rather than to deconstruct it," complains Newitz, who is 28 and likes to call herself "biethnic" because her father is Jewish and her mother is a white Southerner and former Methodist.
Autobiographical details matter a great deal to the whiteness theorists. What might be seen as precursors of whiteness studies -- essays like "The Souls of White Folk" by W.E.B. Du Bois (1920), or "What America Would Be Like Without Blacks" by Ralph Ellison (1970) -- were written by blacks, working in a tradition of belle-lettristic social criticism. Today, most of the academics identified with the field are white, and they sometimes seem to be writing what amounts to a therapeutic collective memoir, an exquisitely self-conscious chronicle of coming out as white guys and gals. "There is so much writing out there by people of color about their personal daily struggles, but very little writing by white people about how their racial identity feels to them minute by minute, hour by hour," says Newitz. "I mean: What does it feel like to to have people relate to you as a racial stereotype?"
A number of whiteness-studies scholars have taken this kind of admonition to heart and are turning out work that is conspicuously first-person. The "White Trash" anthology alone contains a rather charming recollection of growing up in a trailer park in Bayonne, N.J.; a memoir, by a self-described "Okie," of marrying up and hating herself for it, and an essay that attempts to reconcile the author's childhood memories of religious revivalism in his New Hampshire town with socioeconomic theory about the white underclass.
Actually, this confessional mode is part of what marks whiteness studies as an of-the-moment academic discipline. In some schools of thought, especially those influenced by feminist theory, writing in the first person is supposed to serve the important political function of disclosing the writer's position, which is to say the race/gender/sexual preference/class that shapes and even determines her vision of the world. (Whiteness scholars refer to this social position as your "location," a word they tend to repeat with the fervor of real-estate agents making a pitch.) And, political reasons aside, a lot of academic writing has caught the pants-down confessional bug that animates so many current memoirs and so much daytime TV. The result is a strange hybrid: prose that lurches between Jenny Jones-style self-revelation and undigested social theory.
The other distinguishing characteristic that many whiteness scholars have in common is a deep disdain for American liberalism. Indeed, you can find prominent scholars in both main camps -- the whiteness-as-culture and the whiteness-as-power crowd -- who profess to see greater hope for the future of race relations in, say, the militia movement than in liberal anti-racism. Liberalism, for them, is a pack of pieties about the progress we've made in improving the lives of African-Americans.
When I interviewed Noel Ignatiev in his sparsely furnished town house not far from Harvard Square, he spoke vaguely but hopefully of making contact with home-grown fascists. "The only thing that can win these people away from this nightmare vision is something that is as highly oppositional as the fascist vision, but that is antiracial. To reach them, you have to be as angry as they are. And what is called modern liberalism, multiculturalism, they see -- correctly -- as allied with the establishment."
Even scholars less likely to play the role of professional provocateur will sound much the same note. "Why object so strongly to the militias when it's just as true that the liberal center is white supremacist?" asks Eric Lott, an associate professor of English and American Studies at the University of Virginia and the author of "Love and Theft," a widely praised history of blackface minstrelsy.
Partly, of course, such rhetoric is meant to be shocking; it's the way that professors who'd like to be firebrands say boo! Then again, it suggests how far the most self-consciously avant-garde of them have moved from what was once the liberal consensus on racial politics.
The premium on provocation may be unavoidable. Here, after all, is a field in which the American obsession with race, the new scholarly commitment to commenting swiftly on pop culture and the stresses of the academic job market all conspire to fizz up and speed along the process by which ideas become books become paradigms.
In a job market where last year less than half the newly minted English Ph.D.'s landed teaching positions, graduate students labor to set themselves apart from the pack by publishing early and often. "Given the current job market," says Matt Wray, 33, who is working on his Ph.D. in ethnic studies at Berkeley, "it's very hard not to sort of see the whiteness stuff as something you should grab ahold of and say, 'This is my meal ticket.' Academics like to believe that they have relative autonomy from market forces, but none of us is immune."
This goes along with a publishing environment in which prestigious academic presses snatch up manuscripts on pop cultural ephemera like bargain hunters at a jumble sale. One result is books that seem ill equipped to stand the test of time, dedicated to phenomena that perhaps our deeper thinkers needn't have troubled with. (Consider, for example, "Women on Ice," a collection of scholarly essays about the "Tonya Harding-Nancy Kerrigan Spectacle.")
The twist is that some of the academics who chase hardest after the hippest and the hottest subjects seem fated to produce work that looks worthy-but-dull to the very next cohort of graduate students. Sure, Madonna studies is "past its prime now," Matt Wray told The Wall Street Journal; but, he added respectfully, "a lot of good work was done on the significance of Madonna."
In whiteness studies, the imperative to publish has meant that it is much easier to find criticism on whiteness in the media or literature than it is to find empirical research on actual white people. Both fieldwork and statistical studies -- the kind of work done, often slowly, in sociology or anthropology departments -- is pretty sparse. (An exception is the scholarship of John Hartigan Jr., an anthropologist and historian who has extensively interviewed whites living in inner city Detroit about their racial attitudes.)
And the faddishness of much of this research has meant that some of the more discomfiting questions about the field remain unanswered. What social good does it serve, for example, to heighten Caucasian awareness if in doing so you run the risk of swelling Caucasian pride? Conversely, isn't it disingenuous to argue, as Ignatiev and company do, that "whiteness" is something to be abolished, whereas "blackness" is not? "In their view," says Sean Wilentz, a professor of history at Princeton University, "whiteness is implicitly the racial category that is evil, and blackness is just a response to it. It's black nationalism by another means."
Ultimately, it is hard to say precisely what whiteness means to whiteness scholars. Their common refrain is that race is not a biological fact but "a social construction." Yet in many ways, they are profoundly invested in the idea of racial categories -- so much so that, even without intending to, they could end up making those categories seem immutable.

They have this incredible power, and she's still really smart and overtly sexy and all that.' -- Jennifer Reeder, from White Trash; 'Growing up poor, white and religious, I learned to believe that the world was essentially an evil and unjust place.' -- Matt Wray, from White Trash; 'Whiteness describes, from Little Big Horn to Simi Valley, not a culture but precisely the absence of culture. It is the empty and therefore terrifying attempt to build an identity based on what one isn't and on whom one can hold back.' -- David Roediger, Towards the Abolition of Whiteness; 'Whites are said to consider themselves a neutral universal category, hence nonracial and superior to "racialized" others.
